# 道枢

**Dao Shu (Scripture of the Dao Pivot)**

Title: *Dao Shu*
Compiled by: Zeng Can (Song dynasty)
Volume: Forty-two
Source of the base text: *Zhengtong Daozang*, Taixuan (Great Mystery) Section

Collated editions:
1. *Daozang Zhuan Yao* (Selected Essentials of the Daozang), included in Volumes 3–6 of its *Zi Ji* (Purple Gathering) (hereafter *Zhuan Yao* edition).
2. *Zhi You Zi* (The Wandering Immortal), from *Siku Quanshu Cunmu Conghshu* (reprinting the Chongqing Library’s Ming Jiaqing 45 [1566] edition by Yao Ruxun).

**Volume One of *Dao Shu***
Collected by Zeng Can
**Chapter: Xuan Zhu (The Mysterious Axis)**

When the mind labors and the spirit wearies,
It strays far from the Dao.
When the mind is still and clear,
Then the Dao’s subtle beginnings emerge.

The *Zhi Pu Zi* (Master of Primordial Simplicity) said:
Is not the essence of Heaven its lofty luminosity?
Is not the nature of Heaven its profound emptiness?

Heaven bestows life upon me,
And I inherit it as my nature.
To wield it truly,
One must remain uncarved—
Neither cunning nor clumsy,
Neither wise nor foolish,
But serene, resting naturally
In the boundless field of spontaneity.

Once, the elder of Taoyuan Cave instructed the Master of Fangzhang:
“Alas!
Though you have entered the realm of *wuwei*,
Your nature still does not rest in stillness—
Why is this?”

**Chapter: Xuan Zhu (The Mysterious Axis) – Continued**

You delight in music—
The harmonies of *gong* and *shang* have ensnared you.
Is this not where your mind is ensnared?

Man, once stripped of his primordial simplicity, becomes adorned with artifice.
Things entice from without;
The five desires and six obfuscations mar his purity,
Leaving him unable to perceive the Heavenly Origin.
Thus, he must first purge his defilements.

How shall he purify himself?
My heart is like lawful water.
Then he washes away the *sanmei* (threefold delusion),
Opens the six obfuscations,
Removes the five defilements,
And filters out the turbid to reveal the pure.

To remain luminous and unstained,
One must first reject the perception of external things.
Thus, those who perceive subtleties from afar—
Their sharp insight is called the *axe that hews virtue*;
Those who pursue ornament and glory—
Their love of fame and gain is called the *abandonment of virtue*;
Those who speak with eloquence—
Their clever tongue is called the *poison that confuses virtue*;
Those who devise cunning schemes—
Their deep stratagems are called the *enemies that destroy virtue*.

Why is this?
The deeper the intelligence, the more deceit arises;
The farther the discernment, the more artifice prevails.
Those who confine me with knowledge
Are themselves the originators of knowledge;
Those who burden me with perception
Are themselves the originators of perception—
How could they be dazzled by externals?

Kang Bozi read ancient and modern texts,
Yet upon hearing the Dao, he remained all day as if foolish.
Pan Dong, seeing Zi Zhongli’s child, showed him objects but could not name them.
Zi Zhongli said:
“Great indeed is he who rejects perception!”
All things flourish in their variety,
Yet each returns to its root.
They unfold and bloom, then lose their true nature,
Born in the morning, perishing by evening—
Which of them does not decay?
I must turn inward and reflect.
I too am a thing.
Thus, I seek its source,
Gather its essence,
Abandon being to return to non-being,
And return to the True Void.

To return to the True Void,
One must first remove its ten provocations:
Adorned with fine words,
Confused by resounding sounds,
Indulged with rich foods,
Ensnared by fragrant scents,
Tempted by likes and dislikes,
Accustomed to jealousy and lust,
Enslaved by gold and jade,
Pleased by rank and wealth,
Charmed by flattery,
Deceived by schemes—
These are the ten provocations.
If they are not removed,
One will stray from virtue and lose the Dao.

Zhisongzi said:
“To remove them, one must first clarify their source.
The lowest of fools is dimly aware,
While the wisest may be obscured by evil and thus align with them.
How then shall one awaken from this dimness?
One must abandon the murky and enter the dwelling of pure clarity.”

The Most High said:
“Many know and see much,
Yet they take this as enlightenment—
This is true darkness.
Heaven bestows upon them their nature—
Why should it perish?
The Dao grants them its form—
Why should it wither?
When the seven emotions blaze within the five viscera,
The True Essence is consumed.
If one can extinguish these emotions,
Then in profound stillness, True Joy arrives.”

Shizhenzi studied but did not yet know the Dao,
And in desperation wept beneath the Jade Pool.
The True Lord said to him:
“If your seven emotions are not stirred by external contact,
You will enter True Wisdom.
If your inner heart is not yet pure,
You will still cling to ornamentation
And lose your purity.”

The ancient Perfect Ones
Rejected virtue with virtue,
Forgot form with form.
Virtue is mine—
Yet if I use virtue to obscure virtue, I fall into delusion;
Form is mine—
Yet if I use form to lose form, I fall into artifice.
Internally, I honor simplicity,
Like a withered tree.
Thus, excessive branches harm the trunk,
And elaborate adornments injure the root.

The *Fangong* (Palace of Perfection) is a sacred realm,
With eight divine precincts,
A thousand sacred halls—
The imperial capital.
My body too has its wondrous court,
Illuminated by the Wisdom Sun,
Fanned by the Mysterious Wind.
How then shall I attain it?
By restraining anger and suppressing desire,
By enduring what is gained,
By showing mercy without exclusion—
This is its beginning.

Miaosuzzi said:
“That which transcends form is called the Dao;
That which is beneath form is called the vessel.
The vessel is not virtue—
It is the vessel through which one enters the Dao.”

Alas!
The ceaseless, boundless flow—
This is the current of birth and death.
If I know that dust and toil corrupt the True and harm virtue,
I can sever it.

To converse with the Pine Pavilion and dismiss the white day,
To tune the Jade Zither and contend with the pure moon—
This is to dwell in the Dao.

External thoughts are the Dao’s enemy.
Dazzling colors confuse the mind,
Resounding sounds agitate the emotions.
The Ox of Earth drags them forth,
The Chariot of Heaven carries them away—
They rush outward and return inward,
And thus virtue is lost.

Virtue is like water;
If the wind disturbs it, its clarity is lost.
If I regard external things as mere dust,
I shall contain the Primordial and ascend to the Supreme One.

Jingsizzi said:
“Elaborate speech is a flaw in language;
Wicked glances are a flaw in perception;
Lewd sounds are a flaw in hearing;
Restlessness is a flaw in rectitude;
Familiarity is a flaw in judgment;
Madness is a flaw in thought.
Now, he who guides his *qi* and drifts in the boundless expanse—
Who dares neglect this?”

No greater fault exists than having perception,
Relying on discernment to open countless paths
And seeking victory.
Thus, intention can measure the emotions of the ancients,
And clarity can illuminate the principles of the sages.
Yet even so, there are obfuscations that cannot be opened,
Confusions that cannot be resolved.
To take divergent paths as the great road,
To mistake rushing waters as boundless darkness—
I take this as wisdom,
Yet the farther I stray from wisdom, the more distant I become.
It must be abandoned!

To transcend the sage and abandon intelligence,
To set aside innate knowledge,
And advance to the realm of *wuwei*—
This is the root of the Dao.

Gaolingzi had not yet heard the Dao,
Yet his books filled his home.
After hearing it, he burned his writings,
Blinded his sight,
And severed his perceptions.
The Dao is not nonexistent.
Virtue is not empty.
If it were nonexistent, one would sink into formless chaos;
If it were empty, one would abandon oneself to futile seeking.
Silent sounds are unheard,
Empty colors unseen,
Formless things unattained.

The utmost emptiness possesses its own void,
The true symbol possesses its own reality.
Thus, one must first firmly establish one’s steadfastness,
And only then enter the rectitude.

Not abandoning due to others,
Not shifting due to teachings—
This is the steadfast.

Decisively acting, resolutely entering,
Thus from being one attains to non-being,
From form one reaches stillness.

The Five Voids and Eight Consciousnesses,
Unrecognized from beginning to end,
Yet entering *wuwei*—
Perhaps they do not yet know that *wuwei* is inherently possessed!

To establish the self,
One must first abandon the self.

Lost in dusty confusion,
Obscured by material veils,
Clinging to the self—
This harms the Dao.

Thus, forgetting self and object as one,
And annihilating even that oneness to enter the realm of non-being—
Open and penetrating,
Wise and unobstructed,
Formless in body,
Thoughtless in mind.

The innate nature, when followed,
Cannot be seized by things,
Cannot be stolen by the external.

Heaven grants form to all things;
The Dao grants nature to all things.
Flowing form departs far from the court of nature—
Who does not have steadfastness?

There are those who guard the small and lose the great,
Who guard the external and abandon the internal,
Who guard the other and lose the self,
Who guard the false and betray the true.
Is there a way to guard?

To guard the self with greatness,
To fortify the inner with truth.
If one does not know how to guard,
When the innate and pure arrive,
Who can repel them?

Yuánxùzi said:
“Is it guarding the dark with whiteness?”

Tàishàng said to Fànzi:
“The Five Corruptions are gone,
The Seven Emotions are extinguished—
Do you know this?”

Fànzi said:
“Is it through refining and polishing?”

He replied:
“Without refining to guard, the external will shift;
Without polishing to guard, the possessed will topple—
Only guarding the self suffices.”

Zhuānméng’s son was not inherently different in nature,
Only he was deluded and unaware.
Once awakened,
His spirit settled, his soul steadied,
And he entered the subtle.

Huángfǔzi said:
Awakening has five paths:
Some awaken from calamity,
Some from illness,
Some from hardship,
Some from ignorance,
Some from enlightenment.

Once the streams divide, their source scatters;
Once the emotions arise, nature is obscured.
Thus, if the source is not clarified,
The Six Desires pollute it,
The Three Poisons disrupt it.

Obscuring the source—this is the streams;
Disturbing nature—this is the emotions.
Lustful desires are turbulent waves.
Frivolous pursuits and chasing desires give rise to impurity,
While purity and reality perish in things—
The essence of nature withers and loses its simplicity,
The luminous soul is stained and grows dim;
The roots unsettled, the stem unsteady.

Immersed in a single vision,
Solely guarding the source—
The streams then shine clear and pure.

My innate nature originates the same as others,
Received in purity without blemish,
Preserved in refinement without strife.
Within lies the round—
This is nature.

Flowing without exhaustion,
Merging without congealing.
Exhaustion leads to obscurity,
Congealing leads to stagnation.
Those who are bright and penetrating,
Refined and internally robust,
Harmonious and externally complete—
Radiant as boundless spring,
Divine yet undispersed.
Their yang does not cling to things—
This is the effect of the round!

Thus, obtaining nature,
Quieting it to stillness while unaware of its movement,
Emptying it to its utmost while unaware of its return—
Is this not like the solitary yin’s stillness,
Yet not entering its truth?

Yùhuìzi said:
“When the Six Desires arise, the true spirit is diminished—
How could it remain round?
When the Three Poisons flourish, the harmonious balance is lost—
How could it remain fused?
Roundness and fusion collapse—
The gate to premature death is near.

Things’ natures are never inherently different,
Great and small are confined alike,
Likes and dislikes are received equally.
Following their greatness and smallness,
Their likes and dislikes—
One loses the root,
Drifts from the origin,
Abandons the source,
Loses the ancestor.

Seizing one’s nature,
Startled by the Six Dusts,
Abandoning the Three Pangs—
Only piercing the delusion,
Splitting the stupidity,
Taking clarity as the origin,
Taking purity as nature,
Recognizing the confines of yin and yang,
And aligning with the boundless, void, primordial nature—
This is the ultimate path.

Xiāozhuìzi said:
“Obtaining the One and clarifying—
Rising above the multitude of rulers,
Playing with transformation,
Contracting with nature—
This is the return to the utmost truth.”

Chénglízī said:
“The Three Clarities dwell within,
The Six Orifices are sealed without—
I do not ascend to divergent paths.

Wūxiá’s son took resonance as his doctrine and gained ghostly attendance,
Xībō’s son sought his ancestor through means and received the perverse reply—
What one perceives must be approached with caution!

Within the lawless lies a standard,
Within the boundless lies a constraint.
Voidness governs with the Dao,
Emptiness transforms the confines.
This void is not the void they speak of,
This emptiness is not the emptiness they speak of.
Not voiding thought,
Not thinking of voidness—
This may be called penetration.

To draw water with a basket—
Is this not seeking from the void?

I know how to supplement it,
Thus restoring true nature.

If one sincerely takes non-being as non-being,
How can one speak of the Dao’s greatness?

True cultivation responds like the green shoots—
No entering, no abandoning,
While the luminous heart manifests externally.
Thus, the true purity stands erect,
The profound principles are uniquely attained,
Heaven’s purity is unblemished,
And one enters wisdom.

Zhōnglízi said:
When insight is luminous, its name is wisdom;
When the spirit is full and steadfast, its name is roundness.

Those who attain stillness
Are those who lose stillness.
How excellent their forgetting!
To the utmost depth, the utmost void—
One may ascend to loss.

Their mind is like stagnant ore—
Things cannot entice them,
Thus entering darkness without obscurity,
Entering vagueness without confusion.

The boundless reveals itself in sight,
The silent in sound.
Not-seeing is true seeing,
Not-hearing is true hearing—
Then seeing and hearing are truly realized.

I have never been obscured;
I have entered the profound void,
Guarded the boundless emptiness,
Within stillness attaining the response of stillness.

Above the Nine Transformations, it is nameless;
Before the Four Wanderings, it is formless.
To return to this—only the Void suffices.

To take having as having is the error of excess;
To take non-being as non-being is the error of emptiness.
The having of non-being—true having;
The non-being of non-being—true non-being.

The depths of stillness, stillness again and again;
The depths of the Mysterious Void, the Void again and again.
This is but its coarse manifestation.

To perceive the non-being of non-being—
This is to attain the Dao,
The origin of the Supreme Primordial!

Zhōnglízi said:
Within the Void to seek the Void—
Who can know it?

The premature and impure are marred by mixture;
The vital source, when turbid, is obstructed.
Only the vast, like a valley, receives without retaining;
Only the serene, like the sea, flows without ceasing.

Do not deceive the Dao,
Do not harm its nature.
Vastly preserve its truth,
Silently inherit its qi.
Spirit and essence harmonize—
Perfected in unchanging transformation.

How do we know this?
The real is the response of the void;
The void is the foundation of the real.
They serve each other,
Returning to their origin—
Their transformations unfathomable.

The Mysterious Observer can purify our nature,
But thought without emptiness risks excessive knowledge,
And emptiness without thought risks aimless drift.
Is this not the path to understanding life’s essence?

This is the Dao—the complete and ultimate nature of the Dao.

**The Five Transformations**
All things teem and change without end;
Through the Dao’s transformation, emptiness and clarity flow freely.

Tánzǐ said:
The Dao has Five Transformations.
What are the Dao’s transformations?
The Void transforms into Spirit,
Spirit into Qi,
Qi into Form,
Form generates all things—
This is the Dao’s essence.

Form transforms into Qi,
Qi into Spirit,
Spirit into Void,
Void and clarity unite—
This is the Dao’s function.

The Sage exhausts the extremes of openness and closure,
Attains the source of transformation,
Forgets form to nourish Qi,
Forgets Qi to nourish Spirit,
Forgets Spirit to nourish the Void.
Void and reality interpenetrate—
This is called Great Unity.

Its essence is the Primordial Refined,
Its function is the Ten Thousand Spirits,
Its retreat is the Supreme Unity,
Its release is the Supreme Clarity.

The old maple transforms into a feathered being,
The rotting wheat into a butterfly—
From lifeless to living;
The virtuous woman into solid stone,
The mountain worm into a lily—
From living to lifeless.

The archer who resembles a tiger
Sees the tiger but not the stone;
The executioner of the violent dragon
Sees the dragon but not the water.

Thus all things can be made void,
The self can be made nonexistent.
By uniting my nonexistence with their void,
Naturally I can hide, can manifest,
Can die, can live.
Dust in the air—
Like flying clouds, unseen by the eye;
Ants in the depths—
Like thunder, unheard by the ear.

The corpse is not seen or heard!

The Supreme Void is one Void;
The Supreme Spirit is one Spirit;
The Supreme Qi is one Qi;
The Supreme Form is one Form.

Command it, and it is one;
Root it, and it is one.
To hold it is not to possess,
To abandon it is not to lose—
This is called the Rectification of Unity.

The infant plays with shadows,
Unknowing it is played by shadows;
The madman mocks images,
Unknowing it is mocked by images.

The family transforms—
Unknowing it is transformed by the family;
The nation transforms—
Unknowing it is transformed by the nation;
The world transforms—
Unknowing it is transformed by the world.

The Void transforms into Spirit,
Spirit into Qi,
Qi into blood,
Blood into Form,
Form into the fetus,
The fetus into the infant,
The infant into the child,
The child into the youth,
The youth into the adult,
The adult into the aged,
The aged into death,
Death transforms back into the Void,
The Void transforms back into Spirit,
Spirit transforms back into Qi,
Qi transforms back into things.

Ah!
The transformations are boundless!

The **Supreme Daoist** is the **God of Emptiness and Nonbeing**; the **Heaven and Earth** are the **Gods of Yin and Yang**; **Humans and insects** are the **Gods of Blood and Flesh**. Their common essence is **Spirit**; their differing manifestations are **Form**.

Form is not responsive, yet **Qi** is;
Words are not responsive, yet **Sound** is;
Awareness is not responsive, yet **Dreams** are;
Life is not responsive, yet **Death** is.

Ice floats and returns to clarity,
Form scatters and returns to luminosity—
He who knows **True Death**,
May then wander the **Supreme Daoist’s** capital.

Who embodies the **Transformation of Guarding**?
The **Cloud Dragon, Wind Tiger**—
Those who grasp the **Dao of Spirit and Qi**.

Spirit is the **Mother**; **Qi** is the **Child**.
To summon **Qi** with **Spirit**,
To call the **Child** with the **Mother**—
What cannot be attained?

The **Purification of Filth** must summon the **Qi of the Five Directions**;
The **Subjugation of the Python** must harness the **Essence of the Five Stars**.

Summon it from without, hold it within,
Deploy it from without—
Nothing is beyond reach.

To turn a **ten-thousand-hu** vessel,
One must plant a **one-ren** wood;
To loose a **thousand-jin** crossbow,
One must trigger a **one-cun** mechanism.

The eyes can survey **Heaven and Earth**,
A single person can rule **ten-thousand households**.

The **Great Void** is vast yet bounded,
The **Supreme Daoist** is boundless yet has a **home**.

To grasp **Heaven and Earth’s** principles,
To know **Yin and Yang’s** lodgings,
To perceive **Spirit’s** repositories—
Then **numbers can be reversed**, **fate can be governed**, and **Heaven and Earth can be turned back**.

The **Most licentious** transform into **women**,
The **Most brutal** transform into **tigers**.

The **joyful**—their **Form** is harmonious;
The **delighted**—their **Form** is relaxed;
The **wrathful**—their **Form** is rigid;
The **grieved**—their **Form** is contracted—
This too is the **Dao of Transformation**.

The **worm of the field** bears the **child of the cicada**,
Transmitting their **emotions**, mingling their **essences**,
Moistening their **Qi**, blending their **Spirits**,
According to size, all attain their **truth**.

**Unresponsive movement** lacks fixed **emotion**,
**Unresponsive Form** lacks fixed **shape**—
When **Yin and Yang** clash, **mushrooms and fungi** sprout without roots,
When **dryness and moisture** interact, **oysters and clams** rise without mothers.

The human **roots** **Yin and Yang** and **nurtures** them,
The human **imitates** dryness and moisture—
Nothing fails; why?
The **Noble One** studies **things** to know the **body**,
Studies the **body** to grasp the **Dao**.

**Gully pines** can defy frost,
Because they **harbor** **correct Qi**;
**Fine jade** can withstand fire,
Because it **accumulates** **pure Essence**.

The **Great Sage** wields the **Spirit Banner** by day,
Records the **Divine Herb** by night—
Awakening to thoughts beyond ordinary,
He can **ward off winter winds** without chill,
**Resist summer flames** without heat.

Who embodies **Virtue’s Transformation**?

The **wise** are often **humiliated**,
The **eloquent** often **insulted**,
The **illuminated** often **obscured**,
The **brave** often **slain**.

The **Noble One** can blame himself and thus blame others,
Can refrain from **vengeance** and thus **vengeance** others.
To **save** and claim **righteousness**—
Others will call him **unrighteous**.
To **act benevolently** and seek **reward**—
Others will call him **unrewarded**.

Even **ants** have their **lords**—
A **fist-sized palace** for all to dwell,
A **one-block platform** for all to stand,
A **single grain of food** for all to store,
A **single insect’s flesh** for all to **consume**.

Thus, **heart** must first **communicate** before **Spirit** can,
**Spirit** must first **communicate** before **Qi** can,
**Qi** must first **communicate** before **Form** can—
The **Dao of the Great Ancients**.

Who embodies **Nourishment’s Transformation**?

One day without food brings **weariness**,
Two days without food brings **illness**,
Three days without food brings **death**.

**Nourishment** is the most urgent of human affairs.

Those who **practice divination** will surely be **attached by ghosts**,
Those who **erect images** will surely be **dominated by spirits**.

**Music** is what **joy** is meant to **enjoy**.

The tiger and wolf consume flesh no more than their nature demands,
The dragon and serpent crave blood no more than their instincts decree—
Yet humans lust for all things without restraint,
And thus, when desires are unfulfilled, strife ensues.

When water presses, one casts oneself into the depths,
Knowing escape is impossible, yet hoping for reprieve’s delay.
When the tiger’s jaws open, one hurls oneself into the ravine,
Knowing death is certain, yet clinging to the faintest chance of life.

Who then is shaped by **frugality**?

Water and fire are tools of daily use—
When wielded without **proper method**, they ruin households,
For they lack **simplicity**.
Food and drink are staples of sustenance—
When consumed without **proper measure**, they destroy the body,
For they lack **moderation**.

To guard against ruin, nothing surpasses **frugality**.
Frugality in hearing **nurtures emptiness**,
Frugality in sight **nurtures spirit**,
Frugality in speech **nurtures qi**,
Frugality in private matters **nurtures wealth**,
Frugality in public affairs **nurtures nobility**,
Frugality in gates and doors **wards off thieves and bandits**,
Frugality in defense and protection **prevents rebellion**,
Frugality in consorts and concubines **extends lifespan**,
Frugality in the heart **commands life and death**—
This is called the **pivot of all transformations**.

The extravagant, though rich, are never satisfied,
The frugal, though poor, always have enough.
The extravagant’s heart is ever impoverished,
The frugal’s heart is ever enriched.

The extravagant clings to kin, and thus accumulates faults,
The frugal keeps distance, and thus commits few errors.
The extravagant serves their lord and invites disgrace,
The frugal serves their lord and secures their post.

The extravagant are plagued by worries,
The frugal abound in joy.
The extravagant crave action,
The frugal cherish stillness.
The extravagant seek the difficult,
The frugal embrace the simple.
The extravagant indulge in ease and pleasure,
The frugal savor tranquility and plainness.

Some live a lifetime with a single vessel, never broken,
Others wear a single robe for ten years, never worn out—
Such are the ones who may now **enter the Dao of Purity and Stillness**.

*End of Volume One of the Dao Gun Scroll.*

**Volume Two of the Dao Gun Scroll**

**Chapter One: The Essentials of Nourishing Life in Supreme Purity (上篇太清养生, 下篇太清养生)**

**The Second Volume of the Dao Gun Scroll**
*Collected by Zeng Xi, Master of the Wandering Dao*

**The Upper Scroll of *Zhuangzi’s* "Forgetting the Self" (坐忘篇上)**

The *Treasure Scripture* stands firm—its three compilations preserved.
I grasp its essence, attaining harmony with the True through serene contemplation.

The heart is the sovereign of the body, the general of the spirit.
When still, it generates wisdom;
when agitated, it breeds confusion.

At the outset of Daoist practice, one must gather the heart and depart from the world,
entering emptiness to unite with the Way.

Yet to cling to the heart while dwelling in emptiness is not true non-attachment.
To dwell in attachment exhausts the heart and depletes the *qi*, giving rise to illness.

When one hears praise or blame, good or evil, and receives them with the heart,
the heart becomes full—fullness blocks the Way’s abode.

To hear as though not hearing,
to see as though not seeing—
praise, blame, good, and evil do not enter the heart.
This is called *Empty Heart*.

Empty, the heart finds peace;
peaceful, the Way comes naturally.

The heart is like the eye:
the slightest intrusion disturbs it, leaving no tranquility.

Cattle and horses, though domesticated, if unleashed, become fierce and unmanageable;
eagles and wild birds, once snared, naturally grow tame.

So too is my heart.

Yet the marvel of the method lies in practice, not mere words.
To remain unstained by things, to act without confusion—
this is the subtlety of the Great Dao!

Some say the Dao is difficult to attain,
but they do not know that brocade begins with plain silk,
that cranes soaring to the heavens first feed on grains,
that trees blocking the sun begin as saplings.

Overreaching exhausts wisdom and strength;
excessive striving harms body and spirit.

To hurl a pearl like the Duke of Sui’s at a thousand-*ren* sparrow—
even men laugh at such folly.
Yet some abandon virtue and nature,
neglecting their essence while boasting of their own worth.

What disrupts the body are bandits and thieves.
If I can govern them with a steadfast heart, I am a valiant warrior;
if I observe with wisdom, I wield a sharp blade;
if I cast off external burdens, I achieve victory;
if I dwell in constant joy, I secure honor and blessings.

If I do not act thus, I am like one fleeing battle, abandoning armor—
only to invite blame.

Thus, steadiness is the foundation for attaining the Dao,
the culmination of cultivating stillness,
the completion of maintaining peace.

*Zhuangzi* said: *"The boundless expanse finds order in the radiance of Heaven."*
What does this mean?

*The boundless* is the heart;
*Heaven’s radiance* is wisdom.
When emptiness and stillness reach their peak,
the Dao resides within, and wisdom arises.

Wisdom is our original nature.
Through greed and delusion, we are scattered and confused, unaware—
but if we purify ourselves, we return to pristine stillness.

The spirit’s nature is empty and fluid,
harmonizing with Heaven, responding to change.
When form aligns with the Dao, there is no birth or death.
In seclusion, form merges with the spirit;
in manifestation, the spirit blends with *qi*.
Thus, one may tread fire and water without harm,
face the sun and moon without casting a shadow.
Life and death depend on oneself;
entry and exit are without question.

Yet the Dao of emptiness has depths and shallows:
probing reveals its influence over form,
superficially, it affects only the heart.
What influences form is the spirit;
what touches the heart is wisdom and awareness.
Wisdom and awareness prevent the body from decaying—
why? Because wisdom is the heart’s illumination;
excessive use exhausts its essence.

At first, wisdom brings delight and eloquence,
but this dissipates the spirit, leading to *shixie* dissolution.

Thus, the sage contains light and conceals brilliance,
condenses the spirit to return to substance.
When spirit and Dao unite,
when body and heart align with the Dao,
then the six senses become transparent.

The body exists without ceasing;
the heart communicates without obstruction.

Thus it is said:
When mountains hold jade, grasses and trees do not wither;
when a person embraces the Dao, their form endures forever.

Here lies its subtlety—the pivot of *Zhuangzi’s* "Forgetting the Self."

Those who refine the Dao to attain Truth must first abandon perverse conduct.
External affairs must not disturb the heart.
Seated in stillness, inwardly observing—
when thoughts arise, extinguish them.
Though only the restless heart is extinguished, not the illuminating heart,
only the empty heart is concentrated, not the attached heart.

To practice this, one must receive three precepts:
First, *simplify and discard*—selecting the essential and eliminating excess.
The *Classic* says: *"Few things bring attainment; many bring confusion."*

Second, *renounce desire*—cutting off greed.
The *Classic* says: *"Constantly without desire, one may perceive its marvel."*

Third, *still the heart*—halting its wandering.
The *Classic* says: *"Remove filth, cease thoughts, still the heart, and hold to One—
is this not what is meant?"*

Thus, with an empty heart and no desires,
the Dao is not sought—it comes naturally.

Its essence lies in this:
Amidst affairs and noise, one must intentionally cultivate peace.
Whether occupied or idle, always appear as though without concern;
in stillness or tumult, let the will remain singular.

Binding the heart too tightly brings illness and madness;
if the heart does not move, let it rest naturally,
adjusting tension and ease as needed—
self-regulating without fixation,
releasing yet unmoving—this is true steadiness.

Yet even thus, one must not cling to steadiness
while seeking many affairs or embracing noise.
Instead, like a still mirror reflecting forms,
one must adapt to each thing before responding.

To seek wisdom within steadiness harms steadiness;
steadiness without seeking wisdom naturally generates wisdom.
The attained Daoist’s heart has five phases,
the body seven signs—
these mark the shallow and the deep.

What are the five phases?
When movement predominates and stillness is scarce—this is the first;
when movement and stillness are equal—this is the second;
when stillness predominates and movement is scarce—this is the third;
when stillness prevails in inaction but stirs upon contact—this is the fourth;

To merge with the Dao in silent unity,
and yet remain unmoved even upon contact—this is the fifth.

What are the seven signs?
When actions align with the seasons and demeanor is harmonious—this is the first;
when old ailments vanish and body-mind feels light and refreshed—this is the second;
when one restores youthful vitality and reclaims one’s lifespan—this is the third;
when lifespan extends to ten thousand years, and one is called an *xian*—this is the fourth;
when form is refined into *qi*, and one is called a *zhenren*—this is the fifth;
when *qi* is transmuted into spirit, and one is called a *shenren*—this is the sixth;
when spirit is refined into the Dao, and one is called a *zhiren*—this is the seventh.

In the *"Zuo Wang"* chapter, Tian Yinzi says:
When a person is born, they inherit *lingqi*—
clear and perceptive, learning without obstruction—
this is called *shen* (spirit).

To dwell *shen* within and extend its radiance outward—
this is called *xian* (transcendence).

*Lingqi* must not be sullied by the vulgar world—
only then can it be preserved.

Joy, anger, grief, delight, love, desire, and hatred—
these seven are the perversions of *emotion*.

Wind, cold, heat, dampness, hunger, satiety, labor, and ease—
these eight are the perversions of *qi*.

To abandon these perversions brings one closer to *xian*.

Simplicity is the Dao of Heaven and Earth.
Heaven is above my head;
Earth is beneath my feet.
I perceive them—
thus, simplicity is the virtue of the *shenxian*.

Those who study the Dao
speak in lofty mystification and cling to delusion,
seeking no foundation—this is not my teaching.

Thus, those who study *qi* may be harmed by *qi* itself;
those who study *xian* may be ensnared by *xian* itself.

Yet those who study the Dao must progress gradually—
there are five gates:
First, *zhai jie* (ritual purity);
Second, *an chu* (tranquil dwelling);
Third, *cun xiang* (meditative visualization);

Fourth, *zuò wàng* (sitting in oblivion);
Fifth, *shén jiě* (spiritual comprehension).

**Ritual purity (*zhāi jiè*)**, why is it so? It is to cleanse the body and empty the heart. *Zhāi* means purity and tranquility; *jiè* means moderation and restraint. When hungry, eat; when eating, do not overindulge—this is called *tiáo zhōng* (harmonizing moderation). Do not eat what is unripe; do not eat what is rotten or obstructs the *qi*; do not eat too much of the five flavors. Do not sit too long, do not stand too long, do not labor too long, do not rest too long. Constantly rub the left and right hands until they are warm, then smooth the skin to dispel cold *qi*—this is called *chàng wài* (unblocking the exterior). Thus, when the body is firm, the *qi* will arrive.

**Tranquil dwelling (*ān chǔ*)**, why is it so?
Face south while seated, bind the head while sleeping. The dwelling must be in a house or hut where *yin* and *yang* are balanced. If it is too high, *yang* will be excessive and light will be abundant, which harms the *pò* (vital breath), for the *pò* is *yin*. If it is too low, *yin* will be excessive and darkness will be abundant, which harms the *hún* (ethereal soul), for the *hún* is *yang*. If there is harm, then illness will arise. Moreover, the *qi* of Heaven and Earth—if there is the cutting *yang* of the primordial breath or the invasive *yin* of licentiousness, how could one not be cautious? Therefore, my dwelling has windows on all four sides: when the wind rises, close them; when the wind ceases, open them. The front must have curtains, the rear must have screens. If it is too bright, hang curtains to soften the internal reflections; if it is too dark, roll up the curtains to allow the external light to pass through. Internally, to tranquilize my heart; externally, to tranquilize my eyes. When heart and eyes are tranquil, then the body is tranquil. Thus, those who indulge in emotions and excessive thoughts cannot tranquilize their inner and outer selves—this is clear.

**Meditative visualization (*cún xiǎng*)**, why is it so? *Cún* means to preserve my spirit; *xiǎng* means to visualize my body. How can one achieve this? Close the eyes and you will see your own eyes; gather the heart and you will see your own heart. When heart and eyes do not stray from the body, they will not harm the spirit—this is the gradual process. Ordinary people spend the whole day looking at others, and their hearts wander outward; spend the whole day engaging with external affairs, and their eyes gaze outward. Their minds are scattered and their vision superficial; never do they return inward. How could they not fall ill and die young? Therefore, *returning to the root* means daily stillness; daily stillness means *recovering the vital breath*; recovering the vital breath perfects the nature—this is the gateway to all mysteries.

**Sitting in oblivion (*zuò wàng*)**, why is it so? It arises from meditative visualization and is achieved through forgetting meditative visualization. *Practicing the Dao* without seeing its practice—is this not the meaning of *sitting*? Seeing without practicing what is seen—is this not the meaning of *oblivion*? Not practicing means the heart does not move; not seeing means the form is extinguished. Some say, "The unmoving heart—is there a Dao in this?" Heaven conceals itself, and the adept remains silent, not answering. Some say, "The extinguished form—is there a Dao in this?" Heaven conceals itself, and the adept is blind, not seeing. Some enlighten themselves and say, "The Dao is within me."

**Spiritual comprehension (*shén jiě*)**, why is it so?
Ritual purity (*zhāi jiè*) is *faithful comprehension*, for without faithfulness, one cannot comprehend.
Tranquil dwelling (*ān chǔ*) is *tranquil comprehension*, for without a tranquil heart, one cannot comprehend.
Meditative visualization (*cún xiǎng*) is *leisurely comprehension*, for without a leisurely heart, one cannot comprehend.
Sitting in oblivion (*zuò wàng*) is *wise comprehension*, for without wisdom, one cannot comprehend.
When these four are harmonized with the spirit, then one attains *spiritual comprehension*.

The spirit—when it encompasses the Three Realms (*sān cái*), it is called *Yì* (Ease/Change);
when it aligns with all things, it is called *Dào* (Dao/Way);
when it returns to its original nature, it is called *Zhēn Yī* (True Unity).
The Heaven-concealing adept says:
"Born within *Yì*, dying within *Yì*, moving with all things, tranquil with all things—
is this not the Dao?
The perverse arises from one nature, the true arises from one nature—
I comprehend all with spiritual comprehension.
Whether in man, in earth, or in water,
all may become *xian*.
Transforming and harmonizing it—this is called *shénxiān* (spirit-adept).

The Master of True Unity (*Zhèng Yī Xiānshēng*), upon reading this text, awoke and said, "I differ." Thus, my simplicity and ease are *wu wéi* (non-action) yet without failing to act. My gradual process is to guard the nature and rectify the vital breath, day by day—this is the Dao of gradual progress. The practices akin to ritual purity may also be cultivated together.

In the continuation below, the wandering adept says:
"I have obtained the theory of sitting in oblivion in three treatises, none better than this?"

The Master of True Unity, Sīmǎ Zǐ Wēi, says:
"I recently saw the Daoist scholar Zhào Jiān compose a seven-part treatise on sitting in oblivion. Its scope is broad, its text elaborate, its intent simple, its words persuasive. Those who read it ponder its chapters and memorize its order—this may be called *zuò chí* (sitting while distracted), not what I call sitting in oblivion.

I heard from my teacher that sitting in oblivion is the foundation of longevity. Therefore, to attract the True and refine the form, when the form is clear, it merges with the *qi*; to contain the Dao and refine the *qi*, when the *qi* is clear, it merges with the spirit. When the body aligns with the Dao in profound unity, this is called attaining the Dao.

The True is the origin of the Dao, so to purify the spirit is to grasp the True.
Zhuāngzi says: *Yǔ tài dìng fā hū tiān guāng* (The vast and tranquil harmonizes with the radiance of Heaven).
*Yǔ* is the heart; *tiān guāng* is the illumination of wisdom.
First tranquilize the heart, then the illumination of wisdom arises within.
It shines upon all realms, yet empty and forgotten—
the heart merges into stillness—this is called sitting in oblivion.

Lǎozi says: *Jí wú wú shēn, wú yǒu hé huàn?* (When I have no body, what harm can I suffer?)
To have no body is not to lack this body—
it is to merge the body with the Great Dao,
not to pursue honor or nobility,
nor to seek advancement through means.
It is to be naturally without desire,
forgetting this body of attachments—
this is called sitting in oblivion.

Longevity means the spirit and form are both preserved.
Therefore, the *qi* of Heaven and Earth—
when the *qi* of Heaven and Earth is exhausted, there is no way to see the Dao.
The form and vessel are the abode of nature—
when they decay, nature has no place to reside.
To nurture the spirit without nurturing the form
is like destroying one’s home and dwelling in the open—
how could it not be so?

Some say: "When a person’s lifespan comes to an end, if the heart and mind are upright, then the spirit ascends to the realm of True."
The Master of True Unity says: "This is not the speech of the utmost rectitude.
The virtuous adept, though claiming to forget self and other,
and to extinguish right and wrong,
still frowns at what is unvirtuous and smiles at what is virtuous—
still, they are deceived by virtue and vice."

The final breath arrives, and confusion and dimming senses follow—
I have never seen one who is not seduced by myriad evils.

Thus, there are those whose *consciousness* transforms into *unconsciousness*—
like the Qin woman’s metamorphosis into stone;
there are those whose *human consciousness* transforms into *insect-like consciousness*—
like Master Huang’s transmutation into electricity?

From this, it is clear:
the heart and mind are shaped by yin and yang—
how could they remain steadfast on their own?

Hence, the value of preserving *form* and *spirit* intact—
this is the very reason.

Now, some know that honor and wealth are empty illusions,
and understand that birth and death are but one thread—
yet when death approaches,
they still seek physicians and pray to spirits—
why is this?

They do not yet grasp the *sitting-forgetting* method.

*Forgetting* means to forget all realms—
first, they must *realize* the void,
then all illusions follow,
and only then can the heart be settled.

Above settled heart, there is a sudden clarity—
no *covering* remains;
below settled heart, there is emptiness—
no *foundation* exists.

Though touched and unmoved, *wisdom* may yet arise—
still, it is not free from yin and yang’s shaping,
until they rely on the *elixir of immortality* to ascend,
entering the formless,
emerging beyond the realm of transformation,
only then can yin and yang be mastered by me.

#1 *End of Volume Two of Dao Gunzhu*, with the essential text revised to read: **"then."**
*Volume Twenty-Eight: Upper and Lower Chapters on Nourishing Life in Supreme Clarity*
*Volume Twenty-Eight: Nourishing Life in Supreme Clarity (Lower Chapter)*
*Volume Three of Dao Gunzhu*

The *Essential Gathering* by Master Zeng Can of the Wandering Daoist:

The ancient sages of old spoke in abundance like a forest;
Through the Dao’s vast observation, one may probe its depths.

Master Chao Wenyuan said:
*"Beholding this floating world—
Is it not the realm of birth, old age, sickness, and death?
Is it not the den of sorrow, grief, and torment?"*

Only those with settled clarity perceive:
Within, their body and mind are empty;
Without, all things are empty.
Thus, when all forms are shattered,
There is nothing to grasp, nothing to contest.

All that exists is but a dream’s illusion.
Within dreams, men consort with phantoms,
Yet they say, *"Striking in a dream cannot harm!"*
Is this not knowing dream within dream?

I once sat in the Jade Hall,
Watching a laborer draw water.
Observing the void’s ripeness,
No whole man remains—
Only a block of emptiness,
From west to east.
Is this not knowing illusion within illusion?

Thus, when nothing exists,
Views arise in their diversity.
The Daoist must first still the mind.

When thoughts arise, they are known—
Like a river’s flow, a scoop of earth may dam it,
And the surging tide may be halted.
Like wildfire, a cup of water may quench it,
And the blazing spread may be extinguished.

Yet fear not thoughts arising—
Only fear delayed awareness.
Swift awareness, swift stillness—
This is the Dao’s subtle art.

I have said:
Breath and mind are interdependent;
When breath is regulated, the mind is tranquil.
When thoughts arise, awaken—
Awaken, and they vanish—
This is the Dao’s supreme vehicle.

Master Pei Xiu said:
Earth, water, fire, and wind—
Artificial combinations, gathering and dispersing—
Not my body.
Green thoughts, dusty illusions—
Empty fantasies, flickering and fading—
Not my mind.

I possess a true body—
Perfect, empty, and serene.
I possess a true mind—
Vast, luminous, and harmonious.

Though myriad illusions arise and are shattered,
Water’s nature never truly ceases to exist;
Though a thousand lamps burn and are extinguished,
Fire’s nature never truly vanishes.

Do the world’s people know these three symbols?
When *qi* moves and clarifies—
This is Heaven’s symbol.
When the mind is still and tranquil—
This is Earth’s symbol.
When wisdom is rounded and luminous—
This is the Sun and Moon’s symbol.

When these three harmonize,
Then naturally my divine and wondrous functions appear.

With the three symbols understood,
The six self-examinations must not be neglected.

Test yourself thus:
Are delusive thoughts stilled?
Are external distractions dispelled?
When confronted with all things, am I unmoved?
Are black and white without distinction?
Are dream-thoughts not inverted?
Is the heart’s chamber at ease?

Thus one may measure the depth and shallowness of attaining the Dao.

I have often admonished myself:
*"To know the arising and passing of thoughts is to cut the root of birth and death.
No longer following the turning of delusion—
This is called the Unmoved Noble One."*

If one cannot yet be without thoughts, then practice observing emptiness;
If one cannot suddenly attain emptiness, then practice counteracting [the mind].
These three strategies are applied in sequence.

Zhuangzi’s *sitting-forgetting*, Bodhidharma’s *wall-gazing*—
The beginner cannot comprehend them,
Yet they fall into reckless abandon—
Is this their true intent?

I once sat upright, contemplating the *suchness* of reality,
And saw a demon king’s image pressing upon my foot—
I was terrified.
Is this the way of one who sits unmoved in the Dao?

The *Spattered Gold Scripture*, the *Forgotten Garden’s* profundity,
Zhu Qian’s emptiness—
All harmonize in rectifying the heart,
And share the same function as Confucianism.

Master Chao Wenyuan said:
*"Is there truly any difference in teaching?"*
I have unified the Three Ways into one.

The Confucian tradition holds that rectifying one’s conduct is most urgent—
Do not seek its fruits, and the fruits will naturally manifest.
Zhu Qian’s school holds that restoring one’s true nature is most urgent—
Do not seek its verification, and the verification will naturally be known.

When I first read *Nanhua* [Zhuangzi],
I grasped the principle of *equalizing all things* and attained a method,
Which I named the *Free-and-Easy Great Harmony Observation*—
And found nothing to dispute.

Later, when I read the Western [Buddhist] texts,
I grasped the principle of *no-self* and attained another method,
Which I named the *Equal and Great Emptiness Observation*—
And found nothing to equalize.
Thus I came to know their depths and shallowness.

Shi Jianwu, after attaining the Dao, inscribed the *Three Abidings Inscription*:
*"The heart ever governs the qi,
The qi merges with the spirit."*

Zhu Qian expounded on *Perfect Awareness*:
*"The heart rests, dependent on stillness;
Stillness regulates the heart."*

I observe their principles—
Though different, they converge in essence.

There are three joys in the world:
The Confucian tradition says, *"Yan Zicheng’s bamboo basket and gourd in the humble lane—
His joy did not change."*
The Daoist tradition says, *"Zhuangzi’s child, holding a pestle and mortar in a hillside hut—
The world could not alter his joy."*
Zhu Qian’s school says, *"The joy of birth-and-death cessation, of extinction and final peace."*

These three progress from external to internal,
From shallow to profound.

As for the ills of delusive thoughts,
I attack them with principle.

What has passed, I do not dwell upon;
What is to come, I do not anticipate.

Someone asked: *"How does one verify practice?"*
I replied: *"Place two chess pieces—black and white.
For every good thought, cast the white piece;
For every evil thought, cast the black piece.
At night, tally them—
Then you will know your increase or decrease."*

Master Chao Wenyuan said: *"How roundabout!"*
I, however, within the four daily disciplines,
Do not count emotions or circumstances—
Only measure my strength and persist in still contemplation.

To endure insult while fearing its power is not true endurance;
To endure without fear is true endurance.

The *Yijing’s* *Sūn* [hexagram] says: *"Restrain anger, suppress desire."*
I take this as my warning.
The *Yijing’s* *Xìzì* [Appended Commentary] says: *"Leisurely and unmoved."*
I take this as my steadfastness.
The essence of meaning entering the spirit to achieve function—
I take this as wisdom.

Someone asked: *"What is the joy of leisure?"*
I replied: *"Harmonizing the Great Harmony’s qi,
Savoring the unadulterated taste of Heavenly Purity,
Delving into subtle and profound speech,
Wandering in the most refined Dao."*

Mengzi’s lofty sentiments, the teachers’ transformations;
Zhu Qian’s profound intent, purifying the spirit’s brilliance.

If external [disturbances] arise beyond principle,
Treat it like encountering a tiger—
Avoid it immediately, do not rely on the courage to subdue beasts.
If internal [disturbances] arise beyond principle,
Treat it like plunging into boiling water—
Stop immediately, do not indulge the desire to touch.

Protect the body externally,
As one would guard a towering tree in the sky—
Do not let a single axe’s edge harm it.
Guard conduct internally,
As one would guard a floating raft at sea—
Do not let a single needle’s point pierce it.

When the heart is still, it becomes clear;
When clear, it becomes luminous;
When luminous, it illuminates all things—
Nothing can escape its form.
Thus, the Perfect One observes it and attains the *heart-seal*.

There was a Tang-era man who nurtured a parrot,
Which could recite scriptures and always remained silent and unmoving.
Someone asked why, and he replied:
*"The body and mind are both unmoved—
This is how one seeks the Supreme Way."*

When he died and was cremated,
Sacred relics remained.
Thus, it is known that those who attain the Dao
All enter from within profound stillness.

Master Chao Wenyuan said:
*"As I grow old, my hearing and alertness only sharpen.
There is a natural sound, like a musical reed—
Faint yet resonant, like the first stirrings of thunder,
Vast yet approaching, like the tide’s arrival.*
I call these three *Mysterious Sounds*:
One—*the jade-washing of a hidden spring*;
Two—*the bronze bell shaking the void*;
Three—*the autumn cicada trailing its thread.*"

In the *Yongcheng Scripture*,
Who is the *Dark Elixir*?
Slandered as vain and false;
Its inner emptiness revealed—
Its path is as open as day.

The Perfect Wanderer said:
*"I once obtained Master Cui’s *Pharmaceutical Mirror*,
Which states: In the battle of copulation,
The host and guest are confused—
Same recognition, yet differing intentions;
Same depravity, yet differing accumulations;
Same intercourse, yet differing bodies;
Same bodies, yet differing intercourse—
This is called the ‘unmoving mirror’."*

He who can merge the inner and outer spirits
While the body remains unmoved
Has attained the Dao of true nature.

If movement occurs, the spirit departs—
The true nature is then in sorrow.
If untouched and unattached,
The original substance remains,
Allowing the qi to settle and the spirit to dwell,
Harmonizing to form the central palace,
Eliminating the yin and preserving the yang.

The *Red Snow*—the true essence of the *Blood Sea*—
Is the very substance that forms the human body.
Within the womb, it is yang qi;
When released, it becomes blood.

When the tortoise enters,
Wait for its movement to stir emotions,
Then it twists its neck, closes its breath, and drinks [the essence],
Using rhythmic strokes to draw it in.
When the qi settles and the spirit unites,
The qi enters the *Passageway* [of the spine],
And the *Luo River Vehicle* is drawn upward,
Ascending to Kunlun, paying homage at the Golden Gate,
Entering the *Elixir Field*,
And once more forming the elixir.

The Perfect Wanderer, upon hearing this, exclaimed in astonishment:
*"Master Cui truly spoke of this!"*

I have heard from the ancient Perfect Ones that this was never practiced.

In the past, Zhang Daoling’s teachings of the Yellow and Red Dao, and the method of blending *qi*, were merely one technique for spreading Daoist transformation—hardly the affairs of True Persons. Yet when Zhang Daoling’s movement arose, he no longer practiced this either.

The Pure and Refined True Person said: *"I have seen those who practiced this die from absolute depletion; I have never seen one survive."*

To preserve the mind, observe the inner *bao*#4, and walk the Upper Dao—this is what is called embracing the jade and rushing into fire, burying gold in a dog’s grave. The Purple Cloud Lady said: *"Those who practice the Yellow and Red Scriptures merely serve to summon the drums of the Three Officials and invite punishment."*

The True Person’s shadowy reflections exist only in the two shadows—this is not the intimacy of husband and wife.

If Yellow and Red persist within, how could one ever see the True Person or the Spirit Person?

Wei Boyang said: *"Cutting flesh to insert into the abdomen cannot form a fetus; thus, external substances cannot be made into elixir."* This is clear.

Thus, one who studies the Dao takes purity and stillness as the essence, and inward observation as the foundation. Only then, with deep roots and firm foundations, can pure *qi* be steadfastly guarded, the spirit kept from wandering, and when *kan* and *li* intersect, the Great Medicine be completed.

Ah! Zhuangzi said: *"Only when you polish and purify, without exhausting your body or agitating your essence, can you attain longevity. I have never heard of one who took a woman and attained immortality."*

Only Shou Han Ling Shouguang claimed, *"By practicing this method, I have lived nearly four or five hundred years, my hair and beard entirely white, yet my flesh and sinews remain robust."* Yet in the end, he still could not escape death.

Those in the world who claim to delight in taking women and achieve results should be no different from Shouguang. If Shouguang could not escape death, then how can this Dao truly speak to the principles of eternal life and prolonged vision?

Those alchemists, using methods of warfare to deceive scholars and officials, fearing their words lack credibility, secretly borrow the names of ancient Perfect Ones to lend authority to their texts. Thus, they claim *The Twenty-Four Chapters of Western Hua* was written by Zhongli Yunfang, and *The Eighteen Chapters of Western Jiang Yue* was written by Zhang Pingzhu.

「The alchemists point to women as the *Yǎn Yuè Lú* (a furnace shaped like a crescent moon), and claim that young men and women are the true *qiān yín* (lead and mercury), using filth and turbidity as their *dāo guī* (medicinal knife and ruler). Indulging in lust to its utmost, they perish in a single day—this is called *Tǒng Dǐ Tuō* (the "Escape from the Wine Vessel").

To this, **Zhì Yóu Zǐ** (Master of Ultimate Refinement) replied: *"The Way taught by Master Cui was once obtained by Lü Dongbin, who said it clarified his mind. If Master Cui’s method were flawed and not pure, then how could Lü Dongbin have received it? Perhaps it was a deception passed down by those alchemists?"*

Someone else asked: *"Those who attain the fruit of *wú lòu* (leakage-free/immaculate fruition) should enrich their source while economizing their expenditure. That is why lotus flowers do not grow on highlands or flat plains, but instead arise from mud. What does this mean?"*

**Zhì Yóu Zǐ** replied: *"The Daoists speak of eight *lòu* (leakages/defilements), and Zhù Qiān’s (Master Zhu Qian’s) method involves *zhū yǒu* (various forms of existence). My *wú lòu* is not what you refer to as *lòu*!

As **Sīmǎ Zǐ Wēi** (Master Sima the Subtle) states:
*"The leakage of *zhì* (aspiration) is when the form descends to the *yīn tǔ* (underworld).
The leakage of *niàn* (thought) is when the spirit wanders to the *guǐ xiāng* (ghostly realm).*

My immaculate fruition means no such leakage occurs. To enrich one’s intake while economizing one’s output is indeed the cultivation of *qi*—this is the *tāi xī* (fetal breathing) of the *Dà Mó* (Great Dharma/Ultimate Way).

The lotus from mud is easily destroyed, unlike the pine and cypress that grow on ridges and hills without ever withering. I too have my lotus—one that has emerged from the midst of fierce flames.

Some who hear this may doubt and ask **Zhì Yóu Zǐ**: *"The teachings of Róngchéng Zǐ (Master Rongcheng), Wùchéng Zǐ (Master Wucheng), Tiān Lǎo (The Heavenly Elder), and Tài Yī (The Supreme Unity), along with those of Yáo (Emperor Yao), Shùn (Emperor Shun), Chéng Tāng (King Cheng Tang), and Pángēng (King Pangeng), all contain books on *yīn dǎo* (guiding the yin/sexual essence). The Yellow Emperor and the Three Sovereigns (Sān Wáng) also possess methods for *yǎng yáng* (nourishing the yang/vital essence). The Han dynasty kept these in the *Guǎng Nèi Zhàng* (Palace Repository), and they were recorded in the *Shénxiān Zhìlù* (Register of Immortals). Their origins are ancient—how can you claim they do not exist?"*

**Zhì Yóu Zǐ** replied: *"I do not say they do not exist—I merely state that they are not the true pursuit of the *xiān* (immortals). As heard from the disciples of Liú Xiàng and Bān Gù: *The art of the inner chambers is the culmination of human nature and the essence of the Dao. That is why sage-kings established regulations on external pleasures to restrain internal passions, creating proper rites and restrictions.*

When pleasure is tempered with restraint, harmony, longevity, and wisdom follow. Those who are lost in passion do not heed this, and thus bring illness and shorten their lives."*

Thus, it is indeed seen that this is not the true pursuit of the *xiān* (immortals).

In the *Yīnfú Piān* (Scripture of the Yin Symbols), the *Huángdì* (Yellow Emperor)’s classic, enshrined in *Shénsōng* (Divine Summit), **Liú Xiàng** obtained it and lifted the veil of ignorance from the world.

**Liú Xiàng** acquired the Yellow Emperor’s *Yīnfú* classic from the *Shénsōng* mountain, yet he did not grasp its ultimate purpose. Later, he encountered the *Líshān Lǎo* (Old Lady of Mount Li) and questioned her. She said:

*"The Dao has the **Tàiyì** (Supreme Simplicity), the **Tàichū** (Supreme Primordiality), the **Tàishǐ** (Supreme Beginning), and the **Tàisù** (Supreme Purity).
The **Tàiyì** is the obscure and unfathomable **Xuányuán** (Primordial Mystery), wondrous beyond all names.
The **Tàichū** is the mingled and chaotic **páotāi** (Fetal Embryo).
The **Tàishǐ** is the boundless **dòngxū** (Penetrating Void), which sometimes manifests upon sensation.
The **Tàisù** is the inner containment of the **Zhēnyī** (True Unity)’s essence, the raw foundation of all things—clear *qīngyáng* (pure yang) as Heaven, turbid *zhuóyīn* (impure yin) as Earth.

Yang is the **hún** (ethereal soul), yin is the **pò** (corporeal spirit).
The **hún** seeks to sustain life;
the **pò** seeks to hasten death.
Therefore, the sage observes the Dao of Heaven, follows Heaven’s course, embraces the True and holds to the Unity, returning to the **Tàiyáng** (Supreme Yang) to nourish the yang **hún** and dispel the yin **pò**. Here lies the full extent of the path to *shénxiān* (immortality).

Heaven, through the number **one**, generates water to moisten what is below; it dwells in the north, marking the season of **winter**, corresponding to the **kidney** in the body, known as the **Xuánwǔ** (Mysterious Tortoise)—this is the **kǎn** (abyss) hexagram.
Earth, through the number **two**, generates fire to flame upward; it dwells in the south, marking the season of **summer**, corresponding to the **heart** in the body, known as the **Zhūquè** (Vermilion Bird)—this is the **lí** (fire) hexagram.
Heaven, through the number **three**, generates wood to bend and straighten; it dwells in the east, marking the season of **spring**, corresponding to the **liver** in the body, known as the **Qīnglóng** (Azure Dragon)—this is the **zhèn** (thunder) hexagram.
Earth, through the number **four**, generates metal to follow and transform; it dwells in the west, marking the season of **autumn**, corresponding to the **lung** in the body, known as the **Bái Hǔ** (White Tiger)—this is the **duì** (joy) hexagram.
Heaven, through the number **five**, generates soil as the **jìqiáng** (cultivation walls), dwelling at the center, the mother of all things, corresponding to the **spleen** in the body.

Thus, the Dao gives rise to **one**; **one** is Heaven.
The **Five Phases** (*wǔxíng*) emerge from **one**, as the **Zhēnyī** *qi* (true unity essence) transforms into the Five Phases. That is why the five grains and five flavors nourish humanity.
Humans live by the Five Phases and die by the Five Phases—thus, the Five Phases are the **Five Bandits** (*wǔzéi*).

The sage seizes the Five Phases’ essence-*qi*, returns to the origin and restores the root, thus reuniting with the **Zhēnyī**—this is what **Lǎozi** (Old Master) spoke of: *‘All things in the world, each returning to its root; returning to the root is called stillness, and stillness is called preserving life.’*

Now, the **nature** (*xìng*) is the bright clarity of yang.
The essence of bright clarity condenses into **humanity** (*rén*), stagnant *qi* becomes **ghosts** (*guǐ*), refined *qi* becomes **spirits** (*shén*), turbulent *qi* becomes **beasts and insects** (*chóngwǔ*).
Mixed *qi* forms **birds and beasts** (*qínshòu*), and deceitful *qi* breeds **malevolent spirits** (*jīngxié*).
When one discerns the bright clarity, one can perceive its **mechanisms** (*jī*), and perceiving its mechanisms allows one to establish the Dao of Heaven.

From the fifth month at the **Summer Solstice** (*xiàzhì*), the **#5** hexagram takes effect, and by the tenth month, it becomes **pure kūn** (pure yin)—when yin is excessive, it consumes the yang.
From the eleventh month at the **Winter Solstice** (*dōngzhì*), the **#5** hexagram again takes effect, and by the fourth month, it becomes **pure qián** (pure yang)—when yang is excessive, it consumes the yin.
Thus, dragons and serpents **hibernate** (*qián*) in autumn and winter, and **emerge** (*qǐ*) onto land in spring and summer.
When humanity dispels the yin **demons** (*mó*) with true yang, the hundred spirits harmonize and rejoice, the blood and *qi* flow unimpeded, the five *zàng* (viscera) generate **moisture** (*jīn*), and one attains **longevity** (*chángnián*) and **clear vision** (*jiǔshì*).

This is why **Guǎngchéng Zǐ** (Master Guangcheng) accumulated fire to burn the **Five Toxins** (*wǔdú*)—the Five Toxins are the Five Bandits.
Heaven’s birth is from **kǎn** (abyss), Earth’s birth is from **lí** (fire).
**Kǎn** is water, moon, and **mercury** (*gǒngyín*).
**Lí** is fire, sun, and **lead** (*qiān*).

The sage makes **kǎn** and **lí** alternate in function, so that sun and moon intermingle, lead and mercury balance each other, and the Dragon and Tiger oppose one another—only then can one **sever the corpse** (*zhǎnshī*) and **extinguish the ghosts** (*mièguǐ*), subdue the **semen** (*jīng*) and **absorb malevolence** (*shèxié*), preserving the **orthodox qi** (*zhèngqì*).

Thus, **Tàibái Zhēnrén** (True Person of the Great White) says: *"When the Five Phases do not proceed in order, the Dragon arises from fire, and the Tiger emerges from water."* This is the **mutual interplay** (*hùyòng*) of Heaven and Earth, the **reversal** (*fǎnfù*) of yin and yang.

Earth is the **root** (*běn*) of the **Four Symbols** (*sìxiàng*), the **foundation** (*jī*) of all transformations.
The Dao generates **one**, **one** generates **two**, **two** generates **three**, and **three** generates all things.
**One** is Heaven; **three** is humanity.
The essentials of *shénxiān* (immortality) lie in **embracing Unity and holding the Center** (*bàoyīshǒuzhōng*).
That is why the **Supreme Dao** (*shìdào*) begins with **one** and **three**, and culminates in **five**.
**Five** is the **number** (*shù*).
The classic says: *"Three, five, and one—all affairs are complete."* What Dao is this?
It is the Dao of **lead and mercury** (*qiān gǒngyín*) obtaining **Earth** (*tǔ*) to form the **Elixir of Reversion** (*huándān*).

**Yānluó Zǐ** (Master Yan Luo) says: *"Preserving the whole Unity has three aspects: the outer correspondence must still fulfill the **initial nine** (*chūjiǔ*), this is the Supreme Dao.*
When yang is **overabundant** (*tàishèng*), it **overflows** (*yì*), overflowing generates **heat** (*rè*), and heat **solidifies the pulse** (*shìmài*).
When yin is **excessive** (*tàishèng*), it **decays** (*shuāi*), decaying generates **cold** (*hán*), and cold **weakens the pulse** (*xūmài*).
The **deficient and replete pulses** (*xūshí zhī mài*) and the **ailments of heat and cold** (*hànrè zhī huàn*) can all lead to death.
Yang is **mercury** (*gǒngyín*), its nature being **volatile** (*fēi*).
Yin is **lead** (*qiān*), its nature being **subdued** (*fú*).
The sage **subdues the volatile yang-mercury** (*fùyáng qiān*), refining its **spirit** (*pò*);
**restrains the leaden yin** (*fēiyīn qiān*), binding its **ethereal soul** (*hún*).
When yang cannot overflow and yin cannot overpower, then **external pathogens** (*kèxié*) are dispelled and the **corporeal spirit** (*shīpò*) is lost.
Truly, if there remains even a **hair’s breadth of yang** (*háo fā zhī yáng*), one cannot die;
if there remains even a **hair’s breadth of yin** (*háo fā zhī yīn*), one cannot attain *shénxiān* (immortality).

Now, when the **ears indulge in licentious sounds** (*yínshēng*), the **eyes delight in beauty** (*měisè*), and the **mouth craves flavors** (*zīwèi*), then the five *zàng* (viscera) **agitate** (*yáodòng*) and become unsettled, the blood and *qi* **drift** (*liúdàng*) and are unstable, the **spirit** (*shén*) and **essence** (*jīng*) **scatter** (*fēichí*) and do not remain—thus, the **orthodox qi** (*zhèngqì*) dissipates, and **dampness-pathogens** (*shīxié*) seize the opportunity to generate **illness** (*jī*).

Therefore, humanity’s **three critical orifices** (*sān yāo*) are:
the **ear**, the **eye**, and the **mouth**.
Hence, the **ear and eye** are the **windows and doors of the spirit** (*shén zhī chuāngyǒu*);
the **mouth** is the **portal of qi and fluids** (*qì yè zhī ménhù*).

「Now, if the six *shí* (senses/perceptions) are all **emptied** (*kōng*), serene and void, abandoning form and forgetting matter, while **illuminating wisdom** (*huìzhào*) permeates the **spirit** (*shén*), then this is the **supreme stillness** (*zhìjìng*). To **expel and inhale** (*tǔnà*) in refining the five *zàng* (viscera), to **guide and pull** (*dǎoyǐn*) in opening the hundred *guān* (passages/locks), to recite and uphold **precious scriptures** (*bǎozhāng*) in soothing the spirit, to absorb and draw the **two luminaries** (*èryǐng*) in gathering **clarity** (*míng*), to refine **golden essence** (*jīnjīng*) in solidifying form, and to consume **jade dew** (*yùyīng*) in preserving the body—this is the **supreme activity** (*zhìdòng*).

The **Supreme Sage** (*Tàishàng*) said: **"Stillness"** is **nature** (*xìng*); **"activity"** is **qi** (*qì*). When activity and stillness are as one, the inner and outer are harmonious—this is not something ordinary mortals can attain!

Now, **pursuit of honor and wealth** (*róngmíng fùguì*) are the **dust and grime of Dao cultivation** (*xué Dào zhī chén gòu*); **quarrels and wrath** (*zhēngjìng fènyáo*) are the **thorns and brambles of refining true nature** (*xiū zhēn zhī jīngjí*); **rich wine and delicacies** (*zhíjiǔ zhēn cuàn*) are the **axes and spears that harm nature** (*fá xìng zhī gē máo*); **licentious sounds and beauty** (*yínshēng měisè*) are the **hatchets and saws that shatter the bones** (*pò gǔ zhī fǔ jué*).

Thus, those who **refine true nature and cultivate qi** (*xiū zhēn liàn qì*), **embrace the Primordial and maintain the One** (*bào yuán shǒu yī*), are called **Sages** (*shèngrén*); those who **refine form and solidify qi** (*liàn xíng chéng qì*) are called **True Ones** (*zhēnrén*); those who **refine qi to attain spirit** (*liàn qì chéng shén*) are called **Spiritual Ones** (*shénrén*); and those who **refine spirit to return to true nature** (*liàn shén chéng zhēn*) are called **Supreme Ones** (*zhìrén*).

**Heaven and Earth** are **thieves** (*zéi*) who **plunder** (*dào*) all things, causing them to **wither and decay** (*suī xiǔ*). All things **plunder humanity**, causing **aging and death** (*lǎo sǐ*). Humanity **plunders all things**, yet does so without **constant possession** (*bù cháng cún*)—this is how **utility** (*yòng*) arises. Thus, those who do not **skillfully plunder** (*bù shàn dào*) take only the **form** (*xíng*) but not the **essence** (*jīng*), and in turn are **plundered by all things**. The **skillful plunderers** take the **essence**, and thus are able to **plunder all things** and **attain longevity** (*chángshēng*).

I eat **seasonably** (*qí shí*), not because I crave **wine and sensuality** (*yǐnshēng*), but because I **plunder the essence and qi of all things**. Why so? The **form relies on flavors** (*xíng yǐ shí wèi*), the **spirit relies on qi** (*shén yǐ shí qì*). If one eats **seasonably** to nourish the **form** (*shí xíng*), **stimulating its vitality** (*dòng qì*), yet **plunders its essence** (*dào jīng*), then the **hundreds of bodily members** (*bǎi tǐ*) will follow **natural order** (*shùn lǐ*).

Within my **body**, there are **spirits of luminous essence** (*jīng guāng zhī shén*), **spirits of form and shadow** (*xíng yǐng zhī shén*), and **spirits of pores and hair** (*máo kǒng zhī shén*), each numbering **two thousand**. The five *zàng* (viscera) and six *fǔ* (entrails), as well as the **three Primordials and nine palaces** (*sān yuán jiǔ gōng*), also all possess **spirits**. Yet, if I do not **perceive their spirits** (*wú jiàn shén*), I do not know how they **bestow blessings or calamities** (*xià fú huò*).

Therefore, those who do not **practice reverence** (*jìngwèi*) will fall into **cruelty and rage** (*hěn yáo*), **fierceness and savagery** (*xiōng yè*), **greed and licentiousness** (*tān yín*), and **treachery** (*yīn xiǎn*)—this is **robbery of the spirit** (*zéi shén*). Those who **speak falsely and in vain** (*wàng yán qǐ yǔ*), assuming others **do not know or see** (*bù zhī bù jiàn*), are **obscuring their spirit** (*mèi shén*). My **spirit** connects upward to **Heaven** (*tiān*); thus, those who **rob the spirit** are **offending Heaven**, and those who **obscure the spirit** are **deceiving Heaven**. To **offend and deceive Heaven** is to **invite untimely death** (*qǔ tiāozhé*).

As such, **dampness-pathogens** (*shīxié*) grow stronger daily, the **spirit and qi** (*shén qì*) weaken daily, and the **corporeal shell and ethereal shadow** (*shī máng pò huáng*) run rampant.

Those who can **guard the center and embrace the One** (*shǒu zhōng bào yī*), refining **yin with yang** (*yǐng yǐ yáng liàn*), will **banish the corpse and scatter the shadow** (*shī wáng pò huáng*), and their **spirit and clarity will reign supreme** (*shén míng wáng yě*). Once the **spirit and clarity reign**, they can **ride the eight winds** (*cè pèi bā chén*), **fly in the celestial chariot over the five peaks** (*fēi yú wǔ yuè*), **ascend the nine celestial depths** (*shēng jiǔ xuán*), **sever the jade barrier** (*zhǎn yù guān*), and thus **equal Heaven and Earth in years** (*kě yǔ tiān dì děng nián*).

The **Venerable Laozi** (*Lǎozǐ*) said: **"Qi within qi"** (*qì zhōng yǒu qì*) is my **spirit**; **"spirit within spirit"** (*shén zhōng yǒu shén*) is the **natural Dao** (*zìrán zhī Dào*). Heaven, with **one yang**, descends to the **nine abysses** (*jiǔ quán*), giving rise to **repletion** (*fù*), which is the **first month of the eleven-month yang** (*shí yī yuè yáng zhī shǐ*). When **two yangs** descend, **pregnancy** (*lín*) arises; when **three yangs** descend, **fulfillment** (*tài*) arises; when **four yangs** descend, **great vigor** (*dà zhuàng*) arises; when **five yangs** descend, **maturity** (*fū*) arises; when **six yangs** descend, **completion** (*qián*) arises. At the **summer solstice of the fifth month**, the yang reaches its **peak** (*jí*), and **yin** arises.

Thus, when **one yin** ascends, **encounter** (*gòu*) arises; when **two yins** ascend, **delay** (*chí*) arises; when **three yins** ascend, **opposition** (*pǐ*) arises; when **four yins** ascend, **contemplation** (*guàn*) arises; when **five yins** ascend, **decline** (*bō*) arises; when **six yins** ascend, **receptivity** (*kūn*) arises. The **eclipse and revival, ascent and descent of yin and yang** (*yīn yáng xiāo xī shēng jiàng*) are the **pivotal axis of the Dao** (*sī Dào zhī shū*).

Thus, the **Sage** gathers the **qi of Heaven and Earth** (*shōu cǎi tiān dì zhī qì*) to form **two substances** (*èr tǐ*), called **lead** (*qiān*) and **mercury** (*gǒng*). Each weighs **eight liǎng** (*bā liǎng*), yet together they **combine into 384 chǔ** (*hé yú sān bǎi bā shí sì chǔ zhī shù*), corresponding to the **trigrams and lines** (*guà yáo*) to establish the **laws of great and small** (*dìng dà xiǎo zhī fǎ*).

Above, they **measure the trigrams and qi** (*qǐ guà qì*); below, they **calculate the water clock and divisions** (*tuī lòu kè*), to **balance the five phases’ fire** (*jūn huǒ zhī hòu*) and **harness the power of eighteen hundred years** (*duó yī qiān bā bǎi nián zhī gōng*), thereby **shedding their mortal shell** (*tuō fán tāi*).

At **three thousand two hundred forty years**, the **Sage’s body** (*shèng tāi*) is **perfected**, and thus they **harmonize with Creation** (*cù huà*), **align with the movement of yin and yang** (*yīn yáng tóng yùn*), and **Sagehood is born** (*shèng gōng shēng yàn*), **spirit and clarity emerge** (*shén míng chū yàn*).

The **blind** (*gǔ*) see **nothing**, so their **spirit focuses solely on hearing** (*shén zhuān zài ěr*); the **deaf** (*lóng*) hear **nothing**, so their **spirit focuses solely on sight** (*shén zhuān zài mù*). When the **spirit is concentrated**, no matter is beyond their **precision** (*shì wú bù jīng yě*).

**Profit and gain** (*lì*) can **stir humanity** (*dòng rén*); severing the **source of profit** (*jué lì zhī yuán*) allows the **spirit to concentrate** (*shén yǒu suǒ zhuān*), enabling one to **control lustful pathogens** (*zhì jīng xié*), and to **banish the corpse and annihilate the shadow** (*shī wáng pò huáng*) with **thousandfold efficacy** (*yǒu qiān bèi zhī gōng*).

Laozi said: **"Do not see what is desirable, and the heart will not be disturbed"** (*bù jiàn kě yù, shǐ xīn bù luàn*)—this is what is meant!

Now, what are the **"Nine Returns and Seven Reversions"** (*jiǔ huán qī fǎn*)? They are the **cycles from Child to Monkey** (*zǐ ér zhì shēn*), and from **Tiger to Dog** (*yín ér zhì xū*). These are all **one yin and one yang** (*yī yīn yī yáng*), **one ascent and one descent** (*yī shēng yī jiàng*), **one submersion and one concealment** (*yī chén yī fú*), dwelling in **day and night** (*zhòu yè jū zhī*) without **losing their place** (*ér bù shī*).

When the **water and fire** (*shuǐ huǒ*) trigrams **cycle fully**, the **elixir is perfected** (*huán dān chéng yě*). Thus, one can **control lustful pathogens** (*zhì jīng xié*), **banish the corpse and annihilate the shadow** (*shī wáng pò huáng*), and achieve **ten-thousandfold efficacy** (*yǒu wàn bèi zhī gōng*).

Wei Boyang said: **"The trigrams of *Lún* (Difficulty) are applied at Monkey and Child** (*tún yòng shēn zǐ*); **the trigrams of *Méng* (Darkness) are applied at Tiger and Dog** (*méng yòng yín xū*). Each of the **sixty-four trigrams** has its own **day**, and these are the **three reversions of day and night’s principle** (*sān fǎn zhòu yè zhī lǐ*).

The **heart** is the **master of ten-thousand spirits** (*wàn shén zhī zhǔ*); the **eyes** are the **windows and doors of ten-thousand spirits** (*wàn shén zhī mén yǒu*). When the **spirit enters humanity**, it is **stored in the heart** (*cáng yú xīn*); when it **exits**, it is **manifested in the eyes** (*xiàn yú mù*). Thus, if the **heart is at ease**, the **spirit is at ease** (*xīn ān shén ān*); if the **eyes move**, the **heart moves** (*mù dòng xīn dòng*); if the **heart moves**, the **spirit moves** (*xīn dòng shén dòng*), and the **mechanism of life and death** (*shēng sǐ zhī jī*) lies within these **two**.

Those who can **make their spirit exit and enter through the windows and doors** (*shén chū rù yú mén yǒu*) to **self-illuminate** (*zì zhào*), and **rest within the dwelling and abode** (*jū xī yú zhái shè*) to **self-soothe** (*zì ān*), have **activated the mechanism of life** (*shì shēng zhī jī*). Those who **block the windows and doors** (*sè mén yǒu*) and thus **do not illuminate** (*bù míng*), or **abandon the dwelling and abode** (*fèi zhái shè*) and **do not rest** (*bù jū*), have **activated the mechanism of death** (*shì sǐ zhī jī*).

Wei Boyang said: **"The five phases mutually receive each other to give rise to life** (*wǔ xíng xiāng shòu yǐ shēng*), so **fire’s nature is to melt gold** (*huǒ xìng shuò jīn*), and **gold’s nature is to cut wood** (*jīn fǎ mù róng*). These **three fives** (*sān wǔ*) and **three nines** (*sān jiǔ*) are the **ultimate essence of Heaven and Earth** (*tiān dì zhī zhì jīng*).

The **root and origin** (*fǎn běn guī gēn*)—thus do the ten thousand things **thereby arise in life** (*wàn wù nǎi yīn cǐ ér shēng*).
**Yin and Yang contend in victory** (*yīn yáng xiāng shèng*), the **Five Phases mutually restrain** (*wǔ xíng xiāng zhì*), **by which means** (*suǒ yǐ*) **conquest, punishment, decay, and decline** (*kè fá cuī xiè*) occur.

Yet, **when one returns to the root and abides by the origin** (*fǎn běn guī gēn*), then the ten thousand things **thereby arise in life** (*wàn wù nǎi yīn cǐ ér shēng*).
**When Yin and Yang are stirred**, they become **wind and thunder** (*yīn yáng jī ér wéi fēng léi*); **wind and thunder act**, and the ten thousand things **move and flourish in growth** (*wàn wù dòng ér zī shēng*).

**To refine the Yin and Yang qi** (*huǎn yīn yáng zhī qì*), **like the wind in motion** (*rú fēng zhī xíng*), **like the thunder in rumble** (*rú léi zhī wū*), **to make flow and circulate the hundred vessels** (*tōng liú qí bǎi mài*), **to purge and remove the accumulated stagnant Five Evils** (*táo qù qí jī zhì zhī wǔ dú*), **thus the Five Zang-organs generate Vital Fluids** (*jīn wèi shēng jīng*), **the hundred bones and sinews are harmonized and unobstructed** (*bǎi gāi tiáo chàng*), and **the True Unity abides within** (*zhēn yī cún hū qí zhōng*).
