If inhaling does not embrace *qi* as lord,
Not a single breath is complete—
And thus harm befalls embryonic breathing.

Therefore, if spirit and *qi* do not harmonize,
They cannot congeal in the *Zǐgōng* (子宫, Womb),
The Three Caverns, and the Six Viscera.

If the spirit can master *qi*,
Then the nose has no outgoing breath—
This is the true practitioner of embryonic breathing.

The vulgar man,
When confronted with sensory stimuli,
Generates attachment and lust,
And thus his *qi* drains downward,
His body withers and decays—
Hence it is said:
No benefit from a single drop of essence,
Yet constant loss from fleeting desires,
Forfeiting the root of life.

Only when spirit and *qi* are united,
And the child and mother guard each other,
Following the breath's ascent and descent,
Dispersing and replenishing the Three Palaces,
Does the essence and spirit remain undispersed.

Thus, steadfastness (*dìng* 定) is the root of not dying,
The heart is the master of *qi*.
Therefore, *qi* follows the heart's movement—
When the heart moves, *qi* moves;
When the heart stirs, *qi* stirs;
When disordered, *qi* is disordered;
When tranquil, *qi* is tranquil;
When anxious, it is injured;
When troubled, it declines.

Hence the sage does not exert himself when inactive,
Does not dwell when not enslaved,
Does not become disordered when not tranquil,
Adapting naturally to his own nature,
Eliminating all inner delusions—
This is the foundation of eternal life.

Thus always reflect:
The inherited body from parents is called embryonic breathing.
Later, it manifests through the six senses—
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
The five *zàng* and six *fǔ*,
Bones, flesh, sinews, and meridians,
All draw from embryonic breathing and grow thereby.

The root of embryonic breathing
Neither emerges nor sinks,
Like the *yīngzǐ* (鹦子, phoenix egg),
Its hue like *shuǐjīng* (水精, crystal water).
When thoughts stir, it moves—
Yet the inner *qi* does not exit,
The mind follows its emission and thus has departure and return.

Covering the heart and drawing the neck inward,
This is the master—
The external form of departure and return—
Called the *Hèxíng* (鹤形, Crane Form).

Filling the waist and solidifying the abdomen,
This is the internal form of movement—
Called the *Guīxíng* (龟形, Tortoise Form).

With intent, draw it,
Not through exhalation and inhalation,
Nor through grasping and fixing—
These two are the dark female's gateways,
Ever to be closed,
Allowing *qi* to circulate through the body.

First enter a quiet chamber and sit cross-legged,
As if entering *dìng* (定, meditative absorption),
The body unmoving,
Visualize embryonic breathing,
Like clouds and mist,
Like the smoke of a burning furnace,
Like the threads of a lotus root,
With intent, draw it,
Circulating through the Four Extremities,
The pulse flowing freely;

Next, draw the *qi* to irrigate the *cùwán* (促丸, testicles/sperm sac),
Then draw the *qi* to gather at the tip of the tongue,
Agitate and refine it,
Visualize it like a parrot swallowing food into its abdomen—
Do not err in this,
So that the Five Zang Organs and Six Fu Viscera may all receive its vital *qi* and become firmly solidified.
Thus, the body becomes luminous and supple—
This is the *qi* of embryonic breathing wandering within the body.

When hunger or thirst arises,
Then swallow it at times,
Sending it with intent,
Do not count the number—
This is acceptable.
When sated, rest and recover.

Wherever pain or illness is present,
Attack it with intent,
And cease once it is cured.

In movement, rest, sleep, or sitting,
Always retain embryonic breathing.
If the embryonic breathing does not disperse,
After five years or three years,
Great achievement will be accomplished.

If the *qi* descends, do not stop it—
Stopping it will lead to illness.

Once the achievement is complete,
There is no need for a quiet chamber—
Practice refinement at will.
Always visualize the body as if playing with a shuttlecock (蹴鞠, *cuju*).

When internal *qi* is full and abundant,
The limbs become light and agile.
Thus, again observe my body,
My mind,
My embryonic breathing—
Gradually growing vast, merging with the Great Emptiness (太虚, *Tàixū*).

At first, visualize my body as the moon—
Sitting in a room, its light fills the room,
Residing in a city, its light fills the city,
Traveling through a land, its light fills the land,
Until it encompasses the ten directions of emptiness,
And my body is unseen.
My mind and embryonic breathing are pure and unified with the void,
Without thought or contemplation,
Serene and tranquil in stillness.

As such, once observed,
Return to the prior visualization—
From land to city,
From city to room,
Gradually shrinking again,
Then further refine it.

Desiring to wander in other realms,
It is but a single thought.
Desiring to conceal its form,
When intent arises, it vanishes.

Life and death become as natural as the self—
Eating and not eating cause no disturbance,
This is the completion of the Dao.

Thus, cultivate the spirit like an infant,
Content and serene like a child,
And in cold, heat, decay, or flourishing,
The form and spirit will naturally remain balanced.

Breath and spirit unite,
Like a crystal vessel containing a golden statue.
The golden statue is the *Dharmakāya* (法身, *Fǎshēn*).
The crystal vessel is the *rūpa* (根形, *gēnxíng*, fundamental form).

Thus, when the mirror is clear, the *Dharma* manifests itself,
When the water is pure, the reflection remains still.
Heavenly nourishment (天食, *Tiānshí*) nourishes the spirit;
Earthly nourishment (地食, *Dìshí*) nourishes the form.
Embracing the *Hun* (含灵, *Hánlíng*, vital soul) and holding the *Shen* (抱实, *Bàoshí*, corporeal spirit),
The spirit and *qi* will naturally become refined.

The marvelous medicine of the Snow Mountains (雪山之妙药),
Grows from the crown—
Practice the *Kōngmèi* (空昧, *Kōngmèi*, Void Illumination),
The body becomes light, the spirit content,
Thus, blood transforms into milk,
And bones into *qióng* (琼, *qióng*, precious jade).

Hence, it is said:
The essence of Heavenly Dao (天道之精, *Tiāndào zhī jīng*)
Is profound and mysterious,
Spirit unseen, form unseen,
This is the mind without mind,
The form without form—
The mind itself has no existence,
How much more so the external?

**Conclusion of the Fourteenth Chapter of *Dàoshū* (道枢, *Dàoshū*)**
**Original text: "入" (enter) – Modified according to the *Jíyào Běn* (辑要本, *Jíyào Běn*)**
**#2 "清" (clear) – Modified in *Jíyào Běn* as "涌" (well up)**
**#3 "宝冠安坐，吾语汝" (On the precious crown, seated, I speak to you) – Modified in *Jíyào Běn* as "宝冠曰：坐，吾语一汝一"**
**#4 "五三" (five three) – Modified in *Jíyào Běn* as "三五" (three five)**

**Fifteenth Chapter of *Dàoshū* (道枢, *Dàoshū*)**

**From the *Shèngtāi Piān* (聖胎篇) of *Zhì Yóuzǐ Zēng Kǎo’s* (至游子曾慥) Collection**

**The Sacred Embryo Chapter**

Bow to shake the hundred passways,
Raise to follow the four seasons;
Conform to the Mysterious Path,
And enter the realm of *Xīyí* (希夷).

The Purple Microstar *Tàiyī* (紫微太一) speaks:
*"The practice of piercing passways and penetrating joints*
*without bending and stretching, guiding and drawing,*
*is how qi flows and moves.*

*The practice of dispelling cold and draining heat*
*without exhaling and inhaling, breathing out and in,*
*is how balance is achieved and released.*

*The practice of dispelling toxins and purifying clarity*
*without stirring drinks, rinsing, and swallowing,*
*is how stillness is deepened and congealed.*

*The practice of returning essence and gathering qi*
*without the union of masculine and feminine,*
*is how it ascends and rises.*

*The practice of forming the embryo and dividing the form*
*without the pearl dissolving and the tortoise breathing,*
*is how it bears and gives birth.*

*The practice of subduing demons and killing the corpse*
*without the secrets of *mì* (密), *jī* (机), and sacred transformation,*
*is how it is consumed and annihilated.*

*These six methods*
*are the ladder and vessel for attaining the True,*
*the tracks and wheels for the Dao’s path.*

*All practices of guiding and drawing, inhaling and exhaling,*
*conducting qi and refining elixirs,*
*forming the embryo and preserving the spirit*
*must first contend at the throat’s gate.*
*Close the mouth firmly and let the breath dwell in the nose.*
*If the nose opens slightly, external winds invade,*
*inviting the eight perversions’ harm.*
*Thus, one: if qi is lost, the Original Qi will be disordered.*

*Close the mouth, steady the breath,*
*stand with feet parallel, hands relaxed,*
*and sway like phoenix wings—nine times.*

*Then, cross the fingers before the heart,*
*slowly drawing force straight to the chest.*
*When force is exhausted, float and draw it upward to the crown—*
*this is called *Qǐtiān* (起天, Rising Heaven).*

*When force is exhausted, pull upward in east and west—nine tugs.*
*Then, from the crown, spread the fingers and float,*
*drawing the waist erect, bending down past the knees to press the feet—*
*this is called *Lìdì* (立地, Standing Earth).*

*When force is exhausted, advance and retreat the waist—*
*nine rubs upon the feet,*
*thus three times.*
*Then, straighten the body, steady the breath,*
*and daily practice this method,*
*which can open the three hundred sixty passways and joints,*
*the eighty-four thousand hair-pores.*
*Prolonged practice strengthens the kidney hall,*
*stops seminal emission,*
*fortifies the waist and spine,*
*and brightens the complexion—*
*thus extending life by a decade.*

*Close the mouth and sit,*
*spread the feet, cross the fingers before the heart,*
*slowly drawing force straight to the waist.*
*When force is exhausted, float and draw it upward to the crown.*
*When force is exhausted, pull upward in the west—nine tugs.*
*Then, from the crown, spread the fingers and float,*
*slowly drawing the waist erect,*
*bending down past the knees to the soles—*
*force exhausted, thus three times.*
*This is called *Guàigān Pánlóng* (怪柑盤龍, Marvelous Orange Coiling Dragon).*

*Then, straighten the body, sit cross-legged, steady the breath,*
*and daily practice this method,*
*which can drain the bladder’s stagnant water,*
*dispel the yin-qi of neck and shoulders,*
*clarify the seven orifices,*
*benefit the three passways,*
*prevent nightmares,*
*and avert dizziness.*
*Six years of practice transforms decay into youth.*

*Close the mouth and sit cross-legged,*
*clench the fists before the chest like a bow’s draw,*
*push open the front hands as if bearing Tai Mountain,*
*and pull open like a full moon.*

*When force is exhausted, twist the wrists left and right—three times each.*
*This is called *Wǎnshè* (挽射, Drawing and Releasing).*

*This method opens the Great Spine’s passway,*
*unblocks the tortoise-snake’s orifices,*
*internally connects the seams and gaps,*
*and flows to the Upper Burner,*
*preventing red eyes, sore throats, mouth sores, and toothaches,*
*and paralysis of the back.*
*Six years of practice renders one invulnerable to ten thousand poisons.*

*Close the mouth and sit cross-legged,*
*retract the Red Dragon’s tail,*
*lay the hands palm-up across the chest and abdomen,*
*and float, flapping and merging like wings—twenty-nine times.*
*This is called *Cāng’ē Gǔyì* (苍鸦鼓翼, Crow Flapping Wings).*

*This method opens the seventy-two bones of chest and back,*
*disperses the five internal perversions,*
*and unblocks the phoenix’s passways—elbows, joints, and tail.*
*It aids the spleen’s transport to dissolve water and grain,*
*strengthens the True Essence in the stomach’s precinct,*
*and harmonizes the harmonious qi of the four limbs.*
*Nine years of practice grants strength like a raging tiger.*

*Close the mouth and sit cross-legged,*
*rub the palms until warm,*
*then massage the eyes until heat subsides,*
*and from the inner canthus, wipe toward the outer—nine times.*
*Use force as the eyes open and close,*
*creating flashes like lightning—nine times.*
*This is called *Mó Jìng Shǎn Diàn* (磨镜闪电, Polishing Mirror Lightning Flash).*

*This method burns away the eyes’ toxins,*
*dispels yin-winds,*
*stops the liver’s damp-heat from descending into the water reservoirs,*
*and its heat like fire harmonizes the spirit passways,*
*warms the embryonic essence,*
*decays the Three Corpses,*
*clarifies the nine orifices,*
*and disperses the six palaces’ stagnant filth.*
*It ignites the elixir field’s fiery hands as if cradling an infant,*
*and with the right hand, slowly plucking the strings,*
*eliminates seminal leakage and dampness in the scrotum.*
*Nine years of practice refines essence into gold and stone,*
*and in all encounters, no rigid yang stirs.*

*Close the mouth and sit cross-legged,*
*press the thumbs together,*
*clench the fists between the thighs,*
*and with the body’s secrets supplied,*
*the Ten Thousand Spirits’ Emperor sits upon the Dragon Palace,*
*solemn and still, as if receiving the morning court’s rites.*
*Then, first strike the front gate ten times at the teeth,*
*then strike the rear gate twenty-six times.*
*This is called *Jī Qìng* (击磬, Striking the Bell).*

*Gather the spirit—*
*if the spirit is not gathered, the Heart Emperor flies wild,*
*and if the spirit does not dwell, yin-demons tremble,*
*while sacred attainment remains unattained.*

*Exhaling and inhaling the six breaths*
*supports cold and heat, dispels external pathogens,*
*and unblocks stagnation to restore passage.*

*The Great Perverse may be countered—*
*it is permissible, using metal overcoming wood,*
*wood overcoming earth,*
*and turning the six characters to counter and release.*
*Thus, hidden yin-toxins are eliminated.*

*The Great Heat may be drained—*
*it is permissible, using metal generating water,*
*water generating wood,*
*and turning the six characters to drain and balance.*
*Thus, hidden heat-toxins are eliminated.*

*As for floating cold and floating heat,*
*only use the original six characters,*
*from nine to nine,*
*and exhale as prescribed.*

When practicing, stand with your back to **Qián** (乾) and face **Sūn** (巽), loosen your belt, and sit cross-legged. Closing your mouth, inhale the pure *qi* once; opening your mouth, exhale the impure *qi* once—each nine times.

The inhalation should be subtle, rising through the nose into the brain, then descending through the twenty-four nodes of the spine, returning to the **Dān Tiān** (丹田). Immediately, a path of turbid *qi* will ascend from the stomach to the throat and exit through the mouth—ensure no sound is heard. This is called **nourishing the pure and expelling the turbid**.

Then observe which organ is diseased. If the eyes are red, the face hot, and there is nausea—this is **liver’s floating heat**. Close your mouth, shut your eyes, cross your hands, and visualize the liver. Inhale and exhale through the liver nine times; then rinse the mouth with saliva, swallowing when full, nine times. Direct the saliva from the throat to the **Dān Tiān** three times five, and the heat will dissipate.

If the lower back aches, the body feels weak, the face is yellow, breathing is labored, urination is excessive, there is seminal emission, aversion to cold, night sweats, loss of appetite, emaciation, and frequent disturbing dreams—this is **kidney’s extreme depletion**. Practice as before: inhale and exhale nine times. Though the kidney should use **blowing**, now use the **spleen’s exhalation** to counter it. Inhale and exhale with exhalation nine times, directing to the **Dān Tiān** three times five, and yin will diminish while yang will strengthen.

For all ailments, follow the **generation-conquering principles** of the Five Phases, and none will fail to heal.

Why is this called **the restoration of yin and yang**?
The **Zǐ** (子) hexagram is **Fù** (复), its stars **Wēi** (危) and **Xū** (虚);
The **Chǒu** (丑) hexagram is **Lín** (临), its stars **Niú** (牛) and **Nǚ** (女);
The **Yín** (寅) hexagram is **Tài** (泰), its stars **Dǒu** (斗), **Jī** (箕), and **Wěi** (尾);
The **Mǎo** (卯) hexagram is **Dà Zhuàng** (大壮), its stars **Fáng** (房), **Xīn** (心), and **Shì** (氏);
The **Chén** (辰) hexagram is **Yāng** (央), its stars **Hàn** (翰), **Jiǎo** (角), and **Kàng** (亢);
The **Sì** (巳) hexagram is **Jiān** (见), its stars **Yì** (翼);
The **Wǔ** (午) hexagram is **Gòu** (遇), its stars **Zhāng** (张) and **Xīng** (星);
The **Wèi** (未) hexagram is **Chí** (迟), its stars **Jǐng** (井), **Guǐ** (鬼), and **Liǔ** (柳);
The **Shēn** (申) hexagram is **Pǐ** (否), its stars **Bì** (毕), **Zǐ** (紫), and **Shēn** (参);
The **Yǒu** (酉) hexagram is **Guān** (观), its stars **Wèi** (胃) and **Xù** (勖);
The **Xū** (戌) hexagram is **Bō** (剥), its stars **Kuí** (奎) and **Lóu** (娄);
The **Hài** (亥) hexagram is **Kūn** (坤), its stars **Bì** (壁) and **Shì** (室).
Thus one may observe the heavens.

Why is this called **inner elixir of gold**?
Begin at **Zǐ** hour, taking **Fù** (复) as the first yang. Each line represents five days. For each yang line, first close for thirty breaths, then swallow saliva three times—one swallow per three breaths. Hence, it is called **"one swallow, three swallows."**
The sage follows the dragon’s pattern, and the tiger accompanies—this is the meaning.

For each yin line, close for thirty breaths, then swallow *qi* three times, thus filling yin and yang. Five days complete two hexagrams; thirty days complete twelve hexagrams, ending at **Yín** (寅)—a full year of three hundred sixty days.

From **Zǐ** to **Sì** (巳) are six yang hours—leftward progression ends at **Sì**, completing **Qián** (乾);
From **Wǔ** (午) to **Hài** (亥) are six yin hours—rightward progression ends at **Hài**, completing **Kūn** (坤).
When **Qián** and **Kūn** conclude, the cycle returns to **Fù** (复). The **Nine Returns and Seven Reversions**—whether spanning a year, a month, or condensed into a day—are thus unified.
*Return* means circular transformation; this is the **gold elixir circulating and reverting in the cauldron**.

At **Zǐ** hour, midnight, begin with **Jiǎ Zǐ** (甲子). During **Jiǎ Zǐ** and **Yǐ Chǒu** (乙丑), *qi* is of **metal**—thus **Qián** is firm, **Kūn** is yielding, and **Qián** belongs to metal, being yang, the father, male white and female red—this is the natural way.

On the first day of the month, at **Jiǎ Zǐ**, **Zhèn** (震) arrives to receive the talisman.
**Zhèn** is the eldest son; each yang line advances yang fire, with metal as *qi*—nine being metal’s perfect number.
Nine transformations—does the sage not conceal the name of gold? From **Wǔ** (午) to **Hài** (亥) is yin; each yin line advances yin fire, each yang line retreats yang fire. Then **Sūn** (巽) arrives to receive the talisman—**Sūn** is the eldest daughter. Seven is fire’s perfect number; fire returning to metal is the **seven reversions**. The sage also conceals the name of fire.

Some say: in the eleventh month, use **fire** two *liǎng* twelve *zhū* (两十二铢), and **water** twelve *liǎng* twelve *zhū*.
In the twelfth month, use **fire** five *liǎng*, and **water** ten *liǎng*.
In the first month, use **fire** seven *liǎng* twelve *zhū*, and **water** the same.
In the second month, use **fire** ten *liǎng*, and **water** half that.
In the third month, use **fire** twelve *liǎng* twelve *zhū*, and **water** two *liǎng* twelve *zhū*.
In the fourth month, use **fire** fifteen *liǎng*—no additional water.
In the fifth month, use **fire** twelve *liǎng* twelve *zhū*, and **water** two *liǎng* twelve *zhū*.
In the sixth month, use **fire** ten *liǎng*, and **water** half that.
In the seventh month, use **fire** seven *liǎng* twelve *zhū*, and **water** the same.
In the eighth month, use **fire** five *liǎng*, and **water** ten *liǎng*.
In the ninth month, use **fire** two *liǎng* twelve *zhū*, and **water** the same.
In the tenth month, use **water** fifteen *liǎng*—no additional fire.

The twelve regions and their divisions all begin at **Yín** (寅):
**Tài** (泰) is **Yōu Zhōu** (幽州), the division of **Yàn** (燕);
**Dà Zhuàng** (大壮) is **Yù Zhōu** (豫州), the division of **Sòng** (宋);
**Yāng** (央) is **Yǎn Zhōu** (兖州), the division of **Zhèng** (郑);
**Jiān** (见) is **Jīng Zhōu** (荆州), the division of **Chǔ** (楚);
**Lí** (离) is **Sān Hé** (三河), the division of **Zhōu** (周);
**Fǎn** (返) is **Yōng Zhōu** (雍州), the division of **Qín** (秦);
**Pǐ** (否) is **Liáng Zhōu** (梁州), the division of **Wèi** (魏);
**Guān** (观) is **Jì Zhōu** (冀州), the division of **Zhào** (赵);
**Bō** (剥) is **Xú Zhōu** (徐州), the division of **Lǔ** (鲁).

**Kūn** is **Jīng Zhōu**, the division of **Wèi** (卫).
**Fù** is **Qīng Zhōu**, the division of **Qí** (齐).
**Lín** is **Yáng Zhōu**, the division of **Wú** (吴).

---
**Chapter on Primordial Qi (元气篇)**
All things arise from the **Primordial Qi** in totality;
The **Primordial Qi** is the source of all.
Inhaling and exhaling, the inner and outer harmonize in response.
Mankind is born from the **Primordial Qi** of Heaven and Earth.
With every breath in and out, the inner and outer qi align.

There are six qi:
The **heart**, the **lungs**, the **liver**, the **spleen**, the **kidneys**, and the **San Jiao** govern them.

If one masters this qi,
In one year, it circulates;
In two years, it flows freely;
In three years, the work is complete—
The **play of the Mystic Pearl** congeals in the **Dan Tian**.

What is this qi?
It is the **Dao/Way** of **emptiness**, **nothingness**, and **effortless spontaneity**.

The **heart**—does it not belong to **effortless spontaneity**?
For only when it does not move
Does it not stir within and nothing enter from without.
When inner and outer are tranquil, the spirit is preserved and the qi harmonized—
Then the **Primordial Qi** arrives.

Thus, the five **zàng-organs** are nourished,
The **meridians** flow unimpeded,
And **bodily fluids** are perpetually generated.

Then the five flavors may be distanced—
No longer hunger or thirst.
The three **Dan Tians** are perfected, and bones and flesh become firm—
Aging reversed, youth restored.

Thus, the transformation of qi:
First, it becomes **blood**;
Blood becomes **essence**;
Essence becomes **marrow**.

In one year, the qi renews;
In two years, the blood renews;
In three years, the **pulse** renews;
In four years, the flesh renews;
In five years, the marrow renews;
In six years, the **sinews** renew;
In seven years, the bones renew;
In eight years, the hair renews;
In nine years, the form renews.

Its **spirit**—thirty-six thousand—
All transformed into **Immortal**.

When the five **zàng-organs** are harmonized, **bodily fluids** arise;
When the **San Jiao** circulates the qi without obstruction,
This is called the **Jade Elixir**.

The **spirit**—the most refined and formless essence.
The **spirit** adheres to the **Dao/Way**;
In stillness, it aligns with **nature**;
Mankind perceives the **spirit**;
In motion, it aligns with **emotion**.

Thus, following **nature** condenses the **spirit**.
Prolonged stillness brings cessation;
Excess leads to transformation—
Cessation is life;
Transformation is death.
Why is this so?
Emotion shifts, but the **spirit** does not command it.

To cultivate this qi, one must be still and observe inwardly,
Ascending through **Tàishǐ**, **Tàisù**, **Tàichū**, **Tàijí**, and **Tàigāo**.

Thus, the **Primordial Qi** descends from the **top of the head** to **Yǒngquán**,
Counting the breaths inward,
Forgetting the breaths outward—
The **Primordial Qi** follows the will, reaching the three **Dan Tians**,
Circulating endlessly like water.
This is the method of prolonged observation.

---
**Chapter on Blood and Vessels (血脉篇)**
Within the body’s minutiae lie the five **phases**;
Separation brings conflict;
Union brings generation.

Mankind’s inner five **zàng-organs** correspond to the five **phases**.

The **liver**—**Wood**—its **spirit** is the **Azure Dragon**.
Its qi ascends from the left side of the **spinal column’s victory point**,
Entering the eyes above,
Its transformation is **tears**.
**Tears** are the **true Wood**.
The residual qi flows into the left upper **hip**, becoming **Jade Nectar**.

The **lungs**—**Metal**—its **spirit** is the **White Tiger**.
Its qi ascends from the right side of the **spinal column’s remaining point**,
Entering the nose above,
Its transformation is **phlegm**.
**Phlegm** is the **true Metal**.
The residual qi flows into the right upper **flank**, becoming **Golden Elixir**.

The **heart**—**Fire**—its **spirit** is the **Vermilion Bird**.
Its qi ascends from the left upper abdomen,
Entering beneath the tongue,
Retreating into the **heart**,
Its transformation is **blood**.
**Blood** is the **true Fire**.
The residual qi flows beneath the left tongue, becoming **Divine Water**.

The **kidneys**—**Water**—its **spirit** is the **Dark Tortoise**.
Its qi ascends from the right upper abdomen,
Entering the ears,
Retreating into the **kidneys**,
Its transformation is **essence**.
**Essence** is the **true Water**.
The residual qi flows beneath the right tongue, becoming **Flowering Pool**.

The **spleen**—**Earth**—its **spirit** is **Gōuchén**.
Its qi ascends from the upper **spinal column’s victory point**,
Entering the brain,
Its transformation is **saliva**.
**Saliva** is the **true Earth**.
The residual qi flows into the left upper lip, becoming **Yellow Sprout**.

Thus, there are four **symbols** more.
First, the **Golden Elder (Jīn Wēng)**—
The **lungs’** saliva, belonging to **pure yin**.
Why is it called **Golden Elder**?
Above is the **Golden Elixir**,
Within is **Divine Water** and **Flowering Pool**,
Mingling with **Yellow Sprout** to form **yang**—
This is **upper yang, lower yin**—
Thus, it is called **Golden Elder**.

Like the sun—
The sun is pure **yang**,
Within it, the **three-legged crow** belongs to the **west’s Metal**,
**Externally yang, internally yin**.

Second, the **Maiden (Nǚ)**—
The **heart’s** blood, belonging to **pure yang**.
Why is it called **Maiden**?
Above is the **pure yin** saliva,
Within it, there is **yang**—
Thus, it is called **Maiden**.

Like the moon—
The moon is pure **yin**,
Within it, the **toad and hare** belong to the **east’s Wood**,
**Externally yin, internally yang**.

Third, the **Infant (Yīng’ér)**—
The **kidneys’** essence, belonging to **pure yin**.
Why is it called **Infant**?
Like a man—
Pure **yang** within contains pure **yin essence**,
This is **yang within yin**—
In terms of the **Two Complements**, **Kān’s male, Lí’s female**.

Fourth, the **Yellow Crone (Huáng Pó)**—
The **spleen’s** saliva, belonging to **yin**.
Why is it called **Yellow Crone**?
**Upper yin, lower yang**—
No **yin-yang** pairing—
This is **lonely yin**.

The body contains seven treasures—do you know them?
They are: **saliva**, **water**, **phlegm**, **blood**, **spirit**, **qi**, and **essence**.

The **qi** entering the nose belongs to the **liver**,
The **qi** exhaled belongs to the **lungs**;
The **qi** blown from the mouth belongs to the **kidneys**,
The **qi** expelled belongs to the **heart**;
The **qi** of **anger** belongs to the **bladder**;
The **qi** of **joy** belongs to the **San Jiao**;
The **qi** of **intent** belongs to the **spleen**;
The **qi** exhaled upward belongs to the **small intestine**;

「The **qi** of grains flows to the **lower dantian**—
This is the **true qi** of the Nine Heavens residing within the body.

The **heart**—**li** (離) with its central void—is **fire**;
The **gallbladder**—**xun** (巽) below, short#2—is **wind**;
The **liver**—**zhen** (震) with two upward tilts#3—is **thunder**;
The **small intestine**—**kun** (坤) sixfold, severed#4—is **earth**;
The **lungs**—**dui** (兑) above, truncated#5—are **marshes**;
The **large intestine**—**qian** (乾) threefold, linked#6—is **heaven**;
The **kidneys**—**kan** (坎) full within—are **water**;
The **urinary bladder**—**gen** (艮) inverted like a bowl—is **mountains**.

This is also how the body corresponds to the Eight Trigrams. Those who cultivate the **Dao/Way** should likewise ponder these principles.

In the **"Regulating Qi" (Tiáo Qì) Chapter**—
The **Sea of Original Qi** (Yuán Qì zhī hǎi) is regulated through **breathing** (xī).
After purifying the turbid, the clear gathers itself.

The **Shan Mountain Immortal (Sōng Yuè Xiān Rén) Lǐ Fèngshí** said:
*"Those refining their substance should dwell in a secluded chamber,
With a pillow two inches high,
And a bed three feet in height,
A soft mat for the seat, damp earth for the base,
Clothing suited to the balance of cold and warmth.
Lie on your back with knees firmly pressed,
Close your eyes and do not open your mouth,
Press your tongue to the roof of your mouth#7,
Clasp your hands at the two breasts,
And tap your teeth to gather your **spirit** (shén).
This is the primary task of learning the **Dao/Way**."*

To activate **true qi**, first regulate the joints to open them.
The **"Six Reductions" (Liú Mó Zhě)**—ten exhalations, twenty inhalations—
Hold your eyes wide, gaze like a tiger,
Twist your gaze westward,
Raise fists alternately left and right.
Then massage your eyes and tug your ears,
Extend your hands forward and backward,
And wipe your face—this is the method of **inhalation-exhalation** (xiāo yù).

At the start of **qi cultivation**, if the **San Jiao** is not yet harmonized,
And **swallowing qi** does not descend,
When **upper Jiao** stagnates and fails to discharge,
First learn to regulate its **qi**—
Then turbid **qi** disperses, and clear **qi** flourishes naturally.

The key lies in knowing the **gates** of exhalation and inhalation.
The **nose** is the **Heavenly Gate** (Tiān mén),
The **mouth** is the **Earthly Door** (Dì hù).
Inhaling through the **Heavenly Gate** and exhaling through the **Earthly Door**—
This is **harmonizing qi** (shùn qì).
Reversing this is **countering qi** (nì qì).

Thus, **countering** leads to **blockage** (yōng sè),
**Harmonizing** leads to **freedom** (xuān tōng)—
This is the principle of **yin-yang**.

Once you know its **harmonizing** and **countering**,
Inhale through the nose to draw in clear **qi**,
And exhale through the mouth to expel turbid **qi**.

Why does turbid **qi** emerge from the **organs**?
Humans consume the **Five Flavors**, each governing one **organ**,
And there are also the **qi** of the **Six Fu**,
All converging at one **gate** to form turbid **qi**.

How can you discern it?
When asleep, with the mouth closed, the **Five Organs**’ **qi** stagnates at the throat.
Upon waking, a great exhalation dispels it—
This is the **heavy turbid** and the **accumulation of evils**.

Thus, before **qi cultivation** and **breathwork**,
First exhale to clear the turbid,
Then proceed.

If one suffers from **dry mouth, stiff tongue**,
**Cheeks lacking moisture**, or **sore throat** unable to eat—
This is the sign of **heat**.
One must open the mouth widely and exhale **ten to twenty breaths**,
Then tap the teeth **seven to eight times**,
Roll the tongue and rinse the **Pool of Flowers** (Huá Chí),
And swallow it.
The **Pool of Flowers**’ **water** is **saliva**.

Again, let the **breathing** follow its natural rhythm,
Regulating it **three to two times**,
Then exhale again—
Once done, regulate the **breathing** once more,
Waiting until the **heat subsides** before stopping.

How does one know the **heat has subsided**?
When **clear water** emerges from the throat,
And **sweet nectar** is generated—then it is so.

For **qi** originates from the **heart**;
If the **heart** is **evil**, then **qi** is **evil**;
If the **heart** is **pure**, then **qi** is **pure**.

When one moves hands and feet,
Or experiences **joy, anger, sorrow, or delight**—
All stem from the **heart**.
The **heart**’s impulses all arise from **qi**.

Thus, **qi** complete means **body at ease**,
**Qi** lost means **body perishes**.

Physicians press the **pulse** to discern the **Five Organs**’ and **Four Seasons**’ rising and sinking.
Can I, who observe the **mouth** and **nose** for **taking** and **discarding** **qi** in an instant,
Not allow it to **exit or enter**?
Therefore, one should use the **Six Breaths** to govern it.

The **embryonic origin** is the **master** of the body,
The **Six Breaths** are the **ancestors and progenitors**.
The **Heavenly Gate** draws them in,
The **Earthly Door** expels them—
Continuous inhalation and exhalation,
**Breathing** regulated in rhythm—
Thus, the **Three Dantian** become serene,
And **jade nectar** flourishes from here.

Before noon, after the **child hour** (zǐ shí),
Divide **yin** and **yang**,
Tap the teeth to gather the **spirit**,
Swallow **once, twice, thrice**—
All three are **San Jiao**,
And the **Twelve Jade Palaces** (Yù Lóu) are engaged.
The throat has **twelve nodes**, hence called **palaces**.

Water in **kan** (坎) turns and drips#8.

**Thirty-six breaths** constitute one **cycle** (shí),
And within **ten breaths**, one **sips**—
Prolonged practice leads to **longevity**.

**Swallowing** governs the **lungs**, which belong to the **nose**.
If **qi** is unbalanced,
Or from **exhaustion, heat, or skin ailments**,
Or **ulcers and upper-body heat**—
It can be applied.

**Exhaling** governs the **heart**;
For **heart pain, stagnation, dry mouth, and stiff tongue**,
Or various **evil qi**—
It can be applied,
With wide mouth for **great heat**, and narrow for **less**.

**Blowing** governs the **kidneys**;
For **deafness, cold or weak waist and legs**—
It can be applied.

**Inhaling** governs the **spleen**;
For **weak qi, heat imbalance, abdominal distension, or indigestion**—
It can be applied.

**Hissing** governs the **liver**;
For **blurred or clouded vision, redness, or eye dryness**—
It can be applied.

**Snorting** governs the **San Jiao**;
For **San Jiao** disharmony,
Or **excessive gallbladder fright**—
It can be applied.
The **Five Breaths** each govern one **organ**,
And one **breath** governs the **San Jiao**.

The **Six Breaths** also have **auxiliary methods**:
When **hissing**, raise the eyes and fix them;
When **exhaling**, cross hands behind the neck;
When **inhaling**, lean forward;
When **swallowing**, hold up hands left and right;
When **blowing**, press knees tightly and embrace the chest.

In **large months**, follow the order:
**Hiss, exhale, inhale, sip, blow, snort**.

In **small months**, reverse the order:
From **snort** upward to **hiss**.

In general, after the **child hour** and before noon,
Loosen your clothing and sit upright,
Men press the **left foot** against the **right foot**,
Women press the **right foot** against the **left foot**,
Clasp hands firmly and regulate **breathing** while holding **qi**,
Waiting until **qi** stagnates—
Then, with a long **nose breath**, draw in the **qi**,
Close your eyes,
And according to the **Six Breaths**’ methods,
Exhale gently in accordance with their names—
So subtle that the ears cannot hear it.

**Spring** faces eastward;
**Summer** faces southward;」

「Late summer belongs to earth and the **spleen-qi**,
So face toward the southwest;」
**Autumn** faces westward;
**Winter** faces northward.
When practicing, stand relaxed and open,
Allowing **qi** to flow harmoniously.
If you can rise, then rise—
Men step down from the bed with the **left foot** first,
Women step out of their clothes with the **right foot** first.
Cross your legs without striving for height,
Spit without projecting far,
Walk without haste,
Brush your hair **hundreds of times** until it reaches **hundreds**,
Knock your teeth **constantly** until it reaches **tens**,
Rub your palms together and wipe your face **tens of times**,
Until your face grows warm and you cease.

---
**Dao Gun** Scroll Fifteen concludes:
#1 **"Hiss"** (originally *"pregnant"*);
#2 **"Short"** (originally *"severed"*);
#3 **"Shock, two lifts"** (originally *"shock, lift, and descend"*);
#4 **"Prop"** (originally *"press"*).

**Dao Gun** Scroll Sixteen, from *Youzi Zengchang’s* collection,
**Lingyuan** Chapter:
The **Great Ultimate** spreads its marvels—
Humans receive them.
Preserve and refine the **original harmony**,
Hold them and never lose them.
The **True Person** and **Immortal Matron** say:
*"The root of life lies in the **true breath**."*

The **Great Ultimate** spreads its marvels—
Humans receive **one** aspect of it,
And those who do not lose it are the **good**.
Empty halls and quiet chambers
Allow the spirit to dwell naturally,
Boiling and simmering the **spiritual palace**
Dries up its **vital fluids**—
Grief, joy, thought, and worry
Erode the form in this way.
If one is bewildered and unaware,
Then **qi** becomes disordered
And the spirit lacks foundation,
The **original harmony** exhausted
And the spirit departs.
At its nascent stage, fragile and tender,
It must be nurtured and contained.

My **root recognition** is easily altered,
For there is no fine harvest from barren fields.
Thus, **nine years** suffice to fulfill the **fire phase**,
Where **mystic correspondence** is heartless—
Their spirit is swift.

The **true heart** is **heartless**.
In **stillness and motion**, both forgotten—
This is **detachment from desire**.
The **spirit** is **nature**.
The **qi** is **life**.
If the spirit does not stray outward,
Then the **qi** will settle#1.
Between these two, which is closer?
How can one lose them and still claim **foundation**?

When **mixed and one**, yet again forget **one**,
Then you may harmonize the **original’s** emergence and retreat,
Pierce through metal and thread stone—
No difficulty in this.

Sitting is like standing, fleeting as a breath.
This is the **Dao**—
Easy to know, hard to practice.
Practice while forgetting what you practice,
And the **Dao** is complete.

As for those who **close the breath** and **count the breaths**,
This is not what I call **Dao**.
Concentrating **qi** to achieve softness,
The spirit will stay naturally,
And the **true breaths** will flow effortlessly.
With time, they **gently return** to the **original life**,
Thus the **spiritual spring** flows without drawing—
This is ineffable.

**True qi** can nourish life—
I am serene and selfless,
Fast and abstain to quiet my heart,
Moderate my speech,
Thus obtaining the **fermented sweet dew**,
Hunger and thirst vanish,
And the **true essence** appears.
At first, **laborious** in cultivation,
But when the work is done—
**Leisurely** and free.

Within **laboriousness**, there must also be **leisure**,
To nurture the **original spirit**.
How does my heart find **leisure**?
It lies in **spontaneous mastery**—
My inner practice is **tranquil and vast**,
Seeking the **Great Stillness**.

If **form** and **spirit** cannot yet be complete,
I will not exhaust my **life**—
But will perfect my **nature**?
Those with many talents
Run counter to the path of cultivation,
Like mist and smoke failing to form rain or dew.

The **essence** of cultivation lies in **spirit-qi**,
If they are not settled—
All effort is in vain.
The **marvel** of the **non-dual** is profound,
How hard it is to grasp!

Nurturing an infant,
One must **guard its mother**.
I have often rejected cleverness,
Discarded sharp intellect,
Nurtured the **spirit** as **foolishness**—
Its success or failure
Is not predetermined.
Without **predetermination**,
Its **essence** will naturally endure.
With **predetermination**,
This is **spirit-immortality**.
With **predetermination** yet no **predetermination**,
Only **firmness of heart**—
Then the **true spirit** will not scatter,
And one will **ascend to the primal source**.

---
**Zhongyuan** Chapter:
The **Room Star** is **Azure Dragon**,
The **Parameter Star** is **White Tiger**;
The **Zhenxing Star** governs them,
The **mother of all things**.

What is the **great medicine**?
Gazing upward at the heavens,
The **Room Star** is **Azure Dragon**—
The **essence of mercury**.
The **Parameter Star** is **White Tiger**—
The **essence of lead**.
These two **qi** are **treasures supreme**.

The **Sun** is the **Crimson Bird**,
The **god of fire**.
The **Moon** is the **Dark Warrior**,
The **essence of cinnabar, lead, and elixir**.

Thus, to know the **great medicine**
And establish the **original foundation**,
One must obtain the **central earth** of **Steward-Master**—
The **earth** born from the **Zhenxing Star**,
Capable of bearing the **mother of all things**.

Mercury arises from cinnabar,
Yet cinnabar again becomes mercury—
No cinnabar form is seen,
Until it returns to its root and becomes cinnabar once more.

Thus, the **Azure Dragon** is the dwelling of cinnabar,
Where yin and yang merge their essence;
The **White Tiger** is the abode of black gold.
Clad in coarse robes yet holding jade within,
Black without, white within—
Refined, it becomes true lead.

Hence, the ancient sages said:
*"This is the essence of the divine dragon."*
The **Eight Worthies of Huainan** declared:
*"This is the autumn stone."*

What is the **autumn stone**?
**Geng** is born of metal, corresponding to the **West**,
**Xin** is born of stone.
Within cinnabar, where mercury is born, lies the **divine water**.

Thus, **divine water** is the spirit of mercury—
The **Wood Sovereign of the East (Jia-Yi)**,
The **Lord of Fire in the South**.
This is cinnabar—
Its hue is red, belonging to yang,
The domain of the **South**.

The **Dragon** and **Tiger** are the two **qi**;
When they warm each other within the crucible,
It is as when a person conceives—
The vital essence blends indistinctly,
Their union taking form,
Thus, with water determining the four seasons,
They become the **Great Returning Elixir**.

Their two essences harmonized,
Their form like **milky flowers**—
They naturally restrain each other.

From the **eleventh month**, when **one yang** first emerges,
Until the **fourth month**, when **pure yang** reigns,
Entering the **fifth month**, when **one yin** begins,
Yin and yang generate and interact,
Thus, they naturally mediate.

When yang reaches its peak and yin arises,
At the **center of Jia-Wu**, the yang hexagram is applied—
From **Child** to the **center of Wu**,
Thus, the **six hexagrams** enter the **Qian position**.
The six hexagrams belong to the **Qian palace**.

Cinnabar is produced from metal,
Mercury returns to lead.
The medicine lies within the crucible,
Pushed by the two **qi**,
And when ripe, it is as a person in the womb.

Yin and yang unite and mediate,
As if divine and numinous!

In the **tenth month**, frost and snow descend,
The **yellow sprout** ripens within,
Its color vividly apparent.
When the **yellow sprout** matures,
It is the natural divine transformation of the **Dragon** and **Tiger**.

When the elixir is complete and taken,
One must **guard the One** and preserve the spirit,
Aligning the heart with the **Way**.

I have often sat cross-legged,
Each hand rising forward and backward, swaying **thirty-six times**.
The left hand takes the right—
Swaying the **celestial pillar**, each **thirty-six times**.
Grasping firmly and swaying the **jointed carp**, **thirty-six times**,
Dual-flying the **transverse carp**, also **thirty-six times**.
The hands form a **drawing bow**—
The right draws, the left gazes back.
The hands curve like **hooks**, straining forward with force—
Each **thirty-six times**.

Gaze upon the teeth and rinse with saliva, exerting force to swallow three times—then begin the **fire-alchemy** practice.

The **Child** (子) is four *liang*—each *liang* through nine revolutions makes **thirty-six**;
The **Ox** (丑) is eight *liang*—calculated as **seventy-two**;
The **Tiger** (寅) is twelve *liang*—calculated as **one hundred eighty**;
The **Dragon** (辰) is sixteen *liang*—**one hundred forty-four**;
The **Snake** (巳) is twenty *liang*—calculated as **one hundred eighty**;
The **Horse** (午) is twenty *liang*—each *liang* through six revolutions makes **one hundred twenty**;
The **Sheep** (未) is sixteen *liang*—calculated as **ninety-six**;
The **Monkey** (申) is twelve *liang*—calculated as **seventy-two**;
The **Rooster** (戌) is eight *liang*—calculated as **forty-eight**;
The **Dog** (亥) is four *liang*—calculated as **twenty-four**.
Only **Yin-Mao** (卯) and **Yang-You** (酉) are not practiced.

---
**Central Yellow Chapter**
The Five Grains nourish the form, yet also bring harm;
Feasting on the **Primordial Harmony**, one remains at ease and prolongs life.

Humans receive form in the womb,
Thus **essence** and **blood** are its roots,
**Spirit-mind** and **Primordial Qi** its foundation—
Thus I illuminate the Five Viscera.

Observe the **Primordial Qi**, vast and boundless, congealing into substance.
Nurtured by the Five Viscera, it follows the **Five Phases** in correspondence;
Illuminated by the Seven Orifices, it mirrors the **Seven Celestial Luminaries** in radiance.

Within the human abdomen lies the **true qi** of the Five Phases—
Follow it, and there is no illness;
Defy it, and harm ensues.

The head is **Heaven**, the feet are **Earth**.
The **qi** of the heart, the **qi** of the bones, the **qi** of the joints—all are great,
This is called the **Divine Dwelling**.
Thus, **"Cultivation of the Way is easy, and longevity follows."**

The **Way** employs **heart-mind** and **cognition**—
If one uses the heart and abandons desire,
One ascends directly to the **Nine Heavens**—
This is its greatest essence.

The infant in the womb has no sound, no breath,
In harmony with the **Ultimate Principle**.
Once born, the Six Senses stir,
The body clings to the Five Grains,
Greed and afflictions arise,
Following the senses’ impulses—
The mouth receives external flavors, forgetting the senses;
The body endures internal toil, losing its **virtue**.
The spirit departs the form, scattering and decaying;
The form departs the spirit, losing life—
Yet they do not know
How flesh and skin correspond,
How sinews and bones interdepend.

The liver corresponds to sinews—its exterior is **claws**;
The heart corresponds to vessels—its exterior is **complexion**;
The spleen corresponds to flesh—its exterior is **lips**;
The lungs correspond to skin—its exterior is **hair**;
The kidneys correspond to bones—its exterior is **hair**.

**Salt** harms the bones;
**Bitterness** harms the blood;
**Sweetness** harms the flesh;
**Pungency** harms the **qi**;
**Sourness** harms the sinews.

Who knows their origins?
**Qi** is **Yang**; **flavor** is **Yin**.
Flavor nourishes the form, the form nourishes **qi**, **qi** nourishes **essence**—
At first, did they not mutually support one another?
Yet later, they all oppose each other.

Thus, **essence** consumes **qi**, and **essence** is harmed;
The form consumes flavor, and the form is harmed.
When **grain-qi** flourishes, **Primordial Qi** declines,
Until one reaches old age.

In **Spring**, the month of **seventy-two days**,
Reduce **bitterness**, increase **pungency** to nourish the **lungs**;
In **Summer**, the month of **seventy-two days**,
Reduce **sourness**, increase **sweetness** to nourish the **spleen**;
In **Autumn**, the month of **seventy-two days**,
Reduce **pungency**, increase **sourness** to nourish the **liver**;
In **Winter**, the month of **seventy-two days**,
Reduce **saltiness**, increase **bitterness** to nourish the **heart**;
In the **late seasons** of each quarter, **eight days**,
Reduce **sweetness**, increase **saltiness** to nourish the **kidneys**—
Thus, one may attain **three hundred years of life**.

First, eliminate desire to preserve **essence**,
Then abstain from grains to sustain **life**,
Feast on **fetal qi**, on **spiritual essence**—
This is the **Way of Immortality**.

There is a land called **Hua Xu**,
Thirty *li* outside the **Supreme Sovereign’s** court,
Above, **flying thorns** are arrayed;
Below, **luxuriant flowers** spread.
To enter **Hua Xu**, one must pass through them first.

**Flying thorns** and **luxuriant flowers**—
Are they not like my **Three Pengs**?
When the **Three Pengs** vanish, I ascend to the **Fetal Immortal’s** realm.

The **Nine Immortal Lords** say:
The **Way’s** essence lies in **eighteen chapters**:
The **Classic** states:
*"Dedicate oneself to stillness and tranquility—
The body becomes like jade.
Only consume the **Primordial Harmony**, abstaining from the Five Grains."*
What does this mean?
The heart moves with each moment—
First, contend for its residence,
Internally sever all thought,
Externally sever all desire,
Then **Primordial Qi** will naturally suffice.

The world uses the Five Grains to fatten the skin,
Yet does not know they are the root of bodily decay.
The **Classic** says:
*"Salt, bitter, sour, pungent, sweet—
The Five Viscera fall ill;
Saliva entering the teeth—
The heart grows dim like a mirror."*
This is what is meant.

In the **third month of Spring**, arrange a single chamber,
Set up a low table, a bed, and a mat.

At the hour of **Child** (子), when **Primordial Qi** first arises,
Contend for the **heart-mind**—
Knock the teeth **thirty-six times**,
Clasp the hands firmly,
Raise the gaze, close the eyes,
Wait for the breath to exhale, then seal the lips and inflate the **qi**,
Swallowing as the measure.
Rinse with saliva and swallow it.

If the **qi** enters the abdomen with a **glug-glug** sound,
Stop when hunger arises—hunger, then repeat the practice.

After the **qi** enters, if the mouth grows dry, drink **sesame liquid**.
**Sesame**—three *sheng*, peeled, steamed nine times, dried nine times.
**Dried ginger**—three *liang*, finely ground into powder.
First ingest the **sesame powder**, three *liang*,
Then the **dried ginger powder**,
Decoct with water until it boils several times,
Add a little **ghee** and **honey**.

Over time, the **qi** will flow freely and harmoniously,
The swallowed **qi** will glide smoothly—
Then the **sesame liquid** may cease.
When the dregs in the intestines are exhausted,
Swallowing the **qi** becomes effortless,
And the **tang-liquid** reaches below the navel.

At the start of **qi**-cultivation,
Urination may turn **red-yellow**—do not fear.
If the **tang-liquid** does not cease,
The intestinal dregs will not be exhausted,
And one will never truly discern right from wrong.

To abstain from water and grains,
Measure it by oneself—no fixed distance.
Some do it for **thirty days**, some for **fifty**, some for **one hundred**—
The **Three Elixir Fields** will naturally fill in sequence.

Thus, after **thirty days**, the **Lower Elixir Field** fills,
The **spirit-qi** becomes full and does not disperse,
Nor does hunger arise.

Sixty days, the **Middle Elixir Field** fills,
And the body knows no emptiness nor fatigue—
Steps grow vigorous and sure.

Ninety days, the **Upper Elixir Field** fills,
The inner essence congeals while the outer form grows plump and full.
Thus, the **Three Burners** harmonize and solidify,
The **spirit-qi** condenses, the body clears—
Thoughts grow faint and distant,
And one may dwell in the sacred realm to study **embryonic immortality**.

Yet if one sometimes eats, sometimes abstains,
The will scatters and weakens;
If one indulges in flavors,
The **qi** of grains lingers, hard to dispel—
A grave affliction for those who seek the Dao.

This is the first principle of **nourishing form and spirit**.

The **Classic** says:
*"If you can guard it well, the Three Worms will abandon you,
And you will behold the Nine True Ones and the Five Tooth Qi."*

What does this mean?
To swallow the **tang-liquid** is to know no hunger—
How much more so when cultivating **qi**!

Thus, when one abstains from grains,
The **hun** and **po** transform and shift,
And the **Three Corpses** tremble in agitation.

Yet at the start of **qi**-cultivation,
After **fourteen days** or **twenty-eight days**,
When the filth has passed,
One may gradually feel the body weak,
Every joint powerless—
This is the **original qi** not yet reaching through.

Fear not.
Hold firm to it—
When the **Lower Elixir Field** fills, hunger and thirst will cease.

At first, the skin grows yellow and emaciated,
But later, it will glow with radiance.
If one eats while practicing, there will be no effect.
Generally, to swiftly reach the **Five Viscera** through **qi**-cultivation,
One must cut off the **tang-liquid**.

After **fifty days** of abstinence,
Close the eyes and inwardly visualize the **spleen’s qi**—
Rising from the heart, dispersing to the limbs.
Face outward and recite:
*"Central Steward of Wu-Ji,
Holding the original qi within,
Yellow and firm inside—
Use it to regulate,
Dan-Yang does not refuse,
Zhu-Ling joins in counsel.
When the qi reaches the limbs,
A great yellow cloud arises in the heart—
Thus, at the hour of **Chou**, do not falter.
After twenty-eight days,
One will see within the spleen’s qi,
Pressing like yellow clouds,
Spreading through the four limbs.
With time, this qi can extinguish candles,
Blow out flames—
A hundred paces away, like a great wind,
Raising clouds and mist to shroud the body."*

The **Three Corpses** reside thus:
One in the **Brain Palace**—
The **Upper Elixir Field**—
White and green in hue,
Causing one to crave food and drink,
To indulge in desires,
And unsettle the mind.

One in the **Hall of Light**—
The **Middle Elixir Field**—
Causing one to covet wealth and bribes,
To indulge in joy and anger,
And leave the spirit vague and confused.

One in the **Abdominal Cavity**—
The **Lower Elixir Field**—
Causing one to love fine clothes,
To waste on wine and lust,
And disrupt the emotions.

If one steadfastly focuses the mind,
Feeding on this qi,
Then in **thirty days**, the upper worm dies,
In **sixty days**, the middle worm dies,
In **ninety days**, the lower worm dies.
Thus, the **Five Viscera** contain the **Five Phases’ true qi**,
And one will be in communion with the **Nine Heavens**.

This is the second principle of **mysterious qi-nourishment**.

The **Classic** says:
*"The Five Teeth abhor salty, bitter, and sour flavors."*
What does this mean?
If the **Five Flavors** are not cut off,
The **numinous qi** of the **Five Viscera** will not arise.
This is the third principle of the **Five Teeth’s aversion**.

The **Classic** says:
*"Steam the sinews, dry the bones, open the passes,
Grasp the firm, unblock the **Harbor**, and open all orifices."*
What does this mean?

---

After practicing **qi-nourishment** for five weeks yet unable to sever the **qi of the grains and vegetables**,
When the weather clears and the skies brighten,
At **high noon**, sit in a secluded chamber,
Arrange the bed and spread the mat,
Loosen your hair upon the pillow,
**Grasp the firm** and gently press at the sides of the ribs.
Then **knock the teeth** seven times,
Steady the mind and close the eyes.
If you sense a faint oppression,
Forcefully **grasp the firm** and gradually open the sinews and pulses,
As **numinous qi** flows through the bones and flesh,
Moisture and perspiration nourish the skin.
Repeatedly circulating this **qi**,
Your complexion naturally becomes radiant and your vitality doubles.

**Retain the breath** to refine the form,
And the **original qi** will flow through the **hair and fur**—
The **hair and fur** will tremble and leap.
This is the fourth principle of the **contest of mists and vapors**.

The **Classic** says:
*"All orifices and passes are linked, all holding divine essence."*
What does this mean?
The **orifices** connect to the **hundred openings**,
The **hundred openings** link to the **hundred vessels**.
Above the eyes are two openings,
Which connect to the **Liver’s vessels**,
The **Liver’s vessels** link to the **Heart’s vessels**,
Thus when the **Heart** is sorrowful, the eyes overflow.
Above the brain is also an opening,
Which connects to the **nasal vessels**,
The **nasal vessels** link to the **Heart’s vessels**,
Thus when the **Heart** is sorrowful, the nose feels acid,
And when the brain is heated, the nose feels dry.
Indeed, the **hundred vessels** face the **orifices**,
And the **hundred passes** connect to the **hundred joints**,
Thus if one opening is blocked, one ailment arises,
And if one vessel is clogged, one **channel** is disordered.

For those practicing **qi-nourishment**,
The vessels become unobstructed,
The stomach and abdomen hold no residue to linger,
Cold and heat do not invade,
Toxic substances do not cling,
And the **ten thousand divine essences** begin to gather within the body,
As the **guest qi** of wounds and scars fades away.
This is the fifth principle of **orifices and passes**.

The **Classic** says:
*"What substance is the **suffering of the seventy-seven**?"*
What does this mean?
When the **dregs** are exhausted,
It is most crucial to sever the **qi of the grains and vegetables** for **forty-nine days**,
This is the most urgent matter.
As the vessels gradually open,
**Original qi** returns, bright like a candle,
The mundane mind is abandoned,
The **Five Viscera** harmonize,
And if you cannot **firm the essence**, all prior efforts will be lost.
This is the sixth principle of **enduring preservation**.

The **Classic** says:
*"Obstructed **child**—divine power’s path is hard,
Mostly **grains and vegetables** cause imbalance and disease."*
What does this mean?
When **grains and vegetables’ qi** is dense and solid,
The **Five Viscera** become congested,
**Divine qi** cannot condense,
And **numinous light** does not illuminate.

This is the seventh principle of **salt and bitterness**.

The **Classic** says:
*"When **grains and vegetables’ qi** is dense, its refined essence separates from the **numinous**,
Entangling the **Six Palaces**, dimming all the vessels."*
What does this mean?
After **forty to sixty days** of **qi-nourishment**,
When the **dregs** are exhausted but one does not know the **grains and vegetables’ refined essence** has yet to emerge,
Then thoughts of food arise,
The mind scatters and dissipates,
Nearly moved by the **Three Corpses**.
When later decay appears—
Sometimes like pus,
Sometimes like blood,
Sometimes like rotten fat,
Sometimes like **parrot droppings**—
This is when **grains and vegetables’ qi** is about to emerge.
After **thirty days more**,
If **saliva-like** or **mucous-like** substances appear,
Then the **grains and vegetables’ refined essence** has manifested.
This is the eighth principle of **grains and vegetables’ refined essence**.

The **Classic** says:
*"Self-discernment of **original harmony** and the **Nine Heavens’ qi**."*
What does this mean?
When the **qi of the grains and vegetables** is exhausted,
One recognizes the **original qi**.
This is the ninth principle of the **Three Worms’ dwelling**.

The **Classic** says:
*"From the **child**, movement generates **breathing**,
Residing within the **Elixir Field**, flickering like a flame."*
What does this mean?

「Once the **spiritual qi** is sufficient, **breathing** and movement arise,
Capable of summoning clouds and mist,
And attaining **hidden form** without obstruction.

When the **Elixir Field’s qi** is steady and full,
It ascends above and circulates below,
Forming like a **parrot’s egg**—
Its light shines through several *li*,
Strengthening sinews and bones,
And harmonizing the body.
This is the **true qi of the Nine Celestial Beings**, the tenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"The **true qi of the Celestial Child** nourishes the **Way’s essence**,
Retaining the **true qi** forms the **breathing of the Child**."*
What does this mean?
After **two hundred days of inhaling qi**,
The **Five Zang** are emptied,
And one may then learn the **Celestial Child’s breathing**.

First, one must prepare a **sealed chamber** with thick felt and layered mats,
The pillow’s height four fingers, level with the body.
Abandoning the **heart-mind**, one steadies the breath in a **supine position**,
Initially closing it **from ten to fifteen breaths**,
Then extending to **thirty, fifty, or a hundred breaths**,
So that the **heart-mind remains unmoved**.
Day and night, twelve hours,
Totaling **one thousand six hundred fifty breaths**.
When the breath is **fully suspended**,
The **po** guards the body while the **hun** wanders to the **Upper Heavens**.

After **a hundred breaths**,
The **hun** and **spirit** will encounter the **po**.
The **po**, a **yin spirit**,
Does not wish one to be born.
Its seven **spirits** wear **black robes**,
Their **headgear** is a **black crown**,
Their **insignia** is a **black seal**.
This is the **Dark Mother**.
If one sees her,
One must **retain her in mind** and pray:
*"Dark Mother, Dark Mother,
You are the master of my body,
Nourishing sinews and bones—
Do not leave the **Gate of the Corporeal Frame**.
I and the **Spirit-Father** together roam the **Upper Heavens**,
Next appear three figures,
Each a **foot-and-a-half** in length,
Their robes **vermilion**, their **headgear** **vermilion crowns**,
Their **insignia** **vermilion seals**.
They lead the **spirits of the Upper Primordial Palace’s cerebrum**—
Over a hundred—**outward**.
One’s body then reveals **a single qi** in the **two Elixir Fields**,
Like a **white cloud**, luminous and penetrating.
Then, one must **solemnly call** the names of the **Three Hun**:
The first, **Awakening Spirit**,
The second, **Fetal Light**,
The third, **Profound Essence**.
Having obtained this **yang spirit**,
One leads the **cerebral spirits** by their **radiant qi** to wander in the **Upper Heavens**.
At first emergence,
One feels the body **exit from the black chamber**,
Encountering **ghostly spirits** in **deceptive forms** and **strange essences**—
Some vast, some minuscule.
Only **do not fear** them,
And when **nothing is seen**, it is considered auspicious.

Thus, those who practice this **Dao** must **seek like-minded companions** to dwell with,
Lest one’s visions **inspire terror** and prevent the body from departing.
Then, one must **instruct companions** to **record the number of breaths**.

This is the **true qi of the Child’s Breathing**, the eleventh principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"The **true qi of the Five Zang** flourishes like **rare herbs’ sprouts**."*
What does this mean?
The **liver**—**wood**—
Born from **fire**, conquering **earth**,
Emerging from the **east**,
Its hue **verdant and dark**.
It is received from the **yang**, and this **qi** is **concealed and closed**,
**Retained for a thousand breaths**,
Then the **green qi** circulates and **condenses**.
When practiced,
From the **hour of the Child** onward,
Every **two hours** until **fifty days**,
One sees the **qi** like a **verdant cloud**,
**Visualizing it** can treat:
**Floating heat**, **seasonal epidemics**, **swelling**, **scabies**, **sudden coughs**.

The **heart**—**fire**—
Born from **wood**, conquering **metal**,
Emerging from the **south**,
Its hue **scarlet**.
It is received from the **vermilion yang**,
**Concealed and closed for a thousand breaths**,
Then the **scarlet qi** emerges.
At **midday**, one **retains and visualizes** its **qi**,
Its form vast as a **parrot’s egg**,
Gradually, the **scarlet qi** disperses from the **crown**.
One prays:
*"Southern **Jing-Ding**,
The **scarlet dragon** resides here,
The **yin spirit** avoids this place,
The **yang organs** descend to welcome—
Reflect upon it, and it will come,
Use it, and its power is fulfilled.
After **fifty days**, the **scarlet qi** shines like **flame’s light**,
Capable of treating **ling-cough**."

The **lung**—**metal**—
Born from **earth**, conquering **wood**,
Emerging from the **west**,
Its hue **white**.
It is received for **a thousand breaths**,
Then the **white qi** emerges.
At the **hour of the Ox**, one **retains and visualizes** its **qi**,
Its form like a **white pearl**,
Its light dwelling in the **eyebrow region**.
One invokes:
*"Western **Geng-Xin**,
**Great Micro** and **Profound Darkness**,
Internally responding to the **Six Fu**,
Externally manifesting as the **lung spirit**,
Appearing in the **qi’s ascent**,
Wandering in the **Elixir Field**,
Steadfastly guarding my life—
Use it, and one attains **transcendence**."

After **one visualization**,
At **forty-nine days**,
The **lung** contains **qi** like a **white cloud**,
Capable of illuminating **thick earth**,
All **treasures**, and discerning **human virtue and vice**—
**Seeing the exterior to know the interior**.
If one does not practice the **Five Qi** visualization method,
Then one must **inhale qi for three years**,
Only then will the **Five Zang’s qi** appear,
And one must **distinguish the principles of birth, conquest, cold, and heat**.
When **cold**, one uses the **heart’s qi**—the **fire**—;
When **heat**, one uses the **kidney’s qi**—the **water**.
Thus, if one does not **know how to use the qi**, there will be **no effect**.

The **spleen**—**earth**—
Born from **fire**, conquering **water**,
Emerging from the **center**,
Its hue **pure yellow**.
It is **concealed and closed for a thousand breaths**,
Then the **yellow qi** flourishes.
One **retains and visualizes** it **once daily** without restriction,
At **forty-nine days**, one sees its **qi**,
Capable of **entering walls** while others cannot perceive it.

The **kidney**—**water**—
Born from **metal**, conquering **fire**,
Emerging from the **north**,
Its hue **black**,
Known as the **Lower Primordial**,
**Guarding the Hall of Life**.
Within it lies the **true guardian**.
Do not forget the **spirits of the Five Zang’s qi**,
At the start of each **five-watch period**, one **retains and visualizes** their hues,
Their **qi** all emerges from the **crown**—then it ceases,
No need to **visualize each one individually**.
Thus, the **effect is gradual**,
Taking over **a hundred days** to manifest.
This is the **true qi of the Five Zang**, the twelfth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"The **Primordial Extremes’ true palace** dwells in the **Azure Void**."*
What does this mean?
It is the **palace of the Upper Realm**.
Thus, the **Upper Realm** takes the **Seven Precious Essences’ refined qi** as **sun and moon**,
While the **Lower Realm** relies on **yin and yang** to **carry qi** as **sun and moon**.
A **year in the Lower Realm**—**three hundred sixty days**—
Is **twelve hours in the Upper Realm**.
This is the **Primordial Extremes’ true palace**, the thirteenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"Ascend further to the **Luminous Heavens** and enter **Great Micro**."*
What does this mean?
It is the **fifth hall of the Nine Heavens**.

This **Nine-Qi True Immortal** is the fourteenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"Cultivating stillness and refining truth makes one a **sage**,
The **Nine Practices of the Void** align the **True Load** to bear **virtue**."*
What does this mean?
The **Nine Practices** are:
1. **Compassion** as **garment** for the day,
2. **Abstinence** as **food**,
3. **Rectification of intent** as **vehicle**,
4. **Single-minded resolve** as **wealth**,
5. **Humility** as **bed**,
6. **Upright conduct** as **vessel**,
7. **Diligent benevolence** as **house**,
8. **Cultivation of the Void** as **dwelling**,
9. **Altruistic offerings** as **ornament**.
This is the **Luminous Heavens’ Mysterious Palace**, the fifteenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"All practices without **intent** are **true intent**,
Following **intent** brings one to return to **Heaven’s departure**."*
What does this mean?
The **true intent** without **intent** arises from the **intent** that exists.
This is the **Nine Practices of the Void**, the sixteenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"The **Six Palaces** hold **ten thousand deities**, ever-present and constant."*
What does this mean?
The **Great Intestine Palace** governs the **Lung Chamber**,
Its **nasal septum** marks the center for observing **colors**,
Weighing **twelve jin and ten liang**,
Stretching **one chi and two cun** in length,
And **eight cun** in breadth.
The **Great Intestine** has **twelve bends**,
Storing **one dou and two sheng of water and grain**,
With **deities** present in its **twelve hours**,
Their **garments and crowns** mirroring their respective hues.
When the **eleventh hour** arrives and the **water and grain qi** are exhausted,
Then their **deities** will appear.

The **Kidney Palace** governs the **inner officials**,
Its outer manifestation is the **ear**,
Acting as the **gate of the dwelling**.
For **essence** belongs to the **kidneys**,
The **kidneys** are the **rear officials**,
Within them are arranged **palace maidens**,
**Bing** on the left and **Gui** on the right,
Cycling through the **two ears**,
With **Primordial Deities** guarding them.
**Rage and anger** harm the **kidneys**,
Kidney injury leads to **loss of resolve**,
And the **Primordial Deities** are abandoned.
**Guarding against anger** is the **taboo of the Dao**.

The **kidneys** gather **qi** with the **Bladder Palace**,
Its outer correspondence is the **root of the tongue**,
As **qi** and **fluids** circulate,
Thus the **Bladder Palace** and the **Kidney Palace** combine as the **ferry gate**,
And the **Sea of Qi** flows in cycles as the **key path**.

Before **qi cultivation** is complete, one must **restrain speech**,
To nurture the **ferry**.
Within it are **three hundred sixty deities**,
Each corresponding to a **day’s position** in the year.
Once the **qi** is refined,
If one consistently upholds **non-greed**,
Then the **deities** will manifest and align with **virtue’s essence**.

This is the **Six Palaces of Ten Thousand Deities**, the seventeenth principle.

The **Classic** says:
*"Do not leak **Heaven’s decree**; preserve **intent**."*
What does this mean?
If one **remains steadfast from beginning to end** without leaking,
Then the **Heavenly Deities** will aid them.
This is the **preservation of Heaven’s decree**, the eighteenth principle.

---
*(End of translation, adhering to your guidelines.)*

**#2 "Reduce sour, increase sweet to nourish my spleen**—this sentence aligns with the preceding *"reduce bitterness, increase pungency to nourish my lungs"* in the *Essential Compilation*, though their positions are exchanged.

---
**The *Yunyuan* (循环) Chapter** of *Dao Shū* (道枢) concludes.

---
**#1 *Yunyuan* (运火) Chapter**
The *yin-yang* fires advance in measured cycles;
The *sun-moon’s degrees* (日月之度) are their model and reflection.

**Yin True Lord** (阴真君) says:
*"One, two, two-four, three-six, four-eight, five-ten-six, twelve-seven, fourteen-eight, sixteen-nine, eighteen-ten-two, eleven-twenty-two, twelve-twenty-four, thirteen-twenty-six, fourteen-twenty-eight, fifteen-thirty-one, sixteen-thirty-two, seventeen-thirty-four, eighteen-thirty-six, nineteen-thirty-eight, twenty-ten-one, twenty-two-twenty-two"—these are the cycles of the **ascending yang fire** (进乎阳火).
*"Sixteen-thirty, seventeen-twenty-eight, eighteen-twenty-six, nineteen-twenty-four, twenty-three-twenty-two, twenty-four-twenty-one, twenty-five-twenty, twenty-six-eighteen, twenty-seven-seventeen, twenty-eight-sixteen, twenty-nine-twelve, thirty-seven, thirty-eight-twenty-six, thirty-nine-twenty-four, forty-four, forty-five-twelve, forty-six-twelve, forty-seven-eighteen, forty-eight-twenty-six, forty-nine-twenty-nine, fifty-four-thirty-two"—these are the cycles of the **ascending yin fire** (进乎阴火).*

My **fire’s numbers** (吾火之数) indeed match those of the **Red Gold Lord** (红金子) and **Wei Boyang’s fire** (魏伯阳火), harmonizing with the **sun-moon’s courses** (日月之行度) and the **celestial revolutions of stars** (天轮周星). This exhausts the **numbers of Heaven and Earth** (天地之数) and fulfills their **transformative functions** (造化之功), surpassing the petty methods of external schools.

The **essentials of fire’s alchemy** (火候之要) state:
*"Day and night, four seasons’ fires—Heaven and Earth’s **qi** (气) interflow.*
*All things inherit the **Five Phases** (五行), and fire’s method is in the *Cansame* (参同).*
*From Nine to Six, the cycles complete—cold and warmth’s **transformative power** (造化功) is fulfilled.*
*The **Green Dragon** (青龙) weds the **White Tiger** (白虎), in perfect union, no deviation.*
*Its radiance crystallizes into **worldly treasures** (世宝), steadfast and unyielding.*
*The **Sages** (圣人) preserved this method, hidden in the **fire arts** (火术).*

*When **yin qi** ascends and **yang qi** descends,*
*The **head and tail** (首尾) are questioned in **Wudu** (武都),*
*Five days return to one **watch** (候).*

*The **Gua of Return** (复卦) is the **primary cycle** (先首);*
*Head and tail interweave, motion arising.*
*At **initial nine** (初九), the **hours of *hai*, *zi*, *chou*** (亥子丑), three cycles are the **primary** (先首).*
*At **second nine** (二九), the **hours of *yin*, *mao*, *chen*** (寅卯辰), four cycles align with the **Six Rites** (六律).*
*At **third nine** (三九), the **hours of *si*, *wu*, *wei*** (巳午未), five cycles merge with **Sage’s intent** (圣意).*
*At **fourth nine** (四九), the **hours of *shen*, *you*, *xu*** (申酉戌), fire’s numbers must be **fully realized** (实).*

*The cycles revolve through the **twelve earthly branches** (十二辰),*
*Completing the **four seasons** (四季) in harmony.*

*At **nine-five** (九五), the **Flying Dragon** (飞龙) ascends to Heaven—*
*Do not **alter the fire’s cycles** (运火数).*
*At **upper nine** (上九), the **Dragon in Excess** (亢龙) brings regret—*
*Retreat to a lower position.*

Thus, **nine positions without yin** (九位无阴) are the **Winter Solstice’s ascension** (日升上), while **nine-Heaven without yang** (九天无阳) are the **Summer Solstice’s descent** (日降下). Therefore, the **Sages** (圣人) established methods to **return the four seasons’ fires** (还四时之火), making day and night uniform—when the fire’s numbers are complete, they **ascend to Pengtai** (蓬台) and descend to the **elixir field** (丹田), leaping upward while rooted below, and the **refined furnace** (重炉) returns to its **original essence** (本色).

**As the method dictates, reverse alchemy** (倒焚) is performed—
Thus, the **four seasons’ *qi*** (四气) are fulfilled,
And **mercury and cinnabar** (汞砂) are subdued by fire,
The **transformative work** (造化之功) complete.

**Cinnabar** (砂) is **yin-cooked and yang-refined** (阴煮而阳缎);
**Mercury** (汞) is **yang-destroyed and yin-cooked** (阳毁而阴煮).
This is the **subdued alchemy** (伏制) that yields the **returned elixir** (还丹).

---
**The *Hunyuan* (混元) Chapter**
Move in accord with **Heaven’s Way** (天道), uniting **qi** with the **Primordial** (元);
Stand firm and singular—open **Heaven** (乾) and close **Earth** (坤).

**Hunyuan True Lord** (混元真君) says:
*"**Hunyuan** (混元) is formless like the **egg of chaos** (鹦子),*
*Round above, square below,*
*Within it, **qi** swirls like dust in a crack—*
*Grasped, it has no form;*
*Gazed upon, it has an image.*
*Thus, it was named **Two Principles** (二仪).*

*When **Two Principles** intermingle, **yin and yang** emerge;*
*When **yin and yang** sustain each other, the **Three Talents** (三才) are established.*

Yet, **humans** all inherit **Heaven and Earth’s unified *qi*** (一气) at birth—
Why does **Heaven not collapse** (崩) and **Earth not sink** (陷), while **humans alone die**?

**Heaven**, with its **light and clear essence** (轻清之体), moves in **natural harmony** (顺行).
If it **reverses and opposes *qi*** (逆气), clinging to **heaviness and turbidity** (重浊),
Its **qi** exhausted, it will **collapse** (崩).
**Earth**, with its **heavy and turbid essence** (重浊之体), **rises in opposition** (逆起).
If it **reverses and harmonizes *qi*** (顺气), clinging to **lightness and clarity** (轻清),
Its **qi** exhausted, it will **sink** (陷).
**Humans** are **yang** (阳), while all **formed, tangible things** (有形相之物) are **yin** (阴).
Their **Way** clings to **yin**, veering toward **deviant perceptions** (邪见),
Diminishing **true *qi*** (正气)—
Thus, they reach **death** (死).*

If one **follows Heaven’s Way** (天道) and moves,
Consistently uniting **qi** with the **Primordial** (元),
And **Dao/Way** remains unerring,
Then **longevity** (长生) is attained.

Those who **cannot attain longevity** (不能长生者) have **lost the Primordial *qi*** (本元) and **broken the Three Wonders** (三奇).
Thus, when **Primordial *qi*** is **shattered** (破), it is **insufficient** (不足),
And their **deities** (神) perish.
When **deities** perish and **qi** is insufficient,
One naturally **does not align with Heaven and Earth’s movements** (行动).

If one **originally has no leakage** (无漏泄),
**Deity and awareness** (神识) are **unerring** (无差),
And **does not violate the Three Wonders** (三奇无犯),
With **day and night’s thoughts untainted** (昼夜神思无素),
Then one **can share Heaven and Earth’s virtue** (同德) and **match the sun and moon’s luminosity** (齐明).

Those who **cultivate the body** (修身者) may have **Primordial *qi*** **once shattered** (尝破),
And their **spirit and *qi*** (精神) are **not whole** (不全).
They must **await their spirit’s restoration** (具) and **qi’s completion** (气全),
Then **nourish life** (养命) and **become an immortal** (为仙).

Otherwise, **inner and outer *qi*** (内外之气) **will not unite** (不相合),
And **Dao/Way** cannot be **fulfilled** (成).

Why?
**Inner** (内) is **human *qi*** (人之气);
**Outer** (外) is **Heaven and Earth’s *qi*** (天地之气).
Moreover, **Heaven, Earth, and humans** (天、地、人) are all **born from the unified True *qi*** (真一之气).
When **inner *qi*** is **insufficient** (不足),
It **cannot harmonize with the old** (於旧则不合).

All **ten thousand things** (万物) arise from the **Five Phases** (五行),
And when they **decay**, they are **restored by their own kind** (以其物补之).
Thus, when **humans decay** (人之坏),
They must **investigate their root essence** (根元) to **restore it** (补).

**The Primordial** (元) is **One** (一).
At its **beginning**, it **receives the father’s one-lin *true essence*** (父之一厘之真精)
And **inherits the mother’s one-lin *true qi*** (母一厘之真气),
Sustaining each other to **form** (成).

Thus, **one yin and one yang** is called **Dao/Way**.
**Dao/Way** generates **One** (一), **One** generates **Two** (二), **Two** generates **Three** (三), **Three** generates **ten thousand things** (万物),
And **Heaven and Earth** (乾坤) are established—
Nothing is **omitted** (无不备者).
This is **humanity’s foundation** (根本).

If one **loses the Three Wonders** (失其三奇),
They must **rely on the root essence** (根元) to **cultivate anew** (修之).
Then the **Three Wonders** will **be sufficient** (自足).

The **Three Wonders** (三奇) are **deity, *qi*, and essence** (神、气、精).
**Humanity’s Primordial** (夫人元) arises from **yin-yang’s mutual resonance** (阴阳交感),
And when it **decays**, it can be **restored by yin-yang’s harmony** (用阴阳而补之),
So that **deity and *qi*** (神气) **unite with the body** (合於身).
Then **inner *qi*** will **naturally harmonize with the outer** (内气自合於外),
And when **inner and outer *qi*** unite,
They **become one with Heaven and Earth** (同於天地)."

Now the **Way of yin-yang’s restoration** (阴阳补之者) is **this**: the practitioner first **nourishes life** (养其命) by aligning with the **cyclic movements of yin-yang** (阴阳之运动), regulating **vitality and seasons** (气候), shifting **Heaven and Earth’s polarity** (乾坤), and balancing the **Five Phases’ flourishing or decline** (五行否泰). Endlessly **entering and exiting** (出入), **flowing through** (往来) and **penetrating** (贯串), they **respond to inner and outer *qi*** (与内外相应) without deviation. After **three years of cultivation** (修之三载), they will **ascend as a transcendent** (成仙矣).

Someone asked: *"From where does one obtain the **primordial *qi* and essence** (父母之精气) of the parents? How does one **transform them** (通变之)?"*
The reply was: *"The father is **Wood** (木); the **essence** (精) is **Fire** (火). These two **symbols** (象) are **one vital breath** (一气). **Wood** is the **root** (主), **Fire** is the **function** (用). The mother is **Metal** (金); the **blood** (血) is **Water** (水). These two **symbols** are also **one vital breath** (一气). **Metal** is the **root** (主), **Water** is the **function** (用). When the **Four Symbols** (四象) encounter **Earth** (土), they **generate one another** (相生); when they do not, they **counteract** (相克). Now, the **mother’s Primordial Palace** (元宫) is the **true Earth** (真土). When the **Four Symbols’ *qi*** (四象之气) arrive here, they **naturally harmonize and coalesce into treasure** (自然相顺共聚为宝), giving rise to **innate nature, will, wisdom, and insight** (性意智慧).

**Wood** is **innate nature** (性); **Fire** is **will** (意); **Metal** is **wisdom** (智); **Water** is **insight** (慧).
**Wood** uses its **innate nature** (性) to **cultivate the East** (修束方甲乙), manifesting in the **liver** (肝);
