**Volume 25 of *Dao Gōng***
**太清养生上篇**
**太清养生下篇**
*Collected by Zēng Cáo in "Zhǒuhòu Sāngchéng Piān"*

The **Dao is distant as the sky**—who can ascend it?
**Pointing to the lofty steps**, yet still one must climb them stage by stage.

Master Lü Dongbin of Pure Yang declared:

*"I cultivate the Celestial Rank, and thus the Human Rank may be abandoned;
I awaken to True Emptiness, and thus the vulgar emptiness is despised.

For I know the laws of Yin and Yang’s ascent and descent within the Two Principles,
And the roots of life and nature return to the One Qi.

Its origin: there is a husband and wife;
Its departure: there are three sons and three daughters.
The Golden Son plucks the yellow sprouts from the Nine Palaces’ terrace,
The Jade Maiden gathers the white snow from the Twelve Towers.

Fire arises from water, to divide the Eight Trigrams;
Yin refines Yang within, to distinguish the Nine Regions.

Thus, the Three Fields harmonize, and the Fire Dragon emerges at the dusk crossroads—
When the thousand-day work is complete, one wanders the Penglai Isles.

Its essentials number eighteen:
Seven for the minor attainment, six for the medium attainment, five for the great attainment.

Pure Yang Master says:
One swallow, one exhale, one exhale with ten massages—
Practiced long, wrinkles diminish, the complexion glows.

This is the Heavenly Child’s immortality, the *Gèn* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

Human desires and emotions—six passions, seven sentiments—
Daily wage war within, so joy, anger, sorrow, and delight
Fester in the heart, injuring the vital qi."*

「I awaken in the morning and use my tongue to stir the saliva in my mouth,
swallowing all the foul and impure fluids, then exhale them afterward.
With both hands, I massage my face—left and right—
to disperse the stagnant *qi* of the mind, allowing the true *qi* to surge upward
and enter my face, thus restoring my youthful complexion.

Pure Yang Master says:
Massage once, then exhale once, alternating hands left and right,
until the count of ninety-nine is complete—then the pure Yang will not dissipate.
This is the method of gathering fire to boil the sea—
the *Qián* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

When one’s desires and emotions—six passions, seven sentiments—
are stirred by external things, the vital Yang is consumed,
and the true *qi* is lost.
Thus, illness and aging arise, and aging leads to death—
is this not because the root Yang is depleted and the *qi* grows weak?

At the hours of *Xū* and *Hài*,
I press and rub my navel eighty-one times,
then massage my hands eighty-one times, left and right.
In nine days, results appear; in eighty-one days, success is achieved.

Pure Yang Master says:
One inhale for every nine exhales,
retain three, release seven,
settle the breath and observe inwardly—
no matter the task, it will be accomplished.
This is the harmonization of Yin and Yang—
the *Zhèn* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

When eating and drinking,
sometimes one takes too much, sometimes too little,
and the times vary—cold or hot.
Suddenly, diseases may arise in the five *zàng* organs and six *fǔ* viscera.
I then draw in the *qi* through my nose,
until it reaches nine parts within me,
and cut off the breath by swallowing,
preventing it from flowing freely.
Closing my eyes and quieting my mind,
I retain three and release seven,
beginning to treat the illness by visualizing its location.
If the *qi* is too intense, it becomes difficult to control.

Thus, I must open my mouth and slowly exhale,
without forcing the breath.
If the illness has not yet healed,
I repeat the process until the count of three times five is reached—
no illness remains unhealed.

In daily practice at the hour of *Mǎo*,
when the Yin of the heart descends and the Yang of the kidneys ascends,
and the two *qi*s meet,
I follow the method to regulate them:
allowing the *qi* and fluids to harmonize and generate,
until results appear, then cease.

Pure Yang Master says:
Close the door and swallow upward,
press the lower *guān* and massage downward,
settle the intention and observe inwardly—
the root Yang will naturally suffice.
This is the method of gathering fire and returning to the root—
the *Qián* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

When battling external matters,
the root Yang is consumed, and the true *qi* is lost.
At the hours of *Xū* and *Hài*,
I close my mouth and swallow the *qi*,
press the lower *guān* and massage the *pángguāng*,
then gently stimulate my abdomen.
With steady focus and no distraction,
I observe inwardly and retain the thought,
directing the heart’s fire downward,
while the external kidney fire enters and unites at the *Mìngfǔ*—
when results appear, I cease.

Pure Yang Master says:
Daily, rise and repeat the coiled-knee posture,
exhale like thunder and inhale like rain,
elevate the body and observe inwardly,
sequentially applying the movements of bow and arrow.
This is the method of releasing fire to refine the form—
the *Gèn* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

The *qi* of joy, anger, grief, and delight,
accumulates in the four limbs by evening.
The blood stagnates, and the channels and collaterals become blocked.
I rise in the morning, coil my knees, and sit upright,
massaging my face with both hands from below.
I swallow the foul and impure fluids, as before.
Then, I exhale the *qi*,
tap my teeth,
to drain the accumulated *qi* of the heart and gather my spirit.
When done, I lower my body,
stretching and contracting my limbs
as if drawing a bow and loosing an arrow—
thus, the channels and collaterals open,
and the *qi* flows while the blood circulates.
With time, the illness is permanently removed;
when results appear, I cease.

Pure Yang Master says:
The return to the wife’s chamber,
the moon reaching the Yang Palace,
the bottom of the Peach Blossom Spring’s waves—
the Dragon and Tiger meeting.
This is the union of Dragon and Tiger—
the *Lí* Trigram.
What is meant by this?

Within the body, what is easily dispersed is the root *qi*;
what is difficult to generate is the true essence.
Thus, if the essence is scant,
it cannot generate *qi*;
if the *qi* is dispersed,
it cannot generate essence.
One must make the *qi* and essence unite to form semen,
then refine the semen into essence—
this is the method of *Jièjì* (completion).

At the hour of *Wǔ*,
when the kidney *qi* reaches the heart,
I prevent it from ascending further,
and let it emerge solely through the mouth—
this is the method of *Jièjì*.
Then, I hold the saliva in my mouth,
neither spitting nor swallowing,
settling my spirit and awareness inwardly,
as my breath flows gently through the nose—
thus, the kidney *qi* and the heart *qi* naturally unite,
becoming true *qi* and true essence.
The Yang Dragon and Yin Tiger,
by this union, transform into the Yellow Sprout.

Pure Yang Master says:
The Yellow Mother unites husband and wife,
the same domain where Heaven and Earth harmonize—
the Yang *guān* must be pressed.
This is the method of refining the elixir—
the *Qián* and *Kūn* Trigrams.
What is meant by this?

Within the *qi* sea,
there is true Yin and true Yang.
They yearn for each other in the spleen,
encountering the lung’s fluids to transport them,
harmonizing countless times before entering the Yellow Court.
At the hours of *Xū* and *Hài*,
I gently stimulate my abdomen—
this is the pressing of the Yang *guān*,
to prevent the *qi* from ascending and instead refine it downward.
This is but a minor attainment;
it has not yet reached the medium attainment.

Pure Yang Master says:
Three sons, three daughters,
bowing and rising to open the cosmos,
gradually ascending and storing—
pass the *guān* without haste.
This is the *Zhǒuhòu* (posture) method.
What is meant by this?」

The true *qi* and true essence—
when they unite, they descend into the elixir field.
Thus, the fire’s timing is without flaw,
nourishing the true embryo
and transforming it into pure Yang.

It begins at the hour of *Zǐ*,
after *qi* is born,
employing the *Zhǒuhòu* method
to circulate into the Upper Palace—
this is the Dao of returning essence to nourish the brain,
by which one may attain longevity and keen vision.

What are the three sons?
*Zhèn* (Thunder), *Kǎn* (Water), *Gèn* (Mountain).

What are the three daughters?
*Sūn* (Wind), *Lí* (Fire), *Duì* (Lake).

When I bow my body,
the kidneys naturally unite,
and the *qi* gathers;
when I rise,
the kidneys naturally separate,
and the *qi* disperses.

Piercing through the *wěihéng* (tailbone),
it ascends from the back,
soaring into the brain—
this cannot be achieved in a single day.
It must ascend gradually,
storing the thought of the Dragon-Tiger River Chariot,
so that it may rise from below.

Yet if the kidneys’ void-Yang enters the crown,
it will clog above and generate heat—
thus, one must pass the *guān* without haste.

Pure Yang Master says:
The young son and the elder daughter contend in flight,
the Dragon and Tiger soaring into the Heavenly Pool,
transforming into sweet rain.

This is the *Zhǒuhòu* method of flying golden crystal.
What is meant by this?

Once I apply the *Zhǒuhòu* method,
gradually ascending and storing thought,
until the kidneys’ *qi* enters the brain,
then I practice the flying golden crystal.

Thus, during the *zǐ* hour,
the kidneys’ *qi* arises,
and merges with the lungs’ *qi*.
Then the kidneys’ *qi* seeks to exchange with the liver’s *qi*.
The lungs’ *qi* stored within the kidneys—
this is the golden crystal.

At this time, with focused practice,
as before in bowing and rising,
one strike passes through the Three Passes,
entering the Upper Official,
harmonizing with the Body Sea,
sipping the Heavenly Nectar—
this is the true yin divine water.

When using *gèn* (Mountain), it is called the young son;
when using *xùn* (Wind), it is called the elder daughter.
The left of *Zhǒuhòu* is the Dragon,
the right is the Tiger;
the crown is the Heavenly Pool,
the divine water is sweet rain.
From *gèn* to *xùn*,
one strike enters the crown.

Then, refine the marrow of the crown into water.
If the spirit in the brain grows dim and sluggish,
temporarily store it in the lower body,
then shortly rise again,
entering the crown to refine it.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"Kill the husband, save the wife—
follow her mother.
Nurture with her mother,
for the Five Phases have their lords.
This is the elixir of jade nectar.
What is meant by this?"*

I observe the logic of the Five Phases:
That which generates me—
this is called the mother;
That which I generate—
this is called the son;
That which overcomes me—
this is called the husband;
That which I overcome—
this is called the wife.

If, in the month of spring,
the liver thrives while the spleen weakens,
this is wood strong and earth weak.
I then diminish the liver and strengthen the spleen.
The spleen is the mother—
the heart is its mother,
for fire generates earth.
When fire is strong,
it is the *lí* (Fire) hexagram.

The Five Phases have generation and conquest,
the Five Viscera have flourishing and decline—
thus water, wood, fire, earth, and metal
generate one another as mother and child;
fire, metal, earth, wood, and water
conquer one another as husband and wife.

If practicing the swallowing method,
one must rely on the Five Phases’ conquests.
This Dao—
after flying the golden crystal,
I practice both.

The key lies in recognizing the logic of the Five Phases.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"Fire lodges in the Dark Palace,
water aids the Elixir Platform,
before noon, ascend frequently—
the jade flower blooms of its own accord.
This is the refining of the form by jade nectar.
What is meant by this?"*

To gather herbs as elixir,
without pure Yang *qi*,
they cannot be refined.
Thus, after *Zhǒuhòu* flying golden crystal enters the brain,
refined for long,
if one fears excess,
and yin is insufficient,
then exhale the jade nectar,
refining the form instead.

Before noon, beginning in *gèn* (Mountain) time,
ascend the body to ignite fire,
refining the form.
Fire lodging in the Dark Palace—
refined by pure Yang *qi*;
water aiding the Elixir Platform—
nourished by jade nectar water.

Why ascend frequently before noon?
Refined by *qi*, ascending to fill the body,
then the blood transforms into white grease,
into jade flowers—
lustrous and pure white,
the effect of refining the form.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"When one Yang first arises,
lightly ascend and store afterward,
the Dragon coils, the Tiger encircles,
water fills the high source.
This is the elixir of golden nectar."*

What is meant by this?

The *jade nectar* elixir—its count does not exceed one hundred and eight, then swallow it immediately.
Swallowing, refining—its count varies, yet its timing lies in the four seasons.
It can nourish the Inner Elixir and burn the four limbs—this is the *golden nectar* elixir.

When the *qi* of the kidneys and the essence of the lungs enter the brain,
they transform into *shen* water.
Thus, the three pure yin *qi* meet the pure Yang above and below—this is *jièjí* [fulfilled].

From the *zǐ* [Water] hour, when the kidney *qi* is born,
one may lightly recline the spine, subtly store the body,
gather the kidney *qi*, strike the three passes once,
and enter straight into the *níwán* [mud ball],
where it merges with true marrow and transforms into *shen* water—
then it descends, like sweet dew nourishing the heart.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"After the *zǐ* hour, do not tire of frequent ascension—
golden light fills the body, yin exhausted, Yang pure.
This is the *golden nectar* refining of form."*

What is meant by this?

When the *golden essence* enters the brain, it transforms into *golden nectar*;
the *golden nectar* returns to its origin, transforming into elixir—
three times, and one may achieve longevity.

I wish to shed its husk—
when the *golden nectar* descends from the Upper Elixir Field,
I ascend the body and ignite fire,
so that true fire rises once,
meeting the *golden water* at the side of the *jade pool*—
this is called *jièjí*.

Then, one round of *golden millet* forms, as large as a grain of rice.
One elixir pearl appears, and a golden light arises,
encircling the body—this is called *golden nectar* refining of form.
When the refining of form is complete,
only then does one refine *qi* into *shen* and shed its husk.

Thus, after the *zǐ* hour,
when the kidney and lung essences strike once into the *níwán*,
and one nods and swallows,
the *golden nectar* comes naturally.
Before *jièjí*, the *golden nectar* is refined by fire—this is the elixir.

In general, after each swallow and refinement,
one should ascend frequently.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"Observing the *zhōngchéng* [middle completion],
one then knows the path to *dàchéng* [great completion] is supreme.
When the sun and moon are at their peak,
husband and wife both become immortals—
igniting fire at the proper time,
*qi* naturally ascends to the *cháoyuán* [morning origin].
This is gathering *shen* and ascending to the *cháoyuán*."*

What is meant by this?

The *jade nectar* elixir previously mentioned—
slaying the husband to save the wife,
yet seeking the mother—
I understand this already.

When the liver is strong, the spleen must be weak—why is this so?
Wood is the husband;
Earth is the wife;
Fire is the child;
Water is the mother.

If the liver is strong and the husband is slain,
one cannot exert effort below.
If the spleen is weak and the wife is slayed,
while fire is strong and the mother is sought,
the method of *separation* involves dousing it,
thus saving the spleen.

Therefore, when ascending to the *cháoyuán*,
though one does not violate the principles of the Five Phases’ mutual generation and restraint,
one must ignite fire at the proper time
to refine the *true qi*,
ensuring all *yin* is fully exhausted.

If, during the months of spring,
when the liver is strong,
one ignites fire to refine the liver,
and during the hours of *chén*, *xū*, *chǒu*, and *wèi*,
when the spleen is weak,
one ignites fire to refine the spleen,
then husband and wife both become immortals.

Now, when the liver is strong,
in its month, its day, its hour—
this is the hour of the *three unions*,
its name being *three flowers*.

The *three flowers* are the *three yangs*.
Though fire is ignited,
one still fears the lung’s strength
and harm to the liver.

At the hour of *duì*,
on days *gēng* and *xīn*,
one must not neglect this function even by a hair’s breadth.

By this analogy, the rest cannot differ!

I follow this method,
and thus the *true qi* merges with the *original qi*,
the *original qi* merges with the *true qi*,
and the *three qi* merge to transform into the *three flowers*.

Then the *three flowers* gather at the crown,
the *five qi* ascend to the *cháoyuán*,
merging into the *yang shen*,
and forming the body of *pure yang*—
this is having a body beyond the body,
abandoning the husk and ascending as an immortal.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"Cease the breath by the embryo,
generate the spirit by the qi,
retain the breath to refine the qi,
the form responds to the *true nature of Heaven*."*

And again:
*"Nurture the yang and refine the yin,
foreward reverence and backward submission,
steady the breath and observe inwardly,
sufficient counting brings forth the true*—
this is the refinement of qi into spirit.

What is meant by this?

The method of *embryonic breathing* does not lie in
the breath being few when exhaled or many when inhaled,
but in the union of *Dragon* and *Tiger*,
whereby the *spirit-embryo* is formed.

When the *spirit-embryo* is complete,
the breath naturally ceases.

Those who close the breath to refine it,
cease the breath to refine the spirit—
this is not the *Great Dao*.

I have never seen one who could succeed with this.

When the liver, heart, spleen, lungs, and kidneys are at their peak,
ascend the body and ignite fire,
lower the *sovereign fire* to its proper domain—
thus the breath flows naturally upward,
the qi does not ascend,
and the spirit does not disperse.
This requires no more than ten thousand breaths.

I refine the liver,
and a *green* hue emerges;
I refine the heart,
and a *red* hue emerges;
I refine the lungs,
and a *white* hue emerges;
I refine the kidneys,
and a *black* hue emerges;
I refine the spleen,
and a *yellow* hue emerges.

Having refined all five *zàng* organs,
each for seventy-two days with two extra,
this completes three hundred and sixty-two days of work.

Next, in one year,
one should refine each organ daily,
ascending once per day.

Now, within the state of *stillness*,
if one perceives the *carriage and cavalry* and *female musicians* in their splendid array,
one should consider that *yin* ghosts and *outer demons* may mingle with the *yang shen*—
one must practice *inner observation*,
igniting the *true fire of the three meditations*,
and burning the body,
thus exchanging the fate of mortal and immortal.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"When both inner and outer are still,
the heart is cleansed and observed inwardly,
the flames envelop the body,
and the music and revelry resound through the heavens—
this is what is called *inner observation* in the exchange of mortal and immortal."*

Within the year,
I refine all five *zàng* organs,
and thus the *five qi* ascend to the *cháoyuán*.

The month is governed by the *Purple River Vehicle*,
which enters the *Heavenly Palace*—
then *yin* demons may deceive,
posing as *carriage and cavalry*,
and emitting their *sheng* and *háng* sounds,
mingling with the *yang shen*.

Those who practice the Dao mistakenly believe this to be real,
content with their mortal form,
and thus cannot abandon their substance and become immortals.

Better to have both inner and outer still,
neither emerging nor retreating,
the heart cleansed and thoughts quieted,
observing the *Heavenly Cauldron*—
then the clouds of the *five directions* rise above,
and the *female musicians* and *carriage and cavalry* array themselves below.

These *yin* demons are false—
who would call them true?

My *pure yang spirit* is called *Heaven’s True Nature*,
the *original sovereign of Heaven*.

At this time,
returning to its original form,
the *true spirit* guards and protects,
retreating to the inner chambers of the *Heavenly Palace*—
thus one can abandon the husk and leave the *dusty nest*.

If one does not discern truth from falsehood
and harms the *yang shen*,
one will become mad and easy to sway,
wandering in perverse ways,
and will not escape death.

Though the form may not decay,
what benefit is there to the Dao?

Thus, during *inner observation*,
one must not tire of ascending the body and igniting fire—
then the false will disperse,
and the true will ascend.

Fire has three names:
*burning the body*,
*subduing demons*,
and *ascending to Heaven*—
the *cháoyuán* of the day.

Once one has reached the *Heavenly Palace*,
it is essential to regulate the spirit with proper method.

Pure Yang Master says:
*"Seven-layered *jewel pagoda*,
three-tiered *red mansion*—
when the time comes, do not fear,
for once it emerges, it is hard to retrieve.*
This is the return and emergence of the spirit,
what is called *regulating the spirit*."

The regulation of the spirit to emerge from its husk
must occur on the day of the *Heavenly Palace*,
through *inner observation*.

The *red mansion* is the *three fields*;
the *jewel pagoda* is the *seven qi*.

From below upward,
once reaching the top,
one must not be afraid.

If the *yang shen* is not pure,
*yin* ghosts will mingle with it.

Thus, the count of fire
is not a matter of excess.

If the *true qi* is not firm,
when the body emerges,
it is easily startled—
the gathering is dispersed,
and the body returns,
which is difficult indeed!

Thus the ancient *perfected ones* had the appearance
of *unfastened robes and unbound hair*.

If one desires to attain without fear,
and to emerge yet easily return,
nothing surpasses
the three hundred days of *herb gathering* and *fire regulation*,
and the five hundred days of *form refinement* and *qi merging*—
ascending and descending with measured count.

When igniting fire within the water,
even after the elixir,
one need not fear its excess.

Thus the demons scatter while the spirit gathers—
no need for crimson towers or precious pagodas.

Only by contemplating within the Yellow Court,
do the Five Clouds converge,
and the Fire Dragon leaps forth
amidst crimson light and violet qi,
straight out into the dim thoroughfares.

When it emerges, it fears nothing.
When it passes, it does not disperse.

My outer body has another body—
like a younger brother—
only then can one speak of the Dao of dividing form.

Thus, before completing the prior work,
how could one divide form and emerge?

This Dao is difficult beyond measure.

If the yin spirits do not disperse within meditation,
and mistakenly exit through the Celestial Gate,
then one cannot be a Pure Yang Immortal.

Pure Yang Child said:
*"Once the Fire Dragon emerges,
one must recognize the Golden Light—
coming and going without hesitation,
quickly reaching the Immortal Realm—
this is the transcendence of dividing form."*

When the elixir is complete,
true qi arises naturally;
true qi arises, and the yang spirit gathers naturally.

How does the spirit gather?
It clings to the qi.
How does the qi gather?
It clings to the elixir.

When the spirit emerges, it takes qi as form;
when the spirit returns, it halts the qi with form.

Its emergence is like a cicada’s molt.
Thus its husk—
if left in great rivers, yields pearls;
if hidden in famous mountains, yields jade;
if dwelling in the world, moves freely at ease.

Some, weary of the world, depart—
summoning yin spirits to ride phoenixes and dragons,
and attend at Taiwei.

The sovereign of Taiwei examines their merit,
and grants passage—
from the Lower Isle to the Middle Isle,
from the Middle Isle to the Upper Isle;
when their merit is complete, they return to the Cavern Heavens.

As the *Zhouyi* *Jinzi* says:
*"The Creative governs its beginning,
the Receptive encompasses its end;
this diminutive form
moves easily within."*

The Daoist Zhang Hugong, surnamed Huangzi,
in the Xianfu era, over seventy years old,
went to Yue to seek the recluse Zhou Cheng but did not meet him.
Instead, he saw the bridge attendant, the water spirit Li Bai,
who gave him this text, saying:
*"At the head, seven orifices;
throughout the body, four limbs—
the Creative and Receptive are fixed.
The Creative governs its beginning,
the Receptive encompasses its end—
nobility and lowliness are set.
Yin descends to six,
yang ascends to nine—
the firm and yielding are determined."*

Awakening opens with yang, closing with yin—thus fortune and misfortune arise.
Pure yin seeks the male, pure yang the female—thus transformation becomes manifest.

The nine orifices resonate together,
the five viscera communicate,
the six palaces mutually rely,
the three palaces mutually govern,
the eight trigrams mutually support,
the five phases mutually illuminate.

Balance it with the eldest son,
operate it with the youngest daughter,
shape it with the aged vessel,
name it with the crone,
weaken it with the infant,
harmonize it with the wet nurse.

Ears and eyes are pivotal,
mouth and nose are auxiliary,
saliva and fluids are balanced,
marrow and bones are firm,
the palaces are luminous,
spirit and soul are protected.

When yang matures, it becomes Father;
when yin matures, it becomes Mother.

The earth yields the *liquor* spring,
the heavens descend sweet dew.

Fire is born of wood,
metal is born of water.

Life arises from spirit,
death arises from the ghostly.

Spirit ascends to celestial patterns,
the ghostly descends to earthly forms.

Wood is the mother of fire,
water is the child of metal.

Two woods form a forest—brothers;
two fires form a blaze—sisters.

Wood is the wife of metal,
water is the husband of fire.

Lead is the lineage of fire,
mercury is the ancestor of water.

Lead is easily known,
mercury is simply skilled.

When easily known, lead returns;
when simply skilled, mercury returns.

Lead’s return brings affinity,
mercury’s return brings efficacy.

Affinity ensures longevity,
efficacy ensures greatness.

When simplicity is attained,
then the celestial chamber is established.

Thus, the Daoist observes the body as the *Hexagram*,
studies nature as the *pharmacon*,
with the sun and moon urging,
wind and rain pressing close—
the azure dragon cradles the furnace,
the flying *Lian* beats the cauldron,
the elixir glows resplendent,
the metallic essence shimmers,
melting into rivers,
congealing into peaks.

Refining *qi* here,
separating the clear and turbid;
binding the *Word* here,
illuminating life and death.

Yin and yang return,
balancing transformation;
darkness and clarity alternate,
following day and night;
water and fire chase,
determining high and low.

Thus, *Zhen* is movement—the *Qinglong* symbol;
*Li* is adornment—the *Zhuque* symbol;
*Dui* is joy—the *Baihu* symbol;
*Kan* is abyss—the *Xuanwu* symbol;
*Sun* is compliance—the *Tengshe* symbol;
*Gen* is stillness—the *Goucheng* symbol.

Thus, the Daoist’s dwelling is secure in the *Qinglong* palace,
his delight is in the *Baihu* carriage,
his opening is in the celestial union,
his closure is in the earthly shoulder.

Thus, to the left, observe the dragon and bind the east;
to the right, observe the tiger and play in the west;
to the south, observe the sun and rest at noon;
to the north, observe the moon and play at midnight.

Thus, heaven aids him—
fortune knows no obstruction.

Wood is *Jia-Yi*,
fire is *Bing-Ding*,
water is *Ren-Gui*,
metal is *Geng-Xin*,
earth is *Wu-Ji*.

*Yin-Mao* harms earth,
*Si-Wu* harms metal,
*Shen-You* harms wood,
*Hai-Zi* harms fire,
the four seasons harm water.

Thus, the ears’ alignment lies in *Gen*,
the eyes’ division lies in *Kan*,
the nose’s discernment lies in *Zhen*,
the mouth’s verification lies in *Dui*,
the yin’s leakage lies in *Li*,
the yang’s seepage lies in *Sun*.

Thus, the body has high and low,
*qi* has waxing and waning,
nature has firmness and emptiness,
things have decline and flourishing.

The *Dao* points to its destination;
*virtue* points to its action.

Nature aligns with heaven and earth,
lifespan matches heaven and earth,
law parallels heaven and earth.

Thus, knowing the root of heaven and earth,
recognizing the desires of parents.

Father’s essence is *hun* (spirit),
Mother’s blood is *po* (ethereal soul).

Do not scatter the *hun*,
do not separate the *po*—
thus, above, recognize celestial mechanisms,
below, penetrate human schemes,
enjoying the longevity of metal and stone,
transforming the flesh into gold and jade!

When the ears lose *Gen*, they cannot hear;
when the eyes lose *Kan*, they cannot see;
when the nose loses *Zhen*, they cannot smell;
when the mouth loses *Dui*, they cannot speak;
when the leakage loses *Li*, they cannot move;
when the seepage loses *Sun*, they cannot eat.

Thus, the sun has *hun*,
the moon has *po*.

To weave heaven and earth is *wen* (pattern),
one yin and one yang is *Dao* (Way).

To scorch is fire,
to moisten is water;
to warm is to seek dryness,
to follow is to seek dampness;
to command is by resonant harmony,
to steam is by mutual *qi* seeking.

When hidden, it is the *Potential Dragon*;
when revealed, it is the *Apparent Dragon*;
when nurtured with joy, it is the *Human Dragon*;
when called, it leaps—the *Leaping Dragon*;
when floated, it ascends—the *Flying Dragon*;
when elevated, it soars—the *Ascendant Dragon*.

The six dragons ride the times without constraint,
the common folk use them unknowingly—
thus, the *Junzi’s* Way endures,
the petty Way fades;
superior and inferior communicate,
and purpose is fulfilled;
heaven and earth respond,
and life emerges.

Manifest to the sage,
concealed in practice—
refining yang while diminishing yin,
the true water’s function is born,
the true fire’s function is wondrous.

The *Mao* position is true fire;
the *You* position is true water.

The fire-womb position is *Zi*,
the water-womb position is *Wu*,
the western flank position is the sun,
the eastern remnant position is the moon,
the northwest tilt position is *Qian*,
the southern void position is *Xun*.

*Qian* terminates at *Shangjiu*—*Gen*,
*Kun* terminates at *Shangliu*—*Xun*.

To cut at *Si* is *逆* (perverse),
to cut at *Hai* is *顺* (compliant).

Dragon and tiger consorting is *xian* (transcendence),
yin and yang unfathomable is *shen* (divinity).

Speaking of heaven, it does not decay;
speaking of earth, it does not sink;
speaking of fire, it does not extinguish;
speaking of water, it does not exhaust;
speaking of wood, it does not rot;
speaking of metal, it does not corrode.

The *Qian* is pure in its closure, true in its opening—thus great life arises from it;
The *Kun* is even in its closure, wondrous in its opening—thus broad life arises from it.

Ears correspond to *Jia-Xu*,
eyes to *Jia-Zi*,
nose to *Jia-Yin*,
mouth to *Jia-Shen*,
the *Xie* (urinary) to *Jia-Wu*,
the *Lòu* (menstrual) to *Jia-Chen*.

The Dao is subtle indeed—
thus the *xian* (transcendent) uses it to cultivate nature;
The Dao is silent indeed—
thus the *zhenren* (true person) takes it to preserve life.

When nature is cultivated, it becomes empty—
empty, it clears and mirrors Heaven;
When life is preserved, it becomes harmonious—
harmonious, it is wondrous and follows Earth.

Heaven sends sweet rain,
Earth grows grasses and trees,
Mountains and marshes circulate *qi*,
Dragons and serpents rise from the land.

Parents form the body—
the Dao operates within it;
Sun and moon transform their essence—
the Dao nourishes within it.

Lead and mercury endure—
the gate of nature and life;
Dragon and tiger persist—
the source of nature and life.

The *xian* perceives the luminous *Shangdantian*—
thus called *Shangqing* (Upper Clarity);
The *xian* perceives the flickering *Zhongdantian*—
thus called *Zhongqing* (Middle Clarity);
The *xian* perceives the congealed *Xiadantian*—
thus called *Xiàqing* (Lower Clarity).

The *Xuánwǔ* (Black Tortoise) Upper Pass cannot be opened;
The *Gōuchén* (Worm) Middle Pass cannot be split;
The *Qīnglóng* (Green Dragon) Lower Pass cannot be revealed.

The White Tiger’s Upper Corpse cannot be nourished;
The Vermilion Bird’s Middle Corpse cannot be detained;
The *Téngshé* (Soaring Serpent) Lower Corpse cannot be kept.

Close it, and inner stillness arises;
Open it, and outer movement arises.

Opening and closing must manifest in transformation—
transformation determines nature and life.

The *wūhè* (owl) in the yin—
its child responds to it;
I have a fine cup—
let us polish it together.

It is said:
The true person lowers its dragon and draws forth its spirit-sword—
then a thousand *li* away, it responds;
how much closer does it answer!

It subdues its tiger and raises its spirit-torch—
then ten thousand *li* away, it follows;
how much closer does it follow!

The sword lowers its dragon,
the torch subdues its tiger.

Dragon and tiger are the chariot of the divine and transcendent;
When the chariot is assembled, it is the master of ascending to Heaven.

The divine and transcendent are the gateways of dragon and tiger;
When the gateways open, it is the mechanism of entering and exiting.

*Tóngrén* (harmonizing people) first weeps and then laughs.

It is said:
From the mundane to the sacred—
the path of the *xian*;
From Earth to Heaven—
the path of the *zhenren*.

Dragon and tiger in harmony—
Heaven and Earth become gold;
Water and fire mingling—
the Milky Way forms.

Do not leave the courtyard—
no blame.

It is said:
The three delusions arise—
the six obstructions take root.
Hearing lewd sounds—
loses hearing;
Seeing splendid colors—
loses sight;
Smelling fragrant scents—
loses thought;
Speaking much—
loses resolve.

Yin movement loses true essence,
Yang dispersion loses primordial *qi*.

Thus the true person embraces and does not act,
is cautious and does not reveal.

Ears and eyes are deceived by allure,
mouth and nose by greed,
lust and desire by exhaustion,
thought and deliberation by turmoil.

The domain of ghosts and spirits,
the lure of thieves and bandits.

The five positions harmonize—
each has its union,
thus transformation is complete,
and spirits are moved.

It is said:
A hundred methods of *jīndān* (elixir) exist—
its essence lies in *shuǐhuá* (spirit-water) and *huáichí* (flower-pool);
A hundred methods of divine transcendence exist—
its essence lies in *bàoyī shǒuzhōng* (embracing unity, guarding the center).

*Kǎn* symbolizes water,
*Zhèn* symbolizes wood,
*Duì* symbolizes metal,
*Lí* symbolizes fire.

The four symbols are the medicines,
the two *qi* are the furnace—
refine them, then they become empty;
ingest them, and they ascend.

Nine orifices, five viscera—
the body harmonizes, each in its place;
Seven emotions established—
each has its completion;
Ten thousand things hidden in function—
each has its analogy;
Thousand spirits internally supported—
each has its guardian.

Heaven’s numbers proceed in order,
Earth’s numbers are taken in reverse.

The white-gold register,
the green-jade talisman,
the black-water contract,
the vermilion-fire diagram—
these can free one from the dusty world
and enter the layered heavens.

The *Yán Dì* (Flame Emperor) dwells at *Wu*,
the *Hēi Dì* (Black Emperor) at *Zi*,
the *Qīng Dì* (Green Emperor) at *Mǎo*,
the *Bái Dì* (White Emperor) at *Yǒu*.

When the initial yang rises,
pure yin must align with Heaven and Earth—
drawing the essence of dragon and tiger.

Thus the four spirits enter the cauldron,
nine transformations forge the elixir—
boil it and nourish it,
flow it and ingest it.

The common person’s *qi* contains four Daoist methods;
The common person’s body contains five Daoist foundations.

Those who do not cultivate their nature—
are solid yet not empty,
muddled yet not harmonious;
Those who do not preserve their spirit—
are separated yet not united,
called yet not answered;
Those who do not cherish life—
are turbid yet not clear,
active yet not tranquil;
Those who do not refine their heart—
are sick yet not healed,
worn yet not repaired.

Thus it is said: the common person’s *qi* contains four Daoist methods—
this is what is meant.

Those who uphold the virtue of metal—
revere the lungs;
Those who uphold the virtue of water—
revere the kidneys;
Those who uphold the virtue of wood—
revere the liver;
Those who uphold the virtue of fire—
revere the heart;
Those who uphold the virtue of earth—
revere the spleen.

Thus the *xian* prepares to act,
prepares to move.

Their abandonment of color is like mud,
their restraint of emotion is like discarding,
their preservation of purity is like madness,
their nourishing of resolve is like a tortoise.

The utmost essence is not lost—
to preserve in the lungs at the Golden Hall,
what but Heaven’s white essence could suffice here?
Thunderous lightning shatters mountains,
great winds shake the seas,
music halts the clouds,
bells and drums stir the earth—
majestic yet tranquil,
lofty yet solitary,
external sounds do not enter—
to preserve in the kidneys at the Pearl Palace,
what but Heaven’s black essence could suffice here?

The vast is not seen in *Tàishān* (Great Mountain),
the minute is not seen in autumnal down,
patterns are not admired for their brilliance,
eyes do not gaze upon rouge and powder.

「Black and white, if not distinguished,
right and wrong, if not discerned,
are but the common brightness of the multitude—
yet alone in dimness, alone in clarity.

Alone in profound stillness,
penetrating insight within,
resolute light unscattered—
to preserve in the heart at the Vermilion Terrace,
what but Heaven’s crimson essence could suffice here?

Not indulging in the five flavors,
not craving the eight delicacies,
unafraid of great floods,
unworried by severe droughts—
magnificent, as though feasting at a splendid banquet,
vast, as though reaping rich harvests from fertile fields.

Without thought, without action,
without seeking or avoiding,
plentiful yet never lean,
content yet never hungry—
stillness without motion—
to preserve in the spleen at the Jade Chamber,
what but Heaven’s yellow essence could suffice here?

Speechless yet trustworthy,
unsmiling yet joyful,
divine essence moves without haste yet swift,
physical form governs without rigidity yet strict—
the utmost bliss is soundless—
to preserve in the liver at its Azure Tower,
what but Heaven’s azure essence could suffice here?

Thus it is said: the common body of mortals
holds the five roots of the immortal.
This is what is meant.

Ears are *Lù* (六), eyes are *Èr* (二),
nose is *Lùsān* (六三), mouth is *Lùsì* (六四),
yin is *Lùwǔ* (六五), yang is *Shàngliù* (上六).
Mortal man, the root of death.

Yang is *Chūjiǔ* (初九), yin is *Jiǔèr* (九二),
mouth is *Jiǔsān* (九三), nose is *Jiǔsì* (九四),
eyes are *Jiǔwǔ* (九五), ears are *Shàngjiǔ* (上九).
True man, the root of life.

Behold the dragon’s form—
scaled and verdant;
the tiger’s nature—
furred and white;
the sun’s spirit—
daytime and ardent;
the moon’s shadow—
nighttime and frigid.

With this, cultivate the heart,
retreat and conceal with caution.
When Heaven and Earth unite, it is called *Tàipíng* (泰平, Great Harmony);
when sun and moon pursue each other, it is called *Yì* (易, Transformation).
Earthly *qi* ascends, Heavenly *qi* descends.
The sun at its zenith returns, the moon at full wanes.
When the dragon breathes, clouds arise;
when the tiger roars, winds stir.
Pure *qi* ascends to Heaven, yang rises above;
impure *qi* descends to Earth, yin sinks below.
Who could match this?

The discourse says:
The Metal Sovereign is called *Qiān* (铅),
the Wood Sovereign is called *Gǒng* (汞).
Yellow Mother is called True Earth,
Heaven and Earth are called the Furnace,
yin and yang are called the Charcoal,
*Kàn-Lí* (坎离) are called the Medicinals.
Child and Horse are called Advance and Retreat,
Water and Fire are called Action and Reaction,
Rat and Rooster are called Withdrawal and Addition,
Circulation is called the River Chariot,
Clarity is called Heaven,
Alcohol’s refinement is called Golden Flower.

Jade Nectar, distinct, is called Azure Frost and Vermilion Snow,
Nourished, it is called Infant;
Surprised, it is called Yellow Sprout;
The Great Medicine ripens, it is called Nine Transformations;
Cinnabar is perfected, it is called Rebirth,
Infant is marvelous, it is called Spirit,
The light of things is called Treasure Pearl.

Thus, the *Qi* Sea congeals into the Nectar Sea,
the Nectar Sea congeals into the Blood Sea,
the Blood Sea congeals into the Essence Sea,
the Essence Sea congeals into the Bone Sea,
the Bone Sea congeals into the Spirit Sea,
the Spirit Sea congeals into the True Sea.

Therefore, to nourish the sinews, nothing surpasses the liver;
to nourish the *qi*, nothing surpasses the lungs;
to nourish the flesh, nothing surpasses the spleen;
to nourish the marrow, nothing surpasses the kidneys;
to nourish the vessels, nothing surpasses the heart;
to nourish life, nothing surpasses paternal essence,
to nourish nature, nothing surpasses maternal blood.

Thus, the body has nine orifices—
the sage seals them;
the body has five viscera—
the sage refines them;
the body has three passways—
the sage harmonizes them;
the body has three corpses—
the sage annihilates them;
the body has myriad worries—
the sage purges them;
the body has myriad demons—
the sage subdues them;
the body has myriad diseases—
the sage overcomes them;
the body has ten evils—
the sage excises them.

Thus, the heart’s office holds the King,
so it rules without action;
the liver’s office holds the Minister,
so it attains without thought;
the lungs’ office holds the Elder,
so they come without summoning;
the gallbladder’s office holds the General,
so it commands without anger;
the spleen’s office holds the Scholar,
so it acts without orders;
the kidneys’ office holds the Chaste Woman,
so it stops without restraint.

Dragon essence, where the spirit resides—
tiger might, where the shadow dwells—
when dragon essence shines, a fire pearl glows before it;
when tiger might trembles, a water pearl radiates behind it.
If dragon essence is lost, there is no way to see the spirit;
if the spirit is unseen, the fire pearl nearly vanishes.
If tiger might is extinguished, there is no way to see the shadow;
if the shadow is unseen, the water pearl nearly sinks.

Thus, the *Xùn* (巽) advance of *Chūjiǔ* (初九) is called *Bùlòu* (不漏, Unleaking);
the *Lí* (离) advance of *Jiǔèr* (九二) is called *Bùyán* (不言, Speechless);
the *Zhèn* (震) retreat of *Chūliù* (初六) is called *Bùdòng* (不动, Unmoving);
the *Kàn* (坎) retreat of *Liùèr* (六二) is called *Bùkuī* (不窥, Unpeering);
the *Gèn* (艮) retreat of *Liùsān* (六三) is called *Bùwén* (不闻, Unhearing).

Three yangs guarding the form are called *Zhàngfū* (丈夫, True Man),
three yins transforming the form are called *Nánzǐ* (男子, Man).
Seven orifices unmoving are called *Hùndùn* (混沌, Chaos);
two *qi*s interacting are called *Yīnyūn* (氤氲, Misting);
black and white forming substance are called *Dàbǎo* (大宝, Great Treasure);
emptiness generating nature is called *Yuánshén* (元神, Primordial Spirit.

Blocked yet emptied, it resides in *Shàonián Gèn* (少男艮, Young Male);
united yet illuminated, it resides in *Zhōngnán Kàn* (中男坎, Middle Male);
severed yet harmonized, it resides in *Zhǎngnán Zhèn* (长男震, Elder Male);
gathered yet enriched, it resides in *Shàonǚ Duì* (少女兑, Young Female);
converged yet restored, it resides in *Zhōngnǚ Lí* (中女离, Middle Female);
closed yet compliant, it resides in *Zhǎngnǚ Xùn* (长女巽, Elder Female).

Thus, in man’s birth, *Tàipíng* (泰平, Great Harmony) is within him;
in man’s death, *Pǐ* (否, Blockage) is within him.
Ears that do not hear, Heaven’s black essence is within them;
eyes that do not see, Heaven’s azure essence is within them;
nose that does not smell, Heaven’s white essence is within it;
mouth that does not speak, Heaven’s crimson essence is within it;
yin that does not move, Earthly essence is within it;
yang that does not disperse, Heavenly essence is within it.»

The numinous and illuminated, the lofty paths of Heaven are thus unobstructed;
silent yet perfected, all undertakings of the world are fulfilled.

The divine essence of the East is the bones and sinews;
the divine essence of the South is the breath and *qi*;
the divine essence of the West is the meridians and vessels;
the divine essence of the North is the blood and vessels;
the divine essence of the Center is the flesh and muscles.

*Jiǎo Gāng* (角亢) shines as the light of the Azure Dragon;
*Dǒu Niú* (斗牛) shines as the light of the Dark Tortoise;
*Kuí Lóu* (奎娄) shines as the light of the White Tiger;
*Jǐng Guǐ* (井鬼) shines as the light of the Vermilion Bird.

*Fáng* (房) is the central palace of the Wood Star;
*Xū* (虚) is the central palace of the Water Star;
*Shù* (壮) is the central palace of the Metal Star;
*Xīng* (星) is the central palace of the Fire Star.

The teeth and jaws are the remnants of the Azure Dragon;
the claws and nails are the remnants of the White Tiger;
the hair and fur are the remnants of the Dark Tortoise;
the breath is the remnant of the Vermilion Bird.

Sound is the remnant of Heaven;
shadow is the remnant of Earth.

*Qián* (乾) stands majestic before all—it embodies the *One*;
*Kūn* (坤) blends harmoniously before all—it embraces the *One*.

The Five Thieves are the plunderers of these;
the Three Fields are the cultivators of these.

The cultivation of *zhī* (芝, reishi mushrooms) arises from *yángxū* (阳虚, the void of yang);
The cultivation of *yù* (玉, jade) arises from *yángxiù* (阳秀, the refined yang).

Medicinal efficacy is perfected within;
Divine communication manifests without.

Accumulated *yīn* (阴) scatters the minor;
Accumulated *yáng* (阳) reaches the supreme.

To move Heaven and Earth, to awaken spirits and gods—none excel the *yuánjīng* (元精, primordial essence);
To traverse water and fire, to pierce metal and stone—none surpass *zhìlǐ* (至理, ultimate principle);
To bless ten thousand peoples, to prolong the Nine Regions—none surpass *zhēnqì* (真气, true *qi*);
To refine the Five Spirits, to establish the Four Extremes—none precede *shényòng* (神用, spiritual application).

What fortifies the hundred bones? None surpass *zhēnjīn* (真金, true gold);
What strengthens the hundred sinews? None surpass *zhēnmù* (真木, true wood);
What circulates the hundred vessels? None excel *zhēnshuǐ* (真水, true water);
What elevates the hundred spirits? None overcome *zhēnhuǒ* (真火, true fire);
What fills the hundred joints? None rival *zhēntǔ* (真土, true earth).

How does one preserve the body? By avoiding labor.
How does one preserve life? By avoiding desire.
How does one cultivate nature? By avoiding thought.
How does one govern the spirit? By avoiding deceit.

Thus, the True Person abounds in *yáng* yet lacks *yīn*;
The common person abounds in *yīn* yet lacks *yáng*.
It is not that they lack *yīn*—rather, *yīn* transforms and returns to pure *yáng*;
It is not that they lack *yáng*—rather, *yáng* transforms and returns to pure *yīn*.
Pure *yáng* is the *qi* of the Immortal;
Pure *yīn* is the *qi* of the Ghost.
When the Immortal’s essence is perfected, it dwells in the realm of *yáng*;
When the Ghost’s essence is complete, it dwells in the realm of *yīn*.

Thus, the Immortal has no shadow at noon, no boundary in snow,
Crosses water without drowning, enters fire without burning,
Walks the void without falling, penetrates mountains unseen,
Is unharmed by blades, unaffected by poisons—
Ten thousand demons tremble, ten thousand spirits follow:
For they draw upon the *qi* of pure *yáng*.

The common person, when walking, is sluggish and clogged;
When stationary, is obstructed and congested;
A thousand worries gather, a thousand ailments fester;
Above, distant from the Celestial Gate; below, near the Earthly Door;
Encountering light, they awaken; seeing darkness, they dim;
Wisdom does not flow, desires do not cease;
Exhausted, they forget to return—thus they pass away:
For they draw upon the *qi* of pure *yīn*.

The white lungs correspond above to *Tàibái* (太白, Venus);
The red heart corresponds above to *Yínghuò* (荧惑, Mars);
The green liver corresponds above to *Suìxīng* (岁星, Jupiter);
The yellow spleen corresponds above to *Zhènxīng* (镇星, Saturn);
The black kidneys correspond above to *Chénxīng* (辰星, Mercury).

The *Huángdào* (黄道, ecliptic) corresponds above to the *Tàiyáng* (太阳, Sun);
The *Báidào* (白道, moon’s path) corresponds above to the *Tàiyǐn* (太阴, Moon).
Day governs life, corresponding above to *Nánchēn* (南辰, Southern Asterism);
Night governs death, corresponding above to *Běichēn* (北辰, Northern Asterism).
Thus, the Sage refines human affairs below and aligns with Heaven’s will above.

To listen to extremes brings deafness;
To gaze to extremes brings blindness;
To sniff to extremes brings obstruction;
To speak to extremes brings dimness;
To exhaust flow brings depletion;
To drain dissipation brings termination.
This is why one abandons the Six Extremes for the Five Blessings.

To speak of supreme hearing is to hear within;
To speak of supreme clarity is to see within;
To speak of true *qi* is to nurture within;
To speak of ultimate sound is to circulate within;
To speak of *yángjīng* (阳精, yang essence) is to refine within;
To speak of *yīnzhì* (阴滓, yin dregs) is to purge within.

The most robust in the world is the *hǔ* (虎, tiger);
The most compliant in the world is the *lóng* (龙, dragon);
The most divine in the world is the *dàyào* (大药, Great Elixir).

The Nine Saints illuminate externally—the *Bāguà* (八卦, Eight Trigrams);
The Nine Orifices illuminate internally—the *Bāguà*.
To cultivate them is to achieve longevity and clear vision.

*Dàochu* (道枢, *Dao* Pivot) Volume Twenty-Five concludes here.

*(Note: "花" [flower] omitted in *Jíyào* edition.)*
*(Original: "功成" [achievement complete], corrected to "成功" [successful] in *Jíyào*.)*
