**Volume 28: *Tàiqīng Yǎngshēng* (太清养生) – Upper and Lower Chapters**

**Volume 28: *Tàiqīng Yǎngshēng* (太清养生) – Upper Chapter**

Collected by the wandering scholar Zēng Càng.

Ancient elixirs of precision emerged from the *Tàiqīng*—
First to dispel sickness, finally to awaken the numinous.

**Master Chìsōngzǐ** said:
Crossing the hands above the head, then drawing the head down to the earth,
Five inhalations and five exhalations—
This can stop distended *qi*.

Crossing the hands before the chest and abdomen,
Shaking the head left and right without pause until exhaustion—
This can draw the face and ears inward,
Preventing malevolent *qi* from entering.

Crossing the hands beneath the waist,
Shaking left and right until exhaustion—
This can harmonize the blood vessels.

Crossing the hands before the chest,
Stretching left and right to their limits—
This can dispel the vexing *qi* within the skin.

**Master Yùshēng** said:
Cultivating *qi* is the treatment of the internal;
Guiding and drawing is the treatment of the external.

Facing east, releasing the hair, gripping firmly without pause—
One cycle, raising the head,
Guiding left and right while covering the ears with the hands—
This can prevent hair from turning white.

Pinching the pulse at the neck’s edge,
Two cycles—
This can sharpen the eyesight.

Facing east while seated, without pause for three cycles,
Covering the nostrils with the hands—
This can treat nasal polyps.

Sitting upright, moving naturally,
Shaking the arms left and right without pause for twelve cycles—
This can cure exhaustion and water retention.

Lying on either side without pause for twelve cycles,
If illness is on the right, lie on the right side; if on the left, lie on the left—
This can dispel illness.

At dawn and midday when the sun sets,
Facing the sun and standing upright without pause for nine cycles,
Tipping the head back to absorb the sun’s luminous *qi* and swallowing it—
This can augment the essence.

Crossing the hands beneath the chin,
Extending to the limits of the lung-*qi*—
This can stop violent coughing.

Raising the hands above the head and clasping them,
Extending to their limits—
This can treat rib pain.

Extending the left hand, placing the right beneath it,
Grasping the left thumb and extending to its limit;
Extending the right hand, placing the left beneath it,
Grasping the right thumb and extending to its limit—
This can cure joint pain.

Drawing the right hand from above the head downward,
Then pulling the hand downward again—
This can cure stiffness preventing neck rotation.

Bending the hands backward like a drawn bow,
Extending to their limits—
This can supplement the deficient *qi* of the five *zàng*-organs.

Sitting on the ground, crossing the feet,
Inserting the hands between the bent knees,
Lowering the head and crossing it above—
This can dispel chronic cold.

Facing east while seated, tipping the head back,
Without pause for five cycles,
Using the tongue to scrape the mouth,
Swallowing the saliva in multiples of seven—
This can stop dryness and bitterness in the mouth.

Lowering the head to gaze downward,
Without pause for twelve cycles—
This can heal wind-induced scabs, scabies, and malignant sores.

Squatting northward, pulling the toes with the hands—
This can weaken the *fú*-organs’ stagnation, atrophy, and contracted sinews.

Squatting, inserting the hands between the bent knees,
Pressing the feet to the ground and bending them,
Adding pressure with the hands and lifting the *fú*-organs—
This can dissolve urinary dribbling and genital pain.

Sitting upright, crossing the hands behind the back—
Called *Dàifù*—
This can facilitate bowel movements and treat emaciation.

Using one hand to pull a rope upward,
The other to hold the foot—
This can dissolve chronic hemorrhoids.

Sitting with legs stretched straight,
Crossing the hands and pulling the feet to their limits—
This can cure intestinal blockage and reverse vomiting.

Grasping a rope in both hands, performing the *Yúluán Dàoxuán* inversion,
Turning upside down so the feet are above—
This can cure vertigo, wind-induced seizures, and epilepsy.

**Master Péngzǔ** said:
Guiding and drawing should be practiced from *Zǐ* to *Leǎng*—
Avoid eating to repletion or bathing afterward.

Pulling the feet left and right,
Five breaths—
This can draw the abdomen’s *qi* downward, eliminating hernia and benefiting the nine orifices.

Tipping the toes upward,
Five breaths—
This can mobilize the lumbar spine, spleen, and hemiplegia.

Crossing the hands inward,
Five breaths—
This can draw lung-*qi* downward, stopping coughing and reverse breathing.

Raising the hands to the knees,
Placing them over the heart,
Five breaths—
This can cure lumbar pain.

**Master Wángzǐ Qiáo** said:
Pillow raised four *cùn*,
Feet apart five *cùn*,
Hands three *cùn* from the body,
Unbinding the hair, lying straight on the back,
Thoughts undisturbed—
Inhale slowly through the nose,
Exhale through the mouth,
Directing the *qi* to each *zàng*-organ in turn,
Ending and beginning anew.
When resting, first reach the limit before stopping;
Do not force prolonged breathing.
With prolonged practice, the breath will lengthen naturally.

Let the *qi*’s movement be inaudible to the ears—
As if present, yet as if still—
Do this until the hundred vessels pulse and the abdomen resonates.

What ailment shall the practitioner not overcome?

In guiding and drawing:
The *xū* (deficient) should close the eyes;
The *shí* (replete) may open them.

The *xū* should be supplemented;
The *shí* should be drained.

Inhaling through the mouth and exhaling through the nose—this is supplementation;
Closing the mouth and swallowing warm *qi*—this is drainage.

For illness in the chest, raise the pillow seven *cùn*;
For illness beneath the heart, raise it four *cùn*;
For illness below the navel, remove the pillow.

For neck ailments, tilt the head back;
For foot ailments, raise the toes;
For chest ailments, pull the toes;
For arm ailments, cover the arms;
To dispel abdominal cold-heat or whole-body heat, close the *qi* and distend the abdomen.

On the left flank, inhaling through the mouth and exhaling through the nose—
This can dispel stagnant accumulations vexing the heart.

Sitting and stretching the waist,
Slowly inhaling through the nose,
Using the right hand to hold it—
This can dispel dim vision, eye protrusions, nasal polyps, and deafness.

「Right flank lying down, inhale *qi* through the nose, and swallow warmly through the mouth seventy times, then rub the left and right hands together to generate heat, and use them to massage the abdomen, urging *qi* to descend and exit through the lower body. After seven breaths, cease—this can dispel flank and skin pains.

Lying on the back without a pillow, standing with both feet, inhaling *qi* through the nose sixteen times, then exhaling gently through the nose—
When inhaling, do not close the nostrils, and when the breath reaches its limit, this can dispel internal body heat and back ailments.

Sitting upright with hands crossed behind the knees, close the *qi* and distend the abdomen, repeating twice seven or thrice seven times. When the *qi* is full, exhale—thus all *qi* flows freely. Practiced for ten years, this can reverse aging and restore youth.

Sitting upright, stretch the arms as if drawing a full bow, to treat numbness and stiffness in the limbs and back.

Sitting upright, stretch the waist, raise the right hand with palm upturned, and support the left flank with the left hand. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel stomach cold and indigestion.

Sitting upright, stretch the waist, raise the left hand with palm upturned, and support the right flank with the right hand. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel blood stasis and *qi* blockages.

Lying flat on the back, extend the feet and arms straight, inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths. Shake the feet thirty times—this can dispel chest and foot cold, whole-body numbness, and coughing fits.

Cross the hands behind the head, gently twist the body up and down. This is called *Opening the Flanks*—it can dispel bodily heaviness and stagnation.

Squatting while extending the right foot, use both hands to embrace the left knee, tilt the head back and stretch the waist. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths. Do the same on the left—this can dispel stiffness in bending and rising, as well as joint pains and blood stasis.

Squatting with both hands embracing the knees, inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel waist numbness and back pain.

Lying flat on the back, extend the arms and legs straight, with the soles facing upward and toes pointing toward each other. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel knee cold and joint pains.

Lying flat on the back, extend the arms and legs straight, with both soles facing upward and heels toward each other. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel muscle insensitivity and leg joint cold.

Lying flat on the back, extend the arms and legs straight, raise the toes with soles facing upward. Inhale *qi* through the nose to its utmost, then cease after seven breaths—this can dispel abdominal tightness and sharp, cutting pains.

Sitting upright, stretch the waist, face the sun and tilt the head back. Slowly inhale *qi* through the mouth and swallow it, repeating thirty times—this can remove accumulations beneath the heart.

Sitting upright, straighten the waist. Raise the right hand with palm upturned, and use the left hand to support the right flank#2. Inhale *qi* through the nose—this can dispel stomach cold and indigestion.

Extend the arms to the left and right while straightening the waist. Inhale *qi* through the nose and close it to its utmost—this can dispel flank accumulations.

The *Classic* says: Sit with knees drawn toward the chest, gripping firmly without pause. After one cycle, raise the hands and guide them left and right. Cover both ears with the hands, and place the fingers along the edge of the two pulses#3. Five cycles can clarify the vision, darken the hair, and dispel wind.

The *Classic* says: For nighttime *qi* practice, first purge the lingering *qi* by twisting and turning. Close the eyes, grip firmly, and lean back. With the left fist placed at the *breasts*, raise the pulses of both ears to the back and the *shīnèi*#1, close the *qi*, and let the *qi* from the *Qìhǎi*#2 surge forth from within. Twist and guide it, then exhale#3 forcefully. After nine cycles, cease—only then can one properly regulate and ingest *qi*.

The *Classic* says: Humans inherit the *original qi* of Heaven and Earth. Whether swallowing or exhaling *qi*, the internal *qi* naturally responds in kind.
From the *Qìhǎi*#2, follow the exhalation upward until it reaches the throat. Wait until exhalation is complete, then inhale continuously with a sound like *mìmì*#4, descending from the left through the twenty-four *nodes*.
For women, the *qi* descends from the right. Direct it with intention, and assist with hand movements, urging it swiftly to the five *original qi* at the *Qìhǎi*.
The *Qìhǎi* is located three *cùn* below the navel.

At the beginning of *qi* practice, when the internal *qi* is not yet flowing freely, one must massage to aid its movement. Continuously swallowing without closing the mouth is called *Cloud Movement*; swallowing saliva along with the *qi* is called *Rain Application*. Initially, when internal *qi* is not yet flowing, one cannot continuously swallow. After practicing for three years, the *qi* will flow freely on its own, descending without massage—then success can be achieved.

The *Classic* says: Extend both arms to the sides, repeating nine cycles without pause—this can cure arm pain and exhaustion.

Use both hands as if lifting a stone weighing a thousand *jīn*#5, alternating left and right—this can ensure lifelong health.

Cross both hands behind the knees and embrace both feet, repeating twelve cycles without pause—this can reduce food intake, lighten the body, enhance vitality, and dispel illness.

Squat with knees together and feet extended, repeating five cycles without pause—this can remove heat sores in the nose and mouth, as well as the five types of hemorrhoids.

Sit cross-legged, cross the hands above the head, and pull the head downward to touch the ground, repeating five cycles without pause—this can strengthen *qi* and physical power.

Cross both hands behind the knees and place them on the chest, repeating three cycles without pause—this can stop waist pain, kidney hernia, and back spasms.

Assume the *Tàijī*#4 posture, using both hands to grasp the toes of both feet to their utmost, lower the head to the ground, repeating twelve cycles without pause—this can treat neck, waist, back, and shoulder pains, as well as enhance hearing and vision clarity.

Exchange the legs to sit cross-legged (*jiāobèi*), with both hands crossed behind the head, extending the fingers outward to their fullest, then lowering the head to the ground without pause for six cycles—this can treat waist pain that prevents turning the head to look backward.

Lift the head and rub the abdomen with the hands, then grasp the feet while leaning against a wall, repeating twelve cycles without pause—this can treat knee stiffness that hinders walking, as well as waist and back pain.

Sit upright, with both hands crossed behind the kidneys—this can treat emaciation and regulate urination and defecation.

Sit upright, facing the sky, exhaling the *qi* of intoxication and overindulgence—this can immediately disperse alcohol and food, and if practiced repeatedly, one will endure cold without suffering heat.

Turn the feet outward ten times, then inward likewise—this can replenish exhaustion and strengthen *qi*.

**Laozi** (赤松子) says:
First, kneel for a long time, with both hands stretched forward, fingers pointing outward. Next, cross the hands behind the waist on either side, then with the right hand pull the waist, while the left hand is raised above the head and held still. Next, stretch the right hand backward, while the left hand crosses in front of the abdomen. Then, slowly assume the kneeling posture again, alternating the hands—stretching forward, then bending backward—while crossing them behind the waist. Finally, raise both hands high, and if this is done constantly, hearing and vision will sharpen, and a hundred maladies will not arise, prolonging life.

Each practice begins with kneeling.

**Ge Xian Gong** (葛仙公) says:
I have heard that those who practice fasting and *qi*-cultivation (*fúqì*)* must inhale (*yàn*)* five hundred and forty times in the twelve hours of day and night, continuously without end. However, if one has not first cultivated through diligence and taken nourishing medicines or elixirs, and if the original *qi* is not yet abundant, yet abruptly ceases eating—these two aspects not yet harmonized—then this is a way of inviting peril and early demise.

Some say: "The more one inhales, the better; the goal is to feel fullness. Within a hundred days, if the joints have not yet loosened, then practicing this way will cause the abdomen to swell and become congested—how can this be the method of true cultivation?"

What is meant by *qi*-cultivation is *tāixī* (胎息). Just as an infant in the womb, for ten months without food, yet able to grow and thrive—this is because it draws upon the original *qi*. But once born, it inhales external *qi*, and then there is the sound of crying, and it also knows dryness and dampness, hunger and satiety—this is because it has lost the original *qi*.

Now, those who merely draw *qi* through the nose and swallow it are also inhaling external *qi*—how can this suffice for cultivation? Truly, those who practice *qi*-cultivation must first attain a state of *wú sī wú lǜ* (无思无虑), a tranquil mind severed from all attachments, where all thoughts are forgotten. Then, the original *qi* will naturally arrive, and by swallowing it, each breath returns to its proper place.

Some say: "The five directions correspond to the five *zàng* organs—one must focus on them while cultivating."
**Ge Xian Gong** says: "No. Thinking of them creates attachment; attachment brings disturbance to the mind, and a disturbed mind cannot settle the *qi*. If the *qi* is unsettled, there is no natural harmony, and without natural harmony, the *qi* will lose its measure. Then, one invites harmful *qi*, and maladies will arise from this."

Some say: "Before fifteen days, *qi* is exhaled through the hands; after fifteen days, it is exhaled through the feet."
**Ge Xian Gong** says: "No, that is incorrect."

Those who practice visualization do so because they suffer and employ it as a remedy. As the *Huángtíng Jīng* states: *"Things that do not interfere with the Great Harmony and remain balanced are those without thought or contemplation."*

Some say: *"Count ten breaths with each finger movement; at seventy breaths, swallow once."* **Ge Xian Gong** says: *"No. The act of swallowing *qi* must be done with a mind of non-action, abandoning the body as if it were no body. In movement, rest, sleep, or waking, one must follow nature spontaneously. Only when the belly is empty should one practice; when ill, one must attack the ailment. To count with bent fingers is already laborious!"*

Some say: *"Draw the *qi* in through the nose, compress it, and swallow it. After a long while, continue inhaling and exhaling in succession, like water pouring from a bottle."* **Ge Xian Gong** says: *"This method is harmful enough to kill a person. Only in movement, rest, sleep, or waking should one habitually draw in pure *qi* through the nose and expel turbid *qi* through the mouth. The turbid *qi* is the breath of the five *zàng* organs from food and drink. If the throat is dry, close the mouth and let the nose breathe freely, and thus saliva will generate."*

Those who practice *qi*-swallowing should, upon waking at night or at the hour of *yín* (3–5 AM), internally regulate their *qi* and practice exhalation-inhalation. Lie on your back, stretch out your limbs, lower your pillow, quiet your mind, and unify your intention without thought or contemplation. Dwell on the *qi*, drawing it in through the nose and exhaling through the mouth, with breath flowing naturally. Close your mouth and inhale, drawing the *qi* upward into the mouth, then swallow it gently. After each swallow, rub the area to disperse it and guide it downward with your intention. Rubbing should occur every twenty to thirty breaths.

When the upper *jiāo* is unblocked, the swallowed *qi* will pass beyond the navel. If not yet unblocked, it will remain in the chest. Wait until mealtime—when you feel the chest empty and *qi* descending, then eat only when hungry, never overeating, for overeating obstructs the *qi*. After eating, wait until the chest feels empty again before practicing further.

For beginners, the three *jiāo* are not yet unblocked, and the joints are not yet open. Excessive practice will cause stagnation. Begin with three to five swallows, increasing to a hundred by the hundredth day, then adding thirty to forty swallows by the 150th day, reaching two hundred swallows by the 200th day. After a year, when the *qi* flows freely and the joints open, swallow three to five times in succession whenever the belly is empty. Never exceed three hundred swallows in a day. After three years, the *qi* will circulate fully, harmonizing with the five *zàng* organs. Then the bones will harden, the flesh will fill out, and the number of swallows need not be limited.

Those who practice *qi*-swallowing should eat only plain rice gruel in the morning, plain *miànbǐng* (wheat flatbread) at noon, and plain *bèituō* (steamed bread) in the evening. Avoid greasy, rancid, or pungent foods—such as butter, spoiled oils, raw vegetables, or fermented odors—as well as hot soups. After each meal, open your mouth to expel the five flavors’ toxins. If you feel bloated or *qi* stagnation, sit quietly to regulate the *qi*; soon, it will disperse and descend naturally.

Some say: *"Do not let it descend; retain it tightly."* **Ge Xian Gong** says: *"No. If the five *zàng* organs already harbor stagnant *qi*, forcing retention without release will cause pain and suffocation. Thus, before the old *qi* exits, the new *qi* will clash, leading to illness—how can one not let it descend?"*

**Ge Xian Gong** asks: *"What is the purpose of refining *qi*?"* When practicing *qi*-swallowing, if there is leisure, enter a quiet room, loosen your hair, remove your clothes, cover yourself lightly, lie on your back with limbs extended but not clenched, place a mat beneath you, and arrange your hair to hang down. Then regulate your *qi* and wait for it to settle before swallowing. After swallowing, close your mouth, exhaust the breath until suffocation occurs, then quiet your mind without thought, letting the *qi* move as it will. When suffocation arises, open your mouth and release it.

At first, when the *qi* exits with rapid breathing, regulate it. After seven or eight breaths, up to ten, when the *qi* stabilizes, refine it again. The refinement may be five, six, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty times—gradually increasing. With prolonged practice, the joints will open and the pores will unblock. When refining reaches twenty or thirty times, the body will sweat—this is the effect.

Refinement should be done at will during the day or night, but only when the spirit is clear and calm. Sit and practice swallowing; if sleepy, rest, but do not force it, for forcing will disrupt the *qi*. Thus, refine the *qi* every ten or five days. If the four limbs feel sluggish and uncirculated, practice accordingly.

Why abandon the *qi*? Because the body is pure and harmonious, the mind free of thought. In movement, rest, sleep, or sitting, regulate the breath. Relax the body completely, as if folding clothes upon a bed—without tendons, without bones, without perception or discrimination. Let the body and mind relax freely, like folded clothes, without control. Silent and still, release the form, purify the spirit, and refine the *qi*. Thus, all joints open, tendons and vessels circulate, and fluids flow. Then one can swallow and close the *qi* ten times, up to twenty.

Each swallow must be done naturally, letting the *qi* flow without forcing it. After a long while, the *qi* will exit through the pores, rarely through the mouth—perhaps once or twice in ten cases. Adjust and regulate again, over tens or hundreds of breaths, without inhaling and swallowing due to panting. With prolonged breath regulation, the body will feel as if bathed.

As the practice advances, the essence will be full, the *qi* complete, the spirit calm, and the soul steadfast. The mind will open, thoughts will extend, the *sānshī* (three corpses) will depart, and the *liùchén* (six dusts) will vanish. If the four limbs are restless and the *qi* stagnant, abandon it—whether lying or sitting—and purify the spirit to release the *qi*, regulating the breath to still the mind.

With prolonged concentration, the *qi* will flow and circulate without limit.

What is the Dao of holding the *qi*?
The superior sage, with spirit steadfast and *qi* regulated, banishes external illness naturally.
The middle sage, through proper cultivation and adherence to method, occasionally falls ill, but can heal by lying quietly in a well-appointed room, reclining on thick mats, arms and legs extended four inches apart, each covered with thick cloth.
With a tranquil mind and relaxed posture, they refine the *qi* and swallow it inward.
Then, they open their mouth but not their nostrils, focusing their intent on the afflicted area, directing the *qi* to strike it—when the *qi* reaches its limit, they exhale, then inhale again and close.
If panting occurs, regulate the *qi* over six or seven breaths, and it will soon flow smoothly.
Close the *qi* once more, visualizing and directing it to attack the affliction, repeating the process ten, twenty, thirty, or fifty times.
If the illness is in the left hand, they direct the *qi* inward through the left;
If the illness is in the right hand, they direct it inward through the right.

「If the illness is in the head, they direct the *qi* inward through the head, and thus sweat will emerge, moistening and harmonizing the area, until the illness is cured. If it is not yet cured, at the start of the hour of the Tiger (寅), they repeatedly focus their intent on attacking it until the illness is cured.

The *Tai Qing* Nurturing Life Lower Section (*Jing*) states: The human body has twelve major joints and three hundred and sixty minor bones, each pore facing its counterpart, each pulse connecting and communicating. New *qi* and old *qi* interweave, where the new *qi* may either suddenly stagnate or flow steadily, while the old *qi* may either circulate freely or become congested, or both may be obstructed, or both may rush forth. Congestion indeed is where the *yang qi* gathers and forms clumps and lesions; sudden stagnation is where the *yin qi* accumulates and leads to swelling or ulcers. Since *qi* can be stored and gathered, it also follows that it can be dispersed.

For any illness present, one may use *Dao Yin* (導引) to disperse it, harmonize the *qi* to attack it, focus the mind to guide it, employ clear *qi* to moisten it, swallow saliva to nourish it—what affliction could persist without remedy?

Yet the methods of nourishment and benefit all rely on saliva as their foundation. Thus, gold beams, jade grains, flower pools, and elixir meals are unattainable.

Sudden death is a *yang* phenomenon. It occurs when, due to severe pain, the *yang qi* suddenly stagnates at the four limbs and nine orifices, thus severing the breath.

Corpse-like rigidity (屍蹶) is also a *yang* phenomenon. Though dead, the pulse may still move, with sounds or none in the ears, and the thighs remain warm—this is where the *yang qi* is severed at the nine orifices, yet the four limbs still retain passage.

Sudden collapse (客性) is likewise a *yang* phenomenon. When external forces assault the body, the *yang qi* becomes obstructed and severed.

Five types of corpse-like death are also *yang* phenomena: **flying corpse** (一日飞尸) on the first day, **fleeing corpse** (二日遁尸) on the second, **wind corpse** (三曰风尸) on the third, **sinking corpse** (四日沉尸) on the fourth, and **poured corpse** (五曰注尸) on the fifth. When the chest and abdomen swell and ache intensely, or when a rolling mass rises beneath the ribs, these are all cases where *yang* is closed off by *yin*.

I have a method to revive them: Have the patient exert force to pull their left hand, then the right, then the left foot, then the right foot—each three hundred and sixty times. Then, with a leek heart (葱心) applied to the tip of the nose, blow into it. For men, first close the left nostril tightly and blow into the right, then block the right nostril and blow into the left. Blowing into the ears blocks the nostrils; blowing into the nostrils blocks the ears. The blowing should be slow and prolonged. Afterward, use a finger to close the leek’s hole, blowing forty-nine times into the left nostril, then the same into the right. For women, reverse the order: first blow into the right nostril, then the left, with the same count.

If no leek is available, use a reed pipe or any perforated object instead.

The nose governs the lungs, which are the canopy of all the *zang* organs (藏). The ears govern the kidneys, which are the root of *qi* circulation (通气之本). Sudden *Huo* disorder (霍乱) arises from the scattering of *ling qi* (玲气), where its passage is alternately obstructed and open, and its flow is suddenly halted or released—sometimes the *qi* should move *yin* but instead moves *yang*, or vice versa.

The method to treat it is this: In a secluded room, clad in thick garments, sit upright. Place the left and right hands on the two knees, then turn the body forcefully to the left sixty times, and do the same to the right. Alternate left and right until reaching three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, take seven deep breaths. Afterward, perform seven prolonged blows, seven prolonged exhalations, seven prolonged cries, seven prolonged swallows, and seven prolonged sighs—thus the illness will be cured.

If the illness is severe and *Dao Yin* is impractical, have the patient pull their left hand, then the right, then the left foot, then the right foot—each three hundred and sixty times. Additionally, immerse their hands in boiling water up to the elbows and their feet up to the knees, changing the water as it cools, until the illness is cured. This is effective because external *qi* draws in internal *qi*, and it can also treat corpse-like rigidity.

Leprosy (癞) is a disease of the *Tai Yang* channel (太阳). When *yang* is repelled by *yin* and sinks into the bone marrow, if it lingers long, the new *qi* cannot reach it, and the old *qi* cannot circulate. The passages are congested, heat is suppressed, and foulness breeds parasites—thus leprosy arises.

The method to treat it is this: In a secluded, tranquil space, eat sparingly and remain unperturbed. Sit upright and relax the body, placing the left and right hands on the two knees. Turn the head and body forcefully to the left ten times, then to the right the same. Alternate left and right until reaching three hundred and sixty repetitions. Thus, the joints, blood vessels, and pores will open fully, and one may perform seven prolonged blows, exhalations, cries, swallows, and sighs—each five times—then employ clear *qi* to attack it six times.

The first method is this: Sit upright and relax the body. Slowly and deeply inhale clear *qi* through the nose, combining it with focused intent to make the clear *qi* permeate the bone marrow. Then, slowly and deeply exhale through the mouth. Afterward, rinse the saliva and swallow it—repeat this sixty times.

The second method is to exhale through blowing, the third through exhaling, the fourth through crying, the fifth through swallowing, and the sixth through sighing—all following the same pattern as the breathing method. Then, inhale clear *qi* slowly and deeply through the nose, combining it with intent to make it permeate the bone marrow, and exhale forcefully through the mouth. Rinse the saliva and swallow it sixty times. Thus, the *yang* parasites will be struck by *yin* and should perish.

It is best to perform this at the hours of the Tiger (卯), Horse (午), Rooster (酉), and Rat (子). Avoid consuming garlic (缅) and mutton.

When half the body does not respond, it is due to *yang qi* gathering and being obstructed by external cold, or when *yin qi* surges and disrupts it. Though the pulse may circulate, internally there is no passage.

The method to treat it is this: Sit upright and place the left and right hands on the two knees. Turn the body forcefully to the left ten times, then to the right the same. Alternate left and right, combining the movements, until reaching three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, have someone exert force to pull the unresponsive limbs—each hand and foot three hundred and sixty times—followed by pressing down with the left and right hands on the unresponsive limbs, also three hundred and sixty times each.»

Once the exercises are complete, release the body and slowly inhale through the nose to draw in the pure *qi*. Then, slowly exhale through the mouth. When exhaling, direct the *qi* with intent into the affected limbs, and swallow saliva sixty times in succession. The techniques of *pui* (吹), *xū* (嘘), *hē* (呵), swallowing, and *xī* (唏) are performed likewise.

For severe cases where guided movements are unbearable, have someone forcibly pull the unresponsive limbs while you direct the *qi* with intent—this too may suffice.

When the entire body is swollen, *yang qi* is constricted within the five *zàng* (藏), surging outward to the skin, where it stagnates and fails to disperse. Sit upright, placing the hands on the knees, and forcefully turn the body left and right ten times each. Alternate directions, combining movements until completing three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, inhale deeply through the nose to let the pure *qi* permeate the five *zàng*, exhaling forcefully through the mouth. Swallow saliva sixty times, and repeat the techniques of *pui*, *xū*, *hē*, swallowing, and *xī*.

For cases of extreme heat where saliva is absent, rely solely on guided movements: inhale pure *qi* through the nose and exhale turbid *qi* through the mouth.

This method also treats *páo* (庖) ailments. When heat *qi* assails and stagnates, causing swelling, blow forcefully onto the affected area fourteen times with the mouth. Then, warm the hands by rubbing them and press them firmly against the swelling. Next, exhale forcefully onto the swelling fourteen times. Repeat this process alternately until the swelling subsides.

For red, dry, and painful eyes—symptoms of liver heat—perform guided movements left and right three hundred and sixty times. Then, inhale pure *qi* slowly through the nose while visualizing it ascending to the eyes. The heat *qi* will be dispersed by the pure *qi*, naturally retreating and exiting through the mouth, where it can be expelled with a forceful *hē*. Completing three hundred and sixty repetitions will cure it. *Hē* governs the heart, as it originates from innate *qi*.

For deafness, when kidney heat *qi* assails the ears and is further obstructed by rebellious *yin qi*, perform guided movements left and right three hundred and sixty times. Then, pull the ears forty-nine times with force. Inhale pure *qi* slowly through the nose, directing it with intent to the kidneys, and exhale while swallowing. Repeat this three hundred and sixty times. Swallowing governs the kidneys, and pulling the ears dispels *yin*. Practicing twice daily will restore hearing.

For upward-rushing *qi* and coughing, *yang qi* stagnates within the *zàng*, surging upward and seeking release. If *yin qi* then intrudes, the two clash in the throat region, intensifying the cough as their conflict grows. It is as if blowing on a fire—though the breath (*qi*) is cool, the fire (heat) intensifies with each exhale. Thus, the treatment is as follows: Sit upright and perform guided movements left and right two hundred and forty times each. Then, push the elbows backward while thrusting the arms forward with force. Next, place the hands on the elbows and push them forward until they nearly meet. Stand upright, then bend the knees, placing the hands beneath the kneecaps. Push the elbows outward fourteen times each. Then, tilt the head to the left and use the shoulder to support it, repeating for the right side sixteen times each. Finally, stretch the neck upward four times, followed by seven repetitions each of long exhalation, blowing, *xū*, *hē*, swallowing, and *xī*. Perform this three times daily for swift recovery.

Additionally, inhale pure *qi* slowly through the nose and exhale forcefully through the mouth, swallowing saliva twenty times. The effects will be accelerated.

For upward-rushing *qi*, when beginning the movements, lift the foot and forcefully stamp it forward, then place it firmly behind—this is optimal.

For exhaustion (*láo* 劳), *yang* is depleted, or overindulgence in food causes *qi* to fluctuate—sometimes obstructed, sometimes surging—often worsened by consuming hot foods. The treatment is as follows: Sit upright and perform guided movements left and right forty-nine times each. Inhale pure *qi* slowly through the nose and exhale forcefully through the mouth, swallowing saliva. Complete one hundred and twenty repetitions, and if strength remains, increase to two hundred and forty or three hundred and sixty for even better results. Then, extend the left leg and place the left hand on the foot, rotating it left and right forty-nine times. Repeat for the right foot. Practicing twice daily will restore vitality. Thus, Master Pengzu said: *"Turning the feet inward and outward ten times each can dispel all exhaustion."* This refers to this method.

For *wēn yì* (温疫, febrile disorders), *yang qi* gathers in the *zàng*, permeates the vessels, and reaches the *shèng lǐ* (胜理, critical points). The treatment is as follows: Sit upright and perform guided movements left and right three hundred and sixty times. Guiding movements, as Master Dì Bèi (歧伯) said, involve bowing, stretching, and flexing. Master Gān Shǐ (甘始) said: *"Clasp the hands behind the neck and continuously twist left and right."* He also stated: *"Perform until sweating profusely—sweating is akin to powdering the body."* Then, kneel on the right knee and stamp the left foot forward, then kneel on the left knee and stamp the right foot forward, forty-nine times each. This may also be done while standing. Inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth two hundred and forty times, increasing to three hundred and sixty for optimal results. Master Pengzu said: *"This can also cure malaria."* Malaria occurs when *yang* stagnates beneath the diaphragm, surging upward to escape, while *yin* above the diaphragm obstructs it. When *yang* leaks and discharges, its outbreaks follow a cycle—this is the competition of *yin* and *yang*, governed by natural rhythms.

At the moment when [malaria] is about to flare, perform *Dao Yin* exercises (guided movements) left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, kneel on the right knee, extend the left foot, and stamp it forward forty-nine times; do the same with the right foot. Afterward, inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth, with each breath (呼) and exhale (嘘) counted as twenty-one repetitions—this shall cure it.

If blood is drawn from the nose (*鼻钮血*) or spat from the mouth (*口唾血*), it means the middle burner (*中焦*) is searingly hot, causing water to transform into blood. Thus, when the middle burner’s *qi* surges upward into the lungs (*肺*), the lungs then push it into the nose, resulting in *鼻钮血*. When the middle burner’s *qi* descends into the spleen (*脾*), the spleen then forces it into the mouth, resulting in *口唾血*. For those afflicted by this, few shall perish.

The method of treatment: Sit upright, perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, extend both feet, and with the left hand grasp the right foot’s five toes fourteen times; do the same with the right hand. If blood is drawn from the nose, swallow saliva (*咽津*). Inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth, with each breath and exhale counted as sixty repetitions. If blood is spat from the mouth, swallow saliva as well. Repeat the swallowing and exhaling, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions, once per evening—this shall cure it. For severe cases, doing it three times a day may also suffice.

For *赤下* (hematuria), the lower burner (*下焦*) is searingly hot, and when water is ingested, the *yin* and *yang* *qi* contend within the lower burner, unable to follow the proper *Dao* (Way). When cold *qi* strikes intermittently, pain ensues. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Once done, swallow saliva. Inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth, with each breath (呼), exhale (嘘), and the techniques *呵、咽、晞* counted as sixty repetitions. Then swallow saliva again. Doing this four or five times a day shall cure it.

For *前后没不通* (incomplete defecation or obstruction in bowel movement), *yang* *qi* stagnates in the lower region and is repelled in reverse. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Once done, interlock both hands behind the back, with the left hand directed rightward and the right hand forcefully pulling leftward fourteen times; do the same with the right hand. Then, extend the left hand and with the right hand forcefully lift the left shoulder fourteen times; do the same with the right hand. Afterward, swallow saliva. Repeat the inhalation and exhalation (吐纳), along with *呼、吹、呵、咽、唏*, each for sixty repetitions. Doing this twice daily shall cure it.

Thus, Master Ning said: *"Sit upright and stretch the left hand, using the right hand’s fingers to pull the shoulder, treating obstruction in the anterior region (前搜不通). Interlock both hands behind the back, called '带缚' (girdle binding), treating obstruction in the posterior region (后没不通). This refers to the same method."*

For *淋* (stranguria), the water *Dao* (pathway) is searingly hot and dry, causing urine to leak intermittently. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Then, stand with feet apart and, with both hands inserted beneath the armpits (*陛*), grasp the five toes of the left foot with the left hand and the five toes of the right foot with the right hand, forcefully pulling inward fourteen times. Once done, swallow saliva. Slowly inhale through the nose to gather its pure *qi*, then exhale through the mouth, repeating this three hundred and sixty times. Doing this three times a day is even more beneficial.

For *疢* (a type of *yin* stagnation), it originates from *虚假* (emptiness or weakness), often following illness when the *qi* of all the viscera (*藏*) is disordered, and water is ingested. Once the *yin* *qi* enters, it prolongs the accumulated water. When the *yang* *qi* is taken in, it obstructs the accumulated *yin*. As the water *qi* grows stronger, it reaches the skin, manifesting as *疢*. Its signs include discoloration on the left and right sides of the face resembling an old *蠢* (a type of insect), and a watery sound in the armpits when turning. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Once done, inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth, followed by *嘘、呵、咽、唏*, each for sixty repetitions. Then, visualize the *qi* circulating throughout the body, practicing this three times a day and night. With persistence, it shall be cured. Avoid salty foods; consume *小豆汁* (mung bean broth) or soak cooked mung beans for the left and right feet—this is ideal.

For *反胃* (gastroptosis), the stomach accumulates *玲* (disordered *qi*) over time, causing *yin* *qi* to descend and stagnate at the abdominal opening (*腹口*). When hot food is consumed, the *yin* *qi* resists and rebounds, expelling it. The method of treatment: Always practice *Dao Yin* with an empty stomach, left and right, each for three hundred and sixty repetitions. Interlock both hands and with both feet stamp them against the hands forty-nine times. Place the left hand’s back beneath the left armpit and use the right hand to pull the left elbow seven times; do the same with the right hand. Then swallow saliva. Slowly and briefly inhale through the nose to gather its *qi*, then exhale through the mouth, repeating this one hundred and twenty times. Then swallow saliva again. Next, repeat the exhalation and inhalation techniques *咽、吹、唏*, each for sixty repetitions. Doing this three times a day shall cure it. For those lacking strength, doing it twice daily is also acceptable.

For *心腹坚痛* (severe, fixed abdominal pain), *yin* *qi* stagnates and accumulates in the heart and abdomen, congealing without dispersal. Even with thick layers of clothing, if *yang* *qi* strikes it, the *yin* and *yang* contend, exacerbating the *yin* stagnation. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* movements left and right, completing three hundred and sixty repetitions, then swallow saliva. Slowly inhale through the nose to gather its pure *qi*, then exhale through the mouth, ensuring warm *qi* disperses the accumulation. For all exhalation and swallowing techniques, complete up to two hundred and eighty repetitions. For breath (呼) and exhale (嘘), do the same. Practicing this twice daily and nightly shall cure it.

For *胸胁结癖* (chest and armpit masses or stagnation), it is a *yin* condition. Cold *qi* stagnates in the chest and armpits, or persists from prolonged improper diet. The method of treatment: On a clear morning, lie on your back. Stand with feet apart, and have someone use their hands to locate the mass root (*癖根*), gradually insert their hands beneath the mass root, lifting it slightly. At first, it shall be painful, but later it shall become bearable. Then, forcefully lift it one hundred and twenty times. After two or three days, increase to two hundred and forty repetitions. After five days, further increase to three hundred and sixty repetitions.

「Once this is done, perform *Dao Yin* (导引) three hundred and sixty times, then swallow the saliva (*咽津*). Inhale through the nose (*鼻纳之*), exhale through the mouth (*口呵之*), and with intent, direct the *qi* (气) to the site of the illness. Allow it to exit through the lower *orifices* (下部), completing one hundred and twenty repetitions, gradually increasing to two hundred and forty, and ultimately to three hundred and sixty, which is even more beneficial. Practicing this twice daily—morning and night—shall swiftly cure it.

For sudden distension of the *heart and abdomen* (心腹卒满), it is due to *yin qi* (阴气) dwelling in the *Zang* (藏). When it arises, it surges against the heart. The method of treatment: Perform *Dao Yin* (导引) by moving left and right, completing three hundred and sixty repetitions. Swallow the saliva and inhale the *qi*, then exhale through the mouth, allowing the *qi* to exit through the lower *orifices*. Completing three hundred and sixty repetitions shall cure it.

For *red eyes and protruding eyeballs* (目赤而相出), it is due to the *yin qi* of the liver (肝) surging against the eyes. The method of treatment: As before, perform *Dao Yin* (导引). Once done, swallow the saliva. Close your eyes (*暝目*) and inhale the pure *qi* through the nose (*以鼻纳其清气*); open your eyes (*开目*) and exhale the turbid *qi* through the mouth (*以口呵出其浊气*), completing three hundred and sixty repetitions. Practicing this twice daily—morning and night—shall cure it.

The *Sutra* (《经》) says: When an infant is in the womb, it develops over ten months, with sinews and bones harmonious and supple. By calming the mind (*以心息念*), the *qi* naturally aligns (*和气自至*), so those who practice *qi* cultivation (*服气者*) should emulate this principle. During the six *yang* times of the day, one should ingest the vital *qi* (生气). Thus, at the *zi* hour (子之时), one should cultivate nine times nine, eighty-one repetitions (*九九八十一*); at the *yin* hour (寅之时), eight times eight, sixty-four repetitions (*八八六十四*); at the *si* hour (巳之时), seven times seven, forty-nine repetitions (*七七四十九*); at the *wu* hour (午之时), six times six, thirty-six repetitions (*六六三十六*); at the *you* hour (酉之时), five times five, twenty-five repetitions (*五五二十五*); at the *xu* hour (戌之时), four times four, sixteen repetitions (*四四十六*).

When cultivating *qi*, use the tongue to expel the turbid *qi* (舌去其浊气), then enter and exit through its respective *gates* (门户). The nose is the *Heavenly Gate* (天门); the mouth is the *Earthly Orifice* (地户), where the essence of *qi* cultivation (*服气之魂魄*) resides. Entering through the nose and exiting through the mouth is the *Way of Harmony* (顺气). If practiced without interruption (*不报*), one may eliminate the *Three Corpses* (三尸) and attain longevity (*长生*).

The *Dao* (道) is *qi*. *Qi* is the *Gate of Essence* (精门); if one preserves their *jing* (精), it is like having a guardian within a chamber. When both *jing* and *qi* are complete, one is called a *True Person* (真人).

The body has three *elixir fields* (丹田). What are they? The brain is the *Upper Elixir Field* (上丹田); the heart is the *Middle Elixir Field* (中丹田); and the *Qi Sea* (气海) and *Gate of Essence* (精门) are the *Lower Elixir Field* (下丹田). Each of the three *Palaces* (三宫) has its own *spirit* (神). When the *spirit* wanders (*神驰*), *qi* leaks (*气漏*), and when *qi* leaks, *jing* is lost (*精泄*), and when *jing* is lost, the *spirit* perishes (*神丧*). Thus, *jing* is the root of longevity; the kidneys are the root of life. It is like a tree: without *jing*, the leaves wither; when the leaves wither, the branches decay; when the branches decay, the tree dies.

Generally, inhaling *qi* is *yin*; exhaling *qi* is *yang*. These two are called the *absorption of the essence of the sun and moon* (服日月之精华). *Qi* is the natural, spontaneous, and effortless void. When effortless, the mind remains undisturbed; when the mind is undisturbed, there is no external desire; when there is no external desire, the inner self is tranquil; when the inner self is tranquil, the *spirit* is settled; when the *spirit* is settled, the *qi* harmonizes; when the *qi* harmonizes, the *primordial qi* (元气) naturally arrives; when the *primordial qi* arrives, the five *Zang* (五藏) are nourished; when the five *Zang* are nourished, the hundred *meridians* (百脉) flow freely; when the hundred *meridians* flow freely, the *saliva and fluids* (津液) ascend in response; when the *saliva and fluids* ascend, one forgets the five tastes and ceases to feel hunger or thirst. Thus, *qi* transforms into blood, and blood transforms into marrow. In one year, the *qi* renews; in two years, the blood renews; in three years, the *meridians* renew; in four years, the flesh renews; in five years, the marrow renews; in six years, the bones renew; in seven years, the hair renews; in eight years, the sinews renew; in nine years, the form renews. This is the *Nine Circulations* (炼九还).

The *Sutra* (《经》) says: For the *blue-green essence* (束方青牙) of the liver, when ingesting (*服食*), drink with *morning dew* (朝华), lick the outer surface of the lips with the tongue (*以舌表舐其唇*), rinse the mouth, and swallow three times (*漱口而三咽之*). *Morning dew* refers to the roots of the upper teeth (*上齿根*).

For the *red elixir* (南方朱丹) of the heart, when ingesting, drink with *elixir pool* (丹池), stir with the tongue at the *tooth crevices* (齿曹), rinse the mouth, and swallow three times. *Elixir pool* refers to the roots of the lower teeth (*下齿根*).

For the *bright stone* (西方明石) of the lungs, when ingesting, drink with *dew essence* (露液), polish the teeth with the tongue seven times (*以舌琢齿者七匝*), rinse the mouth, and swallow three times. *Dew essence* refers to the saliva within the lips (*唇内津*).

For the *dark essence* (北方玄滋) of the kidneys, when ingesting, drink with *jade honey* (玉饴), and perform *Dao Yin* (导引) through the nose. Allow the *primordial qi* (元气) to enter the mouth, then breathe in and out while swallowing three times. *Jade honey* refers to the tongue (*舌*).

For the *central essence* (中央戊己), gaze upward at *Great Mountain* (太山). *Great Mountain* is the *preservation of jing* (守精). When ingesting the *preservation of jing*, drink with *honey spring* (醴泉), located behind the teeth and before the *suspended flavor* (悬味). *Flower Pool* (华池) is at the root of the tongue (*舌本根*), also called *Jade Flower* (玉英) and *Golden Beam* (金梁). Rinse the mouth and swallow three times.

For those who cultivate these *qi*, always at the *zi* and *yin* hours, sit upright with proper attire. Strike the *Jade Flower* (玉英) with the tongue, cleanse the *Flower Pool* (华池), rinse the *Honey Spring* (醴泉) and *Dew Essence* (露液), contract the nostrils, and draw the *qi* upward to the head, then downward into the mouth, transforming it into *Jade Spring* (玉泉). Guide the *qi* to the root of the tongue, swallow, and send it forth, so that the throat and abdomen both resonate (*皆呜*). Draw it into the *elixir field* (丹田). This is called the *root of longevity*.

When hungry, ingest the natural *qi*; when thirsty, drink the *Flower Pool’s essence* (华池之浆). What need then for hunger or thirst?

*Jing* is my *spirit*; *qi* is my *Dao*. Nurturing the *spirit* and drinking the *qi* is like an infant in the womb. Thus, I ingest the *yang* in the morning and the *yin* in the evening. *Lingzhi* (灵芝) and *Jade Flower* (玉英) grow within the five *Zang*.

Then, lie on your back to expel the *water Zang* (水藏); cover yourself to expel the *food Zang* (食藏). Next, lean against a wall and lift one foot, clench both hands into fists, and stir the mouth’s saliva with the tongue. Imagine the *qi* descending into the navel (*脐*), reaching down to the feet as the measure (*为度焉*).」

The *qi* is swallowed thus: close your mouth with force, raise your tongue, and make the space beneath it hollow. This is called swallowing the *primordial qi* (元气), and then food will no longer be needed.

When the count reaches ninety-nine (*九九*), it completes the cycle of heaven and earth. Naturally, blood transforms into *jing* (精), *jing* into sinews (筋), sinews into jade (玉), and jade into the *immortal’s bone* (仙骨).

The *Sutra* (《经》) says: those who practice *fetal breathing* (胎息) expel the turbid *qi* from the abdomen (腹), harmonizing heaven and earth, and then release their *spirit* (神) freely.

Their mind is like the boundless void (太空), all thoughts extinguished. The three *passes* (三关) are sealed, and the external *qi* aligns with the internal *qi*. Then, they close their mouth and rhythmically swallow, as if letting water drip into a well to guide it, until thirty-six swallows are completed—this is called the *Highest Purity Refinement of Form* (上清炼形).

But when the abdomen is empty, one may swallow and guide the *qi* without regard to sitting or lying.

Those who ingest *qi* (服气) sit quietly with eyes closed, knock their teeth together, and close their mouth. They contract their abdomen and puff out their cheeks, and then their mouth will open naturally.

Await the *qi* filling the mouth and descending into the throat, until nine breaths are taken in one inhalation (九下一息焉).

In spring and summer, ingest the *cool qi* (玲气); in autumn and winter, ingest the *warm qi* (暖气).

Generally, at the hour of *Yin* (寅), cover your mouth with both palms and forcefully exhale into them—this generates saliva. Use it to rub and wipe your face, and your complexion will become radiant.

Yet the great precepts of the *Dao* (道) are eighteen in number: do not seek wealth and honor forcefully (强求富贵), do not covet treasures and riches (贪冒宝货), do not fear many taboos (多忌讳), do not harm the *royal qi* (王气), do not seek fame and reputation (干名誉), do not commit evil deeds (为诸恶), do not delight in functional achievements (喜功名), do not be deceived by the senses of hearing, sight, and speech (为耳目口所误), do not be domineering (强梁), do not rely on false strength (伪仗), do not be hasty and impulsive (转躁), do not act without deliberation (举事不详), do not let the mind be restless (心倥倥), do not argue over right and wrong (争曲直), do not waste *jing* and *qi* (费用精气), do not indulge in fine clothes and delicious food (好衣美食), do not be excessive (盈溢), do not take pleasure in war (乐兵).

Thus, those who study the *Dao* must not let others know of it. If others know, then I will be born, and if I am born, then my name will arise—with the name comes calamity (祸).

End of the *Dao Gunzhu* (道枢) scroll, the twenty-eighth. #1二: Original reads *"not"* (不), corrected according to the *Jixiao* edition (辑要本).

**#2 Hand:** Possibly a textual repetition. **#3 Exhale:** Original reads *"can"* (可), corrected according to the *Jixiao* edition.
**#4 Great:** *Jixiao* edition reads *"Great"* (大).
**#5 Stagnant:** Originally omitted; supplemented from the *Jixiao* edition.
**#6 Deliver:** Likely a miswriting for *"repeat"* (迭).
**#7 Three hundred sixty:** Original reads *"two hundred forty"* (二百四十), corrected according to the *Jixiao* edition.
