When they **interact and merge (交合)**,
they enter the **central chamber (中官)**,
never straying from the **Wu-Jia (戊己)** harmony.

The **Nine Transformations (九转)** are when
the **four divine essences (四神)** and **Five Phases (五行)** reside within,
and the **two opposing forces (二象)**—**Yin** and **Yang**—
are positioned without and within as **auxiliary (佐)** and **supportive (助)**.

My **sinews, bones, blood, flesh, and spirit-Qi (神气)**,
how could they not be fully nourished by this?
If any one aspect is deficient,
then it becomes **weakness (啧)** or **illness (疾)**.

My **medicine’s completion (药成)**,
must rely on **Yang obtaining Yin (阳得阴)**.
Thus, one must **contain and protect (含护)** it,
until it reaches **three hundred and sixty (三百有六十)**,
then the **embryonic essence (凝胎)** can be solidified,
returning to **spiritual roots (还神)**** and **immortal form (固形)**.
The **jade marrow and golden sinews (玉髓金筋)**** will then be recorded among the **True Ones (真人)**.

To pursue **external shortcuts (旁通之方)** without mastering the **ultimate truth (至理)**,
even if one subdues **mercury (汞)**,
and it lies dormant in **Fire (火)** while perishing,
one will never realize that this is sufficient to **cut short one’s lifespan (夭折其生)**!

It is like **drawing a mirror on the ground (画地为镜)** to pray for its reflection of the **gallbladder (胆)**,
or **forging lead into a blade (冶铅为刀)** to pray for it to slay a **whale (鲸)**—
these are futile endeavors.

The **ultimate medicine (至药)**,
must follow the **laws of Heaven (诸天)**,
the **laws of Earth (诸地)**,
and the **laws of humanity (诸人)**,
and only then can it be achieved.

The **Qi of Azure (青)** is **Heaven (天)**.
Within it are the **Sun, Moon, and Five Luminaries (五曜)****,
as well as the **constellations (经星)**.
If one does not lose the **points of the Sun, Moon, and stars (日月星辰之点)**,
then their **light will be fully transmitted (光通达)**.
Without these **Symbols (象)**,
one merely lies dormant in **Fire (火)**—
this is not the **ultimate medicine (至药)**.

In my **medicine’s calculations (药之数)**,
they align with the **interactions of the Sun, Moon, and Five Luminaries (日月五曜之交)**.
If even a **minute fraction (铢累)** is lost,
or if the **proportions of master and minister (君臣)** are misjudged,
then it will surely **harm my life (害吾生)**.

The **Qi of Yellow (黄)** is **Earth (地)**.
If it is **dense and tranquil (厚则安静)**,
then it fulfills the **Earth’s function (土之用)**!
It must be **akin to mercury (汞之类)**—
the **Five Mountains (五岳)** and **Four Seas (四渍)**** remain stable and unshaken,
with **mountains and rivers (山川)****,
and **various minerals (品汇)**.
Each benefits its **corresponding region (方所)**—
thus, the **Five Mountains (五岳)** become the **furnace (炉)**,
and **mercury (汞)** transforms into myriad things.
**Heaven covers (天覆)** them,
**Earth bears (地载)** them,
and **humankind rests (人民安)** in them.

**Heaven and Earth (天地)** are the **cauldron (鼎)**;
**humankind (人民)** is the **mercury (汞)**.

Since the **human form (形)** is originally composed of the **Five Phases (五行)**,
its **restoration (补)** must rely on the **refined essence-Qi (精气)** of the Five Phases.
In ancient times, **Nüwa (女娲氏)** refined **five-colored stones (五色石)** to patch **Heaven’s breaches (天之阙)**—
this is a fine analogy!

**Bones (骨)** are **Metal (金)**;
**blood (血)** is **Water (水)**;
**flesh (肉)** is **Earth (土)**;
**Qi (气)** is **Wood (木)**;
**warmth (暖)** is **Fire (火)**.
This is not the **Five Phases (五行)** as commonly spoken of!

Only when **four**—**Metal, Water, Earth, and Wood**—
**govern and regulate (管摄)** the **beginning (始)**,
can it be called the **ultimate medicine (至药)**.

I seek **mercury’s kindred (汞之同类)**,
each refined to its **essence (精)** for this purpose.
One cannot **mingle unrelated substances (杂)**—
as the saying goes: *"Foxes and rabbits cannot nurse a thoroughbred (狐兔不乳骥)**,
and *swallows and sparrows do not lay phoenix eggs (燕雀不卵凤)**.*
This is what it means!

The **Five Phases (五行)**,
**retain the spirit (留神)** to restore the **form (补其形)**—
this is the **Dragon-Tiger (龙虎)** method.
If one does not understand the **Five Phases (五行)**,
then one relies on **others’ bodies (他人)** as **parents (父母)**.

Thus, **Qi (气)** is **Wood (木)**;
**bones (骨)** are the **White Tiger (虎)**;
**blood (血)** is the **symbol of Water (水之象)**;
**flesh (肉)** is the **symbol of Earth (土之象)**.
The **path to immortality (不死之道)** lies in the **separation chamber (离宫)**—
once the **Five Phases (五行)** are known,
the **body has its master (身有主)**.

The **Five Phases (五行)** are **closest allies (亲於)** to **mercury (汞)**.
When the **Five Phases (五行)** are properly **aligned (相配)**,
they **generate and complete (生成)** my **medicine (吾药)**.
**Metal (金)** generates **Water (水)**,
**Water (水)** generates **Wood (木)**,
**Wood (木)** generates **Fire (火)**,
**Fire (火)** generates **Earth (土)**,
and **Earth (土)** generates **Metal (金)**.

Thus, **Spring (春)** is **Wood (木)**;
**Summer (夏)** is **Fire (火)**;
**Autumn (秋)** is **Metal (金)**;
**Winter (冬)** is **Water (水)**;
and the **intermediate seasons (四时之季)** are **Earth (土)**.
**Wood (木)** embodies **benevolence (仁)**,
and governs **generative vitality (生成)**,
so the **elixir (丹)** is the **refined essence of Wood (木之精)**.
**Wood (木)** can generate **Fire (火)**,
so the **elixir (丹)** is the **child of Wood (木之子)**.

In the **eleventh month (十有一月)**,
a **single Yang line (一阳爻)**** emerges.
In the **twelfth month (十有二月)**, reaching the **first month (正月)**,
they all belong to **Spring (春)**.

**Fire (火)** governs **propriety (礼)**,
and fosters **vigorous growth (滋茂)**—
my **medicine (吾药)** is also thus in this season.
Hence, **Fire (火)** is the **substance that solidifies myriad things (坚万物)** while remaining **imperishable (不朽)**.

The **Sage (圣人)** thus refines **Yin medicine (阴药)** to complete **Yang medicine (阳药)**,
so that the **Yin body (阴身)** returns to the **Yang position (阳位)**.
When the **form is solidified (形固)** and the **spirit is complete (神备)**,
one attains **guesting in Heaven (宾於天)**—
this is the **function of Fire (火之功)**.

Thus, the **Golden Elixir (金丹)**** arises in **Spring (春)** and flourishes in **Summer (夏)**.
Compare it to **grasses and trees (草木)**,
which **rely on the four seasons (禀四时)** to grow—
how much more so for my **elixir (丹)**!

When **Fire (火)** reaches **two (二者)**,
it can **generate in Earth (土)**.
In the **second (二月)**, **third (三月)**, and **fourth (四月)** months,
they all belong to **Summer (夏)**.

The **intermediate seasons (四时之季)** have **Earth (土)**,
which governs **trustworthiness (信)**—
there is no **abandonment (弃)** in **generation and completion (生成)**.
One must **cherish and select (沃执)** the **central position (中位)**,
even if one does not **grasp the four cardinal directions (执四维)**.

Yet, in the **Four Symbols (四象)**,
**Earth (土)** serves as the **foundation for growth (资)**.
All **myriad things (万物)**,
**originate from Earth (因土而生)**.
My **elixir’s Earth (吾药之土)**,
emerges from the **Flowering Pool (华池)**,
and **generates through Fire (因火而生)**.
Its **refinement (寄治)** lies in **Bing (丙)** and **Ding (丁)**,
revealing what **Earth (土)** generates.

Wood is **completed into Earth by Fire**,
and Earth can **generate Metal**—
thus, **Earth possesses the Five Virtues**.

The **interwoven cycles of beginning and end**,
serve as the **foundation for medicinal use**.

**Earth reigns over the four seasons**.
Autumn embodies **principle (义)**—
why does my elixir **generate and complete** in the **seventh month**?

After the **Establishment of Autumn (立秋)**,
grasses **begin to flourish**.
By this time, my elixir’s **Nine Returns and Seven Reversions** are **already complete**,
and its **qi** surpasses **Mid-Autumn Metal**.

The **two phases of the moon**—
the **Hare and Toad (蟾兔)**—
when **full and bright (三五圆明)**,
my elixir’s **Metal essence solidifies**.

The **Mao (卯) and You (酉) days**—
the **gates of the Eight Trigrams**—
the **Yin and Yang days (寅申)**—
the **roots of Yin and Yang**—
these are the **timely moments of life and death**,
which **cannot be transgressed**.

How so?
Metal’s **generation from Water** is **complete**—
it **retires and yields its position**,
and in the **fifth and sixth months**,
its **position belongs to Water and Autumn Metal**.

When **one Yin line is born**, it becomes Metal—
thus, by the **seventh month**,
there is **no further generation**.

Why?
Because it is the **Autumn order**—
in humans, the **kidneys govern wisdom**.
Wisdom is **concealment (藏)**,
**overseeing the five phases and four symbols**,
**potently transforming in secret**.

The **Sage follows this**,
marking the **beginning of the Great Transformation’s foundation**.

The **Three Affairs** arise from this root!
In terms of **time**, it **rules over ice’s strength and snow’s abundance**,
when **all things retreat and hide**.
The **Sage follows this**,
using **Fire throughout the year**—
the **four seasons are complete**.

Thus, in the **tenth month**, the **embryo sheds its shell**,
from **Yin (寅) to Hai (亥)**,
and the **elixir’s work is complete**.

The **unaware** assume the **tenth-month shedding**,
yet **do not know the four seasons are incomplete**.

The **elixir’s completion** requires **cycling through the four seasons**—
from its **beginning to the tenth month**,
a full **year has already passed**,
and within the **embryo’s refinement**, there are **two purifications and washings**.

Only when the **four seasons are complete** does the **shedding occur**—
then the **four seasons cycle fully**,
the **five phases are whole**,
and the **luminous stars are arranged**.

This is the **beginning of the supreme elixir’s completion**.

The **eighth, ninth, and tenth months** belong to **Winter**—
when the **five phases reach their peak and pass the torch**,
the **transformation’s success returns to purple**.

This is the **principle of effortless, natural harmony**.

Thus it is said:
**The two Yin-Yang** are the **ancestors of the Three Sovereigns**.
Which comes first—**Water or Earth**?
It is the **root source of the Kǔ and Zǐ trees**!

The **Flowering Pool** is the **Tiger’s embryo**;
the **Mao Gate (卯门)** is the **Dragon’s claw**—
the **four symbols and five phases generate endlessly**.

If one **cannot subdue the elixir**,
it **will not submit**.

Metal **overcomes Wood**—
Wood **returns to Metal**.
Wood **overcomes Earth**—
Earth **returns to Wood**.
Earth **overcomes Water**—
Water **returns to Earth**.

The **intermingling of the five phases** has **ten such cases**—
let us speak of **two**:

**Jia (甲)** is the **wife of Geng (庚)**;
**Bing (丙)** is the **wife of Ren (壬)**—
the **wealth of the aged, overpowering matron**.

If one **does not grasp the five phases**,
**exaggerating their harmony**,
**ignoring the master-servant relationships**,
**neglecting the minutest details**,
and **hopes for the elixir’s completion**—
it is like **climbing heaven with a ladder** or **fishing the sea with a needle**!

Thus, if one **does not know how to subdue and refine**,
the **spiritual qi will not converge**.

The Yellow Emperor said: *"The essence of the Golden Elixir lies in the Spirit Water and Hua Pool—what does this mean? It is the regulation of one yin by one yang.*

The Heavenly Old Man replied: *White is the essence of Metal—is this not the yang one? Black is the foundation of Water—is this not the yin one? Water is the Dao, the principle of the three-one.*

The three-one—are they the three *dantian*?

If I can guard them, I shall ride the Dragon Pill and wander in the Upper Clarity.

The three are all obtained from the one.

If one knows this, then half of my elixir is already complete.

Thus, Metal is born from Water, and Water grows from Metal.
When Metal and Water meet in measure, the elixir is perfected—
one must exhaust Water and Fire.

Water and Fire are the five phases within—
not the external Water and Fire.

This is the Dao, by which the Three Sovereigns set their example,
and Confucius expounded the *Ten Wings* to aid it.

*Virtue* is attainment—
cultivate it in the body, and virtue becomes true.

What is *true*?
Is it the Golden Elixir nourishing the form?

Cultivation of the external is not what I call *true*.

Laozi said: *The highest virtue does not virtue itself,
and does not seek virtue as virtue—
it is the lower seeking it.*

Thus, the highest virtue is Water;
the lowest virtue is Metal.

My Golden Elixir has the principle of pottery and casting,
the timing of the sun and moon—
when the sun is full and the moon is full, they alternately pass the torch.
The *Classic* says: *Virtue governs vital qi*—this is so.

The numbers of yin and yang are complete.

The five phases move in cycles—
clear and turbid unfold and contract,
as yang prevails and gradually intermingles,
while yin lies dormant and returns to the treasure.

This is called *true virtue*—how could the elixir fail to form?

The five phases complete themselves in Earth.
If a person ingests it, their qi transforms into treasure—
thus, they attain longevity, becoming a *True Person*.

Thus it is said: *Earth has five virtues*—
not the virtues of the world, such as *ren* (benevolence), *yi* (righteousness), *li* (ritual), *zhi* (wisdom), and *xin* (faith).

The Sun is the essence of accumulated yang—
its number is nine.
In Heaven, it forms the *xiang* (constellation);
on Earth, it forms the *xing* (shape).
It harmonizes all things,
spreading qi to give life to all beings.

Within it is the *bàwū* (striding crow),
the essence of yin.
Its *xiang* is protective and encompassing,
as *hun* and *po* intertwine—
thus, it belongs to the *lǐ* branch and the Fire palace,
also attaining the number nine.

Its gathered qi is the *jūyīng* (crimson seed)—
when refined, it solidifies its form,
thus aligning with the *èryùyī* (two-five-one) mystery.

Thus, the Sun governs the blood vessels—
it is the father of the elixir.

The ancient *Perfect Ones* refined the Sun’s essence,
and their bodies returned to pure yang,
wandering in the Supreme Clarity.

The Moon is the essence of yin—
accumulated, it forms the *kǎn* (abyss),
dwelling in the Water direction,
its number one.

My elixir’s Metal—
is it not like the Moon?

Yang interacts with yin,
congealing into substance.

Thus, the *kǎn* *xiang* is inner yang and outer yin.

The Sun and Moon move at varying speeds,
and the elixir’s nature has dryness and slowness.
Yang is dry;
yin is slow.

But the elixir is otherwise:
Yang is slow;
yin is dry.

Dryness—like the Moon’s movement;
slowness—like the Sun’s movement.

The Sun’s movement—
one degree per day and night,
completing a full cycle in a year.

The Moon’s movement—
twelve degrees per day and night,
completing a full cycle in a day.

Thus, the Sun and Moon—
twelve degrees unite in a year.

The Sage, therefore, takes the symbol of thirty days—
the sequential conjunction of the Sun and Moon—
and opens the cauldron,
purifying my elixir.

The Sun has the crow;
the Moon has the toad and rabbit—
why?

The crow is the essence of yin qi;
the toad and rabbit are the essence of yang qi.

The two qi merge and protect,
returning to nature—
the two qi are inner symbols,
the two qi are outer symbols.

The Sun and Moon’s dual functions are the elixir’s *xiégài* (auxiliary agents).
What is *xiégài*?

The Golden Cauldron—
*kǎn* and *lí* paired to form it?

Thus, *kǎn* is yin, the Moon;
*lí* is yang, the Sun—
Water, Earth, and Metal are the three unified substances.

When the two qi merge within the cauldron,
their light shines and leaps—
is it not like the Sun and Moon linked in an endless chain across the six directions?

Nourish and refine it for a thousand days,
and yin will be exhausted—immortality attained.

Let me establish symbols to verify this.

The *Xuánwǔ* (Mysterious Tortoise) is yin;
the serpent is yang;
the tortoise is yin—
the principle of male and female,
the Dao of the Golden Tortoise.

The pairing of tortoise and serpent—
this is the natural yin and yang of Heaven and Earth.

Thus, the supreme elixir requires the pairing of yin and yang,
extracting the finest essences,
uniting spirit and truth,
with master and minister in proper measure—
then, in accordance with the Sun and Moon’s conjunction,
following the four seasons’ circulation,
only then is it supreme.

What is *exchange and union*?
The male *kǎn*, the female *lí*—
paired with the Sun and Moon, secretly merging,
exhausting one *yuánqì* (primordial breath) as the elixir sprouts.

*Yuánqì* is sixty days.

Thus, from the *yín* hour to the *shēn* hour—
seven returns.

From *zǐ* to *shēn*—
nine returns—
the principle of seven returns is complete.

Thus, the supreme elixir—
at the conjunction of new and full moons,
pursues the principle of the child’s growth and the parent’s longevity,
and completes its cycle here—
this is the use of Fire.

Heaven completes one cycle in a day and night,
moving through 365 degrees.
The Sun, Moon, and stars revolve around Heaven—
thus, Heaven descends and Earth ascends,
the Sun unites once,
and all things are thereby generated and transformed.

Five days—
the symbol of one *yuánqì*,
sixty times.

Thus, one month has six *yuán*,
totaling 360 times—
the first fifteen days are yang,
symbolizing spring and summer;
the latter fifteen days are yin,
symbolizing autumn and winter.
Thus, one month contains the four seasons’ principles of generation and completion.

I can embody the Dao of the annual fire’s timing,
using trigrams and nodes to open the cauldron’s vessel.

A day and night—
its twelve hours:
six are yang,
six are yin—
two *yuán* in ten days.

The daily use of Fire has its measures,
advancing and retreating,
with the principles of waxing and waning—
child and parent ascending and descending in their cycles.

*Xiāo* is to employ its time;
*xi* is to withhold its use.

The Sun and Moon meet once in thirty days.
Fifteen days round—
the half-year’s symbol of two seasons;
until the new moon, when yin prevails—
the year’s symbol is complete.
Thus, the medicine lies fully concealed.

The new moon is birth,
so I model my medicine upon it,
adding or subtracting, cleansing and refining—
this is the timing of years, months, days, and hours.

The *Classic* says:
*"Thirty spokes converge at a single hub."*
This is the method of daily Fire use.

The Sage thus entrusted the *Yì*’s symbols,
establishing trigrams and nodes.
*Lún* and *Méng*—
their clarity comes from dawn and dusk,
so dawn is governed by *Lún*,
dusk by *Méng*—
thus, no error in the waxing and waning.

*Jìjí* and *Wèijì*—
the beginning and end of the month,
the agents of their affairs.

Who knows that within yin there is yang?
Like lead containing white gold—
thus, the yellow sprout emerges from the River Cart.
What is this Dao?
Lead and mercury forge it.

Then, the yin valley contains the yang flower—
this is the essence of inner correspondence.
Compare it to parents transmitting *qi* to form the body;
what sustains the void is the essence-*qi* of the body.
Those who use gold, silver, lead flowers, and cinnabar as the yellow sprout—
is it not like using flesh as a womb?

Who knows that within yang there is also yin?
Yang containing yin, like the Sun’s eclipse—
this is the hidden resonance of yin and yang.
Thus, mercury is born from cinnabar—
yang within yin!
Mercury is yin in nature yet contains yang essence;
*Lí* is externally yang but internally yin.
White gold produced by the River Cart—
yin containing yang.
Its clouds follow the Dragon,
its winds follow the Tiger!
Yin and yang are the Dao of Nature.

My supreme medicine—
its prohibitions, its regulations—
each has its method.
Can this be conveyed by mere documents?
Its essence lies in the Master and Guest mutually nurturing,
harvesting the Four Seasons,
refining the Five Phases—
only then does the supreme medicine emerge.
Thus, it can restore marrow and extend longevity—
how could it not rely on the essence of the Four Spirits,
the purity of the Five Phases?

Those who forge medicine from lone yin and scant yang
can only cure illness—
how could they reverse aging and return to the True?
Why?
Their vital essence is incomplete.
Some see cinnabar concealed beside Fire,
manifesting in mercury,
and say, *"Only mercury can forge the medicine!"*
This is as if a man could generate himself,
or a woman conceive without seed—
never seen since humanity’s birth.

I shall speak of the Nine Transformations’ method,
and have illustrated it.
Within is the Central Yellow Palace,
the domain of *wù-jǐ*—
its exterior is black,
then white,
then red,
then green.
The Green Dragon occupies the east,
the White Tiger the west,
the Vermilion Bird the south,
the Dark Tortoise the north—
and there are Sun, Moon, and stars,
the Five Phases generating and overcoming.
The white gold seed is planted,
making the spiritually adept perceive clearly.
The *Classic* says:
*"Cast it, and it becomes a pearl."*
This is the creation of the Immortals.
As a staff, it subdues like punishment;
as a mirror, it banishes malevolent spirits.

The *Tàiyì*—
the Sun, Moon, and stars are insufficient for its height,
the Four Quarters and Eight Extremes are insufficient for its distance—
near in the body, far in Heaven and Earth.
Heaven, Earth, and Man—
if one attains it, all become great.
Great—
great in form, great in character—
one person is great!
One—
the True One—
those who attain it become True Persons.
They can transform without limit,
command spirits and summon souls—
the power of the Divine Elixir.

To contain Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—
there are green, yellow, red, white, and black.
The Four Symbols divide and govern,
the Five Spirits lack none in power,
the Seven Luminaries display their brilliance—
arrayed in order, ruled by measure—
the foundation of the Primordial,
the suitability of the Manifested—
one can nourish the body and shed the flesh,
and forever dwell at the world’s edge.

*Yì*—
easy, yet encompassing all symbols.
Thus, the Sage exhausted the Sun and Moon,
penetrating the profound and the obscure.
Yet Heaven’s *Yì* has sixteen,
Earth’s *Yì* has sixteen,
Man’s *Yì* has sixteen,
Ghosts’ *Yì* has sixteen—
totaling sixty-four.

If Heaven displays its symbols above,
the Five Stars wander in their mansions,
revealing calamity and fortune;
dawn and dusk divide the light,
overseeing the exchange of yin and yang.

Displayed on Earth,
it transforms *qi* into myriad forms,
planting and nurturing in season;
nesting, dwelling in caves—
each finds its place.

Displayed for Ghosts,
it shapes the formless,
erasing guilt and granting rebirth.

Displayed for Man,
body and spirit soar together,
clinging to the Dragon, riding the clouds—
saluting the Nine Heavens, roaming the Three Palaces,
living as long as the Three Lights.

Thus, the Sage entrusted the *Yì*’s symbols
to refine *yuánqì*,
solidifying form and preserving spirit,
receiving the Four Symbols to attain spiritual clarity,
harvesting the Five Phases to subdue them—
cycling through the Twenty-Four Seasons,
until the supreme medicine is complete.

At ten months,
the embryo unites with Heaven and Earth’s creation.
This Dao can make one return to the Origin and revert to the Primordial.

Man is endowed with *yuánqì* to form the body,
yet is burdened by accumulated yin.
To reverse yin and return to yang,
a thousand days are needed to temper the cold form,
transforming skin, hair, bone, and flesh—
when they become gold and jade, one ascends to Heaven
and attains the rank of True Person.

This is the resolve of the determined scholar—
to refine elixir and body alike, and thus pursue it!

Those who merely aspire to the Great Elixir and ascend to Heaven
are already deluded.

The ancients who ascended did so in plain robes,
ingesting the Lower Elixir first,
thus encountering the Upper Elixir
and attaining Heaven—
for such was their innate destiny.

In days of old, the Yellow Emperor cast nine tripods
in the wilds of Jing Mountain,
to symbolize the Nine Regions.
The First Region was Ji,
the Second, Jing,
the Third, Qing,
the Fourth, Xu,
the Fifth, Yu,
the Sixth, Yong,
the Seventh, Liang,
the Eighth, Yan,
the Ninth, Yang.

Each governed the auspicious and inauspicious of its domain—
yet these were not the uses of the supreme elixir.

Only the elixirs of those who transcended the world
trace their lineage to the Three Sovereigns.
What are the Three Sovereigns?
The Celestial Sovereign, the Terrestrial Sovereign,
and the Human Sovereign.

The Three Sovereigns left behind writings
speaking of the Three Gates.
The Three Gates held three tripods—
the Lü and the Two—making nine in total.

Thus there are:
the Upper Elixir of the Highest Immortal,
the Upper Elixir of the Middle Immortal,
and the Upper Elixir of the Lowest Immortal.
These are the Nine-Cycle Returning Elixirs.

Next are the methods of the Golden Fluid,
also rooted in the logic of the Returning Elixir.
To abandon these for lesser practices
is but to cure disease—
nothing more.

Thus the Great Elixir of the Three Sovereigns
is the foundation of transcendence.

Within the elixir are three elixirs,
corresponding to the Three Heavens, the Three Fives, the Three Lights,
and the Three Talents.

Within the three elixirs are nine revered forms,
corresponding to the Nine Regions, the Nine Palaces, the Nine Qi,
the Nine Heavens, and the Nine Earths.
Each corresponds to celestial hosts with divine guardians—
named the Nine Grades,
thus called the Nine Tripods.

Within one tripod lies the Great Tripod of Luoyang,
its white as silk,
its platform three-tiered,
its furnace eight-sided.
The Flame Emperor enters the *Lí* Gate,
while yin clouds swirl within the *Kǎn*,
thus forming unity.
The world, Heaven and Earth,
the sun, moon, and stars,
the Twenty-Eight Constellations,
the Four Spirits and Five Phases,
rulers and subjects, figures and forms,
lands, mountains, and rivers,
golden platforms and jade towers,
treasure flowers and rare fruits,
jade nectar and sweet springs—
their fragrance permeates the air.
Those who consume it transcend to the Highest Immortals,
wandering in the Hall of Numinous Mushrooms.

The Venerable Master said:
*"I am not one born of Nature’s spontaneity,
but one who learned and attained this."*

The three elixir furnaces differ in scale and fire-count—
their diagrams appear in separate volumes.

To cultivate the supreme elixir, one must first set up the furnace.
The furnace is the tripod, the ramparts and moats.
A tripod without a furnace
is like a man without a dwelling,
a city without its outer walls—
how could it stand secure?

Thus the furnace is the tripod’s gate,
a shelter from winds and gaps,
so the Three Qi do not disperse.
The platform has three tiers,
the furnace eight sides and eight gates,
the Twelve Celestial Stems intersecting,
aligned with the Dipper’s position.
Its form resembles the Tortoise Mountain,
adjusting in size as needed.

The *Classic* says:
*"Before Heaven and Earth arose, it was born,
with ramparts on either side—
a likeness of Penglai."*

Thus one must know the celestial patterns above,
the earthly geography below,
human affairs within,
master the *Xuàn* diagrams,
harmonize yin and yang,
discern the Four Seasons’ auspicious and inauspicious,
grasp the sun’s and moon’s ascensions and descents,
adjust the fire’s timing,
and observe the rites of life and death.
This is the foremost concern in cultivating the supreme elixir.
To act rashly is to fail without exception.

Moreover, Heaven and Earth’s establishment
has boundaries between yin and yang,
fixed positions for the Child and the Horse,
spring’s birth and autumn’s death—
the natural order of Heaven and Earth.

The sun and moon intersect,
yin and yang have their stations,
the supreme elixir has its symbols,
the fire’s timing has its diagrams—
used as in a cyclical method.

The first month corresponds to *Jiǔ Èr*,
when the elixir’s body harmonizes and begins to form.
Its hexagram is *Tài* ,
its tone *Tàizhù*.
*Tài* means *Kǎn* below and *Lián* above.
*Tài* marks the beginning of convergence,
yang and yin balanced,
the Tiger’s spring birth,
sprouts swelling with vitality.
The Four Symbols unite as one,
mysterious and indistinct.
The virtuous occupy their place,
their power vast and boundless.
This is the breath of yang.

The second month corresponds to *Jiǔ Sì*,
when mercury transmutes into gold.
Its hexagram is *Dà Zhuàng* ,
its tone *Jiá Zhōng*.
*Dà Zhuàng* means *Kǎn* below and *Zhèn* above.
The yang lines grow stronger,
*Kǎn* transforms into spirit,
emeralds and pomegranates blend as one root,
pure qi mingles—
victory and defeat unclear,
some sink, some float,
forming the *Mǎo* Gate’s symbol.
This is the breath of yang.

The third month corresponds to *Jiǔ Wǔ*,
when impurities are washed away,
its radiance advancing with clarity.
Its hexagram is *Guì* ,
its tone *Gū Xǐ*.
*Guì* means *Kǎn* below and *Duì* above—
five yang and one yin.
Its body is where yin and yang intermingle,
just and gentle in measure.
Yin retreats in concealment,
the age of the Flying Dragon.
This is the breath of yang.

The fourth month corresponds to *Shàng Jiǔ*,
the time of the Fire Monarch,
when its essence is sealed.
Its hexagram is *Qián* ,
its tone *Zhòng Lǘ*.
The Dragon lies potent yet hidden,
the serpent coiled—
its patterns and laws marked,
yin and yang take root,
yang at its peak then sinks,
guard against excess.
This is the breath of yang.

The fifth month corresponds to *Chū Liù*,
when the supreme elixir’s yang is active
yet positioned in yin.
Its hexagram is *Pí* ,
its tone *Gēng Bīn*.
*Pí* means *Kǎn* above and *Xùn* below.
Its beginnings form,
frost and snow its purity,
the embryo thick and fertile.
Yin rules as yang’s master,
the pivot of the Dao,
concealment as its gate.
The arrival of frost,
ice hard and cold.
This is the breath of yin.

The sixth month corresponds to *Liù Èr*,
when softness transmutes into strength,
its path now flourishing—
though the world fixes on mercury alone.

The seventh month corresponds to *Liù Sān*,
when mercury’s nature is pure yang,
and the elixir reaches its peak—
life and formation now complete,
its breath already still.
Its hexagram is *Dùn*,
its tone *Lín Zhōng*.
*Dùn* means *Kùn* below and *Qián* above.
*Dùn* hides and withdraws,
nurturing and dwelling in repose,
not revealing itself to gain renown,
awaiting the time to unfold.
Once the congealed essence is exhausted,
it ascends in straight lines upon its carriage.
This is the breath of yin.

The eighth month corresponds to *Liù Wǔ*,
when the metal *qi* reigns supreme,
and the elixir’s substance is refined—
the toad and hare thus perfect the luminous round.
Its hexagram is *Guān*,
its tone *Nán Lǘ*.
*Guān* means *Kùn* below and *Xùn* above.
The Dipper establishes *Nán Lǘ*,
observing scales and balances,
to cultivate the primordial *qi*,
replacing decline with flourishing.
The *Mǎo* and *Yǒu* gates stand,
the willow falls while the mallow rises,
harvesting the sprouts,
so calamity no longer prevails.
This is the breath of yin.

The ninth month corresponds to *Jiǔ Èr*,
when the divine *qi* transforms into concealment—
the foundation of fire.
Its hexagram is *Bō*,
its tone *Wú Shè*.
*Bō* means *Kùn* below and *Gèn* above.
*Bō* destroys the body,
plunging into silence,
returning to its aged state,
its essence congealed yet unascended.
When *Pǐ* reaches its extreme, *Tài* follows;
consumption and dissolution grow faint,
the primal auspiciousness flourishes—
the yellow garment beneath.
This is the breath of yin.

The tenth month corresponds to *Shàng Liù*,
when the supreme elixir is fully formed.
Its hexagram is *Kùn*,
its tone *Yìng Zhōng*.
*Kùn* softens the *qi* into unity,
ashen earth its shape,
profound principles like hidden springs,
the *Xīng* of yang, the *Jīng* of yin.
The law is structured, ready to be measured,
the cycle of giving and receiving completes formation.
First, the furnace’s ashes obscure,
then the thread is feared and stirred—
the Dragon battles, drinking blood,
yet its name brings no merit.
This is the breath of yin.

The eleventh month corresponds to *Chū Liù*,
when yang *qi* lies dormant at its edge.
Its hexagram is *Fù*,
its tone *Huáng Zhōng*.
*Fù* means *Kùn* above and *Zhèn* below.
Yang *qi* hides,
nurturing yin’s virtue,
its form blurred yet bound by cosmic law,
a model for all—
first obscured, then revealed.
This is the breath of yin.

The twelfth month corresponds to *Jiǔ Èr*,
when sprouts and seedlings begin to thrive,
the Dipper establishes *Zǐ Chǒu*,
marking the start of the meditative posture.
Its hexagram is *Lín*,
its tone *Dà Lǘ*.
*Lín* means *Duì* below and *Kùn* above.
It circles the furnace, its boundaries complete,
the Dragon seen in the fields,
its radiance divided yet brilliant.
Now it begins its migration,
pushing and yielding in turn,
never acting first,
the morning mist tasted,
the past no longer guiding the present.
This is the breath of yang.

The Heavenly Elder says:
*"What has been listed before
is like beads strung on a thread,
clear and orderly—
unveiling the intricate mysteries of the Daoist Immortals!*
I shall now clarify their applications.

*Fù* reveals the loss of companions,
and the initial rising of fire.
Why?
*Kùn* consists of six yin lines.
The first line changes to yang,
so one yang line beneath five yin—
this is the attainment of companions.
A line that changes to yang—
this is the loss of companions.
*Fù* is *Kùn* above and *Zhèn* below,
the initial stage of the yellow sprout,
the symbol of nurturing the unmanifest,
the guardian of transformation.
*Zhèn* reveals its change.
*Qián* consists of six yang lines,
and *Zhèn* is *Qián*’s eldest son.
Why?
*Kùn* changes from below,
thus becoming *Zhèn*;
*Zhèn* changes from above,
thus becoming *Gèn*—
hence, it is the eldest son,
inheriting the body of *Qián*.
Thus, *Kùn* is *Qián*’s position,
and *Qián* is *Kùn*’s position,
each serving as host to the other.

In the eleventh month,
one line of *Kùn* changes to yang,
and by the fourth month,
all six lines are complete,
returning to *Qián*’s position and function.
*Xùn* reveals its completion.
The sun is yang,
the moon is yin.
From the first day to the fifteenth,
the moon changes and becomes *Qián*.
Thus, *Zhèn*’s function is passed on.
When the moon reaches its fullness at the sixteenth,
it changes one line of *Qián* to *Xùn*—
one yin line is born.
The long line is yang,
the short line is yin—
mercury’s nature is rigid yet hard to subdue.
Thus, it transforms hardness into softness,
completing the elixir’s essence in gentleness.
Hence, *Xùn* receives *Qián*’s transformation,
and on the sixteenth day,
the moon emerges from the *Xùn* earth,
the elixir forming from the new moon’s dawn—
now fire too seeks concealment.

*Zhūn* is *Kǎn* above and *Zhèn* below,
illustrating my purpose—
the fire of day, the fire of moon.
Thus, morning’s function aligns with *Zhūn*’s directness,
evening’s with *Méng*’s directness,
and the waning and waxing phases with *Jìjí* and *Wèijì*.
When the moon reaches its waning and waxing phases,
the vessel is opened to receive yang’s single line.
The moon’s fifteenth day is yang,
and the yang descends to its proper position by the sixteenth.
Its yang is diminished,
so the sun’s light wanes,
changing *Qián* to *Xùn*—
this is the transformation from rigid to soft.
*Duì* reveals its equilibrium.
The sun and moon unite once every thirty days,
and after three days of union,
their light begins to appear.
Thus, the eighth day is called the *upper* crescent,
and the twenty-third day the *lower* crescent.
Crescent means equilibrium.
From the first to the eighth day,
the moon’s waxing reaches half its equilibrium;
from the fifteenth to the twenty-third day,
the moon’s waning depletes half its equilibrium.

My use of fire spans from the first to the eighth day—when metal and water merge—
and by the twenty-third day, the medicine is perfected, motionless.
This is its equilibrium.
**Guàn** reveals its form.

Metal is born at *sì*, reigns at *yǒu*, and is buried at *chǒu*.
Autumn is the season when metal reigns.
On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, its form is round and bright,
and my medicine reaches this stage—
the *Qián* body is now complete,
its five colors radiant,
growing ever firm and solid.
*Chǒu* is the burial of metal,
the position of **Guàn**.
The medicine reaches **Guàn**, its form now clear.

Metal reveals itself only through metal.
By the twenty-third day, it appears in the *bǐng* region,
the lower crescent, motionless—
my medicine lies dormant.

**Qián** reveals its rigidity.
On the first day of the moon, the yang line’s *xiào* intermingle and generate,
reaching fullness by the fifteenth day.
My medicine, when heated for fifteen days,
has metal and water unite, each attaining its place.

Mercury is yang and of rigid nature—
difficult to subdue.
By method, it is made motionless.

The east is the domain of wood.
Metal flourishes with wood;
by the fifteenth day, the moon is in the *shù* region,
the *jiǎ* earth—
its fullness now complete in *jiǎ*.

**Kūn** reveals its transformation.
The single line of **Kūn** shifts to become **Zhen**.
**Zhen** is wood, is yang;
**Kūn** is yin.
Yet it nurtures one yang with five soils.
Yang is wood—mercury is its likeness,
like lead with silver within.
Thus it is said: **Kūn** is the mother of **Zhen**!

**Qián** and **Kūn** combine twelve lines,
the symbol of a year,
establishing the foundation of omens.
What does this mean?
From **Kūn**, yang is born,
from *zǐ* to *sì*—
the six lines’ transformations are complete.
**Qián** arises from *wǔ* to *hài*,
six lines shifting back to **Kūn**.
**Kūn** is soil—
my medicine, after twelve months, becomes soil,
its work now finished.

The *Classic* says: Metal is born from the moon.
At the new moon, it receives the sun’s seal,
so the first day is called *Fù*—
yang *qi* begins to flow.
From the last day to the new moon,
**Zhen** arrives to receive its seal,
following **Kūn** to generate the **Zhen** dragon.
Then, after the moon’s birth,
**Kūn** transforms into **Zhen**—
end and beginning in cycle!

The first month is **Tài**—
the full symbol of the sun’s crow is complete.
Its three lines are yang.
This month holds:
**Lún** (*Zhen* below, *Kàn* above),
**Méng** (*Kàn* below, **Guàn** above),
**Xū** (*Qián* below, *Kàn* above),
**Sòng** (*Kàn* below, **Kūn** above),
**Shī** (*Kàn* below, *Lí* above),
**Bǐ** (below *Kàn*, above).
They align with their proper order.

Thus, on the first day,
morning uses **Lún**, evening **Méng**;
on the second day,
morning uses **Xū**, evening **Sòng**;
on the third day,
morning uses **Shī**, evening **Bǐ**.
From the first to the third day—
its **Zhen** is in motion.

The second month is **Dà Zhuàng**.
The moon clings to the sun but is unseen.
On the fourth day,
morning uses **Xiǎo Chù** (*Qián* below, *Xùn* above),
evening **Lǚ** (**Duì** below, *Qián* above);
on the fifth day,
morning uses **Tài** (*Qián* below, **Kūn** above),
evening **Pǐ** (**Kūn** below, *Qián* above);
on the sixth day,
morning uses **Tóng Rén** (*Lí* below, *Qián* above),
evening **Dà Yǒu** (*Qián* below, *Lí* above).

The third month is **Guì**—
the moon’s right side begins to grow.
On the third day, it appears in the *gēng* region, split asunder.
Thus, for every use of fire in one watch,
there are six lunar watches—
so twelve months yield seventy-two,
its work complete at a thousand.

This month, on the seventh day,
morning uses **Qiān** (**Guàn** below, **Kūn** above),
evening **Yù** (**Kūn** below, **Zhen** above);
on the eighth day,
morning uses **Suí** (**Zhen** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Guì** (*Xùn* below, **Guàn** above);
on the ninth day,
morning uses **Lín** (**Duì** below, **Kūn** above),
evening **Guān** (**Kūn** below, *Xùn* above).

The fourth month is **Qián**.
On the eighth day, the upper crescent appears in the *dīng* region,
its equilibrium straight as a cord.
The moon has two *qi*—
twelve months yield twenty-four *qi*.
On the fifteenth day, the two crescents merge their vital essence,
thus **Qián** and **Kūn** unite to form the *èr bā*,
in accord with the *Yì*’s way—
upright and unerring.

On the tenth day,
morning uses **Shì Hé** (**Zhen** below, *Lí* above),
evening **Bì** (*Lí* below, **Guàn** above);
on the eleventh day,
morning uses **Bó** (**Kūn** below, **Guàn** above),
evening **Fù** (**Kūn** above, **Zhen** below);
on the twelfth day,
morning uses **Wú Wàng** (**Zhen** below, *Qián* above),
evening **Dà Chù** (*Qián* below, **Guàn** above).

The fifth month is **Jù**—
the full symbol of the sun’s crow is complete.
By the fifteenth day, the *Qián* body is complete,
round and luminous in the *shù* region.
On the thirteenth day,
morning uses **Yí** (**Zhen** below, **Guàn** above),
evening **Dà Guò** (*Xùn* below, **Duì** above);
on the fourteenth day,
morning uses **Xián** (**Guàn** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Cháng** (*Xùn* below, **Zhen** above);
on the fifteenth day,
morning uses **Dùn** (**Guàn** below, *Qián* above),
evening **Dà Zhuàng** (*Qián* below, **Zhen** above).

The sixth month is **Dùn**;
the seventh month is **Pǐ**—
the full symbol of the hare is complete.
Metal and water together receive the *Tài Yáng*’s *qi*,
nurtured to form the elixir of return.

The *Classic* says: **Qián** is vigorous, bright, and flourishing.
The sun has twelve hours—
thirty days yield three hundred sixty,
so each month has one day of fire use.
In all, one small cycle is twelve months.

The sixteenth day,
morning uses **Jìn** (**Kūn** below, **Lí** above),
evening **Míng Yí** (**Lí** below, **Kūn** above);

the seventeenth day,
morning uses **Jiā Rén** (**Lí** below, **Xùn** above),
evening **Kuí** (**Duì** below, **Lí** above);

the eighteenth day,
morning uses **Jiǎn** (**Gèn** below, **Kǎn** above),
evening **Jiě** (**Kǎn** below, **Zhèn** above).

The eighth month is **Guān**—
the Five Phases shift in sovereignty,
mutually restraining to govern.
The *Classic* says: On the sixteenth,
its *turn* receives the *tong* (统).
**Xùn**’s *tong* appears at dawn,
**Xùn** cuts off its *tong*, so the sixteenth *turn* receives the *tong*.

The moon waxes then wanes,
so the sixteenth *turn* mutually calls (喊) to one another.
The gap in one *qi* cycle ends on the fifteenth day,
and its color transforms—
the sun shines and illuminates at the *rì quē* (日阙),
thus mercury transforms into liquid!

The nineteenth day,
morning uses **Sǔn** (**Duì** below, **Gèn** above),
evening **Yì** (**Zhèn** below, **Xùn** above);

the twentieth day,
morning uses **Guài** (**Qián** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Gǔ** (**Xùn** below, **Qián** above);

the twenty-third day,
morning uses **Cuì** (**Kūn** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Shēng** (**Xùn** below, **Kūn** above).

The ninth month is **Bō**—
the moon wanes on its right,
while its left remains like a hook.
On the first day, it appears in the **Bǐng** region.
**Gèn** stands straight in the **Bǐng**’s south.
The *lower half* of the month is the twenty-third day.
**Bǐng**’s *principle* converges with its essence,
the **Qián** and **Kūn** forms are complete.

The twenty-fourth day,
morning uses **Kùn** (**Kǎn** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Jǐng** (**Xùn** below, **Kǎn** above);

the twenty-fifth day,
morning uses **Gé** (**Lí** below, **Duì** above),
evening **Dǐng** (**Xùn** below, **Lí** above);

the twenty-sixth day,
morning uses **Zhèn**,
evening uses **Gèn**.

The tenth month is **Kūn**—
the full symbol of the moon is complete.
It is twice diminished to form **Gèn**,
and the twenty-third day of the lower half.
Its water is half a *jīn* (斤).
In all, the alchemical uses of fire, medicine,
and returning to earth’s function are combined,
so its form resembles earthly ash.

The twenty-seventh day,
morning uses **Cán** (**Gèn** below, **Xùn** above),
evening **Guī Mèi** (**Duì** below, **Zhèn** above);

the twenty-eighth day,
morning uses **Fēng** (**Lí** below, **Zhèn** above),
evening **Lǚ** (**Gèn** below, **Lí** above);

the twenty-ninth day,
morning uses **Xùn**,
evening uses **Duì**.

The eleventh month is **Fù**—
the month of renewal, where the sun and moon together complete their cycle of thirty days.
Hence, the sun and moon unite on the **Kūn** root,
while the **yīn-yáng** *qi* converges and is stored within.

When sun and moon unite, the **jīnshā** (金砂, gold-sand) aligns according to its share.
This is the **Kūn**’s thirtieth day—
the day of the **jìxū** (节虚, hollow nodes), the day when the sun and moon’s phases are obscured by eclipses or conjunctions.

The twenty-eighth day,
morning uses **Huàn** (**Kǎn** below, **Xùn** above),
evening uses **Jié** (**Kǎn** above, **Duì** below);

the twenty-ninth day,
morning uses **Zhōngfú** (**Xùn** above, **Duì** below),
evening uses **Xiǎoguò** (**Zhèn** above, **Gèn** below);

the thirtieth day,
morning uses **Jìjiè** (**Kǎn** above, **Lí** below),
evening uses **Wèijiè** (**Lí** above, **Kǎn** below).
Thus, I derive the **Kūn** cycle.

**Kūn** is the **yīn** position,
one transformation yielding **Zhèn**.
**Zhèn** inherits the **Qián** essence,
being the eldest son.

**Zhèn** transforms once into **Duì**,
**Duì** once into **Fù**,
completing the **Qián**’s three phases.
Thus, I derive the **Qián** cycle.

**Qián** is the **yáng** position,
one transformation yielding **Xùn**.
**Xùn** then receives its governance,
returning to the **Kūn** position.

**Xùn** transforms once into **Gèn**,
**Gèn** once again into **Kūn**.
**Kūn** is when the alchemical **virtue/power** is fully realized.
**Kǎn** and **Lí** are the two essential phases.

The **Yuányáng Zǐ** (元阳子, Primordial Yang Master) says:
*"Lónghǔ* (龍虎, Dragon and Tiger) are **qiān yóu** (鉛汞, lead and mercury);
**jīntǔ** (金虎, Golden Tiger) is **qiān** (鉛, lead),
the foundation of **huán dān** (還丹, elixir).
**Qiān**’s hue is black, belonging to the northern realm,
the waters of **rén guǐ** (壬癸, the ninth and tenth heavenly stems),
the singular count of water.

He who knows its singularity
comprehends all affairs.
Thus, **qiān** contains the five colors,
embodies the quintessence of the five phases—
this is the fate of the immortals.

The **Lǎozǐ** (老子) says:
*"Bào yī shǒu zhōng, zǐ shēn zì zhòng* (抱一守中，子身自仲).
He who clings to the singular and upholds the center
shall naturally find his body sustained."

Great is the Dao of the singular!
I observe the **three yellows and one black** (三黄一黑) that confer immortality—
what does this mean?

This is the name of the **soul-nurturing elixir** (灵丹).
In the human body, it manifests as three,
yet one refines the three—
thus ascending to **feīxiān** (飞仙, transcendence).

The three are:
**mù** (木, wood, i.e., sulfur),
**qiān** (鉛, lead),
and **dānshā** (丹砂, cinnabar).
The one is **shuǐ** (水, water),
for **dānshā** is the essence of the southern realm’s **Tàiyáng** (太阳, Great Sun),
its essence being **gǒng** (汞, mercury).
**Gǒng** is the **Qīnglóng** (青龙, Azure Dragon),
the wood’s singular count.

Wood generates fire,
fire is red and belongs to the southern realm—
thus binding the **Fùmǔ** (父母, parent-child) positions.
Wood’s essence, when joined with metal,
becomes **qiān**—
**qiān**, being metal, the Azure Dragon dwelling within the wood’s essence,
is the **Zhōngnán** (中男, Central Male).

**Qiān**’s metal essence resides in **yǒu** (酉, the tenth earthly branch),
dwelling in the western realm as **Báihǔ** (白虎, White Tiger)—
the **Zhōngnǚ** (中女, Central Female).

The **Èrshísì Shèng Gē** (二十四圣歌, Twenty-Four Sacred Hymns) states:
*"Central Male and Central Female,
reside at the gates of **Zǐwǔ** (子午, the fourth and tenth branches),
only when the sun and moon are distinctly divided,
does the longest reign begin.*

*Central Male subdues the Central Female,
both yielding to ash,
uniting with water and earth.
This is the grand principle of the five phases.*

**Dānshā** (丹砂, cinnabar) emerges from **gǒng** (汞, mercury),
**gǒng** being the essence of **yáng** (阳, yang),
prone to ascendance yet difficult to contain—
this is the **Lǎonǚ** (姥女, Old Lady)!

Thus it is said:
*"The Old Lady of the Riverbank,
is subtle and most divine—
when fire is obtained, she ascends,
unseen by filth and dust.
Dragon hides, Tiger conceals,
none know their abode.
To subdue her,
take the yellow sprout as root.*

*The yellow sprout is **qiān** (鉛, lead) and **shuǐ** (水, water);
**gǒng** (汞, mercury) is fire—
can water subdue fire?

Wood’s nature is upright, subduing metal,
water’s nature is yielding, subduing earth,
earth’s nature is thick, subduing wood,
metal’s nature is firm, subduing fire.
This is the profound root and grand Dao
of **qiān yóu** (鉛汞, lead and mercury),
progressing gradually toward **tónglíng** (通灵, attunement with the numinous).

I possess the principle of **nà táizī** (纳胎, embryo-nurturing) and **yuánqì yánshēng** (元气延生, prolonging life through primordial *qi*).
Let me expound it:

The **Tiāndì Tàichū Yuánhé** (天地太初元和, primordial harmony of heaven and earth)
ultimately returns to singularity.
It generates all things,
thus **Qián** and **Kūn** receive the **yuánqì** (元气, primordial *qi*).
Water is the mother of **gǒng** (汞, mercury),
which in turn generates metal.

The **yīn** refines the **Xuányīn** (玄阴, profound *yin*) essence,
first igniting fire to unite with it,
and applying the **guà** (卦, trigrams).

Adding a **yáo** (爻, line) to each **xún** (旬, decan),
until **Jìjiè** (既济, Fulfilled),
then returning to **Gēngshǐ** (更始, Renewal),
thus the sun and moon intermingle,
and the **huán dān** (還丹, elixir) emerges in crimson hue.

From the northern realm, one takes the **Héchē** (河车, River Vehicle).
The **Héchē** is the **shuǐjī** (水基, water foundation)—
this is **gǒng** (汞, mercury).
One must obtain the **Nánfāng Zhǔquè** (南方朱雀, Vermilion Bird of the south),
to merge the **water-fire *qi*** and complete the **huán dān** (還丹, elixir).

The western realm’s metal is refined with **yīn-yáng** (阴阳),
emerging from **Bìshuǐ** (碧水, Jade Water),
its bloom like **yù** (玉, jade).

**Lóngshé** (龙蛇, Dragon and Serpent) are metal and fire,
when first placed in the furnace,
their subjugation is not yet fixed.
One must securely seal the **Dāoguī** (刀圭, Knife and Tablet) vessel,
lest it leak.

Metal, bloom, and **gǒng** (汞, mercury),
when forming the **huán dān** (還丹, elixir),
generate all things,
control life and death,
harmonize with heaven and earth—
they are not of the **bāshí wǔjīn** (八石五金, eight minerals and five metals) kind.

**Chànǚ** (诧女, Astonishing Maiden) is **gǒng** (汞, mercury);
**Xuányīn** (玄阴, profound *yin*) essence is the **shuǐjī** (水基, water foundation).
The two *qi* merge and return to singularity—
the **huán dān** (還丹, elixir) is complete.

The **Héchē** (河车) is not merely **gǒng** (汞, mercury),
but also the convergence of **yīn**’s laws and **yáng**’s conditions.
When the two *qi* merge,
the fire flourishes and the medicine is perfected,
its divine nature like the **Lóng** (龙, Dragon),
unfathomable.

Yet, observing its **huìshuò** (晦朔, waning and new phases),
discerning the fire’s conditions,
and examining its form and substance—
thus, all the **huán dān** (還丹, elixir) methods are exhausted.

**Gě Zhìchuān** (葛稚川) asked **Zhèng Sīyuǎn** (郑思远):
*"What is the human role in the interplay of **yīn-yáng** (阴阳)?"*

*"The **yáng** essence establishes the **hún** (魂, soul),
the **yīn** essence forms the **pò** (魄, spirit).
The two essences intermingle,
giving rise to **shénmíng** (神明, divine clarity).
When the **shén** (神, spirit) departs,
the **xíng** (形, form) perishes.

Dare I ask:
Can the **shén** be preserved?
Can the **xíng** be prolonged?
**Sīyuǎn** replied:
*"The **shén** is perfected through the **Dao**,
the **xíng** is prolonged through **shù** (术, technique)."*

**Zhìchuān** asked:
*"What is the essence of the **Dao**?"*

**Sīyuǎn** replied:
*"Take the **jīn** (金, metal) essence,
blend the **shí** (石, stone) fluid,
bind them as husband and wife,
rank them as **hún** (魂, soul) and **pò** (魄, spirit).
In one undifferentiated mass,
the two essences stir and ignite—
the **hé chē** (河车, River Vehicle) overturns,
the furnace’s vigil knows no pause.
The great kiln blazes fierce,
baking, scorching, roaring—
smoke not yet blackened,
flame without false green.
Like a whirlwind coiled,
or thunder concealed—
the **lǎonǚ** (姥女, Crone) breathes shallow,
the infant’s cry falls silent.
Piercing the **liǎng yí** (两仪, dual principles),
adorned on four walls—
how many times does it pass?
A horse gallops a post,
and lo, it dies.
Yet transformation follows change,
evil discarded, virtue ascendant—
emotion turns, nature shifts.
Purple radiance reaches inward,
red beams shoot outward,
shining like fire’s birth,
then congeals as blood-drops—
called the **zhōnghuán** (中还, Central Return).
Retreating, hidden in secrecy—
mist disperses through five viscera,
rivers flow through a hundred vessels,
bones transmute into golden growth,
complexion returns to jade-like luster.
**Yáng** virtue spreads,
**yīn** function accumulates—
the **Nángōng** (南宫, Southern Palace) records the name,
the **Běidì** (北帝, Northern Sovereign) registers the deed."

**Zhìchuān** asked:
*"Heaven and Earth are vast,
the human body is minute.
Yet one who refines the utmost essence to forge the elixir—
who can fathom its depth?
When **qi** is paired, it harmonizes;
when isolated, it falters.
Harmony brings longevity,
isolation brings early death.
This is the **Dao**—
one **yīn**, one **yáng**.
This is the **dān** (丹, elixir)—
one **jīn**, one **shí**.
The stone, riding **yáng**, grows hot;
the metal, riding **yīn**, grows cold.
Like water flowing to moisture,
or fire moving to dryness."*

**Sīyuǎn** replied:
*"**Yáng** culminates at **wèi** (巳),
**yīn** reaches its peak at **hài** (亥)—
the four seasons cycle endlessly.
Moreover, the **shí** fluid hides in the **guǐ** (鬼, spectral),
the **jīn** essence dwells in the mountains—
these are **gūyīn** (孤阴, lone **yīn**) transformations,
waiting in the **jiǔyōu** (九幽, Nine Abysses).
Better than this is the **jūnzǐ** (君子, noble) embracing the sphere,
pairing with the virtuous maiden—
thus **yīn-yáng** finds balance,
and **hún-pò** (魂魄) knows no bounds.
Yet how does one refine the **shí** fluid?
Harvested before the silkworm feeds,
used after the fire’s transformation—
**yáng** descends from above,
the empty crucible receives it.
Orbiting sun and moon,
waiting through the five **fú** (伏, scorching periods),
urgent as a drum’s beat—
the **jīn** essence will not flee.
Pour with water, and it enters **wú** (无, non-being) from **yǒu** (有, being);
warm with fire, and it enters **yǒu** from **wú**.
White powder lies abandoned—
snow itself is shamed.
Yellow tallow congeals—
gold is made plain.
Endless refinement—
the spirit soars, the **guǐ** (鬼, spectral) hastens—
lifting the **hún** essence,
thus one may match Heaven and Earth in age!"

**Wèi Xiānshēng** (魏先生) said:
*"Three and five combined—
the essence of Heaven and Earth.
Who knows their return to **yī** (一)?
**Yī** is the number of water,
the origin of the Five Phases.
It can generate Heaven and Earth as male and female,
return the sun’s essence to the moon’s cave,
bind the pure within the central **qi**—
the **Zǐlíng** (紫灵, Purple Spirit) portals align with the True.
The *Yì* (易, *I Ching*) speaks of the **Dao** supreme—
thus **qiánkūn** (乾坤, Heaven-Earth) revolve, their virtues gathered;
**kǎn-lí** (坎离, Water-Fire) act, gold and water unite—
this is the **Dao**’s pivot.
Male and female unite,
**qi** mingles, bodies merge—
this is the **Dao**’s application.
Sun and moon revolve,
cold and heat alternate—
this is the **Dao**’s verification.
**Yīn** extends, **yáng** bends,
**yáng** acts, **yīn** lies dormant—
one goes, one returns,
pushing emotion, containing nature—
this is the **Dao**’s three reversals.
Why so?
Splitting **yīqì** (一气, singular **qi**) by Heaven and Earth’s law,
merging **yǒuzuò** (有为, conditioned) with **wúzuò** (无为, unconditioned).
What need for external aid?
**Shénnóng** (神农) said:
*'Knowing white, guarding black—
one may not die.'*
What does this mean?
**White** is the essence of **jīn** (金, metal),
not the world’s **jīn**.
**Black** is the foundation of **shuǐ** (水, water),
not the world’s **gōng** (汞, mercury).
**Qiān** (铅, lead) is black without,
golden flowers within.
The **golden flowers** are the **Qīnglóng** (青龙, Azure Dragon),
its trigrams **qián** (乾, Heaven),
dwelling in the **mù** (木, Wood) position,
its number **sān** (三).
Wearing coarse robes, cradling jade—
the madman outside,
this is the **Báihǔ** (白虎, White Tiger).
Again, it is **dānshā** (丹砂, cinnabar),
**gōng** (汞, mercury),
**kūn** (坤, Earth),
dwelling in the **tǔ** (土, Earth) position,
its number **wǔ** (五).
Thus, three and five in harmony—
the eight **shí** (石, stones)’s framework.
Combining three and five,
their total is **bā** (八).
Thus, **jīn** is the mother of **shuǐ**,
its mother hidden in the child’s womb;
**shuǐ** is the child of **jīn**,
its child concealing the mother’s egg.
Why?
**Jīn-shuǐ** merge in gestation,
rolling within the mother’s depths,
awaiting transformation to birth.
Thus, the eldest son inherits the father’s form,
establishes the mother’s foundation—
cinnabar is born from **jīn**,
so mercury flows as child!
Nourishing the child with **jīn**,
inheriting form and flourishing—
this is Nature’s marvel.
The *Gǎngtōng Jué* (港通诀) says:
*'The **Xuánbái** (玄白, Mysterious White) gives birth to **Jīngōng** (金公, Metal Lord),
towering at the very beginning.'*
The *Jīnbì Piān* (金碧篇) says:
*'Red marrow flows as **gōng** (汞).'*
**Gōng** is not external—
it is born from the union of **qiánkūn** (乾坤, Heaven-Earth),
receiving **qi** and forming.
Heaven’s **qi** descends,
Earth’s **qi** responds,
**yīn-yáng** intermingle—
and **gōng** flows.
Its father is **wù-jǐ** (戊己),
its mother is **huángjīn** (黄金, yellow gold).
Thus observed, **dānshā** (丹砂) is born
from the union of the Three Powers,
harmonizing the Five Phases—
how can it be spoken of with mere words?
The *Jīng* (经) says:
*'Plant millet with millet,
cover parrots with their young.'*
This is **qiān** (铅) and **gōng** (汞)—
they serve only their own kind, do they not?"*

The **emotions** arise from **nature**, and **nature** is inherited through **emotions**; **emotions** and **nature** depend upon each other, returning to the **Dao** of spontaneity—this is the principle of **transformation**.

Yet **Heaven-Earth**, **yin-yang**, **Metal-Water**, **Wood-Earth**, and **nature-emotion**, though their origins are the same, bear different names. If they do not align with their kind, they cannot enter into harmony. Thus it is said, *"Like follows like"*—this is the meaning.

Water subdues Earth, Metal flourishes through Wood; only because they mutually subdue and generate do they become **father and mother** to one another.

**Gōng** (mercury) is not the proper element of any of the Five Phases, nor is **dānshā** (cinnabar) the pairing of **Lóng-Hǔ** (Dragon-Tiger). If they do not belong to their kind, they cannot unite.

Thus it is said:
*"Do not destroy my **lead (qiān)**, lest my life be lost;
Do not abandon my **river chariot (héchē)**, lest I fail to return home."*

Thus it is said:
*"If lead severs the river chariot, all efforts are in vain;
If lead shatters the river chariot, all works come to naught."*

Therefore, within **lead** there is **Metal**, and within **Metal** there is **returning elixir (huándān)**. If one can perceive and recognize this treasure, then the **Dao** is attained.

Yet it is better to refine the **Metal within lead** than to refine the **treasure within Metal**. From this, I know that **Dragon-Tiger** originate from **One**.

The people of the world labor with excessive cleverness, ever farther from the truth. Some say, *"Use lead!"* Others say, *"Use mercury!"*
If one truly uses **mercury**, how can **Heaven-Earth** remain upright? How can **yang-yin** be divided?
If one truly relies on **lead**, how then does **Metal-Water** arise? How does **returning** proceed?

How then can **transformation** arise from its true source?

The ancient sages praised **lead** but did not emphasize **mercury**—why?
Is it because the two together complete the work, and thus must be harmonized in beauty?
Or must **mercury** be the master, borrowing **lead’s qi** to achieve completion—how can one construct the root while neglecting the foundation?

The **Dao** is indeed hidden in what is unsaid!

Later generations, confused by this, seek to till stones for rice—how difficult it is to succeed!

Within **lead** there is **sand-mercury**, just as within a person there are **emotions** and **nature**—they are not external things. **Sand-mercury** in **lead** is not a foreign substance.

The **Three-One Dao** refines **emotions** to harmonize **nature**; when **nature** is harmonized, it returns to the root and recovers simplicity.

The **Golden Elixir** method nourishes **Metal** with **mercury**, then the soul returns and the essence is restored. If external things are **emotions**, then **nature** cannot be harmonized.

Can the **Three Officials** be steadfast?
If **water-silver** is **mercury**, then **lead** cannot be embraced.

Can the **Eight Stones** be perfected?
The **Eight Stones** are another name for the **Three-Five** (trinity of **Heaven-Earth-Man** and the Five Phases).

**Nature** governs the inner realm, establishing **Yín-È** (the alchemical furnace);
**Emotion** governs the outer realm, constructing the **city walls**.

Thus it is known that **mercury-sulfur** is the **emotion** of **lead**; the **Original Qi** is the root foundation of humankind.

**Metal** governs the outer realm, like our **emotions**;
**Mercury** governs the inner realm, like our **nature**.

To govern **mercury** with **Metal** is to uphold the principle of harmonizing **emotion** with **nature**;
To contain **essence** and nourish **spirit** is to practice the **Way** of refining **nature** and attaining **authenticity**.

The **East**—**Jia-Yi Wood**—is the **Azure Dragon**;
The **West**—**Geng-Xin Metal**—is the **White Tiger**.

When the **Dragon** calls to the **Tiger**, the **Tiger** absorbs its **essence**;
The two feed upon each other, both greedy for glory—why?
The **Dragon** is **emotion**, the **Tiger** is **nature**;
Their mutual dependence and return is the profound meaning.

Thus it is said:
The **Great Sun** flows its **pearl**,
Ever desiring to depart from humankind;
Yet when the **golden flower** is attained,
It turns and relies upon each other;
Transformed into **white elixir**, it congeals into **solid perfection**;
The **golden flower** first blooms,
After a brief moment—
It dissolves into water, like **hemp seeds** scattered.

Is this not what the world calls **mercury** and **cinnabar**?

Having already spoken of the principle of **"White Guarding Black"**, thus the **essence of the Great Mysterious** becomes the root of the **Dao**.

Pivoting **Heaven-Earth**, forging **Yin-Yang**,
In accord with **Nature**, accompanying **Transformation**,
Hence the **Two Strings** are set in order,
Combining **Two-Eight** above and below,
Attaining the **body of Heaven-Earth**.

I ponder the **Trigram of the Great Ease**,
Exhaust the functions of **Heaven-Earth**,
Thus the **six lines** contain **three hundred eighty-four**—
The **spirit** resides within them.

**Heaven’s** tally is **two hundred sixteen**,
**Earth’s** tally is **one hundred forty-four**;
Extending and lengthening them,
Classifying and accumulating them,
Totaling **twenty-five thousand two hundred**—
This is how they respond to the myriad things,
Fulfilling the **bodies of firmness and softness**!

**Heaven’s** number is **twenty-five**,
**Earth’s** number is **thirty**,
Thus **Heaven-Earth’s** number is **fifty-five**—
This is how **transformation** and **return** are accomplished.

**Heaven** is the accumulation of **Yang**,
**Earth** is the gathering of **Yin**.
When **Heaven** is **blocked** and **Earth** is **closed**, the **Divine Manifestation** appears.

The **Original Transformation** is applied uniformly,
Its function is boundless,
Also lying in the combination of **Metal-Wood-Water-Fire**.

Its cold and heat, decline and flourishing,
Like the succession of **spring, summer, autumn, winter, day, and night**—
**Metal** generating **Water**, **Water** generating **Wood**, **Wood** generating **Fire**, **Fire** generating **Earth**—this is the use of **Yang**;
**Earth** overcoming **Water**, **Water** overcoming **Fire**, **Fire** overcoming **Metal**, **Metal** overcoming **Wood**—this is the use of **Yin**.

This mutual generation and mutual destruction,
Alternating flourishing and decline,
Conforming to **Heaven-Earth’s** four seasons,
Thus forming the myriad realities.

The **Sun** is the **Yang essence**;
The **Moon** is the **Yin specter**.

**Metal** is born from the **Moon**, thus the **male of Kan**;
The **pearl** is born from the **Sun**, thus the **female of Li**.

**Metal** is the **Moon’s essence**, dwelling in the **Yang** position;
**Mercury** contains the **Li qi**, responding to the **Yin line**.

Thus, using the **Heaven-Earth’s** numinous power,
Conceiving the **Sun-Moon’s essence**,
When **Yin** is exhausted, **Yang** is born;
When **blockage** reaches its extreme, **prosperity** arrives.
Therefore, when **Metal** enters **fierce fire**, its color is not diminished by brightness—
Since the **opening of the gates**, the **Sun-Moon** have not diminished their luminosity.
This is because **Metal-Wood** nurture within,
**Water-Fire** respond without,
**Heaven’s vigor** is unceasing in its function,
The **Sun’s radiance** is not consumed but grows brighter.

The **Sun-Moon** are what enable longevity and duration,
The beginning and end of all things—
The **Dragon-Tiger** in union hold the **key to the Dao**!

Their conformity to **Heaven-Earth’s** standard,
**Yin-Yang’s** numbers,
Enables **Heaven-Earth** to respond in secret,
Like **pearls linked** and **jades joined**,
Turning endlessly without cessation.

The **Ancient Worthies** practiced this,
Thus they could **precede Heaven-Earth**,
Lead all things,
Stand alone and endure eternally,
Their **spirit-form** unaltered.

Pushing this to its utmost correctness,
It can be summed in one word:
**Mercury-sulfur**—without **Heaven-Earth**, they cannot be obtained;
**Dragon-Tiger**—without **Metal**, they cannot be entered.

When the **Great Medicine** is complete,
Then there is the method of **ingestion**.

In the **Jia-Zi decade**, the day aligns with **Jian**,
Until **Gui-Hai**, marking the **seasonal node**.

I then fast for **three days**, preserving **spirit** and steadying **thought** to ingest it—
This is one **sixty-day cycle**.

Within the **Jia-Zi decade**, if the day does not align with **Jian**,
Then **Mǎn, Dìng, Kāi** are also acceptable.

In its ingestion:
At the beginning of the **eleventh month**, thus after **sixty days**, the body becomes light and mobile;
Next **sixty days**, the **four limbs** become agile;
Next **sixty days**, the **complexion** glows;
Next **sixty days**, the **five viscera** are solid, and **malevolent influences** retreat;
Next **sixty days**, the **body** becomes firm and strong;
Next **sixty days**, the **ears and eyes** sharpen—
This is the **first year’s** verification.

Next **sixty days**, the **hands and nails** shine;
Next **sixty days**, the **aura** becomes manifest;
Next **sixty days**, the **essence-qi** grows stronger;
Next **sixty days**, the **hair turns black**;
Next **sixty days**, the **teeth** become firm and strong;
Next **sixty days**, **[missing text]**—
This is the **second year’s** verification.

Next **sixty days**, **[missing text]**;
Next **sixty days**, **[missing text]**;
Next **sixty days**, **virtue and power** become complete;
Next **sixty days**, the **Six Jia spirits** obey;
Next **sixty days**, the **heart opens and the eyes brighten**;
Next **sixty days**, **distant knowledge** of the four quarters—
This is the **third year’s** verification.

Next **sixty days**, **gazing** emits light;
Next **sixty days**, the **five spirits** are not forgotten;
Next **sixty days**, there is **no hunger or thirst**;
Next **sixty days**, the **hundred spirits** come;
Next **sixty days**, the **five viscera** are moistened;
Next **sixty days**, **heat and cold** can be endured;
This is the **fourth year’s** verification.

Next **sixty days**, **floating and sinking** can be mastered;
Next **sixty days**, **depth and shallowness** can be mastered;
Next **sixty days**, **squareness and roundness** can be mastered;
Next **sixty days**, **strength and weakness** can be mastered;
Next **sixty days**, **length and breadth** can be mastered;
Next **sixty days**, **shortness and length** can be mastered—
This is the **fifth year’s** verification.

Next **sixty days**, one can discern **beauty and ugliness**;
Next **sixty days**, one can discern **old and young**;
Next **sixty days**, one can discern **great and small**;
Next **sixty days**, one can discern **light and heavy**;
Next **sixty days**, one can **enter and exit without hindrance**;
Next **sixty days**, one’s **movement knows no bounds**—
This is the **sixth year’s** verification.

If one **prolongs** the practice without ceasing,
one aligns with Heaven and Earth,
transforming through myriad changes,
ascending to the **Supreme Clarity**.

---
**Dao Gun** (卷) **32** [#1: Original "木" (wood), corrected to "水" (water) per *Ji Yao* edition.]
[#2: Original "峡" (gorge), supplemented per *Ji Yao* edition.]
[#3: Original "于" (at), corrected to "行" (movement) per *Ji Yao* edition.]
[#4: Original "德" (virtue), corrected to "得" (obtain) per *Gou Yao* edition.]
[#5: *Ji Yao* edition B reads "大小" (great-small).]

**Dao Shu** (卷) **33**
*Attributed to Youzi Zeng Can*
**Middle Section of *Can Tong Qi***
*Grass-Cloth Sage’s Transmission*
The *Grass-Cloth Sage* (自号草衣子) said:
*"I have observed the **Five Phases’** principles of **generation and conquest**,
measured the **short and long** of sun and moon,
and discerned the causes of **full and waning phases** and **solstices and equinoxes**.
I adjusted the **Southern Dipper** and turned the **Northern Dipper’s** mechanism,
thus understanding the **four seasons**, **eight nodes**, **seventy-two signs**, and **twenty-four qi**.
Refining elixirs within the **Yellow Court**,
I mastered the **transformation of yin and yang**—
twenty-six transformations in all.

The **lead within water**—this is my **primordial essence**.
Supplement its **pure marrow**, and **immortality** is attained."*

**Continuation of *Can Tong Qi* (Middle Section)**

*"To refine the lead, one must rely upon mercury.
Mercury—this is the treasure within the body.
When lead and mercury unite to form the elixir,
then one becomes immortal in the world.

When one essence manifests in three forms,
the body itself flourishes.
When transformations merge into unity,
one understands the union of yin and yang.
Extracting the yang within yin,
when water and fire are harmonized,
tasting the elixir’s essence,
the body thrives anew.

There is no greater cultivation than preserving and nurturing the breath.
Preserving the breath—this is when the three forms coalesce into one.
If one attains a thousand breaths,
then one ascends to the Three Pure Ones.
How so?
Spirit, breath, and qi—
they return to the One.

Essence and fluid—
nine transformations unite them.
This is the elixir’s supreme principle.

Our elixir—
how could it compare to the world’s use of gold and silver in false alchemy?
Gold and silver are external substances;
how could they transform?
Our medicine is but mercury alone.
Taking silver’s essence,
refining gold’s vitality,
and exchanging them—
never straying from the Way’s transformation.

Three, five, and one—
these are the Dao’s truth.
Pairing one yin with one yang,
cycling through seventy-two signs,
completing nine revolutions in twelve celestial stems,
beginning from *jiǎzǐ*—
taking this, one may prolong life.

The left kidney governs the fluids,
called the ‘Morning Emperor’.
If it flows backward, it transforms into fluid;
in the mouth, it becomes the Pool of Flowers’ water.
The Yellow River rises from Kunlun’s peaks,
its vapor ascending as mist,
heaven’s qi descending as dew.
When yin and yang merge,
they form nourishing rain,
thus enriching all things.
This is like the left kidney generating fluids,
swallowed and descending to the five zang and six fu,
transforming into blood,
which nourishes the body and brings radiance.
Thus, without yin and yang’s qi, nothing lives;
without the fluids of the five zang and six fu, illness arises.

The right kidney governs life.
Its essence ascends to the Emperor,
descending into the *Chóngguī*.
At its demise, two bands strike above the womb.
Its blue veins, like threads,
emit essence on the left, urine on the right.
When blood enters the womb, it becomes essence;
essence then transforms into marrow.
When essence is exhausted and marrow spent,
then death comes.
Thus, those who cultivate life
must preserve the breath above,
never waste the essence below,
and harmonize essence, qi, and fluids—
this is how the great elixir is formed.

Why?
For essence becomes treasure;
refined over time, it becomes the Golden Elixir.
This is the nature of life itself.

Thus, spirit, breath, and qi—
one substance in three forms.
When fluids and essence are depleted,
life’s end is near.

The central palace’s true qi—
yellow, the earth—
is governed by the spleen.
This is the *Dan Tian*,
the root and origin of life.
The left and right kidneys’ black and white fluids and essence
merge into the central palace.
This is called the *Crucible*.
Metal and wood—
they restrain each other.
Obtaining the central palace’s qi,
life’s completion is achieved.
How so?
Earth generates metal,
metal generates water,
water generates wood,
wood generates fire,
fire generates earth.
Thus, fluids and essence
align in the central palace,
ascending to the Upper Elixir,
and from this root, life’s origin arises.
This is the foundation of the great medicine.

Daily, with the four seasons,
close the breath and refine it.
If essence is not wasted,
the great medicine is complete.
Breath is fire;
fluids are water.
This is the path of harmonization."*

Lead is born in the left kidney,
its exterior black, its interior white—
the white governs silver.

How does it transform into wood’s qi?
Wood’s true qi is yang,
dominating the north, belonging to the *zi* position.
Silver perishes when its time comes.
Nurtured by yang qi, it turns yellow.
Then, with the four seasons,
following the *wu-ji* cycles,
the Three Bodies revolve in the central palace—
lead transforms into its *dao-jui* form,
its flavor exquisite.

When the *Kan* gate unites with it,
golden essence governs true water.

Mercury is born in the right kidney,
its essence white, governing metal.

How does it refine metal’s essence?
From the *Li* palace, metal’s qi arises,
dominating the south, belonging to the *wu* position—
this is the metal within yang.
Metal is a yin count.
When it ascends to the central palace,
lead’s blossom appears.
Receiving qi from the crucible,
it becomes its outer and inner layers.
Seeking *wu-ji* to forge the elixir,
one substance takes three forms,
returning to its true body.
Thus, true water is born in the *Li* palace,
lead and mercury unite—
their flavor grows ever more refined.

So the Dragon transforms from lead,
the Tiger from mercury.
Why?
The Dragon is wood,
born from lead.
Its hue is green, and it governs qi.
I have observed this deeply—
the Dragon is truly the grandson of metal,
the son of water.
When metal thrice returns to subdue,
its treasure is complete.
It gathers as curdled milk,
it scatters as—
Why?

The Dragon is born of water,
this is the *mao* palace.
The White Tiger of the West—
this is what it fears.
After the *zi* hour, it seals its qi,
preserving its breath for a thousand breaths,
then the Dragon hides in the fields and does not rise.

Thus, the daily soul is born in *zhen*,
and those who wish to refine their bodies and nurture their lives
should recognize what is called the Dragon.

The Tiger is metal and water,
born of mercury.
Its hue is white, and it governs essence.
I have observed this deeply—
the Tiger is truly the grandson of fire,
the son of earth.
Fire thrice returns to punish metal,
then its treasure is complete.
It gathers as flowing pearls,
it scatters as sweet dew.
Why?

The Tiger is born of metal,
its nature fierce and strong.
Before the *wu* hour, it thrice overcomes and battles the Dragon.
Descending into the central palace,
its body flourishes.
Thus, the daily shadow is born in *dui*,
and those who wish to refine their bodies and nurture their lives
should recognize what is called the Tiger.

Thus, lead and mercury combine to form the elixir.
Lead is the sun’s essence,
the true qi of wood;
mercury is the moon’s bloom,
the true qi of metal.
Wood is *jia*, metal is *geng*, metal is *xīn*.
When true yin and true yang’s vital essence mutually devour,
day and night through twelve periods,
they circulate their bodies,
each forming flowing pearls,
gathering in the elixir field.

When gathered, yin and yang coalesce;
when scattered, the pearls spread to the sea’s edge.
This is when lead and mercury unite,
but the Dragon and Tiger have not yet hidden within each other.
What does this hiding mean?
The sun uses the four seasons,
yin and yang battle in exchange,
gathering at the five victories’ domain.
Above, this becomes the Dragon’s wooden essence;
below, this becomes the Tiger’s metallic essence.
The Dragon descends to the lower realm,
the Tiger ascends to the upper.
At the central palace,
the Dragon and Tiger hide within each other,
returning to one.

What is this Way?
*Wu* and *ji* reside within,
water and fire circulate,
thus achieving the *ji-ji* completion.
Then the gold within the crucible is formed.
The Dragon thus transforms into an infant,
the Tiger into a maiden.
The infant is yang, true qi.
Its name is the Golden Ancestor,
the Jade Nectar,
the crystalline elixir of the Flower Pool.
Thus, wood’s circulation
in the central palace
is the root of the great elixir,
the true body of emptiness,
the fundamental mechanism of profound obscurity and hazy indistinctness.
Its ability to pair with the maiden
requires the Yellow Mother to unite them.

The maiden is yin, true essence.
Its name is the Jade Maiden,
the Golden Elixir,
the White Water.
Thus, metal’s circulation
is in the Hall of Illumination.
Within the Hall of Illumination is a chamber,
where the maiden resides.
If I obtain this,
then the great elixir is complete.
This is the substance within emptiness,
the thing within qi,
obtained from profound obscurity and hazy indistinctness.
What was its beginning?
From blood to essence—
the transformation of the Five Phases.
Seal its spirit-breath,
then the elixir naturally halts.

The Yellow Mother is the central palace,
the elixir field.
Its name is the crucible,
the furnace,
the stone chamber.
The Four Symbols and Five Phases
all rely on *wu-ji*’s true earth.
Why?
All things are born of earth,
so earth is the chamber of the Four Symbols,
the master of the Five Phases.
Without its earth, the Four Symbols lack a sovereign,
the Five Phases lose their master.

I have said the Yellow Mother is the root of the great elixir.
The earth of the central palace,
why is it called the altar?
The altar is the furnace—
the altar has three layers below,
must obtain the five directions,
to take true earth.
Thus, one layer below,
its height is one *chi* and two *cùn*,
corresponding to the twelve months of a year.
One day’s twelve periods.
Below, the Eight Trigrams—
within one *chi*,
corresponding to the Ten Heavenly Stems.
The upper layer of the Eight Trigrams,
its height is eight *cùn*,
corresponding to the twenty-four seasons.
The upper plane is round, sixteen *chi* across,
corresponding to the sixteen *liang* measures.
Four blades are planted on its sides,
corresponding to the four seasons.
Eight mirrors are suspended on all sides.
