Thus, I use the four seasons daily,
selecting lead and mercury from the nine-to-one ratio,
discerning the fire’s timing within the body,
taking yang’s transformation to forge the furnace.
The furnace is yang, the divine chamber,
the pivot of the golden elixir.
When the inner spirit takes form,
it is used to refine the elixir.
Secure the furnace’s door,
discern the fire’s timing,
gradually adding the weight.
Do not let dampness linger,
do not rush the lower fire.
One refining, one dose—
if you refine again,
then the already-refined furnace cannot be used.
Its spirit is injured.

The crucible is formed by transforming earth,
not the crucibles of the world.
Yin and yang create in true earth,
cold metal to forge it.
Its mouth must not be too large,
its belly not too vast,
its ears not too sharp or small,
its feet not too wide or narrow,
its nose not too thin or high.
Below, its mouth must be measured correctly,
with no leakage of qi,
then it can be used.
This crucible exists only within my body—
the true qi of the central palace can form it.

Yet the crucible’s flaws are tenfold:
One, iron from spring, summer, autumn, winter;
Two, its mold is uneven;
Three, the fetus is suspended while casting;
Four, its belly is too large;
Five, its feet are too short and curved;
Six, its thickness is uneven;
Seven, its mouth and ears are too narrow;
Eight, its sand holes leak qi;
Nine, its iron is black and not white;
Ten, it is cast out of season.
If cast with the two *bā* (eight and eight),
then the elixir can be formed.

The first transformation of the elixir is called *White Snow*.
*White Snow* is when lead and mercury unite,
when metal and wood mutually restrain each other,
and merge as one—
then the qi arises within the crucible.

When it congeals,
it is like the dew of mid-autumn,
the frost of deep winter—
named *Divine Symbol*,
for it moves through the *zi-wu* [子午] cycle.

The second transformation of the elixir is called *Two Qi*.
*Two Qi* is when lead and mercury bind,
when metal and wood contend,
and the great medicine is refined—
then yellow qi emerges.

Like spring ice in its hue,
its color is green and white,
its radiance red and crimson—
yet it is not yet fully formed,
but already it can dispel illness.

If water and fire do not err in the *two nines* [二九],
then it advances to the ninefold transformations.

The third transformation of the elixir is called *Yellow Sprout*.
*Yellow Sprout* is when lead and mercury unite,
transmitted through the five viscera,
entering the central palace,
gathering the five phases.

*Wu* and *ji* [戊己] are earth.
When metal and wood’s qi find earth,
it is like a ruler with ministers,
a child with a father,
a guest with a host—
then it can be wielded.

Close the breath, preserve the intent,
shut the celestial pass,
return the earthly gate to the lower *dantian*—
thus the root of the great medicine takes form.

Receiving earth’s qi,
its color turns yellow.
This is when the divine breath and qi merge as one,
when the dragon and tiger descend into the crucible.

The fourth transformation of the elixir is called *Four Spirits*.
*Four Spirits* are:
the White Tiger—metal,
the Green Dragon—wood,
the Dark Tortoise—water,
the Vermilion Bird—fire.

Using *yin* [寅] and *shen* [申],
to move the four symbols,
entering the central palace,
paying homage at the Red City,
at the appointed *mao-you* [卯酉] times,
the function operates and turns—
then the infant and maiden unite.

This is the *four nines* [四九] transformation.
Silent and visualizing,
the divine light appears.

The fifth transformation of the elixir is called *White Horse Sprout*.
*White Horse Sprout* is when the five phases are complete.
The true qi of the five viscera, refined by essence and fluid,
merges—
thus the qi and breath unite with *wu* and *ji* [戊己],
moving daily at *yi-hai* [巳亥],
ascending to pay homage at the *niwan* [泥丸].
At *mao-you* [卯酉],
it is conveyed and returns to the lower *yuan* [元],
entering the crucible,
nourished by the *wen-wu* [文武] fires.

At the hour of *chou* [丑],
visualizing reveals white qi emerging.
Thus the medicine of the *dantian* grows,
like a horse’s tooth, emitting white light.

This is the *nine-five* [九五] number—
now all tastes are severed,
and the three corpses [三尸] retreat.

The sixth transformation of the elixir is called *Jade Fluid*.
*Jade Fluid* is when the three yins and three yangs contend,
and the dragon and tiger submit.
The infant is the husband,
the maiden the wife—
then lead and mercury merge.

After *zi* [子] and before *wu* [午],
moving and closing the breath,
the true qi of the six palaces arises spontaneously.
When the six spirits are complete,
they are paired and ascend the twelve layers,
paying homage at the Red City,
entering the Orchid Hall and Purple Bower,
then reentering the crucible—
the jade fluid forms, and tortoise and serpent appear.

The seventh transformation of the elixir is called *Numinous Sand*.
*Numinous Sand* is sevenfold return,
corresponding externally to the *Beidou* [北斗].
At the five night watches,
within the seven orifices,
the true qi of the five viscera moves.
By day, it circulates beneath the skin;
by dusk, it flows above the bones.
When qi moves, the blood flows in harmony;
when blood flows, the qi moves in turn.
If it returns to its source,
it transforms into gold essence.

If the qi reverses,
the blood halts—and then illness arises.
Thus, preserving essence to nourish the marrow
is the great medicine.
Its color is red,
dispersing as flowing pearls,
congealing as a mass.
Within the crucible,
if movement loses its timing,
it flees along its radiance.

I often perform the function at *yin-shen* [寅申] times,
closing the breath,
preserving the spirit—
this is sufficient.

The eighth transformation of the elixir is called *Divine Sand*.
*Divine Sand* is when the four seasons are used daily,
moving the eight trigrams,
with no error in the fire’s timing—
subdued and steadied, it aids the crossing.

Thus, closing the breath,
preserving the spirit,
eating the *yuanhe* [元和] qi when hungry,
drinking the *Huachi* [华池] nectar when thirsty,
all grains are removed, all tastes severed,
the gold essence does not leak—
then the celestial pass does not close,
and the earthly gate locks itself.

The ninth transformation of the elixir is called *Gold Sand*.
*Gold Sand* is when the yin lines—one hundred ninety-two—
form eight *liang* [两] of gold;
the yang lines—one hundred ninety-two—
form eight *liang* of silver.

Dispersed, they become thirty-six thousand *yuan* [元];
congealed, they become the gold elixir—
square and round, five *cun* [寸] in measure,
weighing sixteen *liang* [两],
totaling three hundred eighty-four *zhu* [铢].

This is the *ri-jing-yue-hua* [日精月华] dual qi,
the product of transformation.
A single dose extends life to a thousand years—
the lotus emerges from the fire.

What is meant by *three things as one form*?
Gold, wood, and earth—
gathered, they return to the central palace—
this is the true qi.
Human life and fate depend upon it.

Thus, green, yellow, and white—
born on the left and right of the kidneys,
gathered in the *dantian* as one form,
dispersed as three substances.

Hence the three souls—yang—
obtained, the body flourishes.

Qi transforms into blood,
blood into essence,
like a treasure vase.
Gold, wood, and earth
transform into fluid,
and fire returns to gold—
refined, it becomes true gold.

How do the three things become one?
Water, earth, and metal—
gathered, they become spirit;
dispersed, they become blood, essence, or crucible.
This is my central palace.

Heart, kidneys, and spleen—
are they not red, yellow, and black?

Thus it is said:
The *three-one* number—
the sage’s way of preserving three while guarding one.
Hence, dispersed, they are three;
congealed, they are one—
transforming autumn stone in the *dantian*.

「Once the elixir has undergone nine transformations,
it is refined externally,
turning black and shifting into nine hues—
entering the *central palace*,
it becomes *zizhun* (紫金),¹
and naturally, the body grows robust,
the frame becomes light—
thus attaining the status of an *earthly immortal*.²

What is this Dao?
The *four symbols*³ and *five phases*,
all regarded as *soil*—
this is the origin of the elixir.

The nine transformations align with the *cosmic creation*,
and after a hundred days, the work is complete.⁴

Thus, one must necessarily cultivate *mindful visualization*.
When the hundred days’ work is done,
then, from the hour of *zi* (子) onward,
until the hour of *wu* (午),
and during the hours of *chou* (丑), *yin* (寅), *shen* (申), *wei* (巳), and *hai* (亥),
one sits cross-legged in a quiet chamber,
sealing its doors securely,
closing the eyes and gripping the *qi*,
containing the *essence*,
preserving the *spirit*,
and visualizing the *true qi* of the *five zang* organs⁵
emanating from the *central palace*,
revealing itself before one.

Like the auspicious clouds of five colors
arising from the *crucible*,
this is the method by which a man
conceives a male child.⁶

Then, the *day soul* and *moon spirit*,
the *qi* of water and fire,
transform into the forms of gold and wood.⁷

The *day soul*—yang, the *qi* of fire—
the *moon spirit*—yin, the *qi* of water—
water and fire, mutually generating and restraining each other.

When the internal refinement is complete,
the sun becomes an infant,
the moon a *young maiden*,⁸
never leaving the *nuptial chamber*,
and one sees the *Golden Male*⁹ within the *Jade Hall*.
The maiden is pregnant.

After ten months, she gives birth to the *True Man*,
whose name is *Zhengyang*.¹⁰
This is the essence of the *great medicine*,
the fundamental root of cultivating the Dao and nurturing life.

Those who recognize the elusive *lead-mercury*¹¹
are the true *Dragon* and *Tiger*.¹²

How does one know that gold and wood are formed,
and water and fire transformed?
Is it when the *true yang qi*¹³
of *jiǎ* (甲) and *gēng* (庚) interact?

Grass Cloth Child¹⁴ said:
On the moon’s third day,
the moon appears in the *southwest* at *gēng* (庚),
this is called *obtaining a companion*—
why?
The moon is the *true qi* of water,
the source that generates metal.¹⁵
Thus, when it appears at *gēng*,
this is the *upper arc*, yielding eight *liang* (两) of metal.¹⁶

On the twenty-eighth day, it appears at *jiǎ* (甲),
this is called *losing a companion*—
why?
*Jiǎ* is wood,
and its *essence* is the sun,
revealing itself in the *north*—¹⁷
the sun, the *true qi* of fire,
overcomes metal.
Thus, on the twenty-eighth day,
the moon appears in the *north* and brightens,
the yang reveals itself,
and the moon vanishes—
this is the *lower arc*,
yielding eight *liang* of silver.¹⁸

Metal and silver combine into sixteen *liang*,
and the *yin-yang lines*¹⁹ of each are 192—
altogether, this makes 384 *zhu* (铢).
This is the sixteen *liang* count.

I observe the *arcs*, *fullness*, *towering*, *deficiency*, *eclipse*, and *occultation*²⁰ of the moon,
and at the hour of *zi* (子),
I stabilize my *spirit* and *breath*,
until the hour of *wu* (午),
I contain my *qi*—
reaching a thousand breaths,
the count of gold and silver will not be lost.

Still, I cannot fail to understand
the transformations of the sun, moon,
*eight trigrams*, and *yin-yang*.
Eleven months have passed,
when the *Big Dipper*²¹ stands at *zi* (子).」

The Earth Thunder, *Fù* (復), is the **restoration** one.
Here, one *yang* begins to arise,
**clashing** with five *yin*.
Thus, all times of *zi* (子) are the initial moments of *yang*,
and I begin my work at these hours.
When the **golden elixir**¹ appears,
the medicine has its **root**².

I **refine** it into the furnace,
to **nourish** the **true gold**³.
The second month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *mǎo* (卯).
The Earth Heaven, *Tài* (泰), is the **harmonious** one.
The upper is three *yin*—**Earth**—
the lower is three *yang*—**Heaven**.
Here, *yin* and *yang* **clash** and **struggle**⁴.
The *yin-yang lines*⁵ of each are ninety-six.
The *yin* is **gold four *liang***⁶,
the *yang* is **silver four *liang***.
All times of *mǎo* (卯) are the *Tài* (泰) **hexagram**⁷.
This is the **conjunction**⁸,
where the initial **settlement**⁹ is made in three **returns**¹⁰.
If the *yang* seeks to **prevail**,
it **reverts** to the **origin**¹¹,
thus silver **manifests** while gold **conceals**¹²,
its form like a **calabash**¹³.
I **refine** the **spiritual sand**¹⁴,
to **subdue** the **elixir field**¹⁵.

The fourth month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *sì* (巳).
The **pure *yang***, *Qián* (乾), is the **completion** one.
*Qián* (乾) is **gold**,
the **White Sovereign of the Origin**¹⁶ appears,
and **true sentiment**¹⁷ is **pleased**.
It **unites** with the four directions,
its **water**¹⁸ **refined by Heaven**.
All times of *sì* (巳),
the **great medicine**¹⁹ **reverses** and **rotates rightward**²⁰,
entering the **elixir field**²¹,
penetrating to the **tailbone**²²,
then **transported**²³, it **reenters** the **Upper Origin’s Kunlun**²⁴.
This is the **return** that **reverses** and **supplements** at the **muddy pellet**²⁵.

The fifth month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *wǔ* (午).
The Heaven Wind, *Gòu* (姤), is the **meeting** one.
One *yin* **clashes** with five *yang*.
Before the hour of *wǔ* (午),
one *yin* begins to arise,
thus I **discern** the *yin-yang* **origins**²⁶ in the three **stages**²⁷
to **conduct** my work.
How do I **conduct** my work?
By **using lead to seek lead**²⁸.
When one *yin* arises,
then *Qián* (乾) is **broken**.
**Gold** appears in **Earth**,
not **returning** to its **mother**²⁹,
the **golden elixir** transforms
and **enters** the **Jade Spring**³⁰.

The seventh month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *shēn* (申).
The Heaven Earth, *Pǐ* (否), is the **blocked** one.
Three *yang* are in the upper,
three *yin* are in the lower,
a **struggle** between *yang* and *yin*.
When its **upper arc**³¹ appears,
it is **gold eight *liang***³²,
and **silver sixteen *liang***³³.
All times of *shēn* (申) are the *Pǐ* (否) **hexagram**³⁴,
this is the **seventh return**³⁵!
An **infant**³⁶ and an **old woman**³⁷ share one **pit**³⁸.
At the hour of *shēn* (申),
I **refine** the **fire’s candidate**³⁹,
and the **elixir** is **completed**,
**ascending** to the **Three Cleansings**⁴⁰.

The tenth month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *hài* (亥).
The **pure *yin***, *Kūn* (坤), is the **receptive** one.
All times of *hài* (亥) are the *Kūn* (坤) **hexagram**⁴¹.
The **great medicine** **follows** the west
and **rotates rightward**²⁰,
**ascending** the **double pavilion**⁴²,
twelve **circuits**⁴³,
then **descending** to the **Vermilion Palace**⁴⁴,
**paying homage** to the **Sovereign of the Red City**⁴⁵,
and **refined**, it **enters** the **elixir field**,
this is the **ninth return**⁴⁶.

The second month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *mǎo* (卯).
The Fire Water, *Wèijì* (未济), is the **unfinished** one.

---

**Fire** abides in the **upper**, **water** in the **lower**—
its **hexagram** does not **act** upon **Fire**,
yet its name is *Kāilú* (开炉, "Opening the Furnace").

At all times of *mǎo* (卯),
**qi** is made to **emit** the **pure** and **impure**,
**nourishing** its **blood**,
to **augment** the **transformation** of **metallic essence**⁴⁷.

The *Wèijì* (未济, "Unfinished") is the **cauldron**⁴⁸.
When the **Four Symbols**⁴⁹ obtain **Earth**,
they **intermingle** and **unify**⁵⁰.
The **Central Palace**⁵¹, *wù-jǐ* (戊己),
is the **master** of the **medicine**⁵².

Only in the **cauldron** must there be no **sound of water**⁵³.
The eighth month is when the *Big Dipper* stands at *yǒu* (酉).
The **Water-Fire**, *Jìzhì* (既济, "Completed"), is the **true cauldron**⁵⁴.
The **nine-one**⁵⁵ **count** is **fulfilled**—
the **Dragon** and **Tiger**⁵⁶ have **descended**⁵⁷.
This is the **beginning** of **cultivating the True**⁵⁸,
called the **First Stage**⁵⁹.
Its **essence** lies in **knowing** the **affections of the *couple***⁶⁰.
My **medicine** reaches here and is **perfected**⁶¹.
Thus, I **transform** **True *qi*** into **inner fire**⁶²,
to **consum** my **body**⁶³.
What is **inner fire**?⁶⁴
It is the **circulating** **pure *yang*** of the **Five Organs**⁶⁵.
When its **yin** is **exhausted**⁶⁶,
then **blood** **transforms** into **essence**⁶⁷,
**essence** into **marrow**⁶⁸,
**marrow** **converts** into **body**⁶⁹,
to **produce** **white milk**⁷⁰,
and when the **work** is **fulfilled**,
the **body** becomes **lucid**⁷¹.
When **cold**, it **circulates** in **Heart *qi***,
when **hot**, it **circulates** in **Kidney *qi***,
naturally **neither cold nor hot**⁷².
When it **circulates** in the **fire’s candidate**⁷³ **qi**,
then **fire** **arises** of itself⁷⁴.
And the **Primordial Sovereign**⁷⁵—
the **Dragon** **swallows**, the **Tiger** **receives**⁷⁶,
dwelling with the **Three Officials**⁷⁷ in the **Golden Hall**⁷⁸—
after **a thousand days**⁷⁹,
**purple clouds** **emerge** from the **foot**⁸⁰.

(*Dao* **Gū**⁸¹, Scroll 33, ends here.)
(*Dao* **Gū**, Scroll 34, reaches the *Yóuzǐ* **Zēng**⁸² **Collection**.)

**The Lower Scroll of *The Canon of the Mysterious Concord* says:**

The Master Yunya Zi, surnamed Wei Ao, style name Boyang, a man of Han, who styled himself Yunya Zi, wandered the Changbai Mountains and encountered a True Person, who taught him the principles of lead and mercury, the mechanics of Dragon and Tiger. Thus, he composed eighteen chapters, speaking of the Great Dao.

That which is vague and indistinct—this is lead and mercury;
That which is dim and obscure—this is Dragon and Tiger.
These are the root sources of yin and yang transformation.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Boyang, having composed *The Canon of the Mysterious Concord*, Yuan Yang Zi annotated its meaning:

Yin and yang—from black arises white, this is the number one of water. Water generates metal, its number three.
Water is called *li* generated from *kun*, as earth, as yin, as mother, as female; its vital breath is metal.
Metal is in the northwest, belonging to *qian*, as heaven, as yang, as father, as male.

Thus it is said:
The *li* palace holds its form, concealed in true water;
The *kan* gate contains its bloom, hidden in true metal.
With *qian* generating three sons, *kun* generating three daughters,
Transforming into the eight trigrams, mutually nurturing to complete the number eight.

Yunya Zi said: Cinnabar, black tin, and realgar—when refined and forged within, they become the two *qi*.
Yuan Chang Zi said: This is within oneself, not sought from without.

Yunya Zi said: When it transforms into white snow, yellow sprouts, at the time of lowering the fire, one must be especially cautious.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Cinnabar and black tin are tempered by realgar, then further forged with gentle fire—its transformation into white snow, its completion into yellow sprouts.
Realgar is earth, the five returning to one.

Yunya Zi said: Though it alters the form of the River Vehicle, when seven returns are complete, it follows the reversal of *Ji Ji*.
Yuan Yang Zi said: When it shows the *yin* (leap-year), this is wood; when it shows the *shen* (applicator), this is metal.
Metal can subdue wood; through seven returns, it is concealed within.
The liver and lungs—externally, they bind the west.
Metal is essence; wood is fluid.
When fluid and essence merge, they form the elixir stone.
Why? Essence descends from the *li* palace, producing lead; fluid ascends from the *kan* palace, producing mercury.
*Li* and *kan*—the cauldron of *Water and Fire Both Accomplished*;
The River Vehicle—the true *qi* of the north.
Turning into the *shu* palace, its land of *jia* and *yi*—thus, the golden flower arises!

Yunya Zi said: Nine transformations yield the purple-gold sand, refined into treasure—its gold fills the home.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Lead, mercury, and realgar—when forged, they become the Great Medicine, returning to *qian* and *kun*.
Its yang, 192 *zhu*, is eight *liang* of gold;
Its yin, 192 *zhu*, is eight *liang* of silver.
Combined with the 384 of the trigrams and lines, the return elixir is complete.

Yunya Zi said: First, distinguish the medicine, then observe its sprouts—only then does one know the root, the key.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Beneath the elixir field, the left is *suo*, the right is *yào*; within is a platform.
Hidden in the roots of sun and moon, day and night revolve, the four seasons encircle—refined in the three fields.
This is the essence of the three souls, the source of the Great Medicine.
What is the Great Medicine? *Fu ling* calms the soul, *ren shen* steadies the spirit—but these are not of the mundane world.
*Fu ling*—black within, white without;
*Ren shen*—red-yellow without, white-green within.
When the sprouts appear, one must then discern their roots.

Yunya Zi said: Those who gather must use the sixteen *zhen* of truth.
Within the medicine, there is curd and ghee.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The sixteen—*mao* and *you*, the number sixteen.
This is metal subduing wood; above, applied to *mao*; below, applied to *you*.
*Mao* is the blood of the Dragon; *you* is the blood of the Tiger.
When the two bodies merge, they become curd, ghee—the souls and spirits of sun and moon.
The Southern Palace is the sun, *li*;
The Northern Palace is the moon, *kan*.
Thus, the foundation of water and fire is established, merging the kinds of lead and mercury.

Yunya Zi said: Within the gentle and martial fires, do they regulate each other?

Yuan Yang Zi said: The gentle and martial fires are the functions of the four seasons.
When sealed, *qi* is received, following the nine-one count.
To gather the fluid of wood and fire;
Their regulation—merging the essence of metal and water—this is the lower function.
Entering the central palace, using earth, the Great Medicine is formed.

Yunya Zi said: Slowly pounding—its function and count must not differ—only then is it acceptable.

Yuan Yang Zi said: This is the count of the function.
When sealed, *qi* is received, counted silently with the mind—nine breaths, one swallow, increasing daily until a hundred breaths, then receiving *qi*.
Performing daily sun-moon guiding and drawing, gathering the essence of yin and yang transformation, the essence of sun and moon—thus, the fluid of gold, the essence of jade, gathered in nine-one—this is slow pounding.
Again, performing three-one—this is the gentle and martial fires.
Fire is breath, true earth.

Yunya Zi said: Blending the jade-fluid nectar, forging it into elixir sand.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Jade-fluid—its name is *qiongjiang*, its name is *tianjiu*—this is the water of the Flowered Pool.
Having gathered the medicine, one must then invest fluid and essence.
Sealing the breath, storing and drawing it, obtaining earth to merge—using breath as fire to forge and refine.

Yunya Zi said: The Golden Elixir Refining begins with lead and mercury as its foundation. When taken, the crow becomes a phoenix, the serpent becomes a dragon.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The Refined Elixir forms the Vermilion Bird—what I have seen is the phoenix. I have ridden the *là* serpent, and seen it become the dragon.

Yunya Zi said: The four seasons are the times for practice—spring and autumn.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The four seasons are the *Lì* of spring, the *Lì* of summer, the *Lì* of autumn, and the *Lì* of winter. These are called the four seasons.

Each season comprises seventy-two days, forming the four symbols of Wood, Fire, Metal, and Water—these are called the beginnings of the four *Mèng* periods.

The *Yín-Shēn* (third and ninth earthly branches) are the great medicine where Wood and Metal clash. This great medicine is the cycle of two hundred eighty-eight years.

In my minor practice, I use it at the four *Mèng* periods, each forty-five days—totaling one hundred ninety days. The sun and moon in the four seasons also amount to one hundred ninety days.

Moreover, the subtle numbers of yin-yang creation and eternal life—I practice here.

Yunya Zi said: *Wèi-Hài* (fourth and eleventh earthly branches) are the return—this is the beginning of the Eight Trigrams.

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Wèi* is Fire, the fourth month, the essence of pure yang. Its trigram corresponds to *Qián* (Heaven) and becomes the Heavenly. *Hài* is Water, the tenth month, the essence of pure yin. Its trigram corresponds to *Kūn* (Earth) and becomes the Earthly.

When Heaven and Earth unite, the six yang and six yin are complete.

From *Zǐ* (eleventh branch) to *Wèi* (fourth branch), it begins with the trigram *Dì-Léi Fù-Gōng* (Earth-Thunder Returning), with six yang lines—this is half a year’s count.

From *Wǔ* (seventh branch) to *Hài* (eleventh branch), it begins with the trigram *Tiān-Fēng Xiàn* (Wind-Gentle), with six yin lines—this is half a year’s count.

Thus, the Golden Elixir attains the nine returns of true *qi*—this is the completion of Water and Fire in *Jí-Jì* (Mutual Aid). Water and Fire countering each other, when controlled in their true forms, then the measure of one *jīn* is achieved.

Yunya Zi said: The moon gathers at *Jiǎ-Gēng* (first and seventh heavenly stems), the sun gathers at *Rén-Bǐng* (second and sixth heavenly stems)—do we seek this in the four symbols through mutual counteraction and containment?

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Jiǎ* is Wood, occupying the *shùběi* (束北) position. When the moon reaches the twenty-eighth day, it loses its companion in *shùběi*. Why? Because yang is born while yin is extinguished.

「Regeng (Gēng) is Metal, occupying the southwest position. When the moon reaches the third day, it finds its companion in the southwest. Why? Because yin is born while yang is extinguished.

Rén is Water, born from the sun’s *arcan* (魂). Bǐng is Fire, born from the moon’s *pò* (魄). The *qi* of Metal is thus the yin within yang, known as the sun’s *arcan*; the *qi* of Wood is the yang within yin, known as the moon’s *pò*.

Hence it is said: When the *yin-yang* (阴阳) *zàohuà* (造化) arise, their birth is divided between *Kǎn* (坎) and *Lí* (离). The counteraction of *Kùn* (坤) is to contain and nurture—*bāo* (包) means to *cáng* (藏). Rén (壬) gives birth to Jiǎ (甲), Bǐng (丙) gives birth to Gēng (庚). This is the mutual seeking of the four symbols: Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire.

When they enter the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) *dǐng* (鼎), the Great Elixir can be forged.

The *Sūtra* (经) states: Wood is the Azure Dragon, Metal is the White Tiger, the sun is the Vermilion Bird, and the moon is the Dark Tortoise. When the four symbols converge at the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫), their *chángshēng* (长生) does not depart from the *wù-jǐ* (戊己) Earth. Those who refine the elixir must recognize the Tiger. When yang obtains its yin, it naturally contains the *hù* (互).

Yunya Zi said: When Water and Fire are reversed, the true *dǐng* (鼎) vessel is formed; the *Héchē* (河车) moves, yet *wù-jǐ* (戊己) remains.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The four symbols are born from *wù-jǐ* (戊己), thus making *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) the honored center. Therefore, the four symbols are refined and formed by controlling *wù-jǐ* (戊己)—without *wù-jǐ* (戊己), the four symbols have no master.

Wù (戊) is Earth; Jǐ (己) is dung. When combined, they form one—this is the *Lǎozi* (老子) saying: *"The Dao obtains One and becomes clear; Earth obtains One and becomes tranquil; the Spirit obtains One and becomes responsive"* (天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵).

The reason the four symbols merge into one is that all things arise from the *shàng* (上, upper) realm. Metal, Wood, Water, and Fire entering the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) is called returning to the *dǐng* (鼎). The *dǐng* (鼎) is the *Dāntián* (丹田). Yunya Zi said: The Azure Dragon and White Tiger are born in the south and north, seized and contained within each other, and wander within the *dǐng* (鼎).

Yuan Yang Zi said: The Azure Dragon is Wood, born from the *Kǎn* (坎) *hù* (户); the White Tiger is Metal, born from the *Lí* (离) *gōng* (宫). Thus, the Azure Dragon is lead, born from the north; the White Tiger is mercury, born from the south.

Mercury generates *shā* (砂), its exterior red and corresponding to yang, while its interior produces *shuǐyín* (水银). Lead arises from *shílì* (石砺), its exterior black and corresponding to yin, refining into *báixī* (白锡). Lead is the *jīn* (津), named *Yùyè* (玉液) or *Huápú* (华池) water; mercury is the *jīng* (精), named *Zēngqīng* (曾青) or *Fǎshuǐ* (法水)—these two are one in essence.

At the *Zhōngyuán* (中元) *Cháo* (朝) to the Red Sovereign, when divided between upper and lower, the upper is the yang of lead, and the lower is the yin of mercury. When yin and yang harmonize and obtain *Huángpó* (黄婆), the Great Elixir is formed. This is the Dragon and Tiger wandering within the *dǐng* (鼎).

Yunya Zi said: The Metal Sovereign seeks *Huángpó* (黄婆) to meet with the Jade Maiden.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The Metal Sovereign is lead, also named *Yīng’ér* (婴儿); the Jade Maiden is mercury. When lead and mercury merge and enter the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫), *Huángpó* (黄婆) resides within the *dǐng* (鼎). The center of the *dǐng* (鼎) is the *Dāntián* (丹田) and Earth. One gives birth to Five; Five merge into One—this is called the Ten *Gān* (干, stems). This is the Six *Hé* (合) count.

This is the essence of the sun’s *arcan* (魂), moon’s *pò* (华), sun’s *pò* (魄), moon’s *arcan* (津), silver exterior, and gold interior.

Yunya Zi said: The birth of lead and mercury originates from one essence.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Lead and mercury are the roots of the *Xiàyuán* (下元) *Mìngmén* (命门). At the center of *Qìyuè* (弃钥), they are born from the two kidneys: the left is *Rén* (壬), the right is *Guǐ* (癸). The two *qi* of the kidneys merge into one, forming lead and mercury. They ascend and descend, flying and surging, dividing between south and north, paired at the *Lí* (离) *gōng* (宫) and *Kǎn* (坎) *hù* (户). When they rise and fall, lead and mercury transform.

Lead is yang, named the Metal Sovereign or *Yīng’ér* (婴儿); mercury is yin, named the *Lí* (离) Maiden or *Lǎonǚ* (姥女).

The *Sūtra* (经) states: *"Kǎn* (坎) male and *Lí* (离) female as husband and wife—Water and Fire form them, *Huángpó* (黄婆) as their mother. Those who can preserve this are true Water and Fire."

Yunya Zi said: Gold and silver are the true *Zōng* (宗) of the *Dharma* (法).

They ascend and descend, flying and surging—are these not the two names?

Yuan Yang Zi said: Gold and silver are the *yin-yang* (阴阳) *qi*; upper and lower are the two *xián* (弦, cords). The moon’s third day is seen at *Gēng* (庚); the twenty-eighth day is seen at *Jiǎ* (甲). On the eighth and twenty-second days, it appears at the *Lí* (离) *gōng* (宫). This is the *yin-yang* (阴阳) *biànzhuǎn* (变转), *zàohuà* (造化) forming shapes.

For the first fifteen days, it waxes full; for the latter fifteen days, it wanes. This is the foundation of the Two *Bā* (八), the count of *yin-yang* (阴阳), where all six lines are complete.

Thus, the sun’s *arcan* (魂) and moon’s *pò* (魄) are born from *Kǎn* (坎) and *Lí* (离), the *qi* of Metal and Wood, formed by Water and Fire into an embryonic sac. Nurtured and transformed, they produce the color of the *Huándān* (还丹) and become the Elixir of the Four Spirits.

Yunya Zi said: When *yin-yang* (阴阳) reverse and transform, they form the Nine *Yù* (域). The *Kǎn* (坎) *hù* (户) and *Lí* (离) *gōng* (宫) display their transformative interplay.

Yuan Yang Zi said: It is the gathering of the true *zhèngqì* (正气) of *yin-yang* (阴阳), preserving essence to complete it. Their count is based on the numbers seven, eight, nine, and six; their timing on *Yín* (寅), *Shēn* (申), *Sì* (巳), and *Hài* (亥).

To forge this, one must first temper the lower Fire, restraining lead from flying and mercury from fleeing. Only when they settle harmoniously in the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) *dǐng* (鼎) can they transform into the white tooth of the horse, using its *Dāoguī* (刀圭) to naturally produce *Yùyè* (玉液)—this is named *Huángyá* (黄芽).

To achieve the seven returns, one must begin at *Yín* (寅). The hexagram corresponds to *Tài* (泰), the position where three yin and three yang merge. Internally, it corresponds to the liver; externally, it manifests as *Mǎo* (卯).」

Thus, *Yín* (寅) is the Wood, the longest of the four *Mèng* (孟) months; *Zhèn* (震) is the second, so one may use *Yín* (寅) but not *Mǎo* (卯).

*Shēn* (申) corresponds to the hexagram *Pǐ* (否), where after *Pǐ* (否) reaches its extreme, *Tài* (泰) arrives, and *Tài* (泰) follows *Pǐ* (否). Their union shifts with the times, hence the three *yīn* (阴) and three *yáng* (阳) alternate and give birth. Internally, it corresponds to the lungs; externally, it belongs to *Yǒu* (酉). *Yǒu* (酉) is the Metal of the west; *Shēn* (申) is the longest; *Duì* (兑) is the second. One may use *Shēn* (申) but not *Yǒu* (酉).

From *Yín* (寅) to *Shēn* (申), the Dragon and Tiger suffice within themselves to form the seven returns. The numinous sand undergoes two transformations and returns to the Nine Realms. The Nine Realms are the gateways of the ninefold alchemical process: the first is *Gǔshén* (谷神), the second *Qián Guān* (乾关), the third *Huápéi* (华池), the fourth *Pìn Mén* (牝门), the fifth *Hún Chuāng* (魂窗), the sixth *Tiān Hù* (天户), the seventh *Zhī Yǒu* (知牖), the eighth *Xīyí* (希夷), and the ninth is the Nine Realms itself.

From darkness, the nine-colored *qīng* (青) arise—white, yellow, red, black, green, blue, and purple—entering through this. They originate from the interplay of the heart and kidneys, known as the *Lí Guān* (离宫) and *Kǎn Hù* (坎户). *Lí* (离) is *yīn* (阴), the heart; *Kǎn* (坎) is *yáng* (阳), the kidneys, and the transformation of *yīn-yáng* (阴阳).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: The souls of the sun and moon are what the immortals cherish. They can refine the Three Fields to produce a jade bead, which the immortals consume as their *Dāoguī* (刀圭).

Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: The sun’s soul and moon’s essence are the vital essence (*jīng* 精), the vital *qi* (*qì* 气), the true *qi* of *yīn-yáng* (阴阳), and the root of humanity. This essence and *qi* circulate within the Three Palaces; refining them returns them to the *Dāntián* (丹田), thus forming *Zǐjīn* (紫金)—a substance round and square, filling an inch, weighing a pound. This is the gathering of the true *yīn-yáng* (阴阳) *qi* to completion.

The *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) *dǐng* (鼎) is named *Dāoguī* (刀圭). *Dāoguī* (刀圭) is the Earth, also called *Huángyá* (黄芽).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: The sun’s soul and moon’s essence emerge from *Kǎn-Lí* (坎离). Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: Wooden *qi* arises from the *Kǎn Hù* (坎户) and ascends, corresponding externally to lead (*qiān* 铅), called *Yùyè* (玉液). It resides in *Huápéi* (华池), the left orifice, named the sun’s soul.

Pure Metal emerges from the *Kǎn-Lí* (坎离) Palaces, corresponding externally to mercury (*gǒng* 汞), called *Jīnyè* (金液). In the four seasons, its ascent and descent, circulation and response, never leave the *Dāntián* (丹田)—the child of the *Dāntián* (丹田).

From the right orifice, ascending, it is named the moon’s essence. Its thirst transforms into flowing *zhū* (朱), entering the mud to become bone, then into *jīnmì* (金髓), and finally into pearls. Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: Through the interplay of *Rén* (壬) and *Bǐng* (丙), entering *Xīyí* (希夷), *Jiǎ* (甲) meets *Gēng* (庚), and the divine mechanism shifts.

Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: *Bǐng* (丙) is Fire, the *Lí* (离) Palace; *Rén* (壬) is Water, the *Kǎn* (坎) Palace, the kidneys. When Water and Fire are harmonized (*Jìjí* 既济), the medicine is complete, hence *Xīyí* (希夷). *Xīyí* (希夷) is the root of the Five Phases, born from Earth.

The ninefold alchemical process also forms here, becoming the *Huándān* (还丹). The Fields are Wood; *Gēng* (庚) is Metal. When Metal and Wood mutually restrain each other, true refinement is achieved! Metal and Wood are the medicine’s foundation; understanding this to refine lead and mercury, one attains the divine mechanism.

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: The *Fù* (复) hexagram’s line and the pregnant *tǐ* (体) are the two bases. Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: The *Fù* (复) line is the month of *Jiànzǐ* (建子), where *yáng* (阳) first emerges. It is the precursor to *Zǐ* (子).

The pregnant *tǐ* (体) is the month of *Jiànwǔ* (建午), where *yīn* (阴) first emerges. It is the precursor to *Wǔ* (午).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: The six times can be used to regulate their *qì* (息气). Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: The six times are the numbers of the Six Coordinates (*Liùhé* 六合).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: *Mǎo* (卯) and *Yǒu* (酉) stir and overturn, corresponding to their marrow within the Three Fields, allowing mutual refinement. When the Dragon and Tiger appear, they can be seized.

Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: *Mǎo* (卯) is Wood, corresponding to the second month; *Yǒu* (酉) is Metal, corresponding to the eighth month. They mutually refine each other. Wood transforms its *qi* into liquid, called lead (*qiān* 铅), which is *yáng* (阳) and the true *qi* of the Azure Dragon. Metal transforms its *qi* into blood, and its blood into essence, called mercury (*gǒng* 汞), which is *yīn* (阴) and the true *qi* of the White Tiger. Through sixfold transformations and refinements, one can eliminate the Three Worms (*sān chóng* 三虫).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: The Dragon is born in Fire, revealing its divine light; the Tiger is born in Water, with a firm and resolute nature.

Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: The Dragon is Wood, *qi* (气), ascending from the *Lí Guān* (离宫) and entering *Tiānguān* (天关). Its transformation yields *jīn* (津). Beneath my tongue are two orifices: the left governs *jīn* (津), the right governs *qi* (气). Within the *yín* (阴) are two orifices: the left receives *jīn* (津) and *yè* (液), the right generates tears and saliva.

Wood arises from the *Kǎn Hù* (坎户), residing in *Gèn* (艮), and *Yín* (寅) should be used. *Yín* (寅) is true Wood; use its *qì* (息) to cook it. *Qì* (息) is Fire, and its *jīn* (津) is like silver. The upper condensation forms *sū* (酥), the lower yields *yè* (液)—this is the *Tàiyáng* (太阳) *sū* (酥), which combines with essence to become *dān* (丹), thus revealing divine light.

The Tiger is the moon’s radiance, the *qi* of Metal. When Metal and Wood mutually refine each other, their *qi* and essence combine within the *dǐng* (鼎), and its color becomes like *yúnmǔ* (云母).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: When *Bǐng* (丙) and *Rén* (壬) converge, the two *qi* (气) transform. Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: *Bǐng* (丙) is *Lí* (离), Fire, and the heart; *Rén* (壬) is *Kǎn* (坎), Water, and the kidneys. When Water and Fire mutually restrain each other, *Jìjí* (既济) is achieved. *Kǎn* (坎) produces lead (*qiān* 铅), *Lí* (离) produces mercury (*gǒng* 汞). Refining lead yields white silver, and mercury returns to *zhūshā* (朱砂). When these two are combined and tempered, they form the sand of the two *qi* (气).

Yun Yang Zi (云牙子) said: Within the *Tián* (田), the horse’s tooth sprouts like bamboo shoots. Yuan Yang Zi (元阳子) said: The sand of the two *qi* (气), when moved into the *Dāntián* (丹田), is tempered like the sprouting of bamboo, like the white horse’s tooth.

Yun Yang Zi said: When Metal and Wood interact, they return to the *Dǐng* (鼎); Water and *Kǎn* (坎) are tempered and enter the *Xióngkēng* (雄坑).

Yuan Yang Zi said: Metal is Water, mercury is Yin; Wood is Fire, lead is Yang. Metal becomes *jīng* (精), Wood becomes *jīn* (津). The Four Symbols are tempered and moved into the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) *Dǐng* (鼎), where breath is closed and *qi* (气) is preserved, entering the *Xióngkēng* (雄坑). The *Xióngkēng* (雄坑) is the *Dǐng* (鼎), the Earth.

Yun Yang Zi said: When the Five Phases unite harmoniously, transformation becomes possible. *Yùyè* (玉液) and *yúnshā* (云砂) merge through the Nine Circulations.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The medicine descends from the *Shíngōng* (肾宫), and thus the *Yùquán* (玉泉) congeals. The *qi* of Metal enters and exits the *Lígōng* (离宫), descending through the kidneys to become blood, which transforms into *jīng* (精)—this is called *Jīnjīng* (金精). When it congeals above, it becomes *zēngqīng* (曾青); when it forms below, it becomes *fǎshuǐ* (法水). Its nature is to ascend; when refined to firmness and rigidity, it becomes a treasure.

Yun Yang Zi said: When the two beasts meet, they naturally subdue each other, manifesting before the *Huángjūn* (黄君), and thus vitality flourishes.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The Dragon descends, the Tiger ascends—they meet, and thus naturally unite into One. This is the act of subduing. The *Huángjūn* (黄君) is the Earth of the *Dǐng* (鼎). When lead and mercury are subdued by Earth, they return to the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫). Why? When I close my breath to a thousand inhalations, lead and mercury flow upward and downward through the Three *Tián* (田), returning to the *Xiàyuán* (下元), entering the *Lántái* (兰台) to form *Zǐjīn* (紫金), and vitality flourishes.

Yun Yang Zi said: Follow the transformations of the Three Officials (*Sānguān* 三官), fasting to consume *Yùyè* (玉液) without haste.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The Three Palaces (*Sāngōng* 三宫) are: the upper *Níwán* (泥丸), the middle *Jiāngōng* (绛宫), and the lower *Lántái Shíshì* (兰台石室). The daily *jīng* (精) and monthly *huá* (华) circulate above and below, paying homage to the *Yuánjūn* (元君), with the *Chìdìjūn* (赤帝君) residing in the middle and the *Huángyuánjūn* (黄元君) below. Nourish *jīng* (精) through *qi* (气), and *shén* (神) through *jīng* (精). When *shén* (神) can transform, the Three thrice Three become Nine. The scholar need only cultivate *qi* (气) and still the breath, swallowing the harmonious *chōng* (冲) *qi* when hungry, drinking the *Huápó* (华池) elixir when thirsty. Thus, one may transform *qi* into blood, blood into *jīng* (精), *jīng* (精) to nourish the vessels, the vessels to replenish the flesh, the flesh to enrich the marrow, the marrow to strengthen the sinews, the sinews to moisten the hair, and the hair to return to blackness. Then, when *Jīngǔ* (金骨) is complete, aging is reversed into youth.

When one closes the breath and silently counts to a thousand inhalations, the Five Grains are naturally dispelled, and hunger and thirst vanish. Boiling *Yùyè* (玉液) moistens the Five *Zàng* (藏) and benefits the Six *Fǔ* (府). At ten thousand inhalations, one may attain immortality.

Yun Yang Zi said: Close the *Tiānguān* (天关), seal the *Dìhù* (地户)—the medicine is not yet complete; do not act recklessly.

Yuan Yang Zi said: If *Tiānguān* (天关) does not close and *Dìhù* (地户) does not seal, this is the key to cultivating life. As for feasting on clouds, ingesting *qi*, and using medicines to abstain from grains—these are the actions of the mad, far from immortality. Thus the *Jīng* (经) says: *"Only use the mercury within the body; do not take it from external realms."*

Yun Yang Zi said: *Jīnjīn* (金津) arises from the *Kǎnhù* (坎户), *Yùyè* (玉液) is produced in the *Lígōng* (离宫).

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Jīnjīn* (金津) is *jīng* (精); *Kǎn* (坎) is the kidneys; *Yùyè* (玉液) comes from the *Lígōng* (离宫), merging with *jīng* (精) to return to the *Zhōnggōng* (中宫) and form the Great Elixir (*Dàdān* 大丹). The Great Elixir is lead and mercury.

Yun Yang Zi said: The two are originally One, divided into the Two Principles (*Èryí* 二仪).

Yuan Yang Zi said: Lead becomes *jīn* (津), mercury becomes *jīng* (精)—transformed through *qi* (气). When they reach the *Lígōng* (离宫), they are again divided above and below—this is the creation of Yin and Yang! One substance with two forms. When they unite, using breath to refine them, the Great Medicine is complete, the Five Grains are dispelled, and the Three Worms (*Sānchóng* 三虫) perish.

Yun Yang Zi said: In the realm of *huǎnghū* (恍惚), there is form within the obscure; in the *yǎomíng* (杳冥), there is substance within the void.

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Huǎnghū* contains substance—its emptiness is real, called *Yángqì* (阳气); *Yǎomíng* contains *jīng* (精)—its nothingness is real, called *Yīnjīng* (阴精). *Jīng* (精) and *qi* (气) unite to form *shén* (神). *Shén* (神) is breath; breath is Earth, is Fire. Fire nourishes Earth, Earth preserves Fire. Thus, one substance becomes three!

Yun Yang Zi said: Within the void is real *jīng* (精); within the nothing is the Way made manifest.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The void becomes real through circulating *jīng* (精) to nourish the brain! The nothing becomes manifest through *qi* (气) transforming into *jīn* (津), *jīn* (津) into blood, and blood into *jīng* (精). *Jīng* (精) is *shén* (神); when *shén* (神) is preserved, the body is healthy; when *shén* (神) departs, the body perishes. If one can nourish *jīng* (精) and *qi* (气) while preserving *shén* (神), the Way is naturally complete. Thus it is said: *"Pure Yin does not form an embryo; pure Yang does not congeal the elixir."*

Yun Yang Zi said: Following the body of Creation, Yin and Yang transform harmoniously, and vitality flourishes.

Yuan Yang Zi said: When *jīng* (精) and *qi* (气) interact, *zhèngqì* (正气) is generated. *Zhèngqì* (正气) is the root of humanity. When *zhèngqì* (正气) scatters, *shén* (神) does not gather. *Shénqì* (神息) is life. This is the essence of Metal and Wood! The body, able to create transformation, radiates with vitality and returns to youth.

Yun Yang Zi said: The Nine Returns and Seven Circulations are the functions of *Qiánkūn* (乾坤).

Yuan Yang Zi said: From *Yín* (寅) to *Shēn* (申), and from *Shēn* (申) back to *Yín* (寅)—each half-year’s symbol, hence "return." This is ascending along the spine to the *Nǐnhù* (脑户) and descending to the *Yùquán* (玉泉), also called the Seven Circulations. From *Wèi* (巳) to *Hài* (亥), and from *Hài* (亥) back to *Wèi* (巳), entering the *Jīnsuǒgǔ* (金锁骨) from the tail, ascending through the *Níwán* (泥丸) via the twelve chambers of the *Chónglóu* (重楼), paying homage to the *Chìdì* (赤帝), and flowing to the *Dāntián* (丹田).

The essence is then offered to the Yellow Primordial, and afterward enters the Golden Hall. There are seven heavens, where the noble attends to it, storing it in the Treasure Vault—first as the *Shénzhū* (神珠, Divine Pearl), second as the *Bǎoguī* (宝龟, Precious Tortoise), third as the *Hèchì Jīndān* (赫赤金丹, Crimson Golden Elixir). Its light shines in nine hues, hence the term "Nine Returns."

Yun Yang Zi said: *Shénshuǐ* (神水, Divine Water) and *Zēngqīng* (曾青, Azurite) are names of the earth. They flow upward and downward, each moving in their own course.

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Shénshuǐ* is the essence, governing beneath the tongue, ascending inversely from the kidneys, piercing the *Lígōng* (离宫, Palace of Separation), and passing through—its name is the *Huápí zhī jiāng* (华池之浆, Nectar of the Flower Pool). *Zēngqīng* is the essence, ascending inversely from the right kidney, passing through the *Lígōng*, descending again to emerge at the *Yùquán*, and entering the *Xīyí* (希夷, Mysterious Void).

Yun Yang Zi said: *Shénshuǐ* emerges from *Bǐng* (丙) and *Dīng* (丁); *Zēngqīng* emerges from *Rén* (壬) and *Guǐ* (癸).

Yuan Yang Zi said: *Bǐng* is the South, born in *Wèi* (巳); *Dīng* is also the South, born in *Wèi* (未), both belonging to Yang, clinging to *Lí* (离). Its west is Yang, its center is Yin.

This generates *Shénshuǐ*—called *Yùyè* (玉液, Jade Nectar), *Qiān* (铅, Lead), *Lóng* (龙, Dragon), *Yīng’ér* (婴儿, Infant), *Jīngōng* (金公, Golden Lord), *Tàiyáng sū* (太阳酥, Solar Butter).

*Rén* is the North, located in *Hài* (亥); *Guǐ* is also the North, born in *Chǒu* (丑), both belonging to Yin, clinging to *Kǎn* (坎). Its west is Yin, its center is Yang.

This generates *Zēngqīng*—called *Jīnjīn* (金津, Golden River), *Gǒng* (汞, Mercury), *Hǔ* (虎, Tiger), *Chàinǚ* (诧女, Astonished Maiden), *Yùzhì* (玉质, Jade Essence), *Fǎshuǐ* (法水, Sacred Water).

The *Classic* says: The Five Phases—preserving essence, safeguarding spirit—are the Dragon and Tiger. Not understanding the essence of the Five Phases is like taking others as one’s parents!

Water governs *qi*, Metal refines the marrow, Flesh belongs to Earth, Blood belongs to Water. Thus, the Way of Immortality lies within the *Lígōng*.

Knowing the Five Phases, one’s body has its master.

*Huándān* (还丹, Returned Elixir) is the essence of water and mercury; their differing natures cannot be conflated.

Yun Yang Zi said: Within the central palace, seek the cauldron vessels—eight gates facing each other, thus corresponding to the functions.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The central palace’s cauldron is the Yellow Primordial Sovereign. What are the eight gates? They are *Xiū* (休, Rest), *Shēng* (生, Birth), *Shāng* (伤, Injury), *Dù* (杜, Block), *Jǐng* (景, Appearance), *Sǐ* (死, Death), *Jīng* (惊, Alarm), and *Kāi* (开, Opening). Thus, the daily use of the eight trigrams arises from the eight palaces, making the elixir’s operation follow its course.

Yun Yang Zi said: Use water and fire to complete *Jìjí* (既济, Accomplishment).

Yuan Yang Zi said: Water and fire are essence and *qi*, breath and spirit. Upper water, lower fire—refine them to form the elixir, without deviation.

Yun Yang Zi said: When the solar essence and lunar essence merge and are refined, they become *shā* (砂, sand).

Yuan Yang Zi said: Solar essence is Yang, the *qi* of Wood; lunar essence is Yin, the *qi* of Metal.

Yun Yang Zi said: Knowing the white, guarding the black—its name is *Héchē* (河车, River Vehicle).

Yuan Yang Zi said: It is black in Yin, white in Yang. Yang is lead; refining it with fire reveals inner white tin. Thus, one knows to guard the black while knowing the white.

Black is the One of Water; inner is the Four of Metal. Obtaining One to generate One—this is Yin and Yang, the essence of sun and moon. This is the *Héchē*.

The *Classic* says: The true *qi* of the North is the *Héchē*; the Five Directions’ *jiǎ* (甲, first heavenly stem) and *yǐ* (乙, second heavenly stem) form the Golden Flower—this is what is meant.

Yun Yang Zi said: Within the central palace’s circulation, the *Dāntián* generates the Yellow Sprout.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Using solar essence, lunar essence, and the four seasons’ daily rotation to enter the central palace—this is essence, lead, and the *Héchē*. *Rìhuá* (日华, Solar Flower) is mercury, the Golden Flower; the central palace is Earth. When lead and mercury meet Earth, the Yellow Sprout emerges.

Yun Yang Zi said: The *gǔqì* (谷气, grain *qi*) is exhausted; its Yin is spent; the Golden Flower appears.

Yuan Yang Zi said: Knowing lead and mercury—true *qi* generated from the lower *Dāntián*. But by closing the breath and storing the spirit to nourish the *qi*, when the breath is closed to a thousand counts, the dead *qi* of the five grains is eliminated. Neither hungry nor thirsty, the spirit is preserved, and true *qi* is daily reborn. Feeding on the *Yuánhé* (元和, Primordial Harmony) *qi*, drinking the *Tiānpíng* (天池, Heavenly Pool) jade nectar—its fragrance is like chrysanthemum, hence the Golden Flower.

Yun Yang Zi said: The sea within has no impurities; the Three Worms gradually depart.

Yuan Yang Zi said: The sea of water and grain holds its dregs. Refining lead and mercury for a hundred days; closing the breath to nourish *qi* for a thousand breaths—its dregs are eliminated. What are the Three Worms? The upper is *Péngjū* (彭倨), dwelling in the upper *Dāntián*; in thirty days, it perishes, and my complexion becomes radiant. The middle is *Péngzhì* (彭质), dwelling in the middle *Dāntián*; in sixty months, it perishes, and my hunger and thirst cease while my form becomes moist. The lower is *Péngjiāo* (彭娇), dwelling in the lower *Dāntián*; in ninety days, it perishes, and my desires cease while I return to youth.

How do the Three Corpses perish? I have heard: three hundred sixty breaths, swallowing *qi* twenty-four times per breath, ninety breaths before resting, and at midnight, reciting: "The East’s *Qīngyá* (青牙, Green Tooth) drinks the morning flower; the South’s *Chìyá* (赤牙, Red Tooth) drinks from the elixir pool; the Central gazes upward at *Tàishān* (泰山, Grand Mountain), ingesting primordial *qi* and drinking from the *Lìquán* (醴泉, Sweet Spring). The West consumes the clear and drinks the sacred fluid; the North’s *Xuánzǐ* (玄滋, Mysterious Nourishment) eats the jade ox." Each direction is swallowed three times, and the Three Worms thus perish, while white *qi* emerges from the brow like jade clouds.

Yun Yang Zi said: Its form arises from the Golden Skeleton, accompanying the Floating Inquiry.

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:

*"The refining of lead and mercury—*
when the sun and moon, the four seasons, and the Three Officials are turned in cycles of three hundred,
the **Golden Elixir** is complete in a hundred days.

*By closing the breath and nurturing the **qi**,*
until it reaches ten thousand,
the **Golden Skeleton** transforms.

*When the mind has a direction,*
and one ascends the **Floating Inquiry** upon flying clouds,
these are the **Five Assumptions** of immortality."

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"From one to ten,
one can distribute according to the cycles of years and months."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"From one to ten,
from ten to a hundred,
from a hundred to a thousand,
from a thousand to ten thousand,
from ten thousand to a hundred million,
from a hundred million to a trillion,
from a trillion to a quadrillion,
from a quadrillion to a quintillion*—this is the number.

*A day and a night constitute a hundred **kè** (刻, time-marks)—*
this is the distinction between the great and the small.

*Why so?*
*A day has twelve **shí** (时, hours),
six of which are **Yang**—*
from **Zǐ** (子, 11 PM) to **Wǔ** (午, 11 AM),
*and six of which are **Yin**—*
from **Wǔ** (午, 11 AM) to **Hài** (亥, 11 PM).
*Exhausting the night,*
a hundred **kè** with twenty-four **fēn** (分, minutes) and forty-four **xiāo** (杪, fractions),
seventy-two **biàn** (变, changes),
*—its pattern is that of one year.*
*Ten months—*
this is ten years,
*—the lesser of these.*
*A year has twelve months,*
six of which are **Yang**—
*from the eleventh month to the fourth month,*
*—and six of which are **Yin**—*
*from the fifth month to the tenth month.*
*—This is the greater of these.*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Day and hour, season and cycle—*
these are their numbers,
*—lying only in measuring the **Yin** and **Yang**."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"The day aligns with the hour.*
*For nurturing the nature and refining the life,*
one can use the four seasons and their four **Mèng** (孟, beginnings)—
**Lìchūn** (立春, Beginning of Spring), **Lìxià** (立夏, Beginning of Summer), **Lìqiū** (立秋, Beginning of Autumn), **Lìdōng** (立冬, Beginning of Winter).
*The hour can be used with **Yín** (寅, Tiger), **Shēn** (申, Monkey), **Wǔ** (午, Horse), and **Hài** (亥, Pig)—
*—these are the seven returns and nine reversions.*
**Yín** is wood;
**Shēn** is metal;
**Wǔ** is fire;
**Hài** is water,
*—these are the four **Xiàng** (象, phases).*
*When absorbed into the **Central Palace** (中宫),
*—this is the five **Xíng** (行, elements).*
**Yín** is metal;
**Wǔ** is water;
**Shēn** is wood;
**Hài** is fire.
*When absorbed into the **Central Palace** (中宫),
*—it reverses the **Kàn** (坎, Abyss) and **Lí** (离, Fire)—*
hence, it is called the seven returns.
*The **Clásico** says:*
*'**Lí** contains true water,
**Kàn** contains proper metal,'*
*—hence, it is called the nine reversions.*
*—This is the **Yin** and **Yang**."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **Six Harmonies** (六合) and the **Breaking of the Divine Mechanism** (冲破神机) mutually embrace and complete."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Zǐ** (子, 11 PM) and **Chǒu** (丑, Ox),
**Yín** (寅, Tiger) and **Hài** (亥, Pig),
**Wǔ** (午, Horse) and **Shēn** (申, Monkey),
**Wèi** (未, Sheep) and **Yǒu** (酉, Rooster),
**Xū** (戌, Dog) and **Mǎo** (卯, Hare),
**Chén** (辰, Dragon) and **Zǐ** (丑, Ox)—
*—these are the **Six Harmonies**.*

*And **Zǐ** (子, 11 PM) and **Wǔ** (午, Horse),
**Mǎo** (卯, Hare) and **Yǒu** (酉, Rooster),
**Wǔ** (午, Horse) and **Hài** (亥, Pig),
**Yín** (寅, Tiger) and **Shēn** (申, Monkey),
**Chén** (辰, Dragon) and **Xū** (戌, Dog),
**Chǒu** (丑, Ox) and **Wèi** (未, Sheep)—
*—these are the **Breaking** (冲).*
*By turning within the **Six Harmonies** and acting through their **Breaking**,
*—this is how the **Divine Mechanism** (天机) completes itself.*
*Follow this and there will be no error.*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"When the practice succeeds,*
*—the greater takes nine years,*
*—the lesser takes a hundred days."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"Nine years—*
*—its lesser practice,*
*—still requires twenty-seven years.*
*Closing the breath for a hundred days,*
*—then the **Golden Elixir** is complete,*
*—more effective than the nine-year difficulty."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Yín** (寅, Tiger) and **Shēn** (申, Monkey) align with **Wǔ** (午, Horse) and **Hài** (亥, Pig),
*—and **Zǐ** (子, 11 PM) and **Wǔ** (午, Horse) turn the **Golden Elixir**."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Yín** (寅, Tiger), **Shēn** (申, Monkey), **Wǔ** (午, Horse), and **Hài** (亥, Pig)—*
*—these are the four seasons,*
*—the functional cycles of the

Spring gives birth to all things—
this is **two yang and one yin**,
with yin beneath,
and in thirty days, it blooms into **Hua**.*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Lí** (離, Vermilion Bird) is the **Zhūquè**—
its essence is hidden in the earth."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Lí** arises from **Zhèn** (震),
nurtured by wind, its form is fire—
this is **cinnabar**,
within which lies **mercury**,
its correspondence to **Wǔ** (午, Horse),
rooted in the earth.
Why is it stored above?
**Kūn** (坤, Earth) lies in the southwest,
paired with **Qián** (乾, Heaven) as husband and wife—
in sixty days, **Zǐjīng** (紫精) is complete."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Duì** (兌, Lake) emerges from **Kūn**’s palace,
its essence self-sealed."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Duì** is the west,
the **Yǒu** (酉, Rooster) position,
born of **Kūn**.
Thus, the sun and moon face each other—
the moon waxes, the sun wanes—
this is **one yin and one yang**,
with yang beneath,
and in ninety days, **Zǐjīnshā** (紫金砂) is formed."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"After **Zǐ** (子, 11 PM), the cycle returns to its initial hexagram.
**Yín** (寅, Tiger) and **Shēn** (申, Monkey) unite in harmony—
this is the **seven returns**."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Fù** (復, Recovery) is the **five yin and one yang**—
the **Dragon in the Field**.
From **Zǐ** to **Shēn**,
this is **Pǐ** (否, Opposition)—
three yin, three yang—
thus, the **seven returns**."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Before **Wǔ** (午, Horse), the incoming aligns in response."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Sì** (巳, Snake) and **Hài** (亥, Pig)—
the **nine returns** of **Qián** and **Kūn** are complete.
**Wǔ** is the moment when **one yin first emerges**,
the time to act, aligned with the month.
Its hexagram is **Rǎn** (孚, Sincerity)—
**five yang and one yin**,
treading frost to form solid ice.
**Sì** is the **Qián** hexagram—
the full measure of six yang is achieved.
Yang is **eight liang of silver**,
yin is **eight liang of gold**;
when gold and silver unite,
their combined weight is **384 zhu**—
this is **one jīn**.
The **nine returns** are the **nine transformations**,
and the nine colors are complete."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Gèn** (艮, Mountain) invests **Kūn**—
its yang is nearly exhausted,
cycling through yin and yang,
the nine-month course."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Gèn** is the **northeast**—
**one yang and two yin**.
**Kūn** is the **southwest**—
**three yin**.
When **Gèn** invests **Kūn**,
the hexagram is **Bō** (剥, Shedding)—
the nine-month symbol.
**One yang and five yin** extend to the tenth month,
when yang is exhausted and **Kūn** manifests."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Duì** enters **Qián**—
its yin is nearly severed,
the hexagram divides at the seasons—
this is the **nine-three cycle**."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Duì** is the west;
**Qián** is the **northwest**—
both are **metal**.
When **Duì** enters **Qián**,
this is **Yāng** (央, Central)—
the three-month symbol.
**Five yang and one yin** extend to the fourth month,
when yin is severed and **Qián** is complete—
this is the **nine returns**.
Thus, the **Great Elixir** becomes the **Purple Gold Elixir**."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **upper arc** is the moon’s beginning,
born in the **Gēng** (庚) position."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"On the moon’s third day,
it rises in **Gēng**—
this is the initial **golden crystal qi**.
Thus, the yin line weighs **twelve zhu**,
named **Yuèpò** (月魄, Moon’s Shadow)."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **lower arc** is the moon’s decline,
found in the **Jiǎ** (甲) position."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"On the moon’s twenty-eighth day,
it rises in **Jiǎ**—
the **Great Sun** appears,
and this is the initial **wooden crystal qi**.
The yang line weighs **twelve zhu**,
named **Rìhún** (日魂, Sun’s Soul).
When sun and moon unite,
their combined weight is **one liang**.
The *Yì* says:
*'In the southwest, companions are gained—
the upper arc;
In the northeast, companions are lost—
the lower arc.'
Gaining companions is the sun setting while the moon rises;
Losing companions is the moon setting while the sun rises.
This is the yin-yang line’s measure.
Thus, **lead**, born of wood,
is **yang, silver, the exterior, the husband**;
**mercury**, born of metal,
is **yin, gold, the interior, the wife**—
their union completes the **four symbols**."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Seven and eight—
the sun and moon face each other;
Two and eight—
yin and yang are complete."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"The sun and moon—
on the fifteenth day, they face each other.
When they meet, they are newly born.
Fifteen days prior, there are two days;
the sun waxes, the moon wanes—
fifteen days later, there are eight days.
The moon waxes, the sun wanes—
this is **six yin and six yang**,
and the lines are complete.
Their yin-yang weights,
each **192 zhu**—
this is **one jīn**."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The moon—
paired with the twenty-third day—
its birth hour is in **Lí** (離)."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"On the eighth and twenty-third days,
the moon rises, the sun sets—
both occur in the **south**.
The south is **Lí**;
**Lí** is fire within water.
The moon is the **metal qi**,
as the child of water.
Yin and yang paired—
**gold and silver**—
the **Great Elixir** meets and harmonizes."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Gold** is yin, the moon;
**silver** is yang, the sun.
When **mercury** obtains **lead**, the **Great Elixir** is formed—
this is the sun and moon’s union."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Preserve its spirit and breath,
and the elixir is complete."*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **spirit** is **qi, wood, breath, blood, water**.
**Breath** contains the five grains,
and is also **earth, metal, water, wood, fire**.
**Blood** is water,
and thus also **marrow, essence**.
**Essence** is **spirit**.
He who preserves his **essence-qi**,
thus unites the **jīn-yè qi**,
nourishes his **ming** (命, fate),
and extends his years."*

The **Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Nine transformations—
will the **Three Pure Ones’** celestial talisman arrive?"*

The **Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"Having recognized **lead and mercury**,
refining them into the elixir,
settling them in the **three palaces**,
using the hexagrams daily,
cycling through the six times,
with the **Heavenly Gate** unopened,
the **Earthly Door** unclosed—
thus, there is no leakage.
The celestial talisman should indeed arrive."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Seven transformations—
these arise from the **One Qi**;
the **Divine Talisman** and **White Snow**—
these come from **Jiǎ-Gēng**.*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"Seven transformations—
these are seven returns;
**Qi**—
this is the **true qi** born from the **Dan Field**;
**Jiǎ-Gēng**—
this is the **metal and wood** in mutual assault;
the **Divine Talisman** and **White Snow**—
this is the union of **essence-qi** within the **crucible**.*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Apply the mind to **Yín-Shēn**,
diligently tend the **fire stages**,
preserve the **white and black**,
thus returning the **golden crystal**.*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"**Yín**—
this is **wood**, this is **lead**;
**Shēn**—
this is **metal**, this is **mercury**—
refined from **Yín** to **Hài**."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Daily use—
this is the **four seasons**, this is the **eight trigrams**;
the **Great Elixir** can transform one into an infant.*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"Daily use—
this is one day as one year;
the **four seasons**—
these are **Yín-Shēn-Yǐ-Hài**;
the **eight trigrams**—
**Qián, Kūn, Lí, Kàn, Pǐ, Tài, Fù, Guān**.
Three hundred and twenty days—
the **Great Elixir** is complete;
one thousand three hundred days—
the **three worms** perish."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"When the **three worms** perish, one is serene and without care,
and may then nurture the **golden essence**."*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"Then the **Five Grains** are cut off,
and the **golden essence** abides on its own."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **Heavenly Pass** is sealed,
the **Earthly Gate** is firmly shut—
the **Mid-Court Infant** plays with the sun and moon."*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"When the **Heavenly Pass** is sealed, all flavors do not enter;
when the **Earthly Gate** is shut, there is no leakage below.
The **Mid-Court**—this is the **Cinnabar Field**.
Within it are **lead and mercury**,
whose name is the **Infant**,
playing with the **true qi of Yin and Yang**!"*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"Before the **Bright Hall** lies a **Jade Pool**."*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **Bright Hall**—this is the **Pure Key**, the **Essence Sea**, the **Chamber of Mystery**."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **Yellow Mother** then marries the **Maiden**."*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"When **lead and mercury** meet **earth**, they return to **One**."*

**Yún Yáng Zi** said:
*"When the **binding** is complete, the **true embryo** is shed.
Projected across the **Twenty-Four Breaths**,
ten months mark its term—
then the **Infant** is born from the **crown of the head**."*

**Yuán Yáng Zi** said:
*"The **true qi** gradually congeals in the **Cinnabar Field**,
returning to the **color of a child**—
this is the **shedding of the embryo**.
In the months of **Mao and You**, one must not descend the **fire**,
but may bathe.
Thus, the **year’s work** is but **ten months**.
Preserve and visualize the **true qi**,
as it circulates from the **crown of the head** in and out—
this is the **Infant**."*

*(End of Volume 34 of **Dao Gun Ju** #1—Original text: "或" corrected to "於" according to the **Jí Yào Edition**.)*

**#2 Lead:** Original text: *"松"* (corrected to *"铅"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#3 Ascend:** Original text: *"腾"* (corrected to *"腾"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#4 Stems:** Original text: *"卯"* (corrected to *"爻"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#5 Yang:** Original text: *"阴"* (corrected to *"阳"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#6 Azure:** Original text: *"气"* (corrected to *"青"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#7 Mercury:** Original text: *"承"* (corrected to *"汞"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).
**#8 Augury:** Original text: *"治"* (corrected to *"兆"* in the *Jí Yào Edition*).

Forty-two volumes in total.
Source of the base text: *Dao Gun Ju* from the **Daoist Canon (正统道藏)****, *Tàixuān* section**.

Cross-referenced editions:
1. The *Jí Yào Edition* (辑要本), included in its *Zǐjí* collection, Volumes 3 to 6 of that work (hereafter referred to as the *Jí Yào Edition*).
2. The *Zhì Yóu Zi* (*至游子*), as preserved in the *Cangjie* Collection (*四库全书存目丛书*), reprinted from the Chongqing Library’s Ming *Jiaqing* 45th-year (嘉靖四十五年) edition, engraved by Yao Ruxun (姚汝循).

*(End of Volume 35 of **Dao Gun Ju**—Compiled by Zēng Cùo.)*

**The Chapter on "The Multitude of Marvels"**

The method of **Daoist cultivation (导养)**—to refine the **nature (性)** and preserve the **form (形)**—when practiced without neglect, leads one to **longevity (长生)**.

The **Yin True Master (阴真君)** names **longevity (长生)** as follows:
The **orthodox qi (正气)** of the Northern **Dao (方)** is the **River Vehicle (河车)**;
The **restraining of the first and second **Dao (方甲乙)** is the **Golden Sand (金砂)**.
When one **nourishes (含养)** these two, they merge into **one whole (一体)**.
The **Vermilion Bird (朱雀)**, harmonizing the **circulation (调运)**, then gives rise to the **Golden Flower (金花)**.
The **Flower (花)** is the **treasure of Heaven and Earth (天地之宝)**.
**Yǒu (酉)** is the **Tiger (虎)**; **Mǎo (卯)** is the **Dragon (龙)**.
When **Dragon (龙)** and **Tiger (虎)** generate each other, they achieve **unity (合同)**.
The **Dragon’s (龙)** proper position is the **Sixty-Fourth (六八)**;
The **Tiger’s (虎)** birthplace is the **First Palace (一宫)**.
To **harvest (采)** them requires a precise **time (日)**;
To **take (取)** them requires a proper **season (时)**.
If one misjudges the **climatic conditions (气候)**, the labor will be in vain.
To **seek the Cauldron (鼎)** in the **Central Palace (中宫)**,
To **warm-nourish (温养)** its **fiery phase (火候)**,
To **discern (审)** its **Yin and Yang (阴阳)**,
To **settle (安)** its **furnace-chamber (炉室)**,
One must **choose a secluded and secret place (地而隐密)**.
To **preserve (保)** without loss is the **mechanism of Heaven and Earth (天地之机)**.
**Yang (阳)** is the **True Sand (真砂)**;
**Yin (阴)** is the **True Mercury (真汞)**.
That which **generates substance from non-substance (无质生质)** is the **Returned Elixir (还丹)**.
When **refined (炼)** and **ingested (饵)**, one attains **transcendence (仙)**.
The **Yellow Sprout (黄芽)** is what **Heaven and Earth (天地)** produce;
The **Sand (砂)** is the **essence of water (水之精)** refined into existence.
When these two merge into **one whole (一体)**,
The **Western **Dao (方)** elevates its **Royal Qi (王气)**,
And its attainment of the **Way (道)** lies within the **Central Realm (中华)**.
If one does not grasp this, it is rare not to **lose one’s family (丧其家)**.

**Pure Yang Master (纯阳子)** Lü Dòngbīn (吕洞宾) says:
What is the **True One (真一)**?
It is the **Yang of Heaven (天之阳)** and the **Yin of Earth (地之阴)**,
The **qi of things (物之气)** and the **human nature (人之性)**,
The **ancestor of the body (身之祖)** and the **root of life (命之宗)**,
The **substance of the Dragon (龙之体)** and the **form of the Tiger (虎之形)**,
The **name of vital essence and blood (精血之名)**,
The **source of lead and mercury (铅汞之首)**.
When seen in the **spirit (魂)**, it is **Three (三)**;
When encountered in the **ethereal soul (魄)**, it is **Seven (七)**.
This is the **origin of the True One (真一之源)**.

What is the **method of cultivation (修之之法)**?
Within my **body (身)**, I refine the **qi of the Elixir Field (丹田之气)**,
Until it reaches its **peak (壮)**—then the **natural spirit (自然之神)** is complete.
At the **twelfth hour (十有二时)**,
I **guard the True One’s single qi (天真之一气)**,
Entering the **Palace of the Elixir Field (丹田之宫)**,
With **mind free of thought (心无想)**,
And **external senses unattached (外无意)**—
Neither **emerging nor retiring (不出不入)**,
Nor **departing nor arriving (不往不来)**,
Then the **spirit settles (神定)** and **finds ease (自安)**.

**Pure Yang Master (纯阳子)** says:
**Emissions (发)** should be **prolonged (长续)**;
The **hands (手)** should **always face (常面)**;
The **mouth (口)** should **always refine (常炼)**;
The **body (体)** should **always draw inward (常挽)**;
The **fluids (液)** should **always be swallowed (常咽)**;
The **qi (气)** should **always be refined (常炼)**;
The **vital essence (精)** should **always circulate (常转)**;
The **complexion (色)** should **always be distant from excess (常远)**;
**Meditation (定)** should **always transform (常变)**.

**Master Sun (孙真人)**, Sī Miào (思邈), says:
**Form (形)** desires **exertion (劳)**;
**Alcohol (酒)** should not be consumed to **excessive intoxication (大醉)**,
Then **illness (疾)** will not arise.
**Overindulgence in food (饱食)** is **unbeneficial (无益)**.
After eating, **walk a hundred steps (行之百步)**,
Then **rub the abdomen with the hands (以手摩其腹)**.
On days of **Yín-Chǒu (寅丑)**,
**Trim the nails and comb the hair (剪甲栉发)** a hundred times—
If done after **fullness (饱)**, it leads to **sudden death (立没)**;
If done in **hunger (饥)**, it leads to **sitting death (坐没)**.
**Walking should avoid facing the wind (勿迎风)**;
**Residence should have no gaps (勿有隙)**;
At night, **fear the soles of the feet (惧足)** while sleeping.
**Overthinking (思虑)** harms the **spirit (神)**;
**Excessive joy or anger (喜怒)** harms the **qi (气)**.
**Nose hairs should be removed (去毛)**;
**Spittle should not be cast upon the earth (勿唾地)**.
At dawn, **descend from the bed (下榻)**,
First placing the **left foot (左足)**,
Then **evil is repelled (去邪辟恶)**,
And **one suffers no misfortune (无殃)** that day.
To **walk the Seven-Star Step (七星之步)**,
Then **longevity and joy (寿且乐)** shall be attained.
**Sour (酸)** harms the **sinews (筋)**;
**Bitter (苦)** harms the **bones (骨)**;
**Sweet (甘)** harms the **flesh (肉)**;
**Pungent (辛)** harms the **qi (气)**;
**Salty (咸)** diminishes **longevity (寿)**.
Thus, those **indulging in cravings (耽嗜)** should **avoid extremes (不可偏)**.
In **spring and summer (春夏)**, one should **moderately release (少施泄)**;
In **autumn and winter (秋冬)**, one should **consolidate the Yang (固阳)**.
**Solitary sleep (独寝)** while **guarding the True (守真)**,
Combined with **strict stillness (谨静)**,
Is also **worthy of esteem (可贵)**.

**Wealth and goods (财货)** are **allotted at birth (生而有定分)**;
To **know contentment (知足)** is to **gain their benefit (为利)**.
To **forcefully seek (强之)** is a **great calamity (大患)**;
To **have few desires (寡欲)** is to **avoid burdens (无累)**;
To **have a tranquil spirit (神静)** is to **remain ever at ease (常安)**;
Thus, those who **cultivate the Dao (修道)** should **have a clear beginning and end (有终始)** before success can be achieved.

**Master Qī Zhēn (栖真子)**, Shī Jiānwú (施肩吾), says:
I have seen **thousands of those studying the Dao (学道者)**,
Yet who **understands its essential principle (道之要)**?
It lies in **spirit abiding within the form (神留形住)**—
If the **form is preserved (形住)**, then the **spirit abides (神留)**.
If the **spirit departs externally (神苟外进)**, how can the **form be safeguarded (其形岂能保哉)**?
Yet to **preserve the qi and nourish the spirit (保气养神)**,
One cannot **achieve it through mere stagnation (湛然而得之)**,
Nor **guard it through sheer rigidity (兀然而守之)**.
To **preserve the qi (保气)** lies in **hand movements (手运)**;
To **nourish the spirit (养神)** lies in **proper application (用)**.
I have heard from my **teacher (师)**:
When the **body is empty (体虚)** yet the **qi is firm (气固)**,
And the **form is still (形静)** while the **spirit converges (神会)**,
This is the **mystery of transcending the world (出世之玄机)**!

**Kūn Tái True Master (昆台真人)**, transmitted by **Fù Wénzhōng (富文忠公)**, as **Kūn Tái True Master (昆台真人)** spoke to **Lè Quán (乐全)**, **Master Zhāng Wéndìng (张文定公)**, who recorded it himself, saying:
I **sought the method of nurturing life (求颐生之道)** and obtained one **simple and easy (简易)**.
From the **third watch (子)** until **three or four points (三更三四点)**,
And from the **fifth watch (五更)** onward,
I can **don my clothes (披衣)**, **curl my feet (蟠足)**, and **sit (坐)**—
Even **clasping a quilt (拥袁)** on the bed is acceptable.
Whether **facing south (束向)** or **west (西向)**,
I **tap my teeth (扣其齿)** thirty-six times,
**Clenching them firmly (握固)** to **harmonize my original qi (调其元气)**.

「Now, why **clench firmly (握固)**? I use the **left and right thumbs (左右拇)** to pinch the **three fingers (三指)** on the other hand, or with the **four fingers (四指)** to firmly grasp the **thumb (拇)**—employing the **left and right hands (左右手)** to **prop my waist and abdomen (柱乎腰腹之问)**. Thus, when the **original qi (元气)** is **harmonized (调)**, my **breath (息)** becomes **subtle and faint (微微)**, my **abdomen (腹)** feels **as if hollow (若虚)**, then I **close my breath (闭息)**.

Why **close my breath (闭息)**? I first **shut my eyes (瞑目)** and **quiet my thoughts (静虑)**, making my **heart-source (心源)** **profoundly still (湛然)**, then I **close my mouth and nostrils (闭其口鼻)**, lest the **qi (气)** escape. Internally, I **contemplate (观)** the **Five Zàng-organs (五藏)** and **Six Fǔ-organs (六府)**, the **Three Elements (三元)** and **Nine Palaces (九宫)**, and the **colors of the Zàng-organs (藏)**: the **lungs’ white (肺之白)**, the **liver’s green (肝之青)**, the **spleen’s yellow (脾之黄)**, the **heart’s red (心之赤)**, and the **kidneys’ black (肾之黑)**.

But how do I **know (知)** this? I **drew diagrams (为图)** of the **Five Zàng-organs (五藏)** and **observed them daily (日观)**, thus **knowing them in detail (详矣)**. Then I **imagine (想)** my **heart (心)** as a **flaming fire (炎火)**, its **light (光)** **piercing (洞彻)** down to **below my navel (脐之下)**—this is my **Elixir Field (丹田)**.

When my **abdomen (腹)** is **full (满)**, and my **qi (气)** is **at its peak (极)**, I **gradually exhale (徐出)** it, ensuring it **does not make a sound (勿使耳有闻)**. Once the **breath’s exhalation (息之出)** is **harmonized (调)**, I **stir my tongue (搅)** between the **inner and outer lips (唇)** and **teeth (齿)**, **rinsing and refining (漱炼)** its **saliva (津液)**.

If there is **nasal mucus (涕)**, I also **rinse and refine (漱炼)** it—this is the **True Qi (真气)**, which, with **prolonged practice (久)**, becomes **sweet (甘)**. While **rinsing and refining (漱炼)**, I **must not swallow (咽)** yet. Then, as before, I **close my breath (闭息)**, internally **contemplate (观)**, **draw my heart’s fire (纳心之火)** into the **Elixir Field (丹田)**, and **harmonize my breath (调息)** while **rinsing the saliva (漱津)**.

Doing this **three times (三)**, the **saliva (津)** is **full (满)**. I **bow my head (俯首)** and **swallow (咽)**, **sending the qi (以气送之)** to the **Elixir Field (丹田)**. My **intent (用意)** must be **precise and powerful (精猛)**, so that the **saliva (津)** and **qi (气)** **roll audibly (谷谷有声)** into the **Elixir Field (丹田)**. Then I **repeat (复)** as before.

In total, **closing the breath (闭息)** **nine times (九)**, and **swallowing the saliva (咽津)** **three times (三)**, before **ceasing (止)**. Then I **use both hands (左右手)** to **warmly massage (熟摩)** my **face (面)** and **four limbs (四体)**. Next, I **massage (摩)** the **soles of my feet (足心)**, **flexing and folding (屈折)** them, so that the **Wellspring Spring (涌泉)** **acupuncture point (穴)** **ascends (上彻)** to the **Crown (顶门)**. Then I **gradually massage (徐摩)** below the **navel (脐)**, the **waist (腰)**, and the **spine (脊)**.

It is **good (可)** if **sweat (汗)** **emerges (出)**, but **panting (喘)** is **not allowed (不可)**. Next, I **use both hands (左右手)** to **press and warm (熨)** my **eyes (目)**, **face (面)**, **ears (耳)**, and **crown (顶)**, all **extremely hot (极热)**. Then I **press and knead (按捏)** the **left and right sides of my nasal bridge (鼻梁左右)**, either **five (五)** or **seven (七)** times, and **comb (栉)** my **hair (发)** **up to a hundred (至於百)** strokes. I **loosen my hair (散发)** and **sleep (寝)** until **morning (旦)**. With **prolonged practice (久)**, there will be **benefits (功)**. After **twenty days (二十日)**, the **effects (效)** will **appear (见)**.

Only **practicing breath-closure (闭息)** **steadily (持久)** is **difficult (难)**. I **use pulse-watching (脉候)** to **mark five arrivals (五至)**—one **breath (息)**. I can **close my breath (闭其息)**, up to **a hundred and twenty (百有二十)** times. When I **open (开)** it, it **reaches (盖)** **two thousand (二士干)** breaths.

Yet, one **must not forcefully close (强闭)** the **breath (息)** to **disturb (乱)** the **qi (气)**, or let it **burst forth (奔突)**—this is **harmful (害)**. In the **evening (暮)**, one **must not overeat (多食)**, lest the **abdomen (腹)** be **too full (宽)** and **hollow (虚)**, allowing the **qi (气)** to **circulate freely (回转)**.

During the **day (昼)**, I **also frequently shut my eyes (数瞑目)** to **internally contemplate (内观)**, **rinse and refine (漱炼)** the **saliva (津液)**, and **swallow (咽)** it. I **press and warm (熨摩)** my **ears (耳)** and **face (面)**, to **aid (助)** the **True Qi (真气)** in **clearing and quieting (清静)**—thus the **practice (功)** will **easily succeed (易成)**.

However, there are **three harms (三害)** to the **Dao (道)** in the world: **anger and agitation (忿躁)**, **cunning and deceit (阴险)**, and **greed and desire (#1贪欲)**. Those **pursuing the Dao (学道者)** must **guard against (戒)** them.
