**Master Sū Zǐxán (苏子瞻)** of **Chóuchí Pond (仇池)** said: **"When hungry, eat; when not yet full, stop (已饥而食，未饱而止)**. **Take leisurely walks (散步逍遥)**, keeping my **abdomen (腹)** **hollow (虚)**. When it is **hollow (虚)**, I **enter into meditation (入於定)**, with **no limit to day or night (无昼夜之限)**. Whether **lying down (寝)** or **sitting (坐)**, I can **do this (为之)**.

Only in **restraining (摄)** my **body (身)**, like a **wooden puppet (木偶)**, does it **stand still (兀然)**. I **focus on the white tip of my nose (视鼻端之白)**, **counting (数)** the **breath’s entry and exit (息之出入)**—**softly and continuously (绵绵若存)**. I **use this method (用之)** **sparingly (不勤)**, up to **hundreds of times (至於数百)**. Then my **heart (心)** becomes **tranquil (寂然)**, my **body (身)** **still (兀然)**, **unified with the Great Emptiness (太虚)**. Thus, I **do not move (不动)** even without **restraint (禁制)**.

The **count of breaths (息之数)** may **reach a point where they cannot be counted (至於不能计)**. I then **exhale and inhale (出入)** with my **breath (息)**, **following (随)** it **without end (不已)**. Then the **breath (息)** **naturally ceases (自住)**, neither **exhaling (出)** nor **inhaling (入)**.

Thus, my **breath (息)** may **emerge (从)** from **the pores of my body (毛窍之中)**—**eighty-four thousand (八万四千)** times, like **steam and mist (云蒸雾散)**, and all **ailments (诸疾)** will **be removed (除)**.

Therefore, those **nurturing life (养生者)** must **take prenatal breathing (胎息)** as their **foundation (本)**. Yet, it is **arduous (艰)** indeed! If one **does not close (闭)** the **qi (气)**, but **lets it enter and exit (任其出入)**, it will be **faint and scattered (眇绵)**, and **near boiling (况沸)**—there is **no remarkable effect (近无卓然之功)**. Or one may **hope (望)** for it to **naturally cease (兀然自止)**, but this **will not happen (盖未之有)**.

If one **closes (闭)** and **retains (留)** the **breath (息)**, but it **does not exceed (不过)** **thirty (三十)** or **fifty (五十)**, it will **burst forth (奔突)**. Even if **a slight warmth (微肠)** **emerges (生)** in the **Lower Elixir Field (下丹田)**, it is **like a field irrigated by a boiling pot (稼於汤世)**—it **will wither after one watering (终一溉而后枯)**, not the **method of transcending the world (度世之道)**.

I once **heard (闻)** from **Sūn Sīmiǎo (孙思邈)** that: **"To harmonize the spirit and qi (和神气)**, one must **enter a secluded chamber (密室)**, **shutting the door (肩户)**. The **bed (榻)** must be **settled (安)** and the **mattress (茵)** **thick (厚)**. The **pillow (枕)** should be **two and five-tenths inches high (高二寸有五分)**. Then, **straightening my body (正身)** and **lying down (偃外)**, I **plunge my heart into stillness (冥心)**, **closing the qi (闭气)** between my **chest and diaphragm (胸膈之问)**. I **place a goose feather (鸿毛)** at the **tip of my nose (鼻之端)** and **keep it still (不动)**. After **three hundred breaths (三百息)**, my **eyes (目)** see **nothing (无见)**, my **heart (心)** thinks **nothing (无思)**.

Thus, **cold and heat (寒暑)** cannot **invade (侵)**, and **wasps and bees (蜂趸)** cannot **poison (毒)** me. My **lifespan (寿)** will be **three hundred and sixty years (三百有六十岁)**, **approaching that of a True Person (真人)**.

I **pondered (默而深思)** his **intent (旨)** and said: **"Closing the qi (闭气)** between the **chest and diaphragm (胸膈)**, so that the **breath’s entry and exit (息之出入)** **move yet remain still (动而不动)**, **steaming and wispy (氤氲缥缈)**, like **smoke from a black furnace (若黑炉之烟)** or **vapor from a boiling cauldron (烹鼎之气)**—**breathing naturally (出入自如)**, without **forced inhalation or exhalation (无呼吸之者)**—this is why the **goose feather (鸿毛)** can **remain unmoving (不动)**.

Thus, my **heart (心)** does not **arise in thought (起於念)**, even if **three hundred breaths (过乎三百息)** have **passed (息)**—this is **also acceptable (斯亦可)**. I once **lay down (卧)** and **practiced (为之)** as he **said (方)**. I **focused my intent (以意守)** on the **qi (气)** within my **chest and diaphragm (胸膈之中)**.

When I **wished to inhale (欲吸)**, I **slightly inhaled (微吸)**. When I **wished to exhale (欲呼)**, I **could not exhale (不得呼)**—instead, I **let the qi (气)** **steam and wisp (氤氲缥缈)**, **faintly emerge (微微自出)** on its own. When it **exhausts itself (出尽)**, the **qi (气)** **becomes even (平)**, and I **slightly inhale (微吸)** again.»

Thus, its **outflow and inflow** are **unbroken**, yet the **goose feather** can **remain unmoving**—if it moves, it moves **slightly**. I **awaited** its movement, then **redoubled my intent** to **restrain it**, compelling it to **stand still** before ceasing.

Though I **restrained** it, I did not **seal** it. When the **breaths** reached **hundreds**, the **outflow grew scant**, the **non-outflow abundant**, and **internal cultivation flourished**. The **blood vessels** flowed **throughout**, **pouring between upper and lower**—thus, the **principles of nurturing life** were **realized**.

Commodore Yu said: *"In ancient times, Zeng Zi Chan spoke: ‘Fire is fierce, and men fear it; water drowns, yet men trifle with it.’"* Wing Delivered this, saying the **northern temperament** favors **Acquisition Wolf** (贪狼), while the **southern temperament** abhors **Modesty and Rectitude** (廉正). **Modesty and Rectitude** belong to the **Noble**; **Acquisition Wolf** to the **Petty**. From this, I **gained insight**.

Fire is the **heart**; water is the **kidneys**. **Fierce**, it **begets rectitude**; **weak**, it **begets depravity**. Thus, even the **wise kidneys** cannot avoid **depravity** if the **heart is rectified** while the **kidneys are depraved**. Yet if **not excessive**, the **kidneys obey the heart’s command**. Even the **lowest heart** may be **rectified**, but if **constantly depraved**, the **heart cannot govern**. Knowing this **penetrates the principles of Lead and Mercury, Dragon and Tiger**.

**Lead** refers to **qi**. It **rushes or stumbles**, **inhales or exhales**, **grasps or strikes**—all **movement** is **Lead**. The **lungs govern inhalation and exhalation**, so the **lungs are Metal, the White Tiger**.

**Mercury** refers to **water**. **Saliva, tears, pus, blood, semen, sweat, and urine**—all **moisture** is **Mercury**. The **liver governs storage**, so the **liver is the Azure Dragon**. The **ancient True Persons** who spoke of **internal elixir** all called it the **"Five Phases Reversal Art"**—the **Dragon emerges from fire**, the **Five Phases move counter**, the **Tiger arises from water**—yet none in the world **know this**.

When the **Five Phases proceed in order**, the **Dragon emerges from water**, the **Tiger from fire**—this is the **path of death**. If the **heart does not govern**, **external allurements** of **sound and color** **seduce**, while **internal depravity** **erupts**. The **essence of Ren and Gui** flows downward, becoming **human**—sometimes **rotten and decayed**—this is the **Mercury Dragon emerging from water**.

**Joy, anger, sorrow, and delight** all arise from the **heart**. **Joy** seizes and **drags**; **anger** beats and **strikes**; **grief** causes **leaping**; **delight** prompts **dancing**. **Internal movement** **responds externally**—this is the **Lead Tiger emerging from fire**. Both **emerge and cannot return**, hence it is called the **path of death**.

The **True Person** thus **teaches reversal**. What **path** is this? Confucius said: *"Think without **depravity**."* Without **thought**, one is **wood and stone**; yet there must be **thought without thought**. **Thought without thought** is **upright, solemn, and restrained**, not **licentious**—this is **discipline**. **Discipline begets calm**; **calm begets stillness** of **inhalation and exhalation**; **stillness of inhalation and exhalation** **extinguishes the heart’s fire** from **flaring upward**.

Fire in the *Yijing* is **Li**—**adherence**. It **must adhere**; it **never stands alone**. Water is its **consort**. If the **fire does not flare upward**, it **follows its consort**. When **water and fire unite**, the **essence of Ren and Gui** flows upward, entering the **brain**, overflowing at the **Mingmen**. If the **nasal fluid is not salty**, it is not **kidney essence**. This is the **Mercury Dragon emerging from fire**. The **elixir of longevity**, the **seed of internal elixir**, **cannot surpass this**.

At the **beginning of yin and yang**, **Heaven-One is water**, so **human formation begins as water**. The **Five Phases**—**one day water**, warmed by **qi** before **life**; thus **two days fire**, with **qi** before **bones**; thus **three days wood**, bones **hardening** before **rigid strength**; thus **four days metal**, bones **firming** before **flesh**; thus **five days earth**, flesh **forming**. While in the **mother’s womb**, the **mother inhales, and the child inhales**; the **mother exhales, and the child exhales**. The **mouth and nose close**, yet **communication is through the navel**—thus the **navel is the root of life**.

The **Mercury Dragon**, emerging from **fire**, flowing to the **brain**, overflowing at the **Mingmen**, **must return to the root**. The **heart’s fire**, not flaring upward but **following its consort**, is **fire ever at the root**. Thus the **essence of Ren and Gui**, **strengthened by fire**, **reaches the limbs**, overflows the **skin**, and **daily grows robust**, ultimately becoming **the body of steel**—this is the **Lead Tiger emerging from water**.

When **Dragon and Tiger are born**, the **internal elixir is complete**—**longevity and immortality** are achieved, yet **the Dao remains unattained**.

Hongmengzi Gao Xiang once **arrived at the Guanghan Palace**, where the **Jade Sovereign** commanded him to **see the Western Hua Lady**. The **Lady** imparted the **essentials of the Way**:

*"The **True One** lies within the **knocking at the Wu-Ji Gate**—within are **golden seeds**, the **root of yellow sprouts**, the **mother of all things**. The **mother**, meeting her **father**, becomes the **cauldron**. Thus, **sun and moon, soul and spirit** **interact**, one **ascending, one descending**, their **pearls flying** until they **reach Kunlun’s peak**, where they **must seek the Wandering Symbols**. Once obtained, **return to the Vermilion Palace** to **store them**. The **skin turns red**; the **hair turns black**—in **ninety days**, the **elixir is complete**."

In ancient times, **Wei Boyang** composed the *Cansong Contract*—**"the king of all alchemical scriptures for ten thousand ages."** Its opening lines: *"Heaven and Earth"* are the **gateway of the *Yijing***. **Heaven’s Way is male**; **Earth’s Way is female**—yet the world **does not know True Yin-Yang**, blindly **seeking Dragon and Tiger**.

The **sun is Li**; the **moon is Kan**. The **sun and moon**, **yin and yang**, **devour each other**. The **Golden Crow dies**; the **Jade Rabbit is born**—thus all **things are born** from the **circulation of Heaven and Earth**.

「The Dao of Heaven and Earth **resonates** in harmony, and male and female **unite**. The Four Symbols and Five Phases **converge** and **gather** here.

Day and night **are the *Zhun* and *Meng***—they **emanate** from Nature itself, not from **toiling** to observe the **auspices of fire**.

Some say: *"Below the navel* is the **domain of the Supreme One (太一)**. First, **envision the divine furnace within** it, then **preserve the true fire** blazing there. At the hour of *Zi*, **gather the vitality of the sun and moon** and cast them into the **crucible**, with **my own fluids** rinsing down into the **elixir field (丹田)**—this is the **divine water**. In ten months, **the embryo is cast off**, and a **baby is born**.

**Master Zhengyi (正一先生) Sima Ziming (司马子微)**’s *"Song of Forgetting Sitting"* says:
**Always remain silent** to **preserve the primordial *qi*** without harm,
**Minimize thought** so **wisdom illuminates the inner light**,
**Do not rage**—then **all spirits are serene and at ease**,
**Do not be reckless**—then **the mind is pure and clear**,
**Do not seek**—then **there is no flattery or deception**,
**Do not cling**—then **all is both round and square**,
**Do not covet**—then **true wealth and honor abound**,
**Do not act hastily**—then **what fear of princes and kings?**
**Taste ceases**, and **the spirit of the divine spring descends**,
**Resolve is steadfast**, and **true breath naturally lengthens**.
**Qi leaks**, and **the form returns to thick Earth**,
**Thoughts dissipate**, and **the spirit drifts to the realm of ghosts**.
**The heart dies**—then **the spirit may truly live**,
**The *pò* (魄) is extinguished**—then **the *hún* (魂) flourishes**.
**The utmost essence penetrates the form**, **vague and elusive**,
**The Great Dao aligns with the **mixed and boundless**,
**Transforming things is difficult**—yet **mystical applications endure**,
**Responding to changes does not stray** from **True Constant (真常)**.
**Creation and transformation**, if they **know the measure and compass**,
**Ghosts and gods cannot fathom** their **actions and concealments**.
**Moderate drinking, eating, and sleep**—this is the **True Person’s Forgetting Sitting**.

**Master Gao Xiangxian (高子名象先)** says: *"Close your eyes, curl your feet*, and with the **left hand embrace below the navel**, the **right hand rest upon the kidneys’ sides**. Then **envision the elixir field**, making it **blaze like fire**—this is the **Jade Maiden Embracing the Navel**.

**The Wandering Recluse (游子)** says: *"Embracing the Primordial and Preserving the One* is the **supreme essential** for nurturing life. Its names are nine:
1. **One-character *qi***,
2. **The Yellow River in Reverse Flow**,
3. **Flying Golden Crystal from the Elbow’s Back**,
4. **The River Chariot’s Rotation**,
5. **Returning to the Root and Restoring the Primordial**,
6. **Recycling the Light and Mixing the Essence**,
7. **The Five *Qi* Converging at the Primordial**,
8. **One Strike at Three Passes**,
9. **Three Fields in Reciprocal Motion**.

**The Wandering Recluse** further says: *"I possess the **orthodox method of prolonging life**, yet the world does not know it. **Above, I draw it into the *qi***; **below, I do not let it escape into the essence**. Thus, **I circulate it** with the **flow of the Jade Pool**, and **over time, it becomes the elixir**. This is my **life and vitality**—no other secret. **It is spirit, breath, and *qi***—a single substance with three forms. **The heart abides in the subtle**; the **mind in the profound**. The **navel’s *qi* surges** with its **movement**, nurturing the **elixir field**.

**The Embryonic Breath (谷神)** does not die*—this is **baby-breathing (胎息)**.

**Master Chongxu (冲虚子)** says: *"Only when the heart dies* can one **embrace the One**, **contain the *qi**, refine the essence**, and **assist the spirit**, preserving the **form**. Thus, **killing the Yin** generates the **Yang**—then the **spirit is born**, and the **Dao is complete**."

**Master Gao Xiangxian** says: *"At the peak of Kunlun (昆仑) lies the **Mysterious Pearl (玄珠)**. Only those who **seek the Wandering Symbols** can find it. **Return to the Vermilion Palace** to **store it**, and then **the skin becomes lustrous red**, the **hair twice as black**, while the **Northern Pole erases the register of death**."

**Du Ge (杜革)** says: *"There are **methods for refining gold elixir** and **secrets for reversing the flow to replenish the brain**. I have practiced **sitting upright in meditation**, awaiting **the *qi* to settle**. Then, **I spit out my turbid breath** thirty-five times, **seal the earthly orifices**, and **prevent any leakage**. Afterward, **I inhale the pure breath**, retaining it for **nine counts**, exhaling for **six**. This **timing** is **repeated**—then **it is perfect**.

When **the fluids are generated**, the **Red Dragon plows at the sides**—this occurs at **sixteen counts**. By the time **the mouth is full** and **I hollow my throat** to **stretch the *qi*** nine times, **I send the *qi* to the elixir field**. Then, **I slowly draw it out**. With **patience, results will come**.

I have also **sat upright in meditation**, awaiting **the *qi* to settle**, and **beaten the heavens** thirty-six times, **twisting the spine like a donkey’s** fourteen times. Then, **I kneel and bow my head to the earth**, using my **hands to rub the kidney chambers** thirty, fifty, or up to **a hundred times**—**gradually increasing**. **I exhale through the nose**, and **thus the sides rub each other**. When **it grows hot**, I **warm the external kidneys**. If the **count reaches a hundred**, and **the nasal *qi* is full**, I **slowly release it**.

**This practice occurs** in the **early hours of *Yin* after *Zi***—this is the **secret of reversing the flow to preserve the essence**.

**Emperor Huizong (徽宗)**, during the **early years of the Xuanhe reign (宣和初)**, when he was **Grand Minister of the Treasury (太府卿)**, once **asked Li Fu (李傅)** about **internal elixir methods**. Li Fu replied: *"The essence of internal elixir lies in **preserving the heart** and **nurturing the *qi***. **Repelling evil influences** is how **one preserves the heart**; **inner observation** is how **one nurtures the *qi***. **Preserve the heart and nurture the *qi***, then **the true fire will daily blaze**, and **the divine water of the Jade Pool will daily flourish**, allowing **one to flow above and below with Heaven and Earth**.

**The Dao of Heaven** is **circulation without accumulation**. The **sage follows this pattern**, and **simplicity reveals the harmony of Heaven and Earth**—thus **the principle is attained**.

**What sustains humanity’s life** is **the *qi***. When **the *qi* settles**, the **spirit settles**; when **the spirit settles**, the **form settles**. If **one can truly grasp this**, then **long life and enduring vision** begin **from here**!

Observe **the ebb and flow of cold and heat**, the **rotation of sun and moon**—this is how **Heaven and Earth endure**. **Blow and exhale**, **call and inhale**, **expel the old and take in the new**—this is how **the True Person endures in the world**.

**Master Dan Yuanzi (丹元子)** says: *"The form abides when the spirit settles; the spirit abides when the *qi* gathers. **The *qi* is the body’s fullness**; **the form is the spirit’s dwelling**. Thus, **when the *qi* is solid**, it **flourishes**; when **it is void**, it **wanes**; **when it settles**, it **generates life**; when **it is dissipated**, it **perishes**. **The *qi*** is what **Master Guangcheng (广成子)** **preserves** and what **Master Yanluo (烟萝子)** **refines**. Therefore, **in one word, it is all-encompassing**: the **mystery of preservation and refinement** lies in **this inhalation and exhalation alone.**"」

「Thus, the saying goes: **One gulp, two gulps**—the **mystic vapors** rise like clouds and rain reaches down—**three gulps, five gulps**, the **inner landscape** is filled and nourished. **Ten gulps, nine gulps**, the **heart’s fire descends**, the **kidney’s water ascends**; when **water and fire are harmonized**, then **the inner elixir is complete**. It can **ward off illness**, **preserve life**, **extend years**, and **transcend mortality**. Here lies the **key principle** of **advancing fire and guiding water**—the **pivotal method** of this Dao.

**At the hour of Zǐ (子) and before Wǔ (午)**, this is the **time for advancing fire**. **At the beginning of the fifth night**, when **yang vitality is at its peak**, it is **especially suitable for advancing fire**. **Sitting on the bed**, either **facing south** or **facing north**, **clasping the perineum** and **curling the feet**, **closing the eyes** and **straightening the spine** while seated, **calm the heart** and **quiet the thoughts**, then **internally observe the five viscera**. **Lifting the head** and **closing the mouth**, **draw in the pure *qi* through the nose** until it reaches its utmost limit—then **straighten the spine** and **swallow it**. **One swallow** is followed by **contracting the throat passage**; **one contraction**, then **another inhalation**; **two contractions**, then **another swallow and contraction**. If the *qi* reaches its peak and **cannot be stopped**, then **lower the head** and **open the mouth** to **exhale it**, ensuring no sound escapes the ears. This process, repeated **three times**, constitutes **one session**.

After the *qi* has **settled**, proceed to **guide water**. **Collect the nasal mucus** and **saliva from the mouth**, combining them into one; the more, the better. When **the rinsing reaches a hundred times**, the **saliva becomes warm and sweet**, then **lift the head** and **expand the chest**, gazing **leftward, rightward, and straight ahead**, performing **one swallow each**—**three swallows total**—and **imagine the *qi* descending to the elixir field**. **In all swallowing**, also **contract the throat passage**. This process, once, is **one session**. **The work of water and fire is thus completed**.

This Dao **outstrips Heaven and Earth’s natural transformations**; when first practiced, **the region below the navel feels as if burned by fire**, and **appetite increases**, **the limbs grow strong**. **With prolonged practice**, **white hair turns black**, **fallen teeth regrow**, and **spirit is fully restored**. **Returning to the state of an infant**, **cold and heat cannot harm**, **and spirits and demons cannot intrude**.

**Master Wèizōng (微宗)** said: *"Good."*

**The monk from Guìjī (会稽), a thousand-year-old sage**, said: *"I possess the **Seven Qi Methods**:*
**First, the *Qi* of *Kòu* (叩).** *Kòu* means **striking the teeth seven times**, to **gather the spirit**; within the mind, **visualize**—for each strike of the teeth, **contemplate one star**. The stars are **Kuí (魁)**, **Kuí (魁)**, **Wú (魑)**, **Mèi (魅)**, **Wú (魑)**, **Lián (魉)**, and **Yuán (鳄)**.

**Second, the *Qi* of *Tuō* (托).** *Tuō* means **lifting each hand**, as though **supporting a hundred pounds**, alternating **up and down eighteen times** per hand.

**Third, the *Qi* of *Zhāng* (张).** *Zhāng* means **first drawing the left hand**, as though **pulling a bowstring**; after pulling the bowstring, **then use the feet to draw a crossbow**; the right hand and feet follow the same, each **eighteen times**.

**Fourth, the *Qi* of *Mó* (摩).** *Mó* means **rubbing the left and right hands**, then **warming them** to **rub the ears**, called **awakening water**; next, **rub the eyes**, **thirty-six times each**, called **awakening fire**; then **rub the face** and **proceed to the torso**.

**Fifth, the *Qi* of *Yáo* (摇).** *Yáo* means **placing the left and right hands on the waist**, **crossing the feet** while seated, **shaking the left shoulder and scapula**, then **the right**, each **eighteen times**.

**Sixth, the *Qi* of *Kāi* (揩).** *Kāi* means **rubbing the left and right hands together**, then **warming them** to **rub the kidney chambers**, generating heat.

**Seventh, the *Qi* of *Shù* (漱).** *Shù* means **rinsing until saliva fills the mouth**, then **swallowing three times**; afterward, **rub the hands together**, **warming them** to **massage the elixir field** without limit.

**Xiàngshān Zǐ (象山子)** said: *"Those who **refine the primordial *qi*** can **unblock the nine orifices and hundred joints**, allowing it to **circulate freely**. **With prolonged practice**, **results will manifest**. **All who wish to refine *qi*** must first **calm the heart**, then **guide and draw** left and right **smoothly**, ensuring **all joints harmonize**. Then **clasp the perineum**, **close the mouth** and **inflating the cheeks**, **open the teeth** and **strain the abdomen**, swallowing **straight and unobstructed**. **Nine swallows** make **one cycle**; **four cycles of nine—thirty-six swallows**—comprise the **middle cycle**; **achieving three hundred sixty swallows** is the **great cycle**.

**Those who refine *qi* do not rely on fixed times**; only **the nasal *qi*** is allowed to **enter and exit freely**, while **the mouth swallows it**. If the body feels **cool**, then **warm *qi* must be drawn**; if the body feels **hot**, then **cool *qi* must be drawn**. **This primordial *qi*:** **swallowing three to fifty times daily**, up to **a hundred**, can **assist yang vitality** in **digesting food**, **preserving youthful complexion**, **nurturing hair and beard**, and **strengthening the body**.

If **the head feels dizzy and hot**, then **clasp the palms over the mouth** and **forcefully exhale**, **fifty times**—this will **cure the ailment**; if not yet cured, **repeat the process**.

**Those who refine this *qi* should take **Rehmannia wine** to **guide the inhalation**; when ready to practice, **wait until food is digested**, then **swallow the *qi***.

**Zhōu Zǐ (游子)** said: *"I have heard that **ancient perfected beings** possessed **methods to refine the body and transcend the world**. Their essence is as follows: **At the hour of Zǐ (子)**, when **one yang begins to emerge**, **loosen the clothes** and **clasp the perineum**, **strike the teeth thirty-six times**, **retract the eyes** and **reverse the ears**, **internally recall the location of the five viscera**, **lower the tongue** and **relax the throat**, **twisting it three times**. **Following the sun’s movement**, **twist three times**; **relaxing the throat**, **twist three times**—**naturally, the saliva arises in the **Crown Pool** (華池, *Huápóu*), **rinsing until the mouth is full**, then **swallowing three times**, passing through the **Crown Canopy** (華蓋, *Huágài*), and **connecting with the heart**, **liver**, and **spleen-stomach**. Doing this **three times**, then **visualize two channels of white *qi* between the stomach**, **further observing the two kidneys**; from between the kidneys, **two channels of white *qi* emerge at the **paravertebral region** (夹脊, *Jiājí*), **twisting like a carp**, ascending into the **Brain Marrow** (泥丸, *Níwán*). **From the face’s gate** to the **throat’s opening**, the **divine water overflows in the mouth**. This process, **three times**, is **one swallow**.

**From the middle elixir field**, **envelop with the heart**; **send it to the lower elixir field** and **halt**. This process, **three times**, is **one cycle**. **Igniting the fire** to **burn the divine water** stored in the **lower elixir field**, doing this **nine times**, is **one passage**. **Counting the saliva**, **nine passages** equal **eighty-one times**. **From Zǐ (子) to Wǔ (午)**, **this practice can be performed**; **with prolonged effort**, **its efficacy will become evident.**"*」

Thus arises the **Yellow River’s reverse flow**—why? Beneath the nape and beside the throat lie **two meridians**, the **Path of Longevity**. Pressing them with the hands yields **two hundred pulses**; beneath the wrists, **two more meridians** exist—**the Four Symbols’ encircling orbit**. First the left, then the right; pressing each yields **fifty pulses**.

Within the **Two Thresholds** stands the **Central Peak**—here lie **two meridians**, the **Golden Pass and Jade Lock**, the **Two Ravines**. Pressing them yields **eight hundred pulses**. At the edges of the **Two Flanks**, the **Tendons of the Leaping Blade** hold **two meridians**—the **Path of the Supreme One**. Pressing each yields **two hundred pulses**. Practice this daily, and its efficacy shall manifest.

After the **Winter Solstice**, prioritize the **heavy**; after the **Summer Solstice**, prioritize the **light**.

**Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"I have heard of the **soaring union of Sun and Moon**, the **true transformation of the Five Phases**.*

**Earth begets Metal**, Metal begets Water, Water begets Wood, Wood begets Fire, Fire begets Earth.
The **begetter is the Mother**; the **begetten is the Child**.

**Earth subdues Water**, Water subdues Fire, Fire subdues Metal, Metal subdues Wood, Wood subdues Earth.
The **subduer is the Husband**; the **subdued is the Wife**.

The **kidneys are Water**, dwelling below; the **heart is Fire**, dwelling above; the **liver is Wood**, dwelling to the left; the **lungs are Metal**, dwelling to the right; the **spleen is Earth**, dwelling centrally.

Thus, the **logic of begetting and subduing** rests within humanity, as **qi transmits**—beginning with the **kidneys**. The **kidney’s qi** transmits to the liver (**Water begets Wood**); when the **kidney’s qi is full**, the **liver’s qi arises**, transmitting to the heart (**Wood begets Fire**); when the **liver’s qi is full**, the **heart’s qi arises**, transmitting to the spleen (**Fire begets Earth**); when the **heart’s qi is full**, the **spleen’s qi arises**, transmitting to the lungs (**Earth begets Metal**); when the **spleen’s qi is full**, the **lung’s qi arises**, transmitting to the kidneys (**Metal begets Water**); when the **lung’s qi is full**, the **kidney’s qi arises**—**cycling endlessly**, as **qi and fluids transmit**, with the **heart as origin**.

The **heart’s fluid** transmits to the lungs (**Fire subdues Metal**); when the **heart’s fluid arrives**, the **lung’s fluid flows**, transmitting to the liver (**Metal subdues Wood**); when the **lung’s fluid arrives**, the **liver’s fluid flows**, transmitting to the spleen (**Wood subdues Earth**); when the **liver’s fluid arrives**, the **spleen’s fluid flows**, transmitting to the kidneys (**Earth subdues Water**); when the **spleen’s fluid arrives**, the **kidney’s fluid flows**, transmitting to the heart (**Water subdues Fire**); when the **kidney’s fluid arrives**, the **heart’s fluid flows**—**cycling endlessly**.

If the **heart’s fluid lacks the kidney’s qi**, it **stagnates**; if the **kidney’s qi does not align with the heart’s fluid**, it **fails to generate**. **Fluids circulate between Husband and Wife**; **qi transmits between Mother and Child**. **Wood lodges in Metal’s domain**; **Metal conceals Wood’s essence**—**inverted and reversed**, in **subduing and begetting**.

In my **central qi cultivation**, I sought the **true water**; within the water, the **true qi**. The **true fluid** internally unites with the **true qi** for **forging**. **Nurture the yin to solidify the yang**; **nurture the yang to dissolve the yin**. To **preserve form and dwell in the world**, one may **refine essence into substance**; to **shed substance and ascend as an immortal**, one may **refine qi into spirit**.

This **Dao** is governed by the **Moon’s waxing and waning**, discerns **yin and yang by the Sun**, and **judges ebb and flow by the hour**. Within its timing, **numbers are applied**; within its realm, **forms are revealed**. Without **directly serving the numinous**, yet **distinguishing the Five Phases’ logic**, one may **enter the realm of Xi Yí** and **achieve great efficacy.**

**Zhì Yóuzǐ** once sang of the **Golden Elixir**:

*"Take the essence of things,
Nurture their brilliance;
Gather in my **elixir field**—
There my elixir dwells.

What is my elixir?
**Lead, mercury, cinnabar**—
Guest and host in harmony,
Like a nest cradling crows.

Sow with **Steel and Water**,
Plow with the **Red Serpent**,
Nurture with **Fire and Wood**,
Irrigate with the **River Chariot**—
Thus root, thus pearl,
Thus bud, thus bloom.
By day, forge in fire—
Glowing, vermilion clouds;
By night, bathe in water—
Pale, pristine blossoms.
The **Golden Elixir** forms—
Daily, think without deceit."*

**Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"How does one summon the **Water of the Flowering Pool**? I have heard that **rolling the tongue to lick the **Palate Suspension***, practiced for a full day, causes the **tendons beneath the tongue to tighten and ache**. I gradually trained myself until the **tip of the tongue reached the Palate Suspension**—thus summoning the **Water of the Flowering Pool**; nothing is swifter than this."*

**Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"How does the **soaring of Sun and Moon** occur? Sit upright, **concentrating spirit and stabilizing qi**. With the **left hand clasping beneath the navel**, the **right hand gripping the upper thigh**, imagine **great smoke and flame**, burning the **heart first**, then the **liver, the lungs**. Then, **release a slight breath through the nose** to clear the passage.

After a moment, again imagine the **fire descending to burn the elixir field**. When it grows **intensely hot**, by day visualize the **Sun’s light**; by night, the **Moon’s light**—or visualize nothing at all. When burning the **heart**, do so briefly; when burning the **elixir field**, prolong it.

Next, stand on **bent knees**, with **both hands clasping them**, letting the **heat circulate through the body**. When the heat is extreme, cease. This practice knows no fixed time.

When I am **full from eating**, I **circulate fire**—thus **digestion occurs instantly**. Why? **Hang the arms, tuck the feet**, **shake the abdomen**, **gather the qi**, and **recline**. When the **qi is full**, **roll onto the back**—thus the **fire ascends."*

**Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"I wish to **ascend the Three Palaces**—what is the method?"*

The **Master** gathers his feet, using the middle finger of his left hand to press upon the **Lower Palace**—the **Lower Palace** being that which lies above the navel. With the right hand forming the **True Martial Seal** to pinch the breath at the nostrils, he lets the **qi** fill fully before releasing it slightly. Thus, three times.

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"Stretch out both feet, hang both arms, and when the **qi** is full, recline backward with the body raised. Thus, five times—this is the **Five Qi’s Return to the Primordial**."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"Rub my hands until they grow hot, then with the left hand clasping below the navel, use the right hand to assist. Thus, sitting cross-legged, close the eyes and visualize the **heart’s essence** descending to the **kidneys**, the **kidney’s qi** ascending to the **heart**, circulating endlessly above and below. When practiced for long, the region below the navel burns like fire—this is the **foundation of the Elixir Field**."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"Cross the feet, alternating left and right hands, clasping the lower abdomen. Then, through the nose, inhale the **Western White Qi** seven times; next, inhale the **Southern Red Qi** three times; then, inhale the **Eastern Green Qi** nine times; then, inhale the **Northern Black Qi** five times. Finally, facing south and tilting the head back, inhale the **Central Yellow Qi** once. This is the **True Transformation of the Five Phases**."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"With the middle finger of the left hand pressing the center of the navel—the **Navel Heart**—use the right hand to cup the **external kidneys**, pressing with the middle finger at the **tailbone**. Then visualize the **Sun and Moon descending together into the Elixir Field**, waiting until the **qi** is full before releasing it slightly. Thus, three times—this is the **Stirring of Fire**. This is the **Sun and Moon’s Flight in Union**."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"Raise the palms upward to regulate the **Three Burners**. The **liver** on the left, the **lungs** on the right—like shooting a hawk. **Standing alone in the West**, this stabilizes the **spleen and stomach**; **turning back to gaze**, this harmonizes **injury and fatigue**; **bowing high and low to Heaven**, this opens the **Five Viscera**; **swallowing saliva to nourish the **qi**, and with left and right hands plucking the **hand tendons**, shaking the **cicada’s tail**, this loosens **heart distress**; with left and right hands grasping the feet, this treats the **lumbar region**."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"Straighten the body and raise outward, quieting the mind and closing the breath. Place the hands above the abdomen and flanks, then leap upward, pulling the toes, rising and falling alternately, exhaling slightly—prioritizing frequency over force."*

Then **Zhì Yóuzǐ** said: *"**Fu** is **seven**, the **young maiden**, the **lungs**. It governs the **intent**—when the **intent moves**, thought arises. Thus, repeatedly descending the **vital breath**, the **nature matures**. If the **minor male** unites, **semen is lost**. **Kūn** is **two**, the **earth**, the **small intestine**. The **Spirit of the Curved River** cannot be measured. If **Earth Mother** ascends from **Kān** and unites with it, the **essence is refined into elixir**.*

**Qián** is **six**, **heaven**, **metal**, the **father**, the **large intestine**. The **kidney’s palace** lies in **Kān**, its **temple** in **Qián**—the **kidney** can unite with **Gèn**. **Bian Que** said: *"The **large intestine** is the **Gate of Vital Breath**—if it refines the **qi**, the **Central Earth** responds naturally. **Central Earth** refers to the **spleen and stomach**. This is the **Yellow Dao’s method of refining qi**.*

**Lí** is **nine**, the **heart’s fire**, the **young maiden**, governing the **spirit**. When the **spirit is settled**, it transcends **emptiness**; when **disturbed**, it loses count and wanders. Thus, the **nine** depends on recognizing **three, five, one, two, eight** before uniting with **nine and three**. Then all **pulses circulate through the Five Essences**, ascending and merging to transform into **spirit**. Within, the **method’s vessel** can elevate the **spirit**, allowing **piercing qi** to enter the **Purple Treasury** and see the **Dao**."*

**Kān** is **one**, the **kidney’s water**, the **middle male**. **One** is the **number of essence**. **Nine** is its **wandering**; **one** is its **obscurity**. If united, the **numbers are lost**; if pushed to extremes, **essence leaks**, and the **vital breath descends**, becoming a **ghost**. Before reaching the extreme, it can be controlled—this is its **manifestation**.*

**Xùn** is **four**, **wind**, the **gallbladder**, the **eldest daughter**. It governs the **multitude**—fear can subdue its **multitude**.*

**Gèn** is **eight**, **mountain**, the **ghost gate**, the **young male**, the **bladder**. When **qi** reaches here, **death is near**. As a **son’s successor**, its **numbers extend beyond**.*

For those who cultivate and refine, before speaking of the **Dao**, initially, through **artifice**, one arrives at **essence within**. With **essence**, one refines **qi**, governing the **intent** as **essence** reaches the **vital breath**. Its **desires** follow the **soul**—to the **heart**, to the **liver**, to the **spleen**, to the **lungs**, to the **kidneys**. The **Five Essences descend**; at their peak, they **transform into ghosts**!

**Zhèn** is **three**, **thunder**, its **body wood**, the **liver**, the **eldest son**. It can **settle the nature** and **elevate the qi**! Its essence lies in this: when the **metallic wind** rises from the **yang** of **Kān**, the **spirit flourishes**. Practiced through the **twelve double-hours without ceasing**, one attains **immortality**!

Now, my **body and form** are counted thus: the **top** is called the **Crown**; below it is the **Purple Treasury**—the **ears**, **eyebrows**, **eyes**, **nose**, **mouth**; below it is the **Primordial Palace**, the **pathway to the Highest Dao**. Below it is the **throat**; below it is the **Double Tower**; below it is the **Meeting of the Throat and Heart**; below it is the **Pulse**; below it is the **Heart**, the **Mother of Qi**, the **law within the diaphragm**. Below it are the **liver and gallbladder**; below it is the **spleen**; below it is the **stomach**—the **stomach’s strike** is the **small intestine**, the **small intestine’s strike** is the **bladder**, the **bladder** returns to the **kidneys**, which are the **heart’s network**. The **small intestine’s left** is the **large intestine**; below it is the **Lower Technique**—this is called the **Diagram of One Qi**."*

The Master Youzi said: "Excellent! The *Shangqing Zifu* teachings state: 'To swallow the *qi* and light of the sun and moon'—this is the method of refining the **Red Elixir (赤丹)**, the **Essence of Gold (金精)**, the **Luminous Spirit of Stone (石景)**, and the **Mother of Water (水母)**.

Its practice is as follows: When the sun rises, face east and strike your teeth nine times with your tongue, close your eyes tightly, and visualize the five-colored effulgent *qi* of the sun as flowing mist, all entering through your mouth. When the moon rises, face west and strike your teeth twelve times with your tongue, close your eyes tightly, and visualize the five-colored luminous *qi* of the moon as flowing mist, all entering through your mouth. Within the moon’s light is a yellow *qi*, and its pupils are the **Essence of Flying Yellow (飞黄)**, the **Moon’s Radiance (月华)**, and the **Jade Capsule (玉胞)**.

If I can cultivate this, then I shall rush into the sun and moon and become an immortal.

The Master Youzi said: "The *Shangqing Zifu* teachings are subtle indeed, and I shall now expound their coarse aspects.

At dawn, stand in an open place and gaze toward the east, observing the sun’s emergence and its colors, lights, and *qi* forms until you are thoroughly familiar with them after many days. Then, during the **Yin Leak (寅漏)**—after three *ke* (刻) and before four *ke*—sit slightly on a couch, strike your teeth nine times while facing east, and kneel with your legs folded. Hold your hands tightly, opening the **Heavenly Gate (天门)**—the Heavenly Gate refers to the two nasal passages. Close the **Earthly Door (地户)**—the Earthly Door refers to the mouth. Visualize the sun’s initial *qi* rising before your eyes, drawing it in through your nose and letting it enter your mouth. Wait until your mouth is filled with *qi*, then rinse your mouth **forty-nine times** in an empty manner. With utmost effort, swallow it, imagining the *qi* reaching the **Elixir Field (丹田)**. Strike your teeth repeatedly—this is called **Ingesting the Sun’s Essence (服日精) in one cycle**."

For those cultivating the **First Earthly Stage (初地)**, you may advance to three cycles.

The Master Youzi said: "This is the Sun’s Essence. There is also the **Nine Return Method (九还之方)**. Between the **Child Hour (子)** and the **Peril Hour (午)**, face east and rinse your mouth twelve times, mingling the **Dragon (龙)** and **Tiger (虎)**—this is called **Ingesting the Sun’s Essence in one cycle**, known as the **Red Cycle Child (红圆子)**.

From the **Child Hour (子)** to the **Peril Hour (巳)**, these are the so-called **Six Yang Times (六阳之时)**. Face east, and with the **left and right nostrils**, exhale and inhale to draw in the pure *qi*, filling your mouth with it. Then, internally visualize a *qi* that is neither green, nor yellow, nor blue, nor verdant—like the sun’s color and light. For each rinse, rub your palms together once. The left hand represents the **Dragon (龙)**; the right hand represents the **Tiger (虎)**. When the rinsing reaches twelve times, the number of rubs is the same. Swallow on the left side, then on the right—this completes one cycle. One cycle is **Yang (阳)**; two cycles are **Yin (阴)**. For **Yang**, swallow on the left; for **Yin**, swallow on the right.

At first, ingest three cycles daily. After three decades (三旬), advance to five cycles on one day. After five decades (五旬), advance to seven cycles on one day. If desires are not yet eliminated, stop at seven cycles. If the **Tailbone Leak (尾闻)** is not yet sealed, and the *qi* leaks without being contained, it will be difficult to truly fill your abdomen. You must advance to ten cycles after seven decades (七旬), and after twenty decades (二十旬), refine the **Red Water (赤水)**. This is the method for eliminating the **Nine Vermin (九虫)** of accumulated malevolence.

Then, you may ingest the **Moon’s Essence (月精)**.

On the **second day of the month (月之二日)**, after the **Peril Hour (午)** and before the **Child Hour (子)**, these are the so-called **Six Yin Times (六阴之时)**. Face west, and the method is as before. Reduce the Sun’s Essence to five cycles, but do not abandon the Moon’s Essence—this is called the **White Cycle Child (白圆子)**. When the practice reaches sixteen days (旬有六日), and the supplementation reaches twenty decades (二十旬), then you no longer use the Moon’s Essence but rely solely on the Sun’s Essence.

For the five cycles: first ingest four, then use the remaining one to send to the **Elixir Field (丹田)**. Each month, send one cycle daily. In the second, third, fourth, and fifth months, increase one cycle each month until you reach five cycles. Then, constantly gaze at your reflection in a mirror, and ponder the **infant within your abdomen (腹之婴儿)** as resembling your form. In the seventh and eighth months, you will neither eat nor feel hunger. By the tenth month, you will reside in a **Quiet Chamber (静室)**, contemplating the exit through the **Heavenly Gate (天门)**. Close your eyes and do not look—if you do, your heart may tremble.

After three years, you may open your eyes again. But never stray far from your body.

When the second *ji* (紀) arrives, one emerges with clarity.

Then, employing the *bān yùn* method, the *xīn*’s *qi* is directed into the Lower Elixir Field (下丹田), ascending from the tail’s base up the spine, entering the brain—like the sound of wind and rain. The sand falls upon the face, its taste sweet; it must not be discarded. This is what nourishes and flourishes the five *zàng* organs.

The *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: At the *xū-hài* hours (戌亥), close your eyes, still your mind, and sit upright. Let the nasal *qi* subtly settle. Then, cultivate the thought of swallowing saliva. If weary, rest. When the hour of *zǐ* arrives, face south—or east—and sit upright, cutting off all thought. Let the nasal *qi* move once and dwell in the mind. Shortly, let it move again, as before. With one breath of *qi*, swallow and send it to the navel. With both hands lightly embracing the navel wheel, quickly contract the *gǔdào*, then move another breath, driving the previous two breaths of *qi* past the navel before contracting again. Gently press the abdomen, awaiting the fire’s descent below the navel, where it grows hot. The waist and hips gradually rise, ascending until the *qi* passes the tailbone—then waist and hips grow hot. Thus, exhale from the chest and tighten the *bì*, leaning against the two *jiā* (夹) to steady it. Do not let the empty intestines rise first; wait until the fire’s *qi* fully reaches the *jiājǐ* (夹脊), then open the *jiājǐ*’s double gates. Quickly tilt the head back, contract the neck toward heaven—do not let the empty *yáng* rise first. When the fire arrives, quickly nod and shake the neck, directing the fire into the *suǐhǎi* (髓海). Only then draw it past the *Tiānmén* (天门), through twelve tiers of pavilions, to the *Jiānggōng* (绛宫), entering the Elixir Field. This is the method of kindling fire at the *Yángguān* (阳关).

The *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: From *chén-wǔ* until before *wǔ*, sit quietly with closed eyes, setting aside all thought. Let the breath move subtly, then saliva fills the mouth. Do not spit nor swallow—press down to settle the true dragon, preventing its ascent. Gently draw the nasal *qi* to rouse the true tiger, pressing the abdomen to prevent its descent. The abdomen must not be slackened; when the *qi* is full, release it slightly—but do not let it disperse. Then, let the breath move subtly again, filling the mouth with saliva, storing it without exhaustion. Initially, swallow dryly; next, let the heart surge. When it flows freely, divide it into three swallows. Thus, one may perform this once or thrice—this is called the *yuánzhū* (元珠).

The *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: Someone asked, “Is there also a method for seated repose?” He replied: “There is.”

Place your left foot atop the right knee, extending the right foot outward. With both hands, grasp beneath the second crease of the middle fingers, then after a moment, use the left hand to massage the right flank **sixty-four times**. Next, place the right foot atop the left knee, extending the left foot outward, maintaining the same grip, and use the right hand to massage the left flank **sixty-four times** as well.

Then, sit cross-legged and massage above the navel—**thirty-two times** on each side—first massaging the hands, then the kidney chambers, and finally the shoulders (three times each). Strike the cheeks with the *Red Dragon* **fourteen times** each, the upper and lower lips **seven times** each, and the central teeth **seven times**. Twist the tongue and stir it **three times**; when saliva arises, hold it in the mouth and steady the breath for a moment.

Pinch the nostrils with both hands and swallow fire **three times**, ensuring no water descends. Then divide the saliva into two portions, pinch the nostrils, and swallow it with a sound. This is the method of seated repose.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: Sit cross-legged, with the left hand cupping the external kidney and the right hand gripping firmly, subtly circulating the *qi*. Then, visualize fire burning the heart, extending to the lungs and liver. When warmth arises, next visualize the fire descending to the *elixir field*, then to the *tail bone*. Lift the body, waiting for the sensation to pass; then visualize it passing through the *Upper Pass*, bow slightly forward, and let it enter the *mud pellet*, reaching the crown, the brain, descending through the *Celestial Court*, and returning to the heart, lungs, liver, and *elixir field*—repeating this **nine times**. This is the *Nine Circulations of the Returned Elixir*.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: Excessive exhalation is inferior to minimal exhalation, and minimal exhalation is inferior to no exhalation. If one cannot retain even a single inhalation and exhalation, then the *qi* of heaven and earth will be stolen by it. Some call swallowing *qi* "fetal breathing," others count breaths, close them, endure them, or store them—but this is not the ultimate. Truly, when internal *qi* does not escape and external *qi* does not enter, the spirit governs the *qi*, the nostrils do not lose breath, and the two *qi*s ascend and descend endlessly between the *mud pellet* and *elixir field*. Buddhists call this *fetal breathing*; Daoists call it *Taiyi Embracing True Qi*; and scholars call it nurturing the *Hàorán* (浩然) *qi*. Though paths differ, their destination is the same.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: I shall now seize and refine the *Golden Essence*—there is a method. Choose the hour of *Zi* (子, midnight), sit upright facing east, left hand pressing the knee, right hand pressing the thigh. Inhale through the nose and exhale through the mouth **twenty-seven times**, clasp the hands at the waist and nod the head **seven times**, waiting until the *qi* grows warm and then the *mud pellet’s* original *qi* enters. Clasp the hands alternately, binding them tightly **three times**; then extend both feet flat on the mat, grasping the toes with both hands in unison and moving them back and forth **seven times**. Return to the initial seated posture and rest. Hug the right breast with the left arm, extending the right hand, and strike backward as if angry **seven times**; then hug the left breast with the right arm, repeating the motion. My practice lies in *precision of essence* without interruption, thus performing the *Jade Maiden’s Cloud Branch Dance* **twelve times**, pressing left and right as before. Perform *dry swallowing* and *saliva swallowing* once each. When practiced until the **fifty-fifth day**, the *essence-qi* circulates through the four limbs, advancing without ceasing—thus attaining longevity.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: Stand facing south or north, pinch paper to block the nostrils, and when sneezing arises, remove it. Bend the wrists downward, then open them backward like a phoenix spreading its wings, and fold them forward in embrace **three times**. Raise the sleeves with both hands, covering the mouth and nose, and nod the head **three times**; then extend the left arm fully to shake the shoulder **three times**, and repeat with the right. Next, clasp the hands in reverse, fingers pointing outward, bowing the face to the ground, and cup the hands as if cradling a heavy object, lifting them to the mouth **three times**. Then kick the left foot to the buttocks **three times**, and repeat with the right. Clasp the *elixir field* with both hands, straining at the nose to rouse the *qi* and swallow it. Enter the *Lower Elixir Field* **three times**, then pause when the breath harmonizes and cease. Practice without fixed timing, but do so frequently.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: The methods of nurturing life are five:
1. *Prolonging Life by Descending Fire*—when heart-*qi* reaches the *elixir field*, then lift and contract;
2. *Taiyi Embracing True Qi*—when the *qi* of the lungs, heart, and liver all descend to the *elixir field*, then lift and contract;
3. *Jade Maiden Dividing the Fetus*—lie on the right flank, placing the external kidney outside the thigh, avoiding heat to prevent the *qi* from dispersing;
4. *Golden Crystal Flying Behind the Elbow*—when the *qi* of the lungs, heart, and liver descend to the *elixir field*, turn left and right **eighty-one times** each;
5. *Opening the Heavenly Gate, Closing the Earthly Door, Striking the Three Passes*—clench the hands and feet, focusing intent on the dual passes of the spine, where black *qi* entwines with red *qi*, ascending to the *mud pellet*. I then nod the head several times.

Yet closing the Three Passes also has its method. Strike the nose and gently press the lower abdomen, and the heart will naturally lift, the essence will reverse upward, and the pulse will pause—thus the *Upper Pass* is closed.

As *Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: The ancient sages had methods of *xū* (嘘, inhaling), *yàn* (咽, swallowing), *hē* (呵, exhaling sharply), *chuī* (吹, blowing), *hū* (呼, exhaling), and *xī* (嘻, laughing-breath). Always at the hour of *Zi*, sit cross-legged and steady the breath, drawing the abdomen through the nose until full.

Hē is practiced three times, hū twelve times, and yàn jìn (swallowing saliva) three times.
At the hour of *Mao*, facing east, hū is practiced twelve times, yàn seven times, xī twelve times, and yàn jìn three times.
At the hour of *Wu*, facing south, yàn is practiced seven times, chuī five times, xī twelve times, and yàn jìn three times.
At the hour of *You*, facing west, xū nine times, hē three times, xī twelve times, and yàn jìn three times.

What is xū? Clench the fists with both hands, gaze upward, and then exhale sharply.
What is yàn? Hug the knees with both arms, tilt the head back, and then swallow.
What is hē? Clasp the hands behind the head, tilt the head back, and then exhale sharply.
What is chuī? Extend the arms outward, clench the fists, and then blow.
What is hū? Let the arms hang loosely, embrace the spleen region in front, and then exhale.
What is xī? Sit upright with the head tilted back and laugh-breath.

The lungs correspond to the *qi* wheel. When the *qi* wheel is diseased—sometimes like clouds obscuring the sun, then suddenly clearing, or like the *Great Storehouse* (stomach) with heat and constipation—swallowing (yàn) is appropriate.
The spleen corresponds to the inner wheel. When the inner wheel is diseased—flanks swollen and painful, lips parched—exhaling (hū) is appropriate.
When the throat swells, laugh-breath (xī) is appropriate.
The kidneys correspond to the water wheel. When the water wheel is diseased—seeing one object as two, the sun appearing as if viewed through water, or a *ling* (resonance) beneath the navel—blowing (chuī) is appropriate.
The heart corresponds to the blood wheel. When the blood wheel is diseased—fleshy growths encroaching on the eyes, or heat in the diaphragm—exhaling sharply (hē) is appropriate.
The liver corresponds to the wind wheel. When the wind wheel is diseased—wind rushing out upon sight, mist or smoke arising—exhaling sharply (xū) is appropriate.

*Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: I have heard the teachings of the Three Fires.
The *Min Fire* is the external kidney. At sunset, gather the *Min Fire* twenty-seven times, then collect water thirty-six times, forming one swallow into the *Elixir Field* (Dan Tian). Gently press and massage the external kidney once, then water flows downward from above while the *Min Fire* of the external kidney enters from without—water and fire nourishing each other.

The *Chen Fire* is the internal kidney. When refining the sea at the hour of *Xū-Hài* (7–9 PM), first cup the external kidney with the left hand, and knead beneath the navel with the right hand, drawing up the *Chen Fire* to cook the *Elixir Field*, causing yin to diminish while yang grows. Each hand moves eighty-one times, completing one cycle.

The *Jun Fire* is the heart. After the hour of *Hài*, sit quietly, circling the *Elixir Field* with the mind’s intent—first left, then right—each rotation eighty-one or three hundred sixty times. Then the heart’s *Jun Fire* descends, merging with the internal kidney’s *Chen Fire* and the external kidney’s *Min Fire*. The Three Fires converge and condense into the elixir, known as the *Complete Heavenly Fire*.

*Zhì Yóuzǐ* says: Fire is taken at the hours of *Yín, Wǔ,* and *Xū*. Sit in a quiet chamber, placing thick mats on the couch, cross-legged and facing south. Cup both hands around the kidneys, pressing beneath the navel’s *wheel*. Calm the mind, letting inner and outer be as one. Then focus intently on the *wheel*’s interior, where a substance exists—
As large as a pellet, its hue like cinnabar, its brilliance like the sun. Make the breath entering through the nose exceedingly subtle, letting each inhalation store within the pellet. If a thought arises, swiftly dispel it with spirit, then refocus on the pellet, ensuring all breath enters it. Gradually, warmth spreads through the navel’s *wheel*, growing like fire. Then strike the teeth ninety times, rinse the mouth with saliva nine times, each swallow directed by intent into the *mud pellet*. Then practice the fire-raising method: strike the teeth ninety times, swallow saliva nine times nine times, and close the breath three times.

Next, rub the palms until hot, first massaging the tail of the eyes several times. Then rub the palms, applying heat to the nose several times. Next, rub the palms, applying heat to both ears several times. Then rub the palms, applying heat to the face and neck until warm. Finally, open and close the breath alternately, drawing a bow three times.

If this method is practiced daily, it can ward off the eight evils, preserving the face and form from decay—this is called *minor refinement of form*.

Why must fire be taken at these three times? *Yín* is when fire thrives; *Wǔ* is its imperial hour; *Xū* is its grave. Practicing this dispels yin and strengthens the yang spirit.

With prolonged practice, performing it twelve times a day, thought naturally becomes clear and unclouded, and in darkness, inner and outer become luminous. This is the sign of elixir completion, full vitality, and abundant *qi*.

When true *qi* is abundant, the spirit becomes clear and refreshed. One can go without food yet not feel hunger, and foreknow events before they occur. This is the sign of Dao completion.

A hundred days’ practice cures lingering illnesses; two hundred days make the navel firm and *qi* robust; three hundred days condense essence and *qi* into the elixir.

At first, gradually increase effort, practicing for half a candle-hour, then extending the duration. When perfected, warmth turns to heat within, and inner vision reveals the pellet clearly. Then *qi* flows smoothly, the spirit steadfastly guards without loss, and all breath is drawn into the pellet—still and unaware of its presence. This is called *breath condensing in the embryo, the embryo dwelling with the breath*.

With prolonged practice, suddenly one forgets self and object, both merging into emptiness, the body filled with heat and sweat. This is the sign of the *embryonic immortal*’s attainment.

「If one suffers from an ailment, one should immediately close the breath and inhale several times, allowing sweat to flow until the condition ceases, then resume the method of *rising fire* (起火之法). The illness shall then be removed.

As for the Wandering Student (游子), someone asked: Why, when practicing the first stage of Dao (初地修进), are the four methods (四法) employed simultaneously? The Wandering Student replied: The day has four times, each corresponding to the cycles of Heaven and Earth’s *yin* and *yang* (阴阳之数). The four times of Heaven and Earth are spring, summer, autumn, and winter; the four times of the sun and moon are waxing, waning, dark, and new. The four times of humanity are the hours of *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you*.

At the hour of *zi*, the heart-*qi* (心气) enters the kidneys (肾), its fire residing below (在下), and thus the true-*qi* (真气) of the kidneys ascends. At the hour of *mao*, the true-*yang* (真阳) follows the victory of *yin*-*qi* (阴气) and arrives at the waist (腰), while the lesser *yang* (少复) returns to its original position, dividing the *yin* and *yang* *qi* (阴阳二气) into forward and backward movements. For males, this is the left *yang* (阳); for females, this is the *yin* (阴). One should then use the method of *rising fire* and *dispersing qi* (升火散气).

At the hour of *wu*, the kidney-*qi* (肾气) enters the heart (心), and thus the *yin* descends from the Nine Heavens (九天) to above the throat and diaphragm (咽膈之上), dividing and moving forward and backward. At the hour of *you*, the *yin*-*qi* (阴气) weakens and kills vitality, while the *yang*-*qi* (阳气) grows feeble. One should then use the method of *gathering qi* to *nourish yang* (聚气养阳) and assist its restoration.

Thus, the four methods (四法) are the daily practices (一日之用). The hours of *hai*, *zi*, and *chou* mark the time when *yang*-*qi* is just beginning to arise. To elevate the true *yang*-*qi* (一阳之真气), one must sit quietly until dawn (达旦), avoiding loud speech or vigorous conversation. One may converse with others, but should not engage in heated discussions. If one speaks daily, one should reply in a calm voice. After social interactions (应接之劳), during the evening of the *zi* hour, one should cease practice and rest. When the time reaches *bing* (鹰呜), one may resume.

If, before the day of the *yang*-*qi*’s full ascension (南至), one has not yet elevated the true *yang*-*qi*, then at the evening of the *yang*-*qi*’s full ascension (南至之夕) and the next day at the hour of *xiao* (小至) and *zi*, one should perform the practice again. If one has already elevated the true *yang*-*qi* before the *yang*-*qi*’s full ascension, then performing it again at the hours of *xiao* (小至) and *zi* after the *yang*-*qi*’s full ascension is also beneficial. It is not necessary to sit until dawn.

In general, *qi* (气) ascends from the *yongquan* (涌泉) before the *yang*-*qi*’s full ascension (十一月), reaching the knees (膝) in the eleventh month, the thighs (股) in the twelfth month, and the waist (腰) in the first month. This is called the *Three Yang* (三阳) completion. In the second month, it reaches the arms (膊), in the third month the neck (颈), in the fourth month the crown (顶), and after the fifth month, the *yin*-*qi* follows the same pattern. Therefore, those who study the Dao (学道者) should practice abstinence from desires (绝嗜欲) in the fourth month and the tenth month to avoid the pure *yang* and pure *yin* phases (纯阳纯阴之用事).

The Wandering Student further said: Sit upright and close your eyes, imagining the heart as the *Grandmother* (诧女), the kidneys as the *Infant* (婴儿). First, warm the kidneys until they feel hot, then stir the fire to rise upward. Next, inhale through the nose to draw in the clear *qi*, visualizing the *wind-qi* of Heaven (天之风气) passing through nine times (九过). Exhale the *Grandmother*’s *qi* along with the *Dragon Fire* (龙火), letting them meet below and see the *Infant*. The *Infant* then rises again, meeting the *Grandmother* as husband and wife unite (交合焉). This is the *Dragon-Tiger* (龙虎) interaction in practice.

To inhale the *qi*, close the mouth, shut the eyes, and sit upright. With both hands clasping the external kidneys (外肾), cultivate warmth and heat until it permeates, then use the mind’s intention to embrace the kidney-*qi* as it ascends and guides it upward. If the breath is drawn in swiftly, imagine the heart as the *Grandmother* uniting with the kidneys and merging their essences (合精). Then imagine the kidneys as the *Male* responding and uniting in turn, ascending and descending fifteen times (十五过) until the essence settles in the body. Guide the essence upward into the heart, then let the heart’s blood descend again. Repeat this ascending and descending process twenty-one times (三七过).

Finally, store the essence in the *Spleen Palace* (脾宫) and seal it. This is known as the *Three Lineages Dwelling Together* (三姓同居), located above the heart and below the navel, its size like a ring (环). Next, use the *Six Yang Fire* (六阳之火) to forge it and the *Six Yin Water* (六阴之水) to irrigate it, practicing the *Nine-One* (九一) method of interaction day and night.

Thus, when the heart moves, the lungs, liver, gallbladder, and small intestine all move in response, aiding the heart. When the kidneys move, the external kidneys, bladder, large intestine, and spleen all move in response, aiding the kidneys. Therefore, the heart and kidneys are both the masters of cultivating the True Essence (俱修真之主).

The Wandering Student further said: The *Three Arcana* (三魄) are named *Day Spirit* (爽灵), *Day Essence* (幽精), and *Fetal Light* (胎光). The *Seven Arcana* (七魄) are named *Corpse Dog* (尸狗), *Crouching Spirit* (伏负), *Sparrow Yin* (雀阴), *Heavenly Thief* (天贼), *Non-Virtue* (非毒), *Purification* (除秽), and *Scent of Lungs* (嗅肺).

The *Three Primordial Spirits* (三元神) are named *Nurturing* (来育), each seven inches long (七寸). The *Stomach Spirit* (胃神) is three and a half inches long (三寸有半). The *Mud Pellet Spirit* (泥丸神) dwells between the eyebrows, three inches inward, and is named *Imperial Realm* (帝乡). The *Vermilion Palace Spirit* (绛官神) resides within the heart, one inch in length (一寸). The *Elixir Field Palace* (丹田官) is located two inches below the navel and is named *Grain Upright* (谷立). The *Heart Spirit* (心神) takes the form of the *Crimson Bird* (朱雀), nine inches long, and is named *Radiant Yang* (焕阳). The *Liver Spirit* (肝神) is named *Child* (童子), manifesting as two *Jade Maidens* (玉女), each nine inches long. The *Gallbladder Spirit* (胆神) dwells beneath the membrane, appearing as a *Jade Boy* (玉童) bearing a spear (执戟), and is named *Dragon Virtue* (龙德), three inches long. The *Lung Spirit* (肺神) is named *Luminous Flower* (皓华), three inches long, appearing as a *Jade Boy* bearing a weapon (执兵). The *Spleen Spirit* (脾神) is named *Precious Origin* (宝元), manifesting as three *Jade Maidens* (童女), seven inches and three divisions long (七寸三分). The *Kidney Spirit* (肾神) is named *Primordial Truth* (元真), resembling a *two-headed white deer* (白鹿而二首), three inches and seven divisions long (三寸七分).

The *Nine Vermin* (九虫) are named *Crouching Worm* (伏虫), four divisions long (四分), and the master of all vermin (群虫之主), dwelling between the intestines and stomach. It can transform into various diseases (能变成诸患). The *Hookworm* (蛔虫) is as long as a leech (蛭), four inches long (四寸), causing the abdomen to rumble (善令人腹呜). The *White Worm* (白虫) is one inch long (一寸), producing offspring up to four or five feet in length (乃至四五尺), capable of killing a person (能杀人). The *Flesh Worm* (肉虫) resembles a rotting apricot (烂杏), causing agitation and vexation (善令人烦懑). The *Lung Worm* (肺虫) resembles a silkworm (蚕), causing coughing (善令人咳嗽). The *Stomach Worm* (胃虫) resembles a toad (蟆), causing vomiting, spitting, and frequent belching (善令人呕逆吐、喜喊). The *Diaphragm Worm* (膈虫) resembles a slice of melon (瓜瓣), causing excessive salivation (善令人唾). The *Red Worm* (赤虫) resembles a leech (蛭), causing abdominal rumbling (善令人腹呜). The *Burning Worm* (烧虫) manifests as *scrofula*, *itching mange*, and *lichen* (为疽为疥为癣).」

---

**Volume Thirty-Five of *Dao Shu* concludes.**
#1: The nine characters following *"日"* were originally missing; supplemented from the *Ji Yao* edition.
#2: *"Right"* was originally *"Left"*; corrected from the *Ji Yao* edition.

**Volume Thirty-Six of *Dao Shu*—Collected by Youzi Zeng Kuò—The *Great Return Elixir* Chapter**

That which is born yet does not live—this is the Gate of Longevity;
That which dies yet does not perish—this is the Root of the Dao.

The Primordial Lord spoke: *"The Primordial Essence of the Great Yang generates that which does not live;
The Primordial Essence of the Great Yin causes that which does not die to perish.
That which is born yet does not live—this is the Gate of Longevity;
That which dies yet does not die—this is the Root of the Dao."*

The Supreme Sage said: *"What is meant by the Primordial Essence of the Great Yang?"*
The Primordial Lord replied: *"When yin and yang transform, they generate the Five Phases.
The Five Phases, in their mutual generation, conceive the numinous transformations.
Which is to say:
The essence of Earth generates the numinous fluid;
The essence of the numinous fluid generates white gold.
White gold is the essence of water, generating the red-luminous numinous sand;
The essence of the numinous sand generates the light of the Great Yang;
The essence of the Great Yang generates the Primordial *qi*;
The Primordial *qi* generates the numinous clarity.
Numinous clarity—this is the Gate of the Dao.
Thus, the Great Intestine is called the Primordial Yang.
It begins by gestating in the womb of white gold-water,
And becomes the Gate of the red-luminous numinous sand,
To merge with the Primordial *qi*,
To transmit the numinous clarity,
To harmonize yin and yang,
To reverse the Five Phases—
And thus the Primordial Essence is spontaneously generated."*

Master Xuan said: *"Its essence is the Great Return Elixir.
The so-called Great Return Elixir is that which the soul and spirit converge upon.
From the Fire position of the Southern Pole,
It transforms the Yin of *Ren* and *Gui* in the Northern Pole,
Passing through the Five Phases, its hue contains the Five Colors.
Its efficacy matches that of Heaven and Earth—
Its depth is unfathomable.
Its method consists of twelve stages,
Symbolizing the twelve months of a year.
The first is called *Hua Chi’s Primordial Mystery*.
The generating *qi* of the beginning,
Creating the forms of Heaven and Earth,
The numbers three and five,
Where male and female, pure and turbid, remain undivided—
The hidden dragon’s position.
The virtuous one, guarding the Dao,
Awaits the time to obtain it—
This is the crucible and furnace.
The *Classic* says: *Knowing white, guarding black, the numinous clarity comes of itself.*
Thus, the Mysterious is the mother of all things—
The secret of the Sage."*

The second is called *White Gold, Yellow Sprout*.
It is the refined gold flower from the Hua Chi elixir.
Congealing into chaos, it belongs to the initial stage of the alchemical robe,
Where the Mysterious Pass remains unopened,
Yin follows the Tiger, Yang follows the Dragon.
With the strength of *Gèn* for thirty days, it submits to *Lí*’s office,
After nine transformations, it returns—
And thus becomes the White Gold, Yellow Sprout,
Not the transformation of the Five Metals or Eight Stones.
Its origin lies in the union of *Kàn* and *Kūn*,
The flow of the Great Mysterious,
Sensing *qi* to form.
Like parents transmitting *qi* to give birth!
Thus, our supreme medicine—
The male of the Abyss, the female of the Flame—
Their natures depend on each other,
Their *qi* coalesces to form it.
Its symbol is the *Yì*’s second hexagram:
*The Dragon appearing in the field.*

The third is called *Five Phases*.
Water generates wood—this is *mercury*, not the *mercury* of the world;
Wood generates fire—this is *numinous sand*, not the *numinous sand* of the world;
Fire generates earth—this is *spiritual *qi*, not the *earth* of the world;
Earth generates metal—this is *white gold*, not the *metal* of the world;
Metal generates water—this is *black water*, not the *water* of the world.
Metal conquers wood, water conquers fire, earth conquers water, fire conquers metal.
Earth dominates the four seasons’ transitions,
Each spanning eight days in its net of influence.
Thus, the Five Phases’ generation and conquest form the supreme medicine.
It is said: *"Hold it to return to Heaven above,
And grant it the water’s gold within."*
After three years of fire, the nine transformations deepen.
At dusk, the Mysterious Crane cries in the clear shade.

The fourth is called *Four Symbols*: the Azure Dragon, the White Tiger, the Vermilion Bird, the Dark Tortoise.
The Azure Dragon governs the Eastern direction—wood, *mercury*.
Its stem-branches are *Jia* and *Yi*—
Refined, it is not clear; stirred, it is not turbid,
Near it cannot be taken, far it cannot be abandoned—
Like the dragon hidden, transforming without limit.
The White Tiger governs the Western direction—metal.
Its stem-branches are *Gēng* and *Xīn*—
Obtaining the True One’s position, the essence of the utmost refinement.
Thus, the Sage says: *"The *Fu* female is the Azure Dragon’s mate,"*
For this is how the Five Phases generate each other—
The utmost essence and true *qi* congeal, subdue, and remain motionless.
To grasp one is to complete all things.
The Vermilion Bird governs the Southern direction—fire, *cinnabar*.
Its stem-branches are *Bǐng* and *Dīng*—
Severing fluid to form the dragon, congealing *qi* to form the tiger.
Its *qi* ascends to become Heaven, descends to become Earth.
Thus, the Great Elixir—when seen in fire—flies,
The Vermilion Bird’s symbol.
The Dark Tortoise governs the Northern direction—water, blackness.
Its stem-branches are *Rén* and *Guǐ*.
The *Laozi* says: *"The highest virtue is like water."*
Not lead, not tin, not stone—
The numinous essence of the River Vehicle,
The numinous water of the River Chariot.
Born before Heaven and Earth,
It can be yielding, it can be firm,
It can nurture all things—
Our crucible must contain all four symbols,
The so-called Four Spirit Elixirs.
When the four positions form dust,
They return to their original master,
Like the Water Official capturing beasts,
The Golden Gate becoming its neighbor.
Those who join are those whose natures align.
Through the mediator, the Dao grows ever closer.

The fifth is called *Clarifying the True Nature of Lead and Mercury*.
Lead is *Kàn*—congealed white;
Mercury is *Lí*—flowing fluid.
Thus, the River Vehicle’s water is *Lí*,
The Dragon’s fire unites with it.
Nourished by wood, it becomes clear without end.
Thus, the lead’s gate contains gold,
Gold within holds the Return.
Know that within black water,
White gold is born,
White gold transforms into yellow gold,
Yellow gold transforms into purple gold.

The five colors are abandoned—its name is the *Great Elixir of Return*. Why so?

White gold arises from lead and is born through water,
Thus the Dragon and Tiger bind themselves in the West to obtain it,
Transforming into yellow sprouts.
Yellow sprouts grow dependent on earth,
Taking on earth’s nature—hence, they are called *yellow sprouts*.

Water mingles with yellow, the moon intermingles with black,
Thus the revolving fan of black days and white months,
Taking their parent-child as one—
The crane’s cry in the shadow’s form.

Here, the tiger roars and the dragon bellows—
Things of like kind resonate with one another.

Thus, mercury is *nature*, lead is *emotion*—
The two unite in harmony.

How could the Dao of Nature’s constancy
Be an external thing?

The sixth is *Sun and Moon*—
The essence of Heaven and Earth, the sovereign of elixirs.

*Kàn* (the male) is symbolized by the moon;
*Lí* (the female) is symbolized by the sun.

The sun has the *cloven hoof*—a yin-like form;
The moon has the *lunar toad*—a yang-like being.

White gold is born from the River Vehicle—
Yin within yang;
Mercury comes from the *Spiritual Sand*—
Yang within yin.

What of its form and substance?
It is *profound and yet more profound*.

「Thus, the Sun and Moon dwell within the hands,
Where the *造化* (Creative Transformation) gives birth to their forms.
Hence, the left kidney is the Sun,
And the right kidney is the Moon.

*Guàn* (the male, Earth Trigram) collects the elixir in the *Lí* (the female, Fire Trigram) palace,
And returns it to the *Kàn* (the male, Water Trigram) gate.
With jade tripods and golden cauldrons, the Eight Trigrams are employed,
And the River Vehicle of black waters carries the sand and mercury.

This is the transmission of the *Sages* and the instruction of the *Worthy Ones*.

The seventh is *Bright Elixir* (明药),
The root of colored elixirs, born in conjunction with *profound waters* (玄水).
Thus, it governs white gold,
Which then transforms into yellow gold,
And yellow gold into purple gold.

He who obtains white gold becomes a *Earthly Immortal* (地仙),
He who obtains purple gold becomes a *Celestial Immortal* (天仙).
What is this Way?
It is a single substance manifesting in five hues,
Not an ordinary elixir—
Nourished by fire, contained in a *cauldron* (鼎),
It undergoes no change.

My elixir, however,
Moves with the Sun and Moon to the *Supreme Treasure* (至宝).
Begin the work at *zi* hour (子时),
Without ceasing, though in the sixth month fire is not used.
The *Yang Spirit* (阳神) shines with its portents,
And the *Yin Law* (阴律) radiates its luminous currents within its bounds.

He who recognizes the *infant* (婴儿),
Must grasp the *veil of the old woman* (姥女之帷).

Thus, it encompasses all that is coarse,
And penetrates all that is fine.
Its symbols descend from Heaven,
And it generates its own light.
Its symbols descend to Earth,
And the *wronged spirits* (冤魂) are freed from their *calamity* (涂炭).
Its symbols descend upon the body,
And the *form and spirit* (形神) ascend together to Heaven.

The eighth is *Nine Returns, Seven Circuits* (九还七返).
*Nine Returns* refers to the great cycle of a year,
Or the small cycle of a month—
Like the *Big Dipper’s* (北斗) degrees,
It completes the day and night.

Heaven descends and Earth ascends,
Giving birth and transformation to all things.
From *yín* (寅) to *shēn* (申),
This is the *Seven Circuits*.
Returning again to *kūn* (the Earth Trigram, 坤),
This is the *Nine Returns*.

To advance toward the *Immortal Way* (神仙),
One must obtain the *pure qi* (正气) of three thousand six hundred years.
Now, let us take the great cycle of a day’s twelve hours,
Six *yang* (阳) and six *yin* (阴),
With *yang* corresponding to spring and summer,
And *yin* to autumn and winter.

Thus, one hour represents the symbol of a day;
One day represents the symbol of a month.
A month has three *decans* (旬),
Totaling three hundred sixty hours—
The symbol of a year.
Extending this upward,
Twelve hours become twelve months,
Three hundred sixty days—
Is it not like three thousand six hundred years?

Thus, a man’s body is formed in ten months,
And the elixir is refined in ten months to break free from its *fetal bonds* (脱胎).
Are not the *human path* (人道) and the *elixir path* (药道) fundamentally aligned?

The ninth is *Selecting Friends* (择友).
A ruler without friends loses his kingdom,
A minister without friends loses his loyalty,
A commoner without friends loses his family,
And a *Way* without friends loses its *true essence* (飧其真).
To obtain a friend,
Is to select the day when the *qi* (气) aligns.

What is this alignment?
It is following the *sovereign qi* (王气).
A single action releases the *flowing pearls* (流珠),
And the five hues appear bright.

If the work begins at *Spring Day* (日春), *Summer Day* (日夏), *Autumn Day* (日秋), or *Winter Day* (日冬),
And the *qi* (汞) is pursued according to its nature,
Then *yin* and *yang* will invert,
And the matter will be left unfinished.

The tenth is *The Golden Cauldron* (金鼎).
The Golden Cauldron responds to Heaven above,
To man in the middle,
And to Earth below.
