To **swallow once, then swallow again (一咽复一咽)**, double-gathering with twofold containment, using **empty swallowing (虚咽)** as the method, is to **cherish *qi* and extract essence as irrigation (惜气取水以溉灌)**.

To **sit upright and elevate the body (正坐升身)**, filling the **Four Great Elements (四大)** with *qi*, allowing the **blood channels (血络)** to flow freely, and harmonizing the **nutritive and defensive *qi* (营卫)**—this is to **distribute *qi* to burnish the body (布气以焚身)**. Yet these are not true methods of **cultivating *qi* (养气)**.

True cultivation of *qi* means:
- Nourishing it at the time of birth, so it does not decline.
- Nourishing it when it is weak, so it does not perish.

The ancients who embodied the **trigram Zhen (屯)** took **yang** at its nascent stage—when it is bent yet not yet stretched—thus, they practiced **Zhen at dawn (朝屯)** to cultivate the **flourishing of *qi* (气之茂)**. Those who embodied the **trigram Meng (蒙)** took **one yang** amid **grouped yin**—when it is obscured and unclear—thus, they practiced **Meng at dusk (暮蒙)** to seek the **principle of yang (阳之义)**.

Thus, *qi* must not be harmed. If one’s **talent (才)** is not sharp yet forces **excessive thinking (强思)**, it will be injured. If one’s **strength (力)** is insufficient yet forces **excessive exertion (强举)**, it will be injured. **Sorrow and grief (悲哀)** lead to **emaciation (憔悴)**, which exhausts *qi*. **Excessive joy or anger (喜怒过度)** will injure it. **Pursuing desires with haste (汲汲所欲)** will injure it. **Nursing grudges (戚戚所怀)** will injure it.

Not only this—**prolonged speech or raucous laughter (久谈剧笑)**, **sleeping or resting at improper times (寝息失时)**, **drawing the bow or tensioning the crossbow (挽弓张弩)**, **indulging in wine and vomiting (耽酒呕吐)**, **eating until sated (饱食则外)**, **leaping about and panting (跳步喘息)**, **shouting or weeping (欢呼哭泣)**, **failure of yin-yang interaction (阴阳不交)**, or **accumulated injuries until exhaustion (积伤至尽)**—all these lead to **premature death (夭)**.

True cultivation of *qi* lies in **dwelling in stillness and solitude (寂寞)**, **indifference without desire (淡然无欲)**—for at the **winter solstice (冬至)**, **yang** begins to arise. After the **spring equinox (春分)**, when **yang is strong and yin disperses**, one must guard against **residual yin entering the abdomen (腹)**, causing **bitter cold afflictions (苦寒之患)**; at the **summer solstice (夏至)**, **yin** within **yang** is born. After the **autumn equinox (秋分)**, when **yin is strong and yang disperses**, one must guard against **residual yang entering the abdomen**, causing **severe heat afflictions (酷暑之患)**.

Do not **observe the dead (死)**, for their *qi* **clashes with the living’s *qi* (触生气)**. Do not **draw near filth (秽)**, for its *qi* **clashes with true *qi* (触真气)**. Before the **solstice of life-force (真气未壮)**, do not **eat until empty (虚食)** at dawn—always **keep the mouth full (常充口)**. When **true *qi* nears depletion (真气欲绝)**, do not **eat until sated (实食)** at dusk—always **leave the mouth partially empty (常臧口)**.

For *qi* is like a **thread (缕)**—if touched, it is severed. It is like **marriage bonds (姻)**—if disturbed, it scatters. If one cannot **nourish it properly (养之)**, one loses the **way of preserving the form (保形之道)**.

Yet **cultivating *qi* (养气)** is inferior to **gathering medicine (采药)**, and **gathering medicine** is inferior to **refining *qi* (炼气)**. To **gather *qi* and return it to its origin (采气还元)**, one can forge **the Golden Elixir (金丹)** and attain **transformation (羽化)**. Thus, before refining, one must first gather, and before gathering, one must first **nourish (养)**—this is what I call **cultivating *qi* (养气)**.

Humans take the **form (形)** as their dwelling and the **heart (心)** as their master. The heart is **fire (火)**—it is the **essence of the South (南方)**, the **abiding yang (盛阳)**. Its **lodging is in the wandering star (荧惑)**, its **spirit is the Vermilion Bird (朱雀)**, its **shape is three leaves (三叶)**, its **color is the red lotus (朱莲)**—this is where **divine clarity (神明)** depends.

Thus, to **receive life from the Dao (从道受生)** is called **fate (命)**; to **inherit the form from one’s parents (自一禀形)** is called **nature (性)**. The **heart’s role in governing the body (任物)** is called **mind (心)**. The ancient **sages (至人)** taught people to **cultivate the Dao (修道)**, which is to **cultivate the heart (修心)**.

To **empty the heart (虚心)** is to **return it to its true nature (还其实)**. To **have no heart (无心)** is to **remove its false attachments (除其有)**. To **settle the heart (定心)** is to **keep it unmoved (不动)**. To **calm the heart (安心)** is to **keep it from peril (不危)**. To **quiet the heart (静心)** is to **keep it from chaos (不乱)**. To **rectify the heart (正心)** is to **keep it from deviance (不邪)**. To **purify the heart (清心)** is to **keep it from turbidity (不浊)**. To **cool the heart (冷心)** is to **keep it from defilement (不秽)**.

Moreover, this depends on **few thoughts and few recollections (少思少念)**, **few desires and few affairs (少欲少事)**, **few words and few laughs (少语少笑)**, **few sorrows and few joys (少愁少乐)**, **few likes and few dislikes (少好少恶)**—so that **the divine light (灵光)** does not stray, and **spirit-*qi* (神气)** does not go wild, and only then can one **enter the Dao (入道)**.

**Excessive thinking (多思)** weakens the **spirit (神)**. **Excessive recollection (多念)** scatters the **will (志)**. **Excessive desire (多欲)** shortens **lifespan (寿)**. **Excessive affairs (多事)** enslaves the **form (形)**. **Excessive speech (多语)** weakens *qi*. **Excessive laughter (多笑)** harms the **viscera (藏)**. **Excessive sorrow (多愁)** **congeals the blood (摄血)**. **Excessive joy (多乐)** **overflows the mind (溢意)**. **Excessive delight (多喜)** disturbs *qi*. **Excessive anger (多怒)** unsettles the **hundred vessels (百脉)**. **Excessive likes (多好)** bring **stupor (昏迷)**. **Excessive dislikes (多恶)** lead to **emaciation (憔悴)**.

If its **source is impure (源不洁)**, the **harmonious *qi* (和气)** will naturally **deplete (耗)**. This is my teaching on **nourishing the heart (养心)**.

To **gather the spirit (集灵)** and **resource the Dao (资道)**, when **spirit-*qi* (神气)** **converges harmoniously (相合)**, it becomes **lifespan (寿)**—the greatest may reach **twelve thousand years (一万二千岁)**, the moderate **one thousand two hundred years (一千二百岁)**, the lesser **one hundred and twenty years (一百二十岁)**.

To know the **methods of refinement (修炼之方)** yet not know how to **nourish lifespan (养其寿)**, then **refinement is in vain (无功)**. How does one **nourish lifespan**?

To **walk without excessive speech (行不多言)**, for speech **injures the spirit and depletes *qi* (伤神而损气)**...」

「Sleep without opening the mouth, lest it **leak *qi* and harm the spirit** (*泄气而损神*).

Do not **venture near peril to ascend heights** (*临危而登峻*), lest the **soul depart** (*魂飞*).
Do not **engage in bloodshed or witness combat** (*玩杀、看斗*), lest the **vital *qi* stagnate** (*气结*).
Do not **lament the dead or inquire about illness** (*吊死、问疾*), lest the **spirit be scattered by excessive sorrow** (*喜神散*).
Do not **sleep in dampness or face the wind** (*卧湿、当风*), lest the **true *qi* weaken** (*真气弱*).
Do not **enter ancient temples or places of ill omen** (*古庙凶祠*), lest the **spirit be startled** (*神惊*).
Do not **mock wild or strange beasts** (*戏狂禽异兽*), lest the **spirit be alarmed** (*神恐*).
Do not **lie down before the Three Lights** (*对三光而没*), nor **utter frivolous or false speech** (*绮语妄言*), lest it **shorten one’s years** (*损年*).

When **feasting, do not defile oneself before sacred images** (*亵於圣像*), lest the **soul and vital essence be restless** (*魂魄不安*).
When **sitting outdoors, avoid proximity to mounds and graves** (*近於丘墓*), lest the **spirit and *qi* disperse** (*精神散*).
Do not **rest upon withered trees or large trees** (*枯木大树*), lest the **prolonged yin-*qi* of their roots disturb the yang spirit** (*久阴之气触阳神*).
Do not **cross deep waters or vast marshes** (*探水大泽*), lest the **extreme coldness of their nature oppress the true *qi*** (*至寒之性逼真气*).
Do not **consume untimely fruits** (*不时之果*), lest they **harbor internal pathogenic *qi*** (*内邪气*).

This is my teaching on **nourishing lifespan** (*养寿者也*).

The **kidney** (*肾*) of the male is **preeminent** (*先生*), for it **encases yin within yang** (*外精内血*), with **yin as its core** (*以阴为裹*).
The **kidney** (*肾*) of the female is **preeminent** (*先生*), for it **encases yang within yin** (*外血内精*), with **yang as its core** (*以阳为裹*).

From the kidneys, the **spleen** (*脾*) is born; from the spleen, the **liver** (*肝*); from the liver, the **lungs** (*肺*); from the lungs, the **heart** (*心*); from the heart, the **small intestine** (*小肠*); from the small intestine, the **large intestine** (*大肠*); from the large intestine, the **gallbladder** (*胆*); from the gallbladder, the **urinary bladder** (*膀胱*); from the urinary bladder, the **Three Elements** (*三元*); from the Three Elements, the **Three Burners** (*三焦*); from the Three Burners, the **Eight Vessels** (*八脉*); from the Eight Vessels, the **Twelve Channels** (*十二经*); from the Twelve Channels, the **Twelve Collaterals** (*十二络*); from the Twelve Collaterals, the **One Hundred and Eighty System Collaterals** (*百八十系络*); from the System Collaterals, the **One Hundred and Eighty Encirclement Collaterals** (*百八十缠络*); from the Encirclement Collaterals, the **Thirty-Six Thousand External Collaterals** (*三万六千外络*); from the External Collaterals, the **Three Hundred and Sixty-Five Bones** (*三百六十五骨*); from the bones, the **Eighty-Four Thousand Hair Orifices** (*八万四千毛窍*).

**Essence** (*精*) is the **mother**; **vital *qi*** (*气*) is the **master**.
Each of the **Five Zang** (*五藏*) has its **essence**; within the essence, **vital *qi*** is born.
Each of the Five Zang has its **vital *qi***; within the *qi*, **spirit** is born.

**Refining essence** can yield **elixir** (*丹*), **nourishing *qi*** can cultivate **spirit** (*神*), and this is the **Dao of longevity** (*长生之道*).

Those who **skillfully nourish life** (*善养命*) do so by **nurturing the roots of the Five Zang** (*养其五藏之根*), for when the **roots are firm, the branches flourish** (*根固叶自茂*).
Those who **skillfully nourish form** (*善养形*) do so by **nourishing the Five Types of Vital *Qi*** (*养其五气*), for the **Five Types of Vital *Qi*** are the **source**, and when the **source is deep, the flow is long** (*源深流自长*).

Yet each of the Five Zang has its **seasonal weakness** (*一时*), hence one **Zang reigns while another falters** (*一王则一弱*).
I can **supplement them**, making them **harmonious**, and then the **hundreds of bones** (*百骸*) **function properly**, while **hundreds of ailments** (*百疾*) **are dispelled**.

When **true *qi* moves in great cycles** (*真气大运*), it follows the **heavenly seasons** (*随於天*).
When **elemental *qi* moves in lesser cycles** (*元气小运*), it follows the **daily solar rhythms** (*随於日*).

In **spring**, when the **liver reigns and the spleen falters** (*肝王脾弱*), one should **consume sweet foods to nourish the spleen** (*食甘以养其脾*)—**brown rice** (*粳米*), **dates** (*枣*), **beef** (*牛*), **chive greens** (*葵菜*).
**Calm the heart and avoid sorrow or dread**, lest it **injure the liver** (*清心而无忧恐，其伤於肝*).
The liver **abhors wind**; thus, one should **retire and sit quietly to avoid it** (*恶风，则隐坐以避焉*).
In terms of the **solar hour**, at the **Mao hour** (*卯之时*), one should **await the lesser cycle’s birth from elemental *qi*** (*以待小运生乎元气*), as it **transmits to the liver**; thus, **close the eyes to nourish the liver** (*传送於肝，暝目以养其肝*), and in a **decade** (*一旬*), one can **perceive autumn hairs** (*可以视秋毫*).

In **summer**, when the **heart reigns and the lungs falter** (*心王肺弱*), one should **consume pungent foods to nourish the lungs** (*食辛以养其肺*)—**yellow millet** (*黄黍*), **peaches** (*桃*), **parrot flesh** (*鹦*), **onion greens** (*葱菜*).
**Calm the heart and temper excessive joy or dread**, lest it **injure the heart** (*清心而少喜恐，其伤於心*).
The heart **abhors heat**; thus, one should **sit quietly to avoid it** (*恶热，则静坐以避焉*).
In terms of the **solar hour**, at the **Wu hour** (*午之时*), one should **await the lesser cycle’s birth from elemental *qi*** (*以待小运生乎元气*), as it **transmits to the heart**; thus, **quiet the mind and reside peacefully to nourish the heart** (*传送於心，绝念安居，以养其心*), and in a **decade**, one can **harmonize the Hundred Vessels** (*可以通百脉*).

In **autumn**, when the **lungs reign and the liver falters** (*肺王肝弱*), one should **consume sour foods to nourish the liver** (*食酸以养其肝*)—**beans** (*豆*), **plums** (*李*), **dog meat** (*犬*), **radish greens** (*蕾菜*).
**Calm the heart and avoid grief or dread**, lest it **injure the lungs** (*清心而勿悲恐，其有伤於肺*).
The lungs **abhor cold**; thus, one should **reside quietly to avoid it** (*恶寒，则静居以避焉*).
In terms of the **solar hour**, at the **You hour** (*酉之时*), one should **await the lesser cycle’s birth from elemental *qi*** (*以待小运生乎元气*), as it **transmits to the lungs**; thus, **elevate the body and sit quietly to nourish the lungs** (*传送於肺，升身静坐，以养其肺*), and in a **decade**, the **skin will radiate luster** (*其肤光泽*).

In **winter**, when the **kidneys reign and the heart falters** (*肾王心弱*), one should **consume bitter foods to nourish the heart** (*食苦以养其心*)—**wheat** (*小麦*), **mandarins** (*橘*), **mutton** (*羊*), **gourd greens** (*球菜*).
**Calm the heart and avoid dread**, lest it **injure the heart** (*清心而无恐，恐其有伤於心*).
In terms of the **solar hour**, at the **Zi hour** (*子之时*), one should **await the lesser cycle’s birth from elemental *qi*** (*以待小运生乎元气*), as it **transmits to the kidneys**; thus, **draw inward and sit upright to nourish the kidneys** (*传送於肾，敛身正坐，以养其肾*), and in a **decade**, the **elixir field will be warm**, and the **vital *qi* and strength will be robust** (*丹田暖而气力刚健*).

In the **intermediate seasons**, when the **spleen reigns and the kidneys falter** (*脾王肾弱*), one should **consume salty foods to nourish the kidneys** (*食咸以养其肾*)—**millet** (*粟*), **mountain yam** (*山药*), **pork** (*猜*), **garlic greens** (*韭菜*).
**Reside peacefully and avoid dread**, lest it **injure the spleen** (*安心而无恐，恐其有伤於脾*).
The spleen **abhors dampness**; thus, one should **sit quietly to avoid it** (*恶湿，则静坐以避焉*).
In terms of the **solar hour**, at the **Chen, Xiu, Chou, and Wei hours** (*辰戌丑未之时*), one should **await the lesser cycle’s birth from elemental *qi*** (*以待小运生乎元气*), as it **transmits residual *qi* to the spleen**; thus, **reside in a quiet chamber, conserve breath, minimize exhalation** (*传送余气於脾，静室闭气，多入少出，以养其脾*), and in a **decade**, the **body will radiate brilliance**, and the **channels and collaterals will flow freely** (*则体光华，而经络畅*).

If one **refines with lesser effort** (*修炼下功*), then the **Five Zang need not be so meticulously tended** (*五藏不必如是*).

This is my teaching on **internal supplementation** (*补内*).

The **heart** (*心*), **kidneys** (*肾*), **liver** (*肝*), **lungs** (*肺*), and **spleen** (*脾*) are the **Five Zang**.
The **large intestine** (*大肠*), **small intestine** (*小肠*), **urinary bladder** (*膀胱*), **Three Burners** (*三焦*), **gallbladder** (*胆*), and **stomach** (*胃*) are the **Six Fu** (*六府*).
The **hair and skin**, the **eyes, ears, nose, and tongue**, and the **hands and feet** are the **four limbs** (*四体*); the **Nourishing and Defensive *qi*** (*荣卫*), **channels and collaterals** (*经络*), and **orifices** (*穴*) are also part of them.

The **heart’s *qi* resides in the liver** (*心之气在肝*), and the liver **generates essence** (*自生精*).
If the **essence is not firm** (*其精不固*), then the **eyes will dim and lack luster** (*目眩无光*).
The **heart’s *qi* resides in the lungs** (*心之气在肺*), and the lungs **generate essence** (*自生精*).
If the **essence is not substantial** (*其精不实*), then the **flesh and muscles will weaken** (*肌肉弱*).
The **heart’s *qi* resides in the kidneys** (*心之气在肾*), and the kidneys **generate essence** (*自生精*).
If the **essence is not full** (*其精不满*), then the **spirit and *qi* will be diminished** (*神气臧少*).
The **heart’s *qi* resides in the spleen** (*心之气在脾*), and the spleen **generates essence** (*自生精*).
If the **essence is not strong** (*其精不坚*), then the **hair and teeth will wither** (*发齿自衰*).

The kidneys are the **sea of essence** (*精海*), and the heart is the **hall of *qi*** (*气馆*).
**True essence** (*真精*) resides in the kidneys, while the **remaining essence** (*余精*) returns to the **lower field** (*下田*).
**True *qi*** (*真气*) resides in the heart, and the **remaining *qi*** (*余气*) ascends to the **central realm** (*中元*).

When **thoughts and worries, grief, and sorrow** (*思虑悲哀*) deplete the *qi*, it is like a leak in the **boiling cauldron’s *qi*** (*鼎中之气*).
When **lustful desires and calamitous excesses** (*淫邪祸乱*) dissipate the essence, it is like splitting **firewood beneath the cooking pot** (*析薪釜下*).

The **method of replenishment** (*补之之道*) must first **sever what is improper** (*先绝者也*), particularly in the **chamber arts** (*房中*).

**Essence** (*精*)—from whence does it arise?
All things receive the **pure and refined *qi* of Heaven and Earth** (*天地纯粹之气*), while humans **consume the nourishing resources of the ten thousand things** (*万物充实之资*) in food.
When ingested into the **stomach** (*胃*), it blends with **true *qi*** (*真气*) and circulates downward to the kidneys, filling their **voids** (*虚气*).

When **perceptions evoke the mind** (*对境生心*), the **heart’s fire** (*心之火*) presses down upon the kidneys, preventing the *qi* from ascending.
It **spirals left and right** (*左旋右盘*), like a **violent wind and thunderous clap** (*急风震雷*), piercing through the **bladder** (*膀胱*), transforming into **essence’s refinement** (*精华*).
Thus, **true *qi* is lost** (*真气走失*), and **fire ascends** (*火上起*).
The **lungs open** (*肺开*) while the **heart is disrupted** (*心冲*), the **liver floats** (*肝浮*) and the **gallbladder is unrestrained** (*胆横*).
All **spirits** (*万神*) are scorched by **true fire** (*真火*), wandering outside the body.
**Bones dissolve** (*骨解*), **sinews slacken** (*筋伸*), and it is **no different from death** (*与死无异*).

Thus, **one emission weakens one breath of *qi*** (*一泄则一气弱*), **a hundred emissions deplete one spirit** (*百泄则一神去*), **a thousand emissions damage one organ** (*千泄则一藏损*), until **exhaustion and death** (*枯竭而死*).

Yet, the **Supreme Sage** (*上圣*) possesses the **method of returning essence** (*还精之道*).
If **one’s will is fixed upon the Mysterious Origin** (*志在於玄元*), then the **kidneys’ *qi* merges with the heart’s *qi*** (*肾气交於心气*), accumulating *qi* to generate **fluid** (*液*).
It is **like a suspended bead or dripping dew** (*悬珠垂露*), returning to the **elixir field** (*丹田*).
With **fire and conditions in harmony** (*火候无差*), it **naturally congeals** (*自然凝结*).
Its form is **like a round pellet** (*其形弹丸*), its hue **crimson and orange** (*其色朱橘*).
Thus, **within *qi* arises *qi*** (*气中生气*), **essence and *qi* coalesce into spirit** (*精气成神*), and its accumulation **can lead to sainthood** (*入圣*).

Those of **shallow learning and ignorance** (*少学而无知*), however, **harvest the vital *qi* of maidens** (*采女之津气*) as **yin elixir** (*阴丹*), and **refine metals and minerals** (*炼金石*) into **external elixir** (*外丹*).
When their *qi* is **abundant** (*气盛*), **no harm is yet seen** (*未见其损*).
But when **primordial yang is dissipated** (*元阳耗散*), the **elixir field is void** (*丹台空虚*), and **they ingest it again** (*饵之在复*), then **rapid decline and death** (*速亡之患*) ensue—**unlike my method of replenishing essence** (*非若吾所以补精者也*).

**Yang arises from within Earth** (*地中阳生*), **emanating from yin** (*自阴中来*).
**Yin descends from Heaven** (*天中阴降*), **emanating from yang** (*自阳中来*).

There is no loss, yet there are faults of trembling and imbalance.

Now, consider the kidneys—water indeed. Within water, *qi* arises, subtle as a thread. Yet the Six Desires harm from without, the Seven Emotions from within. The heavy palaces [of the mind] scatter upward, the Golden Tortoise [kidney essence] is spilled downward. How could this not be like a fish slipping through a net or wind escaping a bag—how could there be no damage? Then how can one fail to know the Dao of nourishing *qi*?

The Celestial Sovereign’s Sacred Embryo is the Supreme Method; Damo’s Embryonic Breath is the Middle Method; Bian Que’s exposition of *The Spiritual Pivot* and Ge Hong’s elucidation of Embryonic Breath—nurturing breath from the embryo, guiding breath to the embryo—is the Inferior Method. This is what I call nourishing *qi*.

The methods of supplementation are manifold. Rising and resting follow the early and late hours of the Four Seasons; movement and stillness adhere to the constant measures of harmony. Adjusting sinews and vessels has its reclining and upright methods; nourishing the true and expelling the false has the protective techniques of inhalation and exhalation. Circulating the Circulation and Defense has the laws of supplementation and drainage; moderating labor and rest has the essentials of giving and withholding. Restrain anger to preserve yin; suppress joy to nourish yang. With purity and emptiness, dispel frantic thoughts; with tranquility and ease, cultivate the true nature. Nourish *qi* with *qi*, and *qi* will naturally abound; nourish spirit with spirit, and spirit will never be lacking. When *qi* is abundant, the body endures; when spirit dwells, life is prolonged.

Before noon, one may refine the Heavenly Stem [yang]; after noon, one may refine the Earthly Branch [yin]. Its *qi* arises from the kidneys and begins at the Hour of Child, ending at the Hour of Noon—its *qi* ascends and reigns.

Refining the Heavenly Stem—how so? Sit quietly in a secluded chamber, close your eyes, and quiet your mind. Remain motionless, allowing *qi* to fill the Four Great [elements], permeating your body. When Circulation and Defense harmonize, after days of practice, *qi* flourishes and the Defense clears.

When kidney *qi* reaches the heart, accumulated *qi* generates fluid. This fluid arises from the heart, beginning at the Hour of Noon and ending at the Hour of Child—its fluid descends and thrives.

Refining the Earthly Branch—how so? Close your eyes and quiet your mind. Sit upright, clasping your abdomen with both hands. Lower the heart’s fire to the elixir field, simmering the *qi* of the Sea of Vitality. After days of practice, *qi* reigns and spirit clears.

This is supplementation of *qi*.

In winter, avoid cold; in summer, avoid heat. Avoid wind in cold, heat in warmth. Do not overtax the limbs in motion, nor neglect the skin in repose. Bathe every five days, wash hair every ten. Do not move when *qi* reigns; do not neglect when blood reigns.

This is supplementation of *qi*.

Thus, supplementation of the form is not as good as supplementation of essence; supplementation of essence is not as good as supplementation of *qi*; supplementation of *qi* is not as good as supplementation of spirit. When spirit is supplemented, form and spirit are eternally at peace—near to the Dao of the Transcendent.

The man’s *qi* measures eight hundred and ten *zhang*—eighty-one times nine, the pure yang number. The woman’s blood measures three *dan* and six *dou*—thirty-six times six, the pure yin number. *Qi* diminishes by nine times nine, blood is exhausted by six times six—this is the natural order. Yet to die and decay without cultivation—how lamentable!

The daily prohibition: do not drink to excess at dusk. The yearly prohibition: do not travel far at dusk. The lifelong prohibition: do not indulge in sex by candlelight at dusk. These are the great principles of supplementation and loss.

The Five Flavors must not be overindulged. Thus, sour harms the spleen, sweet harms the kidneys, salty harms the heart, bitter harms the lungs, pungent harms the liver—these must be guarded against.

Before the Great Elixir is complete, hunger and thirst remain. Three meals a day must not be overeaten. Morning meals should not be empty; evening meals should not be full—this is the superior way. Plain and flavorless, bland and without meat—this is the secondary way.

When the Five Viscera accumulate stagnation, use inhalation (*hu*), exhalation (*he*), swallowing (*yan*), blowing (*chui*), laughter (*xi*), and sighing (*xu*) to treat them. Yet in spring, do not exhale; in summer, do not swallow; in winter, do not inhale; in autumn, do not sigh. Laughing in all four seasons ensures the Triple Burner lacks nothing. Blowing at the Eight Nodes ensures the kidney palace can be filled.

If there is excess, draw upon its child; if deficient, kill its ghost—why so? The liver is inherently sighing. If you draw its child, use exhalation to drain the heart’s *qi*. Once the heart’s *qi* flows, the liver’s *qi* will naturally transmit. If the liver’s *qi* is deficient, the one who kills its ghost is the lung—metal overcoming wood. Wood is the wife, metal the husband. The husband is the ghost. When the liver weakens, the lung has excess; use swallowing to drain it.

If neither excess nor deficiency prevails, yin and yang will naturally harmonize. This is my method of supplementation and loss.

The kidneys are water; when *qi* arises within, it becomes fire. The heart is fire; when fluid arises within, it becomes water. At the Winter Solstice, yang arises from Earth; by the Summer Solstice, it reaches Heaven, accumulating yang and generating yin. Yin responds to yin, and yin is not depleted. Thus, it disperses as mist, condenses as dew. Mist and dew are the yin that Heaven produces as true water.

At the Summer Solstice, yin descends from Heaven; by the Winter Solstice, it reaches Earth, accumulating yin and generating yang. Yang responds to yang, and yang is not depleted. Thus, it ascends as clouds, falls as rain. Clouds and rain are the yang that Earth produces as true fire.

It is like the beginning of conception in a person: the two *qi*s unite, and yang *qi* ascends—making the heart the hall of *qi*, where true water is hidden within. Yin *qi* descends, making the kidneys the water palace, where true *qi* is hidden within. Otherwise, how could kidney *qi* reach the heart, generating fluid from accumulated *qi*—how could one yin arise? Two yangs of heart *qi* reaching the kidneys generate *qi* from accumulated fluid—how could one yang arise from two yins?

Thus, a person possesses three *fires* and eight *waters*. The *waters* arise when one *qi* transmits to another, accumulating *qi* to generate fluid, and each of the five *zàng* organs contains its own fluid—this is called **color-water** (*sèshuǐ*).

Within kidney *qi*, the **true-one water** (*zhēn-yī shuǐ*) is hidden, manifesting as the **yin tiger** (*yīnhǔ*), its name being **true water**. The **golden crystal** (*fēijīn jīng*) that flies from the elbow, entering the **upper palace** (*shànggōng*), descends from above to below, meeting with **true fire** (*zhēnhuǒ*) to complete **the accomplished** (*jìjiē*), and this is called **spirit-water** (*shénshuǐ*).

For those afflicted with illness, they should **close their mouths and inhale *qi*** (*bìkǒu nàqì*), swallowing once again and once again, directing it steadily within to where the disease resides—this is called **method-water** (*fǎshuǐ*).

When the **elixir** (*dān*) is formed and poured forth, it becomes the **baptismal method** (*mùyù zhī fǎ*); when the form is refined and **true *qi*** (*zhēnqì*) is generated, it becomes the **reverting elixir method** (*huándān zhī fǎ*).

**Pure Yang Master** (*Chúnyáng Zǐ*) says:
*"When water and fire meet in the Two Radiant Palaces (*liǎngyào diàn*), seven treasures are cast,
A single stream flows to bestow eight nectars of jade.
This is the **jade nectar reverting elixir** (*yùyè huándān*)."*

*"Water and fire come together in mutual inquiry,
The hexagram soars to form **Earth-Heaven Accomplishment** (*Dìtiān Tài*).
One ascends, one descends—yang refines yin,
Only when yin is exhausted does one grasp this truth profound.
This is the **water-fire accomplished** (*shuǐhuǒ jìjiē*)."*

**Free-and-Easy Master** (*Xiāoyáo Zǐ*) says:
*"Method-water can dawn with hidden passes,
Free-and-easy sends it circling night and day.
This is the **method-water** that treats disease."*

Now, what are the **three fires**? The **bladder** (*pángguāng*) is the **people’s fire** (*mínhuǒ*); the **kidneys** (*shèn*) are the **minister’s fire** (*chénhuǒ*); the **heart** (*xīn*) is the **sovereign’s fire** (*jūnhuǒ*). The ignorant, being disturbed by things, may even reach **anger and sorrow** (*nù qǐ yōu*), becoming the **fire of ignorance** (*wúmíng zhī huǒ*).

If one **descends and lowers** (*jiàng ér xiàfén*) to **sear the elixir field** (*Dāntián*), with **sincerity steadfast** (*zhìchéng shǒuzhī*), **unscattered in purpose** (*yīyì bùsàn*), this is called **burning the elixir** (*shāodān*). When its **fire ascends** (*huǒ shēng*), rising from below, passing through the **three passes** (*sān guān*), this is called **river-chariot** (*héchē*). Before it ascends, its **fire emerges** (*huǒ qǐ*), passing above the **double pavilion** (*chónglóu*), and this is called **refining the form** (*liànxíng*). When both **fire emerges before and after** (*qiánhòu gùqǐ*), filling the **four great elements** (*sìdà*), this is called **consuming the body** (*fénshēn*).

**Consuming the body** (*fénshēn*) is practiced by entering a **chamber of stillness** (*jìngshì*), loosening one’s hair, spreading one’s garments, closing one’s eyes, and **calming the mind** (*míngxīn*). Sitting upright and **holding fast** (*wògù*), one **knocks the teeth and gathers spirit** (*kòuchǐ jíshén*), then **ascends the body and ignites the fire** (*shēngshēn qǐhuǒ*), subtly **retaining the breath** (*liúxī*), entering slowly and exiting tardily. In silence, one **visualizes** (*mòxiǎng*) as if beneath the navel there is a **fire-wheel** (*huǒlún*), its size like a **dipper** (*dǒu*), and soon the **fire arises** (*huǒ qǐ*), encircling the body like a wheel—covering it entirely, so that **yin evils dare not approach** (*yīn xié bùgǎn jìn yǐ*).

Practitioners of this must **long abandon desires** (*xū shìyù jiǔjué*), ensuring the **elixir root is firm** (*dānyuán jiāngù*), before it may be done.
This is my **true water-fire** (*zhēnshuǐhuǒ*).

**Pure Yang Master** (*Chúnyáng Zǐ*) says:
*"Observing **Master Cui’s Elixir Mirror** (*Yàojìng*), one’s heart and mind become clear.
The **yang dragon** (*yánglóng*) speaks of emerging from **the hexagram of the Trigrams** (*Lí zhī zhōng*), the **yin tiger** (*yīnhǔ*) returns to **the hexagram of the Abyss** (*Kǎn shàng shēng*).
When these two meet, it is the **source of the Dao** (*dàoběn*).
The **five phases** (*wǔfāng*) complete their course, and one attains the **name of the elixir** (*dān míng*).
Those who cultivate the **highest truth** (*xiūzhēn shàngshì*), if they know this,
Will **ride the red dragon** (*chìlóng*) and return to **the jade capital** (*yùjīng*)."*

The **Elixir Mirror** (*Yàojìng*) states:
*"Within the kidneys, *qi* is generated.
Within the *qi*, **true-one water** (*zhēn-yī shuǐ*) is hidden—
This is the **yin tiger** (*yīnhǔ*) born from **the hexagram of the Abyss** (*Kǎn*).
Within the heart, fluid is generated.
Within the fluid, **pure yang *qi*** (*chúnyáng qì*) is hidden—
This is the **yang dragon** (*yánglóng*) born from **the hexagram of the Trigrams** (*Lí*).
Thus, the **dragon** (*lóng*) is not the **liver** (*gān*); the **tiger** (*hǔ*) is not the **lung** (*fèi*).
Yet who can **grasp the moment of their union** (*dá jiāohuì zhī shí*) and **awaken to the method of gathering** (*wù cǎiqǔ zhī fǎ*)?

When kidney *qi* transmits to liver *qi*, the liver *qi* is thus generated.
Then, the **residual yin** (*shèngyīn*) of the kidneys enters the **spleen** (*pí*), and its *qi*, passing through the spleen, becomes **pure yang** (*chúnyáng*).
Within this *qi* lies **true-one water** (*zhēn-yī shuǐ*), reaching the heart, where accumulated *qi* generates fluid—
Like a **pendant pearl** (*xuánzhū*) and **hanging dew** (*chuí lù*), returning to the **lower elixir field** (*xiàtián*), no longer descending with **the hexagram of the Abyss** (*Kǎn*) to transmit to the bladder.

The ability to **use the fire’s timing without error** (*huǒ yòng wú chā*), refining it into **one *qi*** (*yīqì*), with *qi* merging and **spirit gathering** (*shén jù*), is when kidney *qi* unites with heart *qi*—this is the **tiger joining the dragon** (*hǔ jiāo lóng*).

When **lowering the fire** (*xiàhuǒ*) and **storing it** (*jiāzàng*) is timed, **withdrawing and supplementing** (*chōutiān yǒushù*), with heart *qi* uniting with kidney *qi*—this is the **dragon joining the tiger** (*lóng jiāo hǔ*).

If the **lower pass is open** (*xià guān tòu yǐ*), emerging from **the tail pass** (*wěiyān*), the **left ascent** (*zuǒ shēng*) is the **dragon** (*lóng*), the **right ascent** (*yòuqǐ*) is the **tiger** (*hǔ*).

When the *qi* travels from the **double-spine passes** (*jiājǐ shuāng guān*) to the **dividing paths** (*fēndào lǐng*), it reaches the **inner courtyard** (*nèiyuàn*), where **yang dragon *qi*** (*yánglóng qì*) enters, and the **heavenly pool** (*tiānchí*), where **yin tiger *qi*** (*yīnhǔ qì*) enters. **Left revolving, right spiraling** (*zuǒ xuán yòu pán*), thirty-six cycles (*sànshù*), then **true water descends** (*zhēnshuǐ xiàjiàng*), like **sweet dew entering the heart** (*gānlù rùxīn*).
This is the **dragon joining in the upper palace** (*lóng jiāo shànggōng*), not necessarily distinguishing between **upper union and lower merging** (*shàngjiāo xiàhé*) in heart and kidneys.

When the **embryo is complete** (*tāiquán*) and **true *qi*** (*zhēnqì*) is born, one must **guard against excess** (*fáng qí tàiguò*), ensuring it is **accomplished with water** (*bì jì yǐshuǐ*), thus attaining the **jade nectar and golden nectar reverting elixir** (*yùyè jīnyè huándān*).

Over time, it **travels through the meridians and collaterals** (*jīngluò*), transforming into **yang fat** (*yángsū*).
When it **congeals in the central palace** (*zhōngfǔ*), it **accumulates white snow** (*jī bái xuě*).
Guard against excess, and **raise it with fire** (*bì jǔ yǐhuǒ*), thus attaining **refining the essence and consuming the body** (*liànzhì fénshēn*).

At the time of **reverting the elixir** (*huándān*), the **yin tiger** (*yīnhǔ*) moves alone, not necessarily joining with the **dragon** (*lóng*).
At the time of **consuming the body** (*fénshēn*), the **yang dragon** (*yánglóng*) ascends alone, not necessarily joining with the **tiger** (*hǔ*).
Within **three hundred days** (*sān bǎi rì*), the **inner elixir** (*nèidān*) is complete, and one may **align with Heaven and Earth** (*kě yǔ tiāndì qí yǐ*).

This is what I call the **true dragon and tiger** (*zhēnlónghǔ*).

**Master Guangcheng** (*Guǎngchéng Zǐ*) says:
*"The Dao of Heaven and Earth’s ascending and descending,
The cycles of the sun and moon’s coming and going,
Are practiced as **inner elixir** (*nèidān*).
**Yellow Emperor** (*Huángdì*) followed it, but long labored without success—
His **root and foundation were not firm** (*gēnyuán bùgù yǐ*).
Thus, he **paired with metals and stones** (*pèihé jīnshí*) on **Mount Kongtong** (*Kōngtóng shān*), crafting **outer elixir** (*wàidān*).
**Inner elixir** (*nèidān*) is the **true medicine** (*zhēnyào*);
**Outer elixir** (*wàidān*) is merely for **treating ailments** (*zhìjí*).
The **beginning of inner elixir** (*nèidān zhī shǐ*) originates from the **two *qi*s’ union** (*èrqì jiāo*).
Its **congealing and forming** (*níngjié*) occurs in the **elixir field** (*Dāntián*).
It **transforms essence into mercury** (*jiāng jīng wéi gǒng*), mercury into **sand** (*shā*), and sand into **elixir** (*dān*).
Thus, **true *qi*** (*zhēnqì*) is born, **refining *qi* with *qi*** (*qì liàn qì*), *qi* merging and **spirit gathering** (*shén jù*).
When **spirit gathers** (*shén jù*), the **Dao is complete** (*dàochéng yǐ*).
How can it compare with **outer elixir** (*wàidān*)?
Thus, my **elixir** (*dān*) is when the **dragon joins the tiger** (*lóng jiāo hǔ*), forming the **mysterious pearl** (*xuánzhū*).
The **fire’s timing is without error** (*huǒhòu wú chā*), and it becomes the **great medicine** (*dàyào*)."*

Guangchengzi refined cinnabar (*zhūshā*), nine transformations yielding **divine elixir** (*shéndān*).
Chen Qizi refined it with **seven treasures’ cinnabar** (*qībǎo dānshā*), nine transformations yielding **spiritual elixir** (*língdān*).
Liu An refined it with **boy’s urine** (*tóngbiàn*), seven transformations yielding **returning elixir** (*huándān*).
These are all **external elixirs** (*wàidān*).
Yet, one must cultivate **inner alchemy** (*nèidān*) concurrently—only when both inner and outer are perfected does true mastery arise.
If one relies solely on **external medicines** (*wàiyào*), then *qi* weakens and spirit decays, unable to retain **Heaven and Earth’s refined *qi*** (*tiāndì zhī xiùqì*), instead becoming a harm.

This is what I call **true elixir medicine** (*zhēndānyào*).

At the beginning of humanity, the **kidneys** (*shèn*) are born first, then the **heart** (*xīn*).
The kidneys are **northern *wu* and *guǐ*** (*běifāng rénɡuǐ*)—**water** (*shuǐ*), among the five metals as **lead** (*qiān*).
The heart is **southern *bǐng* and *dīng*** (*nánfāng bǐngdīng*)—**fire** (*huǒ*), among the eight stones as **cinnabar** (*shā*).
To extract lead from silver is like extracting **true One’s water** (*zhēnyī zhī shuǐ*) hidden in the depths of kidney *qi*!
To extract mercury from cinnabar is like extracting **true Yang’s *qi*** (*zhēngyáng zhī qì*) hidden in the depths of heart *qi*!
When these two merge, elixir is formed.

Thus, **kidney *qi* generates *qi***, *qi* generates water—with kidney water ascending to the **heart-kidney junction** (*xīnshèn zhī shàng*), causing **true Yang’s *qi*** to congeal in the **Yellow Court** (*Huángtíng*), this is **true lead** (*zhēnqiān*).
Kidney *qi* merging with heart *qi*, accumulated *qi* forming fluid, congealing into the **mysterious pearl** (*xuánzhū*), returning to the **lower elixir field** (*xià dāntián*), this is **mercury** (*gǒng*).
Once the elixir is complete, **true *qi*** ascends—kidney *qi* enters the **crown** (*dǐng*), and **true water** descends.
One ascent, one descent before the **twelve pavilions** (*shíèr lóu*), this is the **completed cycle** (*jìjié zhī dào*).
After completion, it returns to the lower elixir field—this is **true mercury** (*zhēngǒng*).
This is what I call **true lead and mercury** (*zhēnqiān gǒng*).

The kidneys are **water**—water generates *qi*, named **true fire** (*zhēnhuǒ*).
Within *qi* hides **true One’s water**—for **yin contains yang**, and **yang contains yin**.
The heart is **fire**—fire generates fluid, named **true water** (*zhēnshuǐ*).
Within fluid hides **true Yang’s *qi***—for **yang contains yin**, and **yin contains yang**.

The **three blossoms** (*sānhuā*) are the **three Yangs** (*sānyáng*).
Kidney *qi* is **yang within yin**.
True *qi* within the elixir is **yang within true yang**.
Heart fluid’s *qi* is **yang within yang**.

The essence of the **Way** lies in **yin exhaustion and pure yang** (*yínjìn ér chún yáng*).
*The Sacred Embryo Key* (*Shèngtāi Jué*) says:
*"Lower the heart-fire to the elixir field—external distractions vanish, mad thoughts dissolve.
When one *qi* gathers at the **sea of *qi*** (*qìhǎi*), kidney *qi* cannot ascend, and breathing grows sparse.
Even if released, it lingers faintly.
Thus, **embryonic breathing** (*tāixī*) is natural—how profound!"*

Damo’s words say:
*"Human *qi* daily dissipates—better to internally observe all worlds within the body’s **celestial offices** (*tiānguān*), transcending the **pure and empty** (*qīngxū*) realm.
The noble path is **non-leakage** (*wúlòu*).
Thus, when not a thought arises, not a mind moves, and not a hair’s breadth of *qi* is lost—this is **true embryonic breathing** (*zhēntāixī*)."*

Bian Que’s commentary on *The Spiritual Pivot* (*Língshū*) says:
*"After Winter Solstice, accumulate **one part lead** (*qiān*), shaped like a **playful flower bud** (*xìruǐ*), to settle in the elixir field.
The method: inhale **clear *qi*** (*qīngqì*) through the nose, close the mouth without exhaling, and regulate breath for **twenty-four counts** (*shù*), yielding **one *liang* of fire** (*huǒ*).
In **forty-five days**, fire advances to **sixteen *liang*—thus, the **Yang Embryo** (*yángtāi*) is refined.
After Summer Solstice, accumulate **three parts mercury** (*gǒng*), shaped like an **embryo in an egg** (*bàoluǎn*), to settle in the **vermilion field** (*jiàngguān*).
Again, inhale clear *qi* through the nose, close the mouth without exhaling, regulate breath for twenty-four counts, yielding one *liang* of fire.
In forty-five days, fire advances to sixteen *liang*—thus, **Yin Breath** (*yīnxī*) is refined.
Merge **Yin Breath** into the **Yang Embryo**, generating **true *qi***, which generates **original spirit** (*yuánshén*).
When spirit and form unite as one, one aligns with **Heaven and Earth’s lifespan** (*tiāndì qīnián*).
Separated into two, the body has a body beyond—returning to the **Three Isles, Ten Zous** (*sān dǎo shí zhōu*) above."*

Ge Hong’s commentary on embryonic breathing says:
*"If one does not grasp embryonic breathing’s subtlety, even if breath is closed, it will soon escape.
Unceasing panting not only fails to retain the closed breath but also depletes **original *qi*** (*yuánqì*), letting incoming **Yang *qi*** (*lái yángqì*) seize it instead.
If breath is urgent before urgency arises, one can ascend the body to pause briefly.
Do not force it—first, inhale *qi* through the nose, then follow with newly drawn breath, expelling the lingering residue of the forcibly retained breath.
Thus, one can seize and accumulate *qi*—when form and spirit grow luminous and pure, all ailments depart.
Yet, forcibly retaining breath is not natural—this is the **lower form** (*xià*) of embryonic breathing.
Others practice **swallowing breath** (*yànqì*) to relieve hunger and thirst,
**circulating *qi*** (*xíngqì*) to strengthen the body,
**gathering *qi*** (*shōuqì*) to nourish the lower elixir field,
**nurturing *qi*** (*yǎngqì*) to restore youth,
**moving *qi*** (*yùnqì*) to benefit blood vessels—
none compare to embryonic breathing’s **qi-nourishing power** (*bǔqì*).

When **one hundred breaths** (*bǎixī*) are steadied, the **passages open** (*guāntōng*), and illness departs.
When **one thousand breaths** are steadied, *qi* and blood no longer mingle, and **yin and yang harmonize** (*yīnyáng zìhé*).
When **ten thousand breaths** are steadied, *qi* halts and spirit is concealed—then the **Way is complete** (*dào sīchéng*).
This is what I call **true yin and yang** (*zhēnyīnyáng*).

In the past, when **Yang *qi*** arose after Winter Solstice and **residual cold** entered the intestines after Spring Equinox, causing **injury by cold** (*shānghán*), one would reside in a **quiet chamber** (*jìngshì*), sit cross-legged, close the eyes, quiet the mind, regulate breath and retain *qi*, alternating hands to cradle the **external kidneys** (*wàishèn*), bowing forward as in prostration—**twenty to thirty repetitions** (*guò*), and sweat would emerge, dispersing the cold.

In the past, when the **lower elixir root** (*xiàyuán*) was empty and **semen leakage** (*mèngxièlòu*) occurred in dreams, one would, after sunset, sit quietly in a secluded room, cradle the external kidneys with the hands, and rub **eighty-one times** below the navel, alternating hands to pull—**nine repetitions** (*jiǔ guò*), and the **elixir root would warm** (*dānyuán nuǎn*), while **true *qi*** would fill (*zhēnqì yíng*)."

「。
　　In the past, there were those who dwelled in seclusion and sat quietly, severing thoughts and forgetting speech, lowering the **fire of the heart** (*xīn huǒ*) to the **elixir field** (*dāntián*). With eyes closed, they **visualized** (*cúnxiǎng*) the fire as if it were a furnace, its heat building day by day. Then, the **sea of *qi*** (*qìhǎi*) would solidify and the complexion would grow radiant, all impurities would descend, and they would overcome both cold and heat.

　　When one had overindulged in food and drink, causing **stagnation in the chest** (*xiōngyì*), or if **cold and heat** were congealed and **painful obstructions** (*tòngjié yōngsè*) formed, they would sit quietly and **inhale the pure *qi*** (*qīngqì*) through the nose, keeping the mouth closed, inhaling deeply and exhaling shallowly, to **assault the illness** (*gōng bìng*). If the breath became too constrained, they would release it. **Three to five repetitions** (*sān-wǔ guò*), and the ailment would vanish.

　　In the past, some held that the **upper heart** (*xīn zhī shàng*) as **yang**, yet **yin** could not reach it; and the **lower kidneys** (*shèn zhī xià*) as **yin**, yet **yang** could not extend to them. Thus, above the **gushing spring** (*yǒngquán*), *qi* would ascend but not descend, blood would stagnate but not rise, and **yin would congeal while yang dispersed**, causing **heaviness in the legs and knees** (*zúxī chénzhòng*). In such cases, they would **lift both feet high**, allowing *qi* to flow downward into the gushing spring, ascending through the **elixir gate** (*dānyuè*). Then, the legs would grow light and the illness would diminish.

　　When the **four limbs and five viscera** (*sìzhī wǔzàng*) were congealed and obstructed, they would sit quietly, **clarify the mind** (*chéngxīn*), close their eyes, sever thoughts, and **circulate the heart-*qi*** (*yùnxīnqì*) to assault the illness. After retaining the breath for a short time, their assault would surely prevail.

　　These are all **methods** (*fǎ*), but none compare to the **Dao of yin and yang** (*yīyīn yīyáng zhī dào*).

　　Know that in a single day:
　　At the end of **Chǒu** (2:00–4:00 AM) and the beginning of **Hài** (7:00–9:00 PM), **yang unites with yin** (*yáng hé yīn*).
　　At the end of **Chén** (7:00–9:00 AM) and the beginning of **Wèi** (9:00 AM–12:00 PM), **yang unites with yang** (*yáng jiāo yáng*).
　　At the end of **Wǔ** (12:00–2:00 PM) and the beginning of **Shēn** (5:00–7:00 PM), **yin unites with yang** (*yīn hé yáng*).
　　At the end of **Xū** (5:00–7:00 PM) and the beginning of **Hài** (7:00–9:00 PM), **yin unites with yin** (*yīn jiāo yīn*).

　　Those who know this understand that the **Dao is not distant**. This is what I call **refining methods to enter the Dao** (*liànfǎ rùdào*).

　　The **form** (*xíng*) is the dwelling of *qi*; *qi* is the master of the form. Thus, refining the form requires **true *qi*** (*zhēnqì*).

　　The **Master Peng** (*Péng Zhēnrén*) said: Before **Wǔ** (12:00–2:00 PM), refine the **dryness** (*gān*); after **Wǔ**, refine the **earthiness** (*kūn*). From **Yín** (3:00–5:00 AM) to **Wǔ**, one should **elevate the body** (*shēngshēn*) and sit quietly, close the eyes, and forget speech, making the nasal breath slow and steady. **Secretly visualize** (*mìxiǎng*) the **heart palace** (*xīn gōng*) as if it were the **rituals of husband and wife** (*fūfù zhī yí*), and with time, **longevity** (*chángshēng*) would come.

　　The **Original True Person** (*Yuán Zhēnrén*), surnamed **Fáng** (*Fáng*), said: From **Chén** (7:00–9:00 AM) onward, one should rise without speaking, and with their tongue, **stir the saliva** (*jǐo*) in the **upper jaw** (*shàngkuà*), **lower palate** (*xiàjiāo*), and **filthy, turbid fluids** (*èzú zhī jīn*), swallowing it. Afterward, one would **expel the accumulated *qi* of joy, anger, sorrow, and delight** (*xīn zhōng suǒ jī fèn-āo lè zhī qì*) with a **forceful exhalation** (*hē*), allowing **true *qi*** to rise and dwell in the **face and eyes** (*miànmù*), then **rub it with the hands** (*yǒngshǒu cuōzhī*). By **Wǔ** to **Wèi** (2:00–4:00 PM), when *qi* was abundant and the spirit **dazed** (*shén yīng*), they would **lie on their side with mouth closed** (*cèwài bìkǒu ér mèi*), which could **prolong life** (*yánnián*) and **preserve the form** (*liúxíng*). This is the knowledge of **union times** (*jiāohé shíhòu*), yet they still did not know the **method of gathering** (*cǎiqǔ zhī fǎ*).

　　From **Zǐ** (9:00–11:00 PM) to **Wǔ** (12:00–2:00 PM) is the time when *qi* **generates** (*shēngqì*), and one can use it to **gather *qi* and return to the elixir** (*jùqì huándān*). At **Zǐ**’s time, **kidney-*qi* generates**; at **Mǎo**’s time (5:00–7:00 AM), **liver-*qi* generates**. By **Wǔ**’s time, **kidney-*qi* unites with heart-*qi***, accumulating *qi* to form **elixir fluid** (*huándān*), returning to the **elixir field** (*dāntián*). This is the **medicine of the mysterious pearl for longevity** (*Xuán Zhū Chángshēng zhī yào*).

　　How does one ensure it does not **dissipate** (*bù zǒushī*)? When the time is between **Chén** and **Wèi** (7:00–9:00 AM), one should sit quietly in seclusion, **guard the spirit inwardly** (*shénshí nèishǒu*), fill the mouth with saliva, neither swallowing nor spitting it out. The nasal breath should **enter slightly and be expelled gently** (*shǎo rù yùn chū*), **soft and lingering** (*miánmián ruòcún*), naturally allowing the **two *qi*** (*èrqì*) to unite and congeal like dew. After **one hundred days** (*bǎi rì*), the **drug’s efficacy is complete** (*yàolì quán*); after **two hundred days** (*èr bǎi rì*), the **holy embryo** (*shèngtāi*) is firm; after **three hundred days** (*sān bǎi rì*), the **embryo attains transcendence** (*tāixiān quán*), and **true *qi* is born** (*zhēnqì shēng*). *Qi* within *qi* can be **refined to become spirit** (*liànqì chéngshén*).

　　This is the **method of gathering *qi*** (*cǎiqì zhī fǎ*). From **Wǔ** to **Zǐ** is the time when *qi* **disperses** (*sànqì*), and one can use it to **harvest *qi* and refine the elixir** (*shōuqì liàndān*).

　　**Twenty-four breaths** (*èrshísì xī*) constitute **one *liǎng* of fire** (*huǒ yī liǎng*). After the **summer solstice** (*xiàzhì*), using the **Xùn (巽) hexagram**, the **celestial mist movement** (*tiānyùn zhī yùn*), **twenty-five repetitions** (*èrshíwǔ guò*), one would refine **true mercury** (*zhēn gǒng*) into the **yin embryo** (*yīn tāi*).
　　After the **winter solstice** (*dōngzhì*), using the **Qián (乾) hexagram**, the **numinous symbol movement** (*língfú zhī yùn*), **two thousand five hundred repetitions** (*èrqiān wǔbǎi guò*), one would refine **true lead** (*zhēn qiān*) into the **yang breath** (*yáng xī*).

　　The **yang breath** is cast into the **yin embryo**; thus, it **transforms into the golden elixir** (*biànchéng jīndān*).

　　The **Broad Achiever** (*Guǎngchéng Zǐ*) instructed **Yellow Emperor** (*Huángdì*):

　　From **Chén** (7:00–9:00 AM) to **Mù** (7:00–9:00 PM), one should sit quietly, forget thoughts, and **guard the spirit inwardly** (*shénshí nèishǒu*), maintaining **a single undivided intention** (*yīyì bùsàn*). They would **lower the fire of the heart** into the **elixir field** (*dāntián*), visualizing below the navel as if **contending for a vessel** (*rú zhēng píng*). Within, there is a **pearl-like formation** (*zhū zhuàng*) as round as a **marble** (*dànwán*), which they would **forge with blazing fire** (*yòng yānyān zhī huǒ*), day and night. Until the **embryo is formed and the breath is still** (*tāi chéng xī zhù*), naturally, there would be **no hunger nor thirst** (*bù jī bù kě*), **no cold nor heat** (*wú hán wú shǔ*), and one could **preserve the form and attain longevity** (*liúxíng chángshēng*). This is merely **advancing the fire at the right time** (*jìn huǒ dé shí*), not the **method of the Eastern Breath** (*Dōngqì zhī fǎ*).

　　At the end of **Xū** (5:00–7:00 PM) and the beginning of **Hài** (7:00–9:00 PM), when *qi* follows the **true fluid** in returning to the elixir, **yin unites with yin** (*yīn jiāo yīn*), and the *qi* **desires to disperse** (*yù sàn*). One should then reside in a **quiet chamber** (*jìngshì*), and the breath need not be **retained** (*bì*). A **slight inhalation and gentle exhalation** (*shǎo rù yùn chū*) suffices. When the **fire of the heart descends** into the **elixir field**, the **kidney-*qi* ascends without stopping** (*shènqì shēng ér bù tíng*), and the **heart-fire descends without lingering** (*xīn huǒ jiàng ér bù zhù*). One would then **lightly press the sides of the abdomen** (*qīngxié qí fù*), allowing the **elixir field to warm naturally** (*dāntián zì rè*), which could refine the **medicine gathered during the day** (*rì zhōng suǒ dé zhī yào*).

　　Initially, after **one hundred days** (*bǎi rì*), one would use the **Qián (乾) hexagram**; in the **next hundred days** (*cì zhī bǎi rì*), from **Duì (兑)** to **Qián (乾)**...

「Next hundred days, from **Kūn (坤)** to **Qián (乾)**. When **Qián (乾)** and **Kūn (坤)** meet, the **fire and timing** (*huǒ hòu*) require no adjustment—whether by **shouting to draw** (*jiàn*), **extracting to supplement** (*chōu tiān*), or **adding to harmonize** (*tiān*), all suit their purpose. After the **elbow** (*shǒu*), the **golden crystal ascends** (*fēi jīn jīng*).

Thus, the ancient **Sages of High Dao** (*gǔ xiān shàngshèng*) gathered **medicine** (*yào*) at **Lí (离)**, then **entered fire** (*jìn huǒ*) at **Qián (乾)**. Within **one to two hundred days** (*yī èr bǎi rì*), the **inner elixir** (*nèidān*) was formed. This is what I call **refining the form and transforming the *qi*** (*liàn xíng huà qì*).

To refine the *qi* with the form, the form must then transform the *qi*—thus the body and bones become **light and agile** (*tǐgǔ qīngjiàn*), allowing one to **enter water without drowning** (*rù shuǐ bù nì*) and **enter fire without burning** (*rù huǒ bù rè*). Hence, it is **refining the *qi* with the spirit** (*yǐ shén liàn qì*), where refining the *qi* nurtures the spirit (*liàn qì chéng shén*). This does not depend on **the union of yang and yin** (*yáng jiāo yīn huì*), but rather on **extracting lead and adding mercury** (*chōu qiān tiān gǒng*), **dissolving the twenty-eight yin** (*xiāo èr bā zhī yīn*), and **changing bones to refine form** (*huàn gǔ liàn xíng*), thereby **prolonging the nine-three yang** (*cháng jiǔ sān zhī yáng*).

After **three hundred days**, the **embryo of the Immortal** (*tāi xiān*) is complete, and **true *qi*** (*zhēn qì*) arises—**no further gathering of medicine** (*bù kě zài cǎi yào*) is needed. Only after the **elbow**, when the **golden crystal ascends** (*jīn jīng rù nǎo*), does it rise from the **kidney’s posterior interval** (*shèn zhī hòu wěi jiān*) to the **intervertebral space** (*jiā jǐ*), then from the **intervertebral space** to the **double gate** (*shuāng guān*), and finally to the **Upper Palace** (*shàng gōng*). It is not merely **supplementing the brain with kidney-*qi*** (*bù zhǐ yú shèn qì bǔ nǎo*).

At **midday**, the **true fire descends** (*jiàng zhēn huǒ*) to refine the elixir, **consummating yin to achieve pure yang** (*zhì yīn jìn yáng chún*).

From **Zǐ (子)** onward, when **kidney-*qi* first stirs** (*shèn qì fāng shēng*), one sits upright in a **quiet chamber** (*jìng shì*), **calms the mind** (*qīng xīn*), **closes the eyes** (*bì mù*), and **contracts the body** (*yǎn shēn*), allowing the **kidney-*qi* to gather naturally** (*shèn zhī qì zì jù*).

**Slightly raising the body** (*wēi shēng qí shēn*), **lowering the chest and straightening the waist** (*yǎn xióng zhí yāo*), one first reaches the **intervertebral space** (*jiā jǐ*), then the **Upper Palace** (*shàng gōng*). From **Zǐ (子)** to **Chén (辰)** and **Sì (巳)**, one **stabilizes at one hundred breaths** (*dìng yú bǎi xī*), **striking the three gates** (*yī zhuàng sān guān*), and **reaccumulating the true fire of the heart** (*fú jī xīn zhī zhēn huǒ*), **forging and refining the inner elixir of the Lower Yuan** (*duàn liàn yú xià yuán zhī nèi dān*). Thus, **yin solidifies and yang condenses** (*yīn gù ér yáng níng*).

Within the *qi* lies another *qi*—**the front ascends into the crown** (*qián shēng rù yú dǐng*), **the back enters into the brain** (*hòu qǐ rù yú nǎo*). When both **arise simultaneously** (*qián hòu jù qǐ*), one **raises the body without movement** (*shēng shēn wù dòng*), **burning the body** (*yán qí shēn*), and **driving away the yin demons** (*zhú yīn guǐ*).

Thus, **one burn refines one *qi*** (*yī shāo ér zēng yī qì*), **ten burns refine one spirit** (*shí shāo ér zēng yī shén*), **a hundred burns extend ten thousand years** (*bǎi shāo ér yán wàn nián*), and **a thousand burns transcend the mortal world** (*qiān shāo ér chū chén shì*).

The ancient **Sages of High Dao** (*gǔ xiān shàngshèng*) feared **excessive fire** (*huǒ zhī tài guò*), so they devised the **method of dousing and irrigating** (*jiāo guàn zhī fǎ*).

The first stage of **gathering medicine** (*cǎi yào*) is **returning the elixir with jade fluid** (*yù liào huán dān*). The next stage, after the **elbow**, is **the golden crystal entering the brain** (*jīn jīng rù nǎo*), where **it travels from the Upper Field to the Lower Field** (*zì shàng tián rù yú xià tián*), **collecting the two gaps** (*shuāng shōu èr jiā*), **swallowing hollowly to absorb the *qi*** (*xū yàn nà qì*), and **returning the elixir with golden fluid** (*jīn yè huán dān*).

Once the elixir is complete and **true *qi*** (*zhēn qì*) arises, one **refines the *qi* of the five viscera** (*yǐ zhēn qì liàn qí wǔ zàng zhī qì*). Only **a slight breath adjustment** (*yī xiǎo yùn*) is needed daily—**closing the breath to refine the *qi*** (*bì xī liàn qì*). On **Jia (甲) and Yi (乙)**, one refines the **liver-*qi*** (*gān*); on **Bing (丙) and Ding (丁)**, the **heart-*qi*** (*xīn*); on **Wù (戊) and Jǐ (己)**, the **spleen-*qi*** (*pí*); on **Gēng (庚) and Xīn (辛)**, the **lung-*qi*** (*fèi*); and on **Rén (壬) and Guǐ (癸)**, one refines the **kidney-*qi*** (*shèn*), as detailed in the **Scriptures of Soul Treasures** (*Língbǎo Piān zhōng*).

Refining the *qi* **once every ten days** (*shí rì yī liàn*), **through all five viscera** (*biàn yú wǔ zàng*), **two hundred and fifty days** (*èr bǎi wǔ shí rì*) for each **twenty-five refinements** (*èr shí wǔ shù*), then **true *qi* naturally gathers** (*zhēn qì zì jù*).

Then, the **River Vehicle** (*Hé Chē*) is opened, adorned with **five-colored objects** (*wǔ cǎi zhī wù*), where **the pipes and flutes** (*shēng huáng*) and **vehicle flags** (*chē qí*) each divide into their proper directions. One **ascends to the Imperial Gate** (*shàng cháo yú dì què*), **entering the Celestial Palace** (*rù yú tiān gōng*). Sometimes, **obstructing demons or spirits** (*xié mó wéi gěng*) arise, so one **dons the robe** (*pī yī*), returns to the **quiet chamber** (*jìng shì*), **closes the eyes** (*bì mù*), **plunges the mind into emptiness** (*míng xīn*), and **raises the body to sit upright** (*shēng shēn zhèng zuò*). Then, the **true fire of the threefold concentration** (*sān měi zhī zhēn huǒ*) naturally arises, and the **spirits disperse** (*mó sàn*).

One’s form **constantly seems to soar and fly** (*qí xíng cháng ruò téng fēi*), allowing the use of **the method of adjusting the spirit to emerge from the shell** (*yòng tiáo shén chū ké zhī fǎ*).

This is what I call **refining the *qi* to achieve the spirit** (*liàn qì chéng shén*).

When the *qi* is full and the practice complete, **the five *qi* converge at the Yuan** (*wǔ qì cháo yú yuán*), and **the three flowers gather at the crown** (*sān huā jù yú dǐng*). With **blood congealed and *qi* gathered** (*xuè níng qì jù*), **all spirits bow to the true** (*wàn shén cháo zhēn*), residing in the **Upper Palace** (*shàng gōng*). What one **perceives in splendor and wealth** (*qí suǒ jiàn fùguì huá shèng*) is still **oneself** (*yóu wú shēn ér*), yet if one **remains trapped within the inner precincts** (*yīn yuàn*), **hesitating to emerge** (*yīn xún bù chū*), one is **ensnared in the dim crossroads** (*shì wéi kùn yú hūn qiú*).

The **method of emerging from the shell** (*chū ké zhī fǎ*) I have mastered in **three forms** (*sān yán*).

**Hǎi Chán Zǐ** (*海蟾子*) says: When the **yang spirit seeks to emerge** (*yáng shén yù chū*), it **resides in the Upper Palace** (*fāng zài shàng guān*), yet in the **quiet chamber**, one **sits alone** (*gū zuò*), like a **crane emerging from the Celestial Gate** (*hè chū tiān mén*), a **dragon ascending its old lair** (*lóng shēng jiù xué*), **boldly striking the Celestial Gate and departing** (*měng zhuàng tiān mén ér qù*).

**Zhèng Yáng Zǐ** (*正阳子*) says: In **quiet sitting and inward observation** (*jìng zuò nèi guān*), one **ascends the seven-tiered Treasure Platform** (*rú dēng qī jí bǎo tái*), from **below to above** (*zì xià ér shàng*). When the tiers are exhausted, one **closes the eyes and leaps downward** (*bì mù xià tiào*), like **one awakening from a dream** (*rú mèng zhōng fāng qǐ*), where **a body exists beyond the body** (*shēn wài yǒu shēn*). **Do not wander far** (*wù dé yuǎn yóu*), but **quickly return to the corporeal form** (*jí huán qí qū*). **Entering without emerging** (*rù ér bù chū*), one **aligns with Heaven and Earth** (*yú tiān dì qí yì*); **emerging without entering** (*chū ér bù rù*), one **becomes like the vulgar** (*yú sú tóng yì*).

**Chún Yáng Zǐ** (*纯阳子*) says: As **Zhèng Yáng Zǐ’s method** (*Zhèng Yáng Zǐ zhī fǎ*), in **inward observation of the Purple River Vehicle** (*nèi guān zǐ hé zhī chē*), one **transports the spirit into the Celestial Palace** (*bān shén rù yú tiān guān*). If one **lingers and cannot transcend** (*liú liàn ér bù néng chāo chū*), then the **true fire is kindled within** (*qǐ zhēn huǒ yú qí zhōng*), **transforming into the Fire Dragon** (*huà huǒ lóng*), which **leaps forth from the dim crossroads** (*yuè chū yú hūn qiú*). This is the **wondrous art of abandoning the shell** (*nǎi qì chū ké zhī miào zhě*).

If, in **meditation** (*dìng zhōng*), one **emerges with the yin spirit and cannot return** (*chū qí yīn shén ér bù néng fǎn*), it is called **corpse dissolution** (*shī jiě*), **not the Dao** (*fēi dào*).

This is what I call **refining the spirit to unite with the Dao** (*liàn shén hé dào*).

Once the practice is complete and the spirit **transmigrates** (*shén qiān*), having **already abandoned the shell** (*yǐ qì qí ké*), one must still **accumulate virtuous deeds in the world** (*jī xíng yú shì*). When these deeds are fulfilled and the practice complete, one **receives the Purple Edict and Celestial Scripture** (*shòu zǐ zhào tiān shū*), and **resides in the Cavernous Heaven** (*jū dòng tiān*).

This is what I call **refining the Dao to attain sainthood** (*liàn dào rù shèng*).

*(End of Volume Thirty-Eight of the Dao Gun Scroll #1—originally "他" [tā], corrected to "佗" [tuō] according to the Jí Yào edition. Volume Thirty-Nine of the Dao Gun Scroll follows.)*

**Transmission of the Dao: Upper Section**

When the Mysterious Pass is opened, the Dao has no lingering residue;
Dark and profound, vast indeed is the question!

Master Lü studied the Dao, consulting over seventy teachers,
before encountering Master Zhōnglí from the Zhōnglí lineage.

He often asked Master Zhōnglí:
*"How does one live without illness, remain strong without aging,
and live without dying?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"The two *qi*—yin and yang—combine to form a person.
At the moment of the embryo’s formation,
after the Primordial Origin, there is the Great Essence (*tài zhì*).
Yin supports yang to generate life,
*qi* transforms from the embryo,
and after thirty *xún* (decades), its form is complete.
The spirit-light enters,
and it first emerges from the embryo.

After the Great Substance (*tài sù*) appears,
the cycles of ascent and descent begin.
The yellow sprout grows for five hundred *xún*—its *qi* is then full—
and its span reaches eighty-one.
Some say it is eight hundred and ten *zhàng* (feet).

At fifteen years of age,
within yin, its yang is half spent—
like the first light of dawn,
the ignorant do not cherish it,
losing their Primordial Yang (*yuán yáng*)
until their decline—
is this not the reverse of the sun’s path?

If one wishes as you say—
to take the Dao from humanity and attain sainthood,
and from sainthood attain the Heavenly—
then Master Lü asked:
*"Sainthood is singular—why speak of attaining the Heavenly?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"The purely yin is called *guǐ* (ghost).
The purely yang is called sainthood (*xiān*).
The mingling of yin and yang is humanity—
only humanity can become a *guǐ* or a sainthood.
Sainthood is not singular.

Its ranks are five;
its methods are three.
Five ranks:
1. The sainthood of *guǐ* (ghosts),
2. the sainthood of humanity,
3. the sainthood of Earth,
4. the sainthood of Spirits,
5. the sainthood of Heaven.

Three methods:
1. The lesser vehicle (*xiǎo chéng*),
2. the middle vehicle (*zhōng chéng*),
3. the greater vehicle (*dà chéng*).

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the sainthood of *guǐ*?
How is it achieved?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"Those who do not grasp the Great Dao yet seek swift success—
their bodies wither like dead wood,
their minds grow cold like ashes,
their spirit and consciousness retreat inward,
and their *qi* does not disperse.
In meditation, they emit their yin spirit—
thus, they become the pure and refined *guǐ*.

Beyond the yin, their spirit-forms are indistinct,
with nowhere to rest,
only to return to a human womb
and take residence there."*

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the sainthood of humanity?
How is it achieved?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"In the Dao, there are methods—
some attain one aspect.
Those who abstain from the Five Flavors
do not know the Two *Qi*;
those who forget the Seven Emotions
do not know the Ten Precepts.
Those who practice spitting and swallowing (*sǒu yàn*)
despise inhalation and exhalation;
those who gather and refine (*cǎi bǔ*)
mock purity and tranquility;
those who seize *qi* from things
do not know the art of rejecting grains (*pìgǔ*);
those who cultivate through visualization
do not know the method of adjusting and guiding (*àn yáo*);
those who rigidly hold their breath
do not know the art of natural breathing.
Their resolve is fixed—
the sequence of the Four Seasons cannot change,
the *qi* of the Five Phases loses its harmony—
though they preserve their physical form,
ward off the Eight Evils (*bā xié*),
they only delay death.

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the sainthood of Earth?
How is it achieved?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"Follow the principles of Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent,
take the numbers of the sun and moon’s generation and completion.
Within the body, apply the year;
within the year, apply the month;
within the month, apply the day;
within the day, apply the hour;
within the hour, apply the moment (*kè*).

Thus, one discerns the Dragon and Tiger,
grasps the Kan and Lí,
knows the purity and turbidity of the Water Source,
distinguishes the early and late of *qi* and climate,
collects the True One while observing the Two Principles,
arranges the Three Talents while distinguishing the Four Symbols,
examines the Six Circulations while stabilizing the Six *Qi*,
gathers the Seven Treasures while sequencing the Eight Trigrams,
and practices the Nine Regions while reversing the Five Phases.
The reversal means inversion.

*Qi* is transmitted through parent-child cycles,
fluids circulate through husband-wife cycles.
Through repeated refinement, the Three Fields are burned,
and the Lower Field (*xià tián*) is settled as the Dan Field.
Thus, one can refine the form and prolong life."*

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the sainthood of Spirits?
How is it achieved?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"What I call the sainthood of Earth—
if one perseveres in its practice,
so that the Three Passes and Hundred Nodes are harmoniously connected,
and one draws out and augments the lead and mercury (*yīn yáng*),
then the golden essence is refined in the Nine Heavens—
the Nine Heavens, the vertex.
The jade fluid returns to the elixir—
thus, one refines the form and *qi*,
and the Five *Qi* pay homage to the Primordial.
The Three Yangs converge in the Primordial Palace (*yuán gōng*),
and yin is exhausted, becoming purely yang."*

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the sainthood of Heaven?
How is it achieved?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"In the Dao, one has attained merit;
in deeds toward humanity, one has cultivated virtue.
Thus, one returns to the Cavernous Heaven (*dòng tiān*),
ascends to the Three Officials (*sān guān*),
the Upper being the Heavenly Official (*tiān guān*),
the Middle being the Earthly Official (*dì guān*),
the Lower being the Water Official (*shuǐ guān*).
In one’s heart, toward Heaven and Earth, one has great merit;
toward the past and present, one has great virtue.

Those who traverse the Cavernous Heaven number thirty-six;
those who reach the Yang Heaven number eighty-one.
Then one ascends to the Three Pure Ones (*sān qīng*)."*

Master Lü, thus enlightened, asked:
*"The sainthood of *guǐ* is unattainable,
the sainthood of Heaven is not to be dared—
excluding these two, can the Dao be heard?"*

Master Zhōnglí replied:
*"The sainthood of humanity has three ranks:
The highest prolongs the years and increases longevity,
the next attains peace while prolonging the years,
and the lowest attains peace without illness—
all are lesser vehicles.

The sainthood of Earth has three ranks:
The highest achieves extreme yang and lightens the body,
soaring freely at will;
the next refines the form and extends vision,
reaching a thousand years;
the lowest prolongs the years and increases longevity—
all are middle vehicles.

The sainthood of Spirits has three ranks:
The highest transcends the mundane and enters sainthood,
returning to the Three Isles (*sān dǎo*);
the next refines the spirit to unite with the Dao (*liàn shén hé dào*),
entering and exiting naturally;
the lowest refines the form and *qi*,
so that one day, ancient and enduring, they persist—
all are greater vehicles.*

Master Lü asked:
*"Examining the ancient and modern cultivators of life,
many seek but do not attain—why is this?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"This is not in accord with the Dao/Way. Many hear much and remember strongly,
yet they derive from mere side-paths and minor techniques.
Sainthood? Sainthood? How can it be achieved by mere hearing and remembering?"*

Master Lü asked:
*"May I inquire about the true essence of the Great Dao/Way?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"It is formless, nameless, beyond knowing, and beyond practice (#1: *行* here likely refers to deliberate cultivation or action)."*

Master Lü asked:
*"When scholars first learn the Dao/Way,
then possess the Dao/Way,
then hear of the Dao/Way,
and finally achieve Dao/Way-completion—
yet it is said to be beyond knowing, beyond practice—
does this not imply it is hidden from them?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"I have no hidden teachings.
Scholars hear of the Great Dao/Way yet lack faith,
or have faith yet lack resolute aspiration—
thus, it is difficult to know and difficult to practice."*

Now, the side-path minor techniques—there are thirty distinct kinds:
They are called fasting and abstinence (*zhāi jiè*),
avoiding grains (*bì gǔ*),
refining *qi*,
gargling and swallowing (*sǒu yàn*),
cutting off internal desires (*jué nèi*),
abandoning flavors (*duàn wèi*),
meditative stillness (*chán dìng*),
silent contemplation of the Mysterious (*xuán mò bù yǔ*),
visualization (*cún xiǎng*),
harvesting yin (*cǎi yīn*),
ingesting *qi* (*fú qì*),
friction and massage (*chí mó*),
calming the mind (*xī xīn*),
removing burdens (*qù lěi*),
opening the crown (*kāi dǐng*),
shrinking the turtle (*suō guī*),
severing the edges (*jué biān*),
chanting and recitation (*luò sòng kàn dú*),
burning and refining (*shāo liàn*),
consolidating breath (*gù xī*),
pressing and coaxing (*àn jiāo*),
spitting and inhaling (*tǔ nà*),
harvesting and supplementing (*cǎi bǔ*),
broadly giving and liberally offering (*bó shī jiě cí*),
relieving poverty (*zhèn fá*),
dwelling in mountains (*qī shān*),
adapting to nature (*shì xìng*),
remaining unmoved (*bù dòng*),
and receiving and upholding [the Dao].

Now, those who practice thus
may conquer illness and nourish their nature.
But they use saliva as medicine—
how can they construct the transformations?
They use *qi* as elixir—
how can they halt and stabilize the liver as dragon, the lungs as tiger?
How can they combine the trigrams of *kàn* as lead and *lí* as mercury?
How can they extract and augment, then irrigate the Four Seasons,
to seek the growth of the golden sprout?
These are those who do not know
the roots and foundations of the Five Phases,
the transformations of the Three Powers (*sān cái*),
far removed from the Great Dao/Way.

Master Lü asked:
*"What is the Great Dao/Way?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"The true source has been divided,
the Great Primordial (*dà pǔ*) has been scattered.
The Dao/Way arises from One,
One arises from Two,
Two arises from Three.
The One is the **substance** (*tǐ*),
the Two is the **function** (*yòng*),
the Three is the **transformations** (*zào huà*).
Which is substance and which is function?
Yin and Yang are.
Which is the transformation?
Their interplay is.

The Dao/Way generates the Two *Qi*,
the Two *Qi* generate the Three Powers (*sān cái*),
the Three Powers generate the Five Phases,
and the Five Phases generate all things.
Humans are the most refined of all things,
able to fully manifest their nature and align with Heaven and Earth."*

Master Lü asked:
*"Which Dao/Way is this?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"The Great Dao/Way, once divided, takes form,
and form brings forth measures.
Heaven, receiving the **Creative Dao** (*guàn dào*),
takes One as its substance, its function being Yang;
Earth, receiving the **Receptive Dao** (*kūn dào*),
takes Two as its substance, its function being Yin.
Yang governs ascent, Yin governs descent—
yet they mutually interact—why so?
Heaven is the accumulation of *qi*,
Earth is the accumulation of water.
Heaven, with the **Creative Dao**, draws from the **Receptive Dao**—
once drawn, it forms the eldest son, **Zhen** (☳);
twice drawn, it forms the middle son, **Kàn** (☵);
thrice drawn, it forms the youngest son, **Gèn** (☶).
This is how Heaven interacts with Earth to produce the Three Yangs.
Earth, with the **Receptive Dao**, draws from the **Creative Dao**—
once drawn, it forms the eldest daughter, **Sūn** (☴);
twice drawn, it forms the middle daughter, **Lí** (☲);
thrice drawn, it forms the youngest daughter, **Duì** (☱).
This is how Earth interacts with Heaven to produce the Three Yins.

Thus, the Three Yangs interact with the Three Yins,
and all things are born;
the Three Yins interact with the Three Yangs,
and all things are perfected.
Therefore, the **Creative Dao** and **Receptive Dao** draw from each other,
generating the Six *Qi*,
the Six *Qi* combine to form the Five Phases,
and the Five Phases combine to generate and perfect all things.

When the **Creative Dao** descends below,
the three draws have concluded,
its Yang ascends anew,
Yang within concealing Yin,
returning above to Heaven;
when the **Receptive Dao** ascends above,
the three draws have concluded,
its Yin descends anew,
Yin within concealing Yang,
returning below to Earth.
The Yang concealed within Yin—
its Yin does not dissipate,
this is called **True Yin**.
When it reaches Heaven,
it is born from Yang,
thus Yin descends from Heaven itself.
Hence, it is said: *Can there be no Yang within Yin?*
The Yang concealed within Yin—
its Yang does not perish,
this is called **True Yang**.
When it reaches Earth,
it is emitted from Yin,
thus Yang ascends from Earth itself.
Hence, it is said: *Can there be no Yin within Yang?*

Yin and Yang revolve endlessly—
those who persist ancient and enduring,
their interplay never straying from the Dao/Way."

Master Lü asked:
*"When True *Qi* is invested in True Water,
the heart’s fire and the kidney’s water interact within humans—
how does this manifest?"*

The Master Zhōnglí said:
*"When father and mother unite,
Yang advances first,
Yin is born afterward,
and the embryo forms—
just as the three draws of the **Creative Dao** and **Receptive Dao**.
Thus, my True *Qi*—Yang—
is concealed within water and governs ascent;
True Water—Yin—
is concealed within *Qi* and governs descent.
Yang follows water in descending,
this is the **Creative Dao** drawing from the **Receptive Dao**,
from above to below.
Above is **Zhen** (☳), becoming the liver;
middle is **Kàn** (☵), becoming the kidneys;
below is **Gèn** (☶), becoming the bladder.
Yin follows *Qi* in ascending,
this is the **Receptive Dao** drawing from the **Creative Dao**,
from below to above.
Below is **Sūn** (☴), becoming the gallbladder;
middle is **Lí** (☲), becoming the heart;
above is **Duì** (☱), becoming the lungs.
One pillar of Yang remains in the kidneys,
and True *Qi* is born.
True *Qi* ascends to the heart and lungs,
and True Essence (*zhēn yè*) is born.
Ascending and descending without depletion,
one can cultivate longevity.
If one adheres to the seasons without restraint,
and extracts and augments with measure,
one can achieve long life.
If one practices without weariness,
their *Qi* will flourish,
their spirit (*hún*) will have no Yin,
their Yang will be robust,
their soul (*pò*) will possess *Qi*,
ascending and descending like Heaven and Earth,
waxing and waning like the sun and moon—
one can enter sainthood."*

Master Lü asked:
*"Can one hear of the sun and moon’s revolutions and their interplay within humans?"*

「Master Zhōnglí said to Lüzi: The sprouting of **Xuan** (☵) and **Huáng** (☲) is like Heaven and Earth;
its form is like an egg.
Six directions converge at the center,
like a sphere of **Jū** (☱).
The sun and moon revolve above Heaven and below Earth,
like a shuttle in motion.
The sun and moon are the essence of Yin and Yang,
silently marking the degrees of Heaven and Earth’s union.

Now, the sun—
it emerges from the east at dawn,
retires to the west at dusk,
thus dividing day and night.
In winter, it reaches the southernmost point,
in summer, the northernmost point,
and thus the cold and heat are determined.

The moon—
it carries the **pò** (魄) in the west,
receives the **hún** (魂) from the east,
shines its light in the evening,
and hides its **hún** at dawn.
At its beginning,
the **pò** gives birth to the **hún**, appearing like a bow;
in the early evening, its light blazes in the west.
Next,
the **hún** grows half-full—this is called the **upper xián** (弦).
In the early evening, its light blazes in the south.
Next,
the **hún** is full.
Facing the sun, in the early evening, its light blazes in the east;
then,
the **hún** generates the **pò**, appearing like a broken mirror.
At the start of the next day,
the **hún** hides in the west;
next,
the **pò** grows half-full—this is called the **lower xián** (弦).
At the start of the next day,
the **hún** hides in the south;
next,
the **pò** is full.
With the sun in opposition,
at the start of the next day,
the **hún** hides in the east—
thus, the **hún** generates the **pò**,
and the **pò** generates the **hún**,
advancing and retreating in due season,
conforming to the **Qián** (☰) and **Kūn** (☷) cycles and numbers.

When the sun reaches its southernmost point,
it rises at the very beginning of **Chén** (辰),
and sets at the very end of **Shēn** (申),
each lasting fifty parts.
Beyond this,
its rising and setting shift from south to north.
When it reaches its northernmost point,
it rises at the very end of **Yín** (寅),
and sets at the very beginning of **Xū** (戌),
each lasting fifty parts.
Beyond this,
its rising and setting shift from north to south,
and then again to the southernmost point.
The days of summer are like the evenings of winter;
the evenings of winter are like the days of summer.
At the southernmost month,
its rising shifts from north to south,
comparable to the days of summer;
at the northernmost month,
its rising shifts from south to north,
comparable to the evenings of winter.
